But so what? Your goal should be to reach the end of life and say like Jesus, 'I have brought You glory on earth by completing the work You gave me to do.'

content.title: TIME TO DUCK!
content.introtext:
THIS IS THE ASSIGNED MOMENT FOR HIM TO MOVE INTO THE CENTRE...

JOHN 3:30 TM
When the crowds left John the Baptist to follow Jesus, he said: 'This is the assigned moment for him to move into the centre, while I slip off to the sidelines' (John 3:30 TM). John knew that the crowd leaving him for Christ was never his to begin with. God had simply placed them under his care for a period of time. For John this was just fine. John's view of the crowd presents us with an important principle. John could have said 'I'm a preacher, I NEED people to listen to me' or 'I'm the one who has done all the work why should He get all the credit'. But John knew that for Jesus to increase in the minds and hearts of the people, He must decrease. It was time to duck. Maybe you lead/or would like to lead worship. Maybe you're a preacher or performer. If God has given you gifts it can be easy to stand up and get noticed. But do you need to be noticed? Or do you see the gifts and opportunities God has given you as way of helping others get what they need...JESUS. Even in the Church, with 'famous' preachers, bands and leaders it's easy to think that success is a big crowd, lots of people at your gig, church or festival. But what is success, as God counts success? It's when others hear you, but follow Jesus. It's when others see some quality in you that causes them to fall more in love with Him. Only when that happens, and you feel like you've lost nothing in the process, can you truly say, 'Father, I've done what you called me to do.'

content.title: FAMILY- LOVE SWAP
content.introtext:
MY COMMAND IS THIS: LOVE EACH OTHER AS I HAVE LOVED YOU

JOHN 15:12 NIV
There's an old French saying which goes like this: 'It is not only necessary to love, it is necessary to say so using words if we have to.' You know, Jesus is pretty serious about this love thing, He commands us to love. 'Yeah but Jesus... you've not met my brother!' This is what the Bible says about true love: 'Love is patient and kind. Love is not jealous, it does not boast, and it is not proud. Love is not rude, is not selfish, and does not get upset with others. Love does not count up wrongs that have been done. Love is not happy with evil but is happy with the truth. Love patiently accepts all things. It always trusts, always hopes, and always remains strong. Love never ends...' (1 Corinthians 13:4-8 NCV). When we read those verses it is a real challenge to be able to swap the word love with your own name. Could you say that about yourself and your relationship with your family? Tough isn't it? Maybe you could start with the little things. If you normally wake up with a scowl and a grunt and trundle into the bathroom to find your mum has given you a clean towel, say thank you to her. Little things like this can change a whole person's day and make life more bearable for them. Make someone a cup of tea without being asked. Tidy your room, do your homework, put the bin out. You might make your mum cry - in a good way!

content.title: FAMILY- HOUSE OF HONOURS
content.introtext:
HONOUR YOUR FATHER AND YOUR MOTHER...

EXODUS 20:12 NIV
What does it mean to honour someone? This is what the dictionary says: 'Honour: high respect, a feeling of pride or pleasure from being shown such respect, a person or thing that brings credit' There are ways that we can honour and love our parents whilst recognising that they are far from perfect. It is possible to strongly disagree with someone about something and yet maintain a respectful attitude to them. God wants us to be able to love and respect those people who brought us into the world. If parents feel dishonoured or disrespected, they can make others around them miserable too: 'You never listen to me!' 'I'm fed up with being spoken to like that.' 'How dare you lie to me!' 'While you're under this roof you will do what I say!' Sound familiar? Now, we may find loving our parents very difficult indeed. Particularly if we feel that they have ill-treated us or show some major failing. But honouring them is what we need to aim for. So as hard as it may be, we have to do something about it. It's kind of part of the deal. We all find it hard to be the perfect person to live with. And we also find it very easy to blame anyone/everyone else when things go wrong. Often we feel the solution to our family problems is that other people need to change. But the 'If she stopped doing that' or 'If only he didn't do this' may be just an excuse. The Bible challenges us to be the one who changes. Would your family life be better if you loved your mum and dad differently?

content.title: FAMILY - I'm a TEENAGER...get me out here
content.introtext:
GOD PLACES THE LONELY IN FAMILIES...

PSALM 68:6 NLT
It's was a great idea for a TV show, stick a bunch of over pampered (but publicity hungry) celebs in a jungle and get them to eat bugs, swim through swamps and perform survival challenges. And the moment it gets too much they shout 'I'm a celebrity...get me out of here!' We can sometimes feel like this with our families. How many times have you wanted to shout 'I'm a Teenager...get me out of here' when you were with your family. When your dad is in a mood, your mum is pecking your head and your brother is winding you up: sometimes it's hard to imagine a good reason for having a family. When God created people he designed them to live in peace with Him and each other, but sin soon messed that up. Check out Genesis 4 to see the impact sin had on families. Anger, jealously, cruelty and scandal quickly become part of family life. It breaks God's heart when families act like this. God knows how this can damage lives and He offers His love and healing to anyone who lives with the wounds or scars of a broken and hurting family. God knows that families can go wrong but He also knows they can work. They can protect us, teach us, love us and help us. God hasn't given up on family! It's so important to God that He has adopted us into His OWN family and calls us His children. He even tells the church to love each other like a family especially those who have lost or been let down by their own families. FAMILY IS IMPORTANT.

content.title: Why not?
content.introtext:
...BE ZEALOUS...AND...BE SO ALWAYS...

GALATIANS 4:18 NIV
Admiral Hyman Rickover, who was once head of the United States Nuclear Navy, personally interviewed every officer on board his nuclear submarines. Among them was former President-to-be Jimmy Carter. This is Carter's account of the interview: 'He looked straight into my eyes. He never smiled. I was saturated with cold sweat. Finally he asked a question and I thought I could redeem myself. 'How did you stand in your class at the Naval Academy?' I had done very well so I swelled my chest with pride and answered, 'Sir, I stood fifty-ninth out of a class of eight hundred and twenty!' I sat back waiting for congratulations - which never came. Instead, the question: 'Did you do your best?' I started to say, 'Yes, sir,' but I remembered who this was and recalled several times at the Academy when I could have learned more about our allies, our enemies, weapons, strategy, and so forth. I was just human. I finally gulped and said, 'No, sir, I didn't always do my best.' He looked at me for a long time, then turned his chair around to end the interview. He asked one final question, which I have never been able to forget - or to answer. He said, 'Why not?' I sat there for a while, shaken, then slowly left the room.' That's a question we need to ask ourselves at the end of each day: 'Did I do my best?' You can be certain it's a question you'll face when you stand at the Judgment Seat of Christ to be evaluated and rewarded. If you can't answer yes, the question then will be, 'Why not?'

content.title: Make prayer a habit (2)
content.introtext:
...LORD TEACH US TO PRAY...

Luke 11: 1 NIV
A lot of us struggle with prayer. You set aside some time, you start talking but before you know it your mind has wandered and instead of praying you are wondering 'what's the collective noun for hamsters' (apparently it's a horde of hamsters by the way). Sometimes after two minutes you have run out of things to say. Or you give God a list of things you want Him to do and that's it! The disciples needed help with prayer and so do we: 1) Before you start ask the Holy Spirit to come and help you focus your mind, guide your thoughts and draw you close to Jesus. Jesus called the Spirit "the helper" -so ask for help. 2) Try using some structure: Look at the Lords prayer in Luke 11 - we covered it last month - remember?! Take each line and use it as spring board for your prayers. Another structure to use is A.C.T.S. A=adoration C=confession T=thanks S=supplication (which means asking for things) Try and spend 5 minutes on each letter. 3) Write stuff down: Buy a notebook and start to write your prayers out instead of saying them. It can really help stop your mind from wandering. Also it's a really good thing to look back on and see how God has answered your prayers. God doesn't give us points for prayer. You don't pass or fail. He just loves it when we are praying. So see if any of these tips can help your prayer this week.

content.title: Make prayer a habit (1)
content.introtext:
PRAY WITHOUT CEASING.

1 THESSALONIANS 5:17 KJV
If you're the kind of person who will always turn up for any social event but think you can cancel your daily prayer time at a moment's notice, ask yourself: a) has my love for Jesus grown cold? b) do I believe I can handle life on my own? (except for emergencies of course) c) do I know how much God longs to spend time with me? 'But I'm so busy!' That's the lamest excuse you can offer; how you spend your time reveals what's important to you! The truth is, if you don't pray it's because you don't realize its potential, or you're unaware of the condition of your heart. John Wesley (a famous old skool preacher) said, 'God does nothing except in answer to prayer.' If you don't pray the best thing that can happen - is nothing. Prayer puts the situation into God's hands, otherwise whose hands is it in? Yours? Now that's a scary thought! Paul says, 'Pray without ceasing.' You can pray anywhere, anytime, about anything. Your prayers can be out loud or silent, long or short, public or private. 'Pray without ceasing' just means to be chatting with God wherever and whenever. Does your prayer life need a tune-up? Answer these three questions: 1) How often do I pray? If you can't remember when you last spent time in prayer, you're living undirected, uncorrected and unprotected. 2) How's my sincerity? Are you just going through the motions? That's because you don't know enough about who you're talking to, or how He feels about you. 3) How's my faith level? Do you wonder if prayer really changes anything? After all, if God decides everything, why bother? Why? Because prayer isn't just for God's benefit - it's for yours!

content.title: Refuse to settle
content.introtext:
YOU WILL BE MADE RICH IN EVERY WAY SO THAT YOU CAN BE GENEROUS ON EVERY OCCASION...

2 CORINTHIANS 9:11 NIV
Check out what Paul says to his mates at the church in Corinth about giving: 'Remember: A stingy planter gets a stingy crop; a lavish planter gets a lavish crop. I want each of you to take plenty of time to think it over, and make up your own mind what you will give. That will protect you against sob stories and arm-twisting. God loves it when the giver delights in the giving' (2 Corinthians 9:6-7 TM). Be honest, are you stingy with what God has given you? When was the last time you got well excited about giving? Have you ever sat down and got creative, planning and thinking about outrageous ways to bless people? Paul says that giving shouldn't be something we only think about when the offering comes round and we check what's in our jeans' pocket. God wants us to be considerate and cheerful givers. Consider what you can afford. Be honest how much you spend on yourself, what do you really need and what could you do without? Consider whose world could be rocked by your gift. Remember, its not just about money, Paul says you are made rich in every way. Do you have time or talents that you can give as well as your dosh? Think about what God has been saying to you recently, what or who has He highlighted? Then make a decision about what and to whom you are going give. That will protect you from sob stories and arm-twisting. Once you've decided make sure you enjoy it! Be cheerful. For example, you could have a right laugh by trying to bless people secretly! Don't hold back! Go for it!

content.title: Overcoming the grasshopper mentality (2)
content.introtext:
...WE FELT LIKE GRASSHOPPERS NEXT TO THEM...

NUMBERS 13:33 NLT
When you come up against a giant, either your faith will cause you to soar or your fear will cause you to sink. The Israelites died 21 miles from the Promised Land, walking around the desert in circles. Why? Because they let their fear get the better of them: 'We even saw giants there... We felt like grasshoppers next to them.' If you're to see (and seize) what God's promised you, you'll have to conquer your giants. Now, you have the power to, but do you have the guts to? Joshua and Caleb looked upwards with the eyes of faith, even when everyone else started to look down and get depressed 'The whole congregation...said..."Would to God that we had died...in the land of Egypt..."' (Exodus 16:2-3 KJV). These guys were on a serious downer! This is someone with a 'grasshopper mentality': 1) They constantly talk about life's injustices; about how they've been mistreated and misunderstood. To them Paul answers, '...endure hardness, as a good soldier of Jesus Christ' (2 Timothy 2:3 KJV). 2) They make excuses for not conquering in life. Sometimes they even put others down because they are stepping out in faith. To them Paul writes, '...in all these things we are more than conquerors through Him who loved us' (Romans 8:37 NIV). 3) They complain about what they don't have instead of focusing on what they do. To them Peter writes, 'His divine power has given us everything we need for life and godliness through our knowledge of him who called us...' (2 Peter 1:3 NIV). Sound like anyone you know (including yourself)? Get to know God better. That's how to move from a grasshopper mentality to a giant killer mentality!

content.title: Overcoming the grasshopper mentality (1)
content.introtext:
...WE FELT LIKE GRASSHOPPERS NEXT TO THEM...

NUMBERS 13:33 NLT
You'll never know what you're made of spiritually until you come against something too big to handle alone. That's when you discover what you really believe. Moses sent twelve scouts to the promised land. They weren't the kind with badges on their sleeves for making campfires and tying knots, but spies sent to check out Israel's new homeland. They all saw the same thing: a land rich in honey, milk - and giants! Now that was literally a big problem! Acknowledging or knowing there's a problem isn't lack of faith. And it's not a sin. Paul said, '...we wanted to come to you...but satan stopped us' (1 Thessalonians 2:18 NIV). He knew there was a problem! The difference between the scouts was in how they saw the problem. Ten said, 'We saw the giants...and we were in our own eyes as grasshoppers,' but two scouts called Joshua and Caleb said, '"...do not fear the people of the land...The Lord is with us..."' (Numbers 14:9 TLB). Real faith feeds off the stuff the enemy throws at you. Like the scene with Neo from the matrix, faith has its arm stretched and beckons with its fingers: 'Bring it on! The Lord is with me' The negative report of the ten spies caused three reactions in the people: 1) Fear. Fear is irrational. It can make you forget every good thing God's promised, or done for you. 2) Some wanted to go back to Egypt - back to how things used to be 'Er HELLO!' 3) Others wanted to settle in the wilderness. You've got to move with the cloud, otherwise today's manna is the last you'll see. So, is the God you serve bigger than the giant you see? He says He is.

content.title: Do you keep your word?
content.introtext:
KEEP YOUR WORD EVEN WHEN IT COSTS YOU...

PSALM 15:5 TM
On my notepad, at the very bottom of the cover in small black letters it says: 'OUR PROMISE: Satisfaction guaranteed or your money back' I'm not entirely sure why someone wouldn't be satisfied with a notepad. But if the pages were made of thin layers of jelly instead of paper you might find yourself waving a receipt confident that the company would fulfil their 'money back' promise even at the great cost of 79p! Unlike companies, keeping our promises might not cost us cash. But often it CAN be costly. It might mean you miss out or have to put yourself out to keep your word. It might be a lot harder that you thought (ever promised God you would get up earlier to pray?) Solomon says it's '...better not to vow than to...not fulfil it' (Ecclesiastes 5:5 NIV)! God doesn't want us to avoid making promises he just wants us to be committed to keeping them, and not make them lightly. In Psalms David asks: 'Lord, who may...find refuge...on your holy hill?' Here's the answer: 'Anyone who leads a blameless life...is truly sincere...[and] keeps a promise even if it ruins him' (Psalm 15:2 TLB). So how about it, do you keep your word even when it costs you? For example, when you promise to pray for somebody - do you? When you say you'll be somewhere on time - are you? When you tell people they can depend on you - can they? When you agree to repay that cash you borrowed on time- do you? Of Course, nobody's perfect. But when you fail, do you admit your mistake without making excuses? As Christ's disciple you should.

content.title: BEING A SOLID EXAMPLE
content.introtext:
...HONOUR ONE ANOTHER ABOVE YOURSELVES.

ROMANS 12:10 NIV
Lots of people fancy the idea of being a leader. After all, we love the thought of being given respect, being listened to, and most of all...being in charge. But there's more to being a leader that getting your own way or the buzz of wearing the captain's band on your arm. Often it's more about showing respect than getting it, listening rather than always being listened to. Jesus said some serious sit-up-and-listen things about leadership when he was lecturing on one of his training and development seminars for emerging leaders (in other words when he was hanging out with his mates, a bunch of flimsy followers who one day would end up being the world leaders of His church!). Jesus said: '"You've observed how godless rulers throw their weight around, how quickly a little power goes to their heads. It's not going to be that way with you. Whoever wants to be great must become a servant"' (Matthew 20:25-26 TM). You might fancy being a leader but do you fancy leading the way in being a servant? Being the first to put others first? Paul, who wrote massive chunks of the Bible, as a writer filled his letters with instructions about how to live Jesus filled lives. But as a leader he knew that it's not just about telling people what to do. Check this out: 'I'm not, you know, asking you to do anything I'm not already doing myself.' (1 Corinthians 4:16 TM) Paul knew that leadership means being a solid example. Make sure you're a solid example and God will use you to lead others, whether you get called a leader or not.

content.title: In spite of everything - He loves you!
content.introtext:
...HIS UNFAILING LOVE... IS AS GREAT AS THE HEIGHT OF THE HEAVENS ABOVE...

PSALM 103:11 NLT
No matter what the other disciples told him about the resurrection, Thomas wanted to see for himself; so for 7 days he waited. He needed firsthand evidence. And Jesus gave it to him. '"Put your finger here and see my hands. Put your hand into the wound in my side. Don't be faithless any longer. Believe!"' (John 20:27 NLT). And Thomas did; '"My Lord and my God!"' (John 20:28 NLT). Only God could come back from the dead. And only a God of love would come back for a doubter. Did you know what... your doubts don't separate you from God's love! Listen: 'For his unfailing love toward those who fear Him is as great as the height of the heavens above...' (Psalm 103:11 NLT). The big mind blowing news of the Bible is not that you love God; but that He loves you! He says your name is engraved on the palm of His hand (see Isaiah 49:16). His thoughts of you outnumber the grains of sand on the beach (see Psalm 139:17-18). He sees the worst in you yet still believes the best. Your sins and mess ups from the last few weeks - and even your failings in the future don't surprise Him; He knows them all. God's not like someone blinded by love, unable to see the real deal. He knows you better than you know yourself. And He's reached His verdict: 'I love you!' No discovery will disillusion Him, no rebellion dissuade Him. He loves you with an unfailing love, and that knowledge can lift you, restore you and put you back on your feet.

content.title: Holy kitchen utensils!
content.introtext:
…HOLY AND BLAMELESS IN HIS SIGHT...

EPHESIANS 1:4 NIV
The word ‘holiness’ is a turn-off to a lot of people. It reminds them of finger-pointing religion and negative experiences they’ve had in church. They immediately think of the top-ten things you can’t do. Nothing could be further from the truth. Holiness is not what we do; it’s what God sees. God has a vision for your life, a picture of the perfect you, and everyday he brings you opportunities that – if you take them – will make you a bit more like that perfect you. As you serve, and worship and pray, God will show you more and more of what the perfect you looks like. That’s when His vision for your life starts becoming your vision for your life too. True holiness if having the faith to work at bringing every aspect of your life in line with God’s perfect vision. You work out what please God and what offends God. Put simply, you decide that your life will only be used for one purpose: WORSHIPPING GOD. In the Old Testament, the priests used knives, forks, jugs and basins for the temple sacrifices. They were just ordinary kitchen utensils until they were set aside for God’s use, then they became holy knives, holy forks, holy jugs and holy basins! But check this out: contamination disqualified them from being used, so they had to be protected. Are you getting the idea? When God chose you He had a specific vision of you, and for you. You might think that you’re just Jo/Joe, but now you’re holy Jo/Joe! Like a sim card, you can be used on one network, Godcom! Once you understand that and fully accept it, you’ll never be scared off by the word ‘holiness’ again.

content.title: Ooops!
content.introtext:
…A GREAT DOOR…HAS OPENED TO ME…

1 CORINTHIANS 16:9 NIV
Yesterday we looked at a chat that Moses had with God. Here’s another important bit of the conversation: Moses told God: ‘…If your Presence does not go with us, do not send us…’ (Exodus 33:15 NIV). What old Mo’ was getting at here is still massively important for us today; we need to know that the things we do in life are not totally random ideas off at a tangent from God’s big plan. If God’s not behind it, you don’t want to be involved in it. Sometimes we need to stop and say ‘Oops, that was me, not God.’ So does this mean that as long as we pray, the right prayers we’ll sail gently in to our God-given destiny? No. Even when God is right at the heart of your mission you’ll still deal with delays, discouragement and setbacks. Opportunities and obstacles seem to come together. Some of you will be at the other extreme here. Rather than being happy-go-lucky and wrongly assuming God’s in everything you do, you’re always asking paranoid questions. ‘Does God love me? Has He really chosen me? Am I in His will?’ Listen, there are some basic promises that you can ALWAYS trust: 1) He always loves you (see Jeremiah 31:3) 2) He chose us before the creation of the world (see Ephesians 1:4) 3) He assures us that if we resist the mindsets of the world, we will know what he wants for us (See Romans 12:2). So live today with a healthy mix of confidence and caution. Don’t get an over-inflated ego and think that every good idea you have is a direct download from God. But don’t go the other way and get paralyzed at the pants drawer because God hasn’t revealed whether he wants you to wear black or white today!

content.title: Buy a tent!
content.introtext:
…ANYONE ENQUIRING OF THE LORD WOULD GO TO THE TENT...

EXODUS 33:7 NIV
Moses did something we can learn from today: ‘Moses used to take a tent and pitch it outside the camp some distance away, calling it the ‘tent of meeting.’…Anyone enquiring of the Lord would go to the tent…’ (Exodus 33:7 NIV). And what would happen in that tent? ‘The Lord would speak to Moses face to face, as a man speaks with his friend…’ (Exodus 33:11 NIV). Face to face time with God! That’s what we need. Turn off your mobile phone. Sell your TV on Ebay and buy a tent! Ok – maybe you don’t really need the tent – underneath your duvet will do just fine . So what did they talk about in that tent? Moses prayed: a) ‘…Let me know whom you will send with me…’ (Exodus 33:12 NIV). Some of the problems you’re experiencing are because of the people who are influencing you b) ‘…teach me your ways…’ (Exodus 33:13 NIV). Your way of doing things doesn’t seem to be working too well, so get God’s input! c) ‘…so I may know you…’ (Exodus 33:13 NIV). This word ‘know’ isn’t a casual matey-thing; it’s proper intimacy between two people. d) ‘…so I may…continue to find favour with you…’ (Exodus 33:13 NIV). God’s favour; you need it because it opens doors, gives you the edge, and influences people before you speak a word. And what did God say back to Moses in that tent? ‘…I will do the very thing you have asked, because I am pleased with you and I know you by name’ (Exodus 33:17 NIV). Would you like to be on a first name basis with God? Get in that tent!

content.title: God’s gadgets?!
content.introtext:
…THE HOLY SPIRIT…WILL PRODUCE THIS KIND OF FRUIT IN US...

GALATIANS 5:22 NLT
We all like our gadgets… Our mobile phone, MP3 player, PSP! Well, all these gadgets are useless without power. You could say the same about us too. It’s the power of the Holy Spirit that fires us up and makes us function. Here’s three ways the Holy Spirit works: 1) He moves us. When Jesus was born Mary and Joseph wanted to make sure they didn’t stuff things up. It was the custom to get kids blessed at the temple so that’s where they headed. They didn’t know it but an old priest called Simeon had been waiting his whole life for them to arrive. ‘That day the Holy Spirit led him to the Temple. So when Mary and Joseph came to present the baby Jesus…Simeon was there. He took the child in his arms and praised God saying, “Lord, now I can die in peace! As you promised me, I have seen the Saviour...”’ (Luke 2:27 – 30 NLT) The Holy Spirit will move you so that you don’t miss these destiny moments! 2) He comforts us. Jesus referred to the Holy Spirit as the ‘comforter’ who would never leave us (See John 14:16). When you wake up worried about your day He whispers, ‘I’ve got everything under control.’ When you feel like you can’t go on, He holds your hand, and says ‘I’m right here with you.’ You’re not alone in this life; you’ve got God’s help! 3) He protects us. Paul said to Timothy ‘With the help of the Holy Spirit who lives in us, carefully guard what has been entrusted to you‘. When the enemy moves against you to steal the good things God has given you, pray, ‘Holy Spirit, be my bodyguard.’ You can count on this; the Holy Spirit will do a better job than Kevin Costner!

content.title: The Lord’s Prayer (9)
content.introtext:
…YOURS IS THE KINGDOM, AND THE POWER, AND THE GLORY, FOR EVER, AMEN.

MATTHEW 6:13 NKJV
This is the great big ‘KABOOM’ at the end of the prayer. It echoes down the centuries like a firework exploding down a narrow alley! ‘Yours is the Kingdom,’ reminds us that if Jesus is not the boss of all, He’s not Boss at all. When you wake up in the morning you should pray: ‘Father, make my life like an advert today to everyone I meet I want them to see how much better life works when it’s lived in your kingdom instead of the kingdom of self.’ ‘Yours is…the power’ reminds us that God’s destiny for our lives can only be fulfilled through God’s power at work in our lives. The Apostle Paul took time to explain the tug of war that we often feel going on inside us. In his usual matter of fact way he puts it like this, ‘…people who are ruled by their sinful selves cannot please God.’ (Romans 8:8 NCV). Elsewhere he expands on that saying, ‘Those who belong to Christ Jesus have crucified their own sinful selves. They have given up their old selfish feelings and the evil things they wanted to do. We get our new life from the Spirit, so we should follow the Spirit’ (Galations 5:24-25 NCV). ‘Yours is…the glory,’ reminds us that the credit always goes to the One Who truly deserves it. – The One who gave us this fantastic life in the first place! This final line of the Lord’s Prayer simply means ‘Lord, You are in charge, not me; You are infinitely strong, I’m not. And I will live my life to make you famous’. So that’s the end of our Lord’s Prayer marathon. Make sure you use it again and again and again.

content.title: The Lord’s Prayer (8)
content.introtext:
…LEAD US NOT INTO TEMPTATION, BUT DELIVER US FROM THE EVIL ONE.

MATTHEW 6:13 NIV
When Jesus taught us to pray ‘…lead us not into temptation, but deliver us from the evil one,’ He was teaching us to pray for His protection. Does satan have power? Look back. Haven’t you played into his hands more than once? His objective is to ‘…kill, steal and destroy…’ (John 10:10). But check out these words: ‘…God’s Spirit, who is in you, is greater than the devil, who is in the world’ (1John 4:4 NCV). God sent an urgent message to a first century church in Smyrna (part of Greece then – now part of Turkey), ‘Do not be afraid of what you are about to suffer. I tell you, the devil will put some of you in prison to test you, and you will suffer for ten days. But be faithful, even if you have to die, and I will give you the crown of life’ (Revelation 2:10 NCV). This is an amazing example of the way God allows certain things to happen because he knows the final outcome, God tells them how long the attack will last (‘ten days’), the reason for the attack (‘to test you’), and the outcome of the attack (‘a crown of life’). Every time satan tries to score – we win! When satan knocks us down, God picks us up. David, who’d experienced more than his fair share of attacks, writes, ‘The steps of the godly are directed by the Lord…Though they stumble, they will not fall, for the Lord holds them by the hand’ (Psalm 37:23-24 NLT). Jesus lets us know in this line of the prayer just how important it is for us to pray for protection. So pray today. Place your small hand into God’s big hand and face the problems of the day together.

content.title: The Lord’s Prayer (7)
content.introtext:
…FORGIVE US OUR SINS, JUST AS WE HAVE FORGIVEN THOSE WHO HAVE SINNED AGAINST US.

MATTHEW 6:12 NLT
This is a pretty extreme part of the Lord’s Prayer. When we pray it, we give away our right to rage, revenge and resentment. But this is the line that rescues us from our inbuilt tendency to kid ourselves that we can live by one set of standard but expect something different from other people. In this line of the prayer the shadow of the cross falls onto the page. Ultimately Jesus forgave His enemies when He had the power to destroy them. Think about this - if God: a) was a bit choosy in forgiving like you are b) took His time before forgiving just to rub it in c) told everybody who’d listen what you’ve done to Him d) forgave, but refused to give you another chance e) made up His mind to blank you and avoid you f) next time you were in trouble, refused to help you saying, ‘You should’ve learned your lesson last time,’ could you live with that? No? Then offer to other people the same forgiveness God offers to you. When you pray ‘Forgive us our sins, just as we have forgiven those who have sinned against us’ you’re asking for a change of heart! Nehemiah writes, ‘…you are a forgiving God…‘ (Nehemiah 9:17 NIV). Aren’t you glad he didn’t write, ‘you are a God ready to put us on probation.’ No, forgiveness is God’s generous attitude toward us. His forgiveness was assured before we even went out and did those sins. Wow! Doesn’t that make you want to live life God’s way! The only place unforgiveness belongs is in the wheely bin! That’s where we put all the rubbish that stinks the house out. Remember that, next time you pray The Lord’s Prayer.

content.title: The Lord’s Prayer (6)
content.introtext:
GIVE US TODAY OUR DAILY BREAD.

MATTHEW 6:11 NIV
Did you know there are two reasons for praying, ‘Give us today our daily bread’. First there is the natural reason: while we may have so much food that our prayer is, ‘Lord, help me to lose some weight,’ millions still go to bed hungry. They pray this same prayer but without an answer they won’t make it. And we dare not turn away from them because: ‘God blesses those who are kind to the poor. He helps them out of their troubles. He protects them…he publicly honours them and destroys the power of their enemies’ (Psalm 41:1-2 TLB). Secondly there is the spiritual reason: When he was being tempted by the devil Jesus said, ‘…Man does not live on bread alone, but on every word that comes from the mouth of God’ (Matthew 4:4 NIV). Note the phrase ‘every word.’ Some words God feeds us are pleasant; some are painful. And we need both. ‘Ice cream Christians’ pick Scriptures that taste sweet but as a result they don’t develop the spiritual muscle required to stand strong in the hard times. It’s easy to tell when you’re not eating right. People get on your nerves, you go through mood swings, you cave into fear. Don’t let that happen; sort your spiritual diet out! So we can see that this bit of the Lord’s Prayer works on two levels, we are asking God to take care of our needs in a natural way and a spiritual way. Either way, the truth is, without your daily bread you won’t make it!

content.title: The Lord’s Prayer (5)
content.introtext:
…YOUR KINGDOM COME...

MATTHEW 6:10
We live in the United Kingdom – but it doesn’t always seem united, does it?! That’s because everybody wants to have their own little kingdom, the kingdom of self. In the kingdom of self, you rule. And what’s life like in the kingdom of self? It’s generally a total mess - because the wrong person’s in charge! In the Kingdom of God, Jesus rules. His Word settles every issue. No, ‘Yeah, but…’. The fastest route to success in any job is to find out what the boss wants, and do it with excellence. Well Jesus said, ‘…make the kingdom of God your primary concern’ (Matthew 6:33 NLT). Did you know that the gravity is different in God’s kingdom? Everything is upside down. 1) The way up, is down. ‘Humble yourselves…that he may lift you up in due time’ (1Peter 5:6 NIV). Note the words, ‘due time.’ Your blessing is already scheduled on God’s calendar. Just keep your head down. 2) By forgiving others you free yourself. Holding on to bad feelings about somebody is so tiring. When you choose to forgive someone, all the energy you lost to self-pity and bitterness comes flooding back. Jesus made it clear on the cross that forgiveness is at the heart of his mission. And in the Kingdom of God we do things His way. Each time we take a step in Jesus’ footsteps, God’s will is done, a little more of His Kingdom comes. So why bother praying, ‘Your kingdom come, Your will be done on earth, as it is in heaven’? Because the kingdom of God is so massive that we can only see a tiny bit of it. We need God’s inspiration to show us which boundaries he wants us to push back. So pray it today and play your part in making god’s kingdom grow.

content.title: The Lord’s Prayer (4)
content.introtext:
…MAY YOUR NAME BE HONOURED.

MATTHEW 6:9 NLT
If you ever get invited to Buckingham Palace and have the privilege of meeting the Queen, don’t show up in sawn-off jeans and a raggedy T-shirt. They won’t let you in. You’re not going to your mate’s house, you’re meeting royalty! Likewise, when Jesus told us to pray, ‘May your name be honoured,’ He was teaching us that there’s only one way to enter God’s presence. And it’s not with a shopping list of all the things you want. If the only time someone comes to visit you is when they need something, you’ll soon stop answering the door. So, when you pray to him, big him up! David tells us more about how to approach God: ‘Know that the Lord is God: It is he who made us, and we are his…Enter into his gates with thanksgiving, and his courts with praise: give thanks to him, and praise his name’ (Psalm 100:3-4 NIV). When we close our eyes in prayer, we imagine our self walking through those great big fancy gates. God can hear us coming through because we’re making a Rukus about all the top stuff he’s done for us! Then we walk across His courtyard making a big fuss about Who He is: ‘My Saviour, my defender, my provider, my source of strength, the giver of my joy, the lover of my soul, the author and finisher of my faith.’ If you can express yourself when your favourite team’s winning or when your favourite X-Factor finalist wins the competition then you can definitely praise God! Whether you’re a morning person or a night person, the Bible says, ‘From the rising of the sun to the place where it sets, the name of the Lord is to be praised’ (Psalm 113:3 NIV). The way to enter and to enjoy God’s presence – is by honouring His name.

content.title: The Lord’s Prayer (3)
content.introtext:
…“OUR FATHER IN HEAVEN...

MATTHEW 6:9 NIV
When we pray to our Father God, we recognize His position. Daniel said, ‘…the Most High rules over the kingdom of the world…’ (Daniel 4:17 NLT). That’s the ultimate reality that we need to remember when we see frightening headlines. This rebellious world has been wrestling against God for thousands of years. The prophet Isaiah cried, ‘Oh, the raging of many nations – they rage like the raging sea!...’ (Isaiah 17:12) If God isn’t in control – who is? The Prime Minister? Well, he wears smart suits and always has a smile for the camera, but that’s not good enough if you really want to sleep peacefully in your bed at night. The Psalmist said, ‘My help comes from the Lord…’ (Psalm 121:2 NIV). Think: if He really is King over everything that’s going on, and if He’s promised to help us when we call on Him, what do we have to worry about? You say, ‘What about terrorism? What about The Middle East?’ God’s heart breaks over the hatred and violence that human beings inflict on each other – but Jesus told us that it would be this way as the end comes near: ‘You will hear of wars and rumours of wars, but see to it that you are not alarmed – such things must happen, but the end is still to come...’ (Matthew 24:6 NIV) Still think God’s not running the show? He’s God, and He has a master plan. The exciting bit of that plan is that it’s not a big secret; He’s already told us the way it ends: ‘…at the Name of Jesus every knee should bow…and every tongue confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father’ (Philippians 2:10-11 NIV).

content.title: The Lord’s Prayer (2)
content.introtext:
…OUR FATHER...

MATTHEW 6:9
Jesus taught His disciples to pray: ‘This, then, is how you should pray: “Our Father…”’ (Matthew 6:9 NIV). The relationship you have with someone has a massive effect on the amount of security and confidence you feel when you approach them. So Jesus begins by getting this sorted out right at the start by saying: ‘Our Father.’ Now, if you, like so many nowadays, have a father who was never there for you, or an abusive father who hurt you, or an emotionally vacant father who never showed you much love or acceptance, then there’s a whole new dimension of fatherhood waiting for you here. Don’t let your past rob you of this revelation. You can trust God. He really, really loves you. And the more you start believing that, the more you’ll open up to Him. Only as you do that can your wounded areas be healed. ‘Our Father’ – you are part of a massive global family who all find peace in His arms. So now you understand Who you’re talking to, and the relationship you have with Him, you can approach God as a child, knowing that He’ll be delighted to hear your voice. Your Heavenly Father is a promise making, promise keeping God. When two people in Bible days made a promise, it wasn’t a casual ‘call me sometime’ with no commitment. No, they sealed it with blood, meaning, ‘I’ll give my life for you if necessary.’ And we know that if wasn’t an empty promise. The cross of Jesus proves that God keeps his word. So, to really enter into the Lord’s Prayer and find its source of power, we must be ready to speak those first two words loud and proud – Our Father.

content.title: The Lord’s Prayer (1)
content.introtext:
…LORD, TEACH US TO PRAY...

LUKE 11:1
Jesus always led by example. One day Jesus’ disciples watched him praying. Afterwards they said: ‘Lord, teach us to pray.’ It was then that He gave them what’s become known as ‘The Lord’s Prayer.’ Can you remember when you last prayed it? If not, how come? Did you grow up saying it so often that it’s become boring? Or have you never actually taken the time to learn it off by heart? You should – it’s amazing – and powerful! ‘Well, the Lord’s prayer’s a bit old fashioned – a bit traditional – I just like to freewheel when I chat with God’. Fair enough, but in all your laid back matey-ness with God watch out because ‘When you pray, don’t babble on and on…’ (Matthew 6:7 NLT). There are actually lots of models of prayer in the Bible: prayers for guidance, for forgiveness, for unity, and none of them include waffle or babble! Here’s the score: when you pray it should be a) passionate b) scriptural c) intimate d) unhurried e) faith-filled. Take a moment to chew on each of those five things. They’re your keys to effective prayer. We only tend to keep doing stuff that we feel there’s a point to, so when prayer feels like it’s got no point, we quit. If that’s why you never pray The Lord’s Prayer, the look at it again and take up the challenge. For the next few days we’re going to go back to the only prayer Jesus Himself gave us to pray. And let’s face it, who knows more about prayer? Can you imagine Jesus giving us a prayer that wouldn’t move us, move God, or move and of the mountains we face? Exactly, so let’s get moving!

content.title: Moment of opportunity
content.introtext:
…NAMAAN TOLD THE KING WHAT THE GIRL HAD SAID

2 KINGS 5:4 CEV
God used a cleaning maid to reach an army general, and introduce him to a God who could heal him of his leprosy. Her story’s recorded in 2 Kings, chapter 5. Dig your Bible out and take a look at it. There are two important lessons in it for you: 1) There’s a purpose in your being where you are! Instead of complaining, start looking for somebody who needs what God’s given you. This girl wasn’t there just to make the beds and sweep the floors; she was there because God specially arranged it. Think: all of your life can be training for one shot, one opportunity, one moment. Peter writes, '…Always be prepared to give an answer…' (1 Peter 3:15 NIV). Will you capture it or just let it slip? 2) What a difference a day can make! Yesterday she was a nobody; today she’s a gift from God, and the most popular person in the house. The world focuses on the big names, but when they’ve run out of answers and out of hope, God says ‘I’ll even pour out my Spirit on the servants, men and women both’ (Joel 2:29 TM). When He does, people who normally just blank you in the street will suddenly begin to listen, because you’re in the right place, at the right time with the right answer. Don’t allow your lack of experience, your postcode or the naff grades you got in your last exam to silence you. Keep your mind fresh and your faith strong! Just be available for God to use you today as only He can!

content.title: Practice
content.introtext:
…EVEN BEFORE HE MADE THE WORLD, GOD LOVED US AND CHOSE US IN CHRIST TO BE HOLY...

EPHESIANS 1:4 NLT
The world’s attitude is to be able to brag to other people: ‘I did it my way’ and ‘nobody tells me what to do’. It’s an independent streak which is breaking apart families and communities. But here Paul shows us that God’s best for us is to be holy in Jesus – something we can’t do on our own! And this didn’t start with us making one or two good decisions – God had it in mind even before he made the world! Paul writes later, ‘…put off your old self…put on the new self…’ (Ephesians 4:22-24 NIV). When you first start letting go of the self-made you and putting on the god-made you, it’ll feel strange. But just as new shoes don’t feel comfortable at first, so your new way of approaching life will also take a bit of getting used to. As you continue to ‘put on the new self’ you’ll become more and more at home with it. It works like this. You have to: a) practice doing the right thing until you automatically do the right thing b) practice turning up on time for youth group until it feels weird to ever be late for anything c) practice giving some of your spending money to the needy in the world d) practice telling the truth until the smallest lie troubles your conscience and sticks in your throat e) practice speaking encouragement until every cynical word is deleted from your vocabulary. By taking practical steps like these, you are re-training yourself to walk God’s way – and restraining yourself from walking any other way. You are saying to God, ‘Ok boss, it’s no longer a matter of me making up my own rules, it’s about what You say and direct me to do.’

content.title: Displaying Jesus
content.introtext:
…“SIR, WE WANT TO MEET JESUS”

JOHN 12:21 NLT
One day some Greeks came to Philip saying, ‘…“Sir, we want to meet Jesus”’ If you listen carefully – that’s what people around you are still saying today. You might suggest: ‘Telling them to go to church and they’ll see Jesus.’ Maybe, maybe not. Get close enough to some people who fill a pew every Sunday and it might put you off for life! When we recognise that somebody is looking for Jesus, we should not need to send them anywhere. When we made our decision to give our lives to Him, He came and made His home in our heart (see Ephesians 3:17). Yes, they may have questions that you can’t answer yourself, but you have the power of prayer. If someone is genuinely seeking for God, they won’t decline your offer of prayer. Ask them gently if you can put your hand on their arm while you pray. Then invite Jesus to come and flood their life with His love. And when you get to the ‘Amen’, ask them if they would like to add anything – they need to know that the door is open for them too. So whatever you think you are or aren’t good at - listen; your gifts and abilities are secondary to this – people want to see Jesus in you. Sure, invite your friends to church, but when the meeting’s over people want to see Jesus - in you. When you get through telling your schoolmates what you believe, they want to see Jesus – in you. You don’t have to defend Him, just display Him through your attitudes and actions each day. Jesus said, ‘…I, when I am lifted up…will draw all me to myself’ (John 12:32 NIV). We do the lifting; Jesus does the drawing – that’s how it works!

content.title: Don’t be dragged down
content.introtext:
…“I AM DOING GREAT WORK!...”

NEHEMIAH 6:3 NLT
We all know people who are unwilling to take responsibility for their life, so they plough through each day complaining about everything and blaming everyone else for things that go wrong. Because they’re incapable of loving themselves, they can’t extend love to others. Often their negativity is a sign that a really deep struggle is going on. Deep down their afraid of being rejected, so they just have a very small circle of friends – who are equally mixed up! So how should you respond to such people? Well be careful – if you can’t lift them up, make sure they don’t drag you down. Nehemiah got a lot of hassle from shady people who criticized the wall he was building. He put it to them straight: ‘…”I am doing great work! I cannot stop to come and meet with you”’ (Nehemiah 6:3 NLT). He didn’t get sidetracked, and ‘…the wall was…finished - just fifty-two days after we had begun. When our enemies…heard about it, they were…humiliated. They realised that this work had been done with the help of our God’ (Nehemiah 6:15-16 NLT). Was it easy working around neggy people like that? No. How did Nehemiah do it? When he started getting discouraged he prayed to the Lord God to strengthen him! (See Nehemiah 6:9 NLT). Notice he didn’t day, ‘Lord, zap them. ‘Or, ‘Lord make them nice to me.’ No, he asked for strength, maintained a good attitude and prayed that God would take care of his critics. And God did. So remember Nehemiah and don’t develop a ‘victim mentality’. Many of the people who aggravate you don’t do it on purpose – it’s just their nature.

content.title: Groundhog Day
content.introtext:
…ON THOSE LIVING IN THE LAND OF THE SHADOW OF DEATH A LIGHT HAS DAWNED.

ISAIAH 9:2 NIV
Have you seen Groundhog Day? The film where a guy gets stuck in the same day again and again. At first he thinks it’s just a weird phase he’s going through. Eventually he starts freaking out because he feels so trapped. Life loses its meaning because he‘s living without a future. Well, the world is full of people really living like that. And that’s why the message of Jesus’ resurrection is so amazing! You see the resurrection proves that Jesus wasn’t just some good bloke or wise teacher. He was God the Son – sent from heaven to earth when there was no hope of a better tomorrow. The whole world needed a breakthrough. And the Bible says: ‘…on those living in the land of the shadow of death a light has dawned’ (Isaiah 9:2 NIV). Jesus’ resurrection was like the sun coming up over the horizon after the endless night that had hung over the earth. When he broke through death itself he not only dealt with all the sins of the past but he blazed a trail for us into a new future. So listen…The resurrection is absolutely at the heart of our Christian faith and it is an invitation to everyone who feels like they’re stuck in Groundhog day; 1) To everyone who feels trapped in a life that is less than God’s best 2) To everyone who has tried to change but failed again and again 3) To everyone who has given up hope that tomorrow can be different to today. The resurrection says: ‘…if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation; the old has gone, the new has come!’ (2 Corinthians 5:17 NIV).

content.title: The power of crying
content.introtext:
…I…CRIED OUT TO MY GOD; HE HEARD MY VOICE…

PSALM 18:6 NKJV
In his book, The Power Of Crying Out, Bill Gothard writes: ‘The most significant difference between the prayers of God’s people in scripture (so powerfully effective) and our prayers today (so seemingly ineffective) is this: there was a fervency in the prayer of biblical saints – a fervency that is inherent in crying out. When we grasp this fact, the pages of scripture come alive with sound!’ The Oxford dictionary defines ‘fervent’ as: ‘having or displaying passionate intensity’ David gives us a picture of this when he says: ‘…I called upon the Lord, and cried out to my God; He heard my voice…’ (Psalm 18:6 NKJV) The Hebrew word that describes David’s outcry is shava, a higher pitched cry for help. Again he says: ‘…I called to you for help and you healed me’ (Psalm 30:2 NIV). A true father’s heart hears his children’s cries, and lovingly responds. In the same way crying out to God is our impulse, planted within us by the Holy Spirit. John says, ‘See how much our heavenly Father loves us, for he allows us to be called his children, and we really are!...’ (1 John 3:1 NLT) God loves you so much – you should never be embarrassed about calling out for His help. He longs to get involved in every aspect of your life, yes, even the messy stuff. Especially the messy stuff! Desperate situations call for desperate measures. Did you know we can also allow the Holy Spirit to cry out from within us? Have you ever found yourself deliberately suppressing an urge to cry out to God? Could you be quenching the Spirit of God? If so, its time to make a change; forget about your inhibitions and start ‘crying out.’

content.title: True Leader
content.introtext:
HE MADE HIMSELF NOTHING; HE TOOK THE HUMBLE POSITION OF A SLAVE…

Philippians 2:7 NTL
It’s dangerous when someone ends up in leadership simply because they’ve got a big personality or because they get good marks in their exams. Before anyone becomes a leader their character needs to be seen. If someone is unwilling to wait, or won’t serve in a lower spot, they probably don’t have the maturity to handle a higher one. True leaders follow in the footsteps of the One who ‘…made himself nothing…’ (Philippians 2:7), they nail their ego to the cross and humbly serve because they are concerned about other people – not themselves. The apostle Paul warned his apprentice Timothy, ‘Don’t appoint people to church leader positions too hastily…’ (1 Timothy 5:22 TM). It’s a lot easier to get someone into a job than it is to get them out of it! Meanwhile God’s work is held up while the mess gets sorted out. When Philip the evangelist went to Samaria to preach, a whole city was blessed by the things he said and did. If ever a church needed leadership in a hurry, they did. And that’s when a guy called Simon the sorcerer showed up. The Bible says ‘…all the people, both high and low gave him their attention…’ (Acts 8:10 NIV). But then, just when you think he’s a really genuine guy who really wants to be a disciple of Jesus, the mask comes off and he offers Peter money saying, ‘…Give me this power…’ (Acts 8:19 NKJV). Peter replied, ‘…May your money perish with you… your heart is not right before God...’ (Acts 8:20-22 NIV). People’s true character can’t stay hidden for ever. Who we are deep down will always be seen eventually.

content.title: Are you hoping?
content.introtext:
…LET PATIENCE HAVE ITS PERFECT WORK, THAT YOU MAY BE PERFECT AND COMPLETE, LACKING NOTHING.

JAMES 1:4 NKJV
Are you hoping – maybe even praying – for something? Are you starting to get fed up of waiting? Listen, just because it hasn’t happened yet doesn’t mean it won’t, or that God has changed His mind. While you are waiting; God is working. The timing may not be right for Him to get the ultimate fame and you the ultimate gain. That’s why James writes: ‘Let patience have its perfect work, that you may be perfect and complete, lacking nothing. You may not want to hear this; but impatience is a sign of immaturity. You know what kids are like, they can’t wait for anything! But a good parent knows what’s best. God has got all sorts of amazing stuff in store for you. We call this His purpose, for our lives. Paul writes: ‘…we know that all things work…according to His purpose’ (see Romans 8:28 NKJV). When you really believe God has a purpose for you, you won’t let things get in the way of it, including hurry and worry. You’ll also have a clearer idea of what to do with your energy and even your money. God says, ‘I make known the end from the beginning…’ (Isaiah 46:10 NIV). First God sets the goal, then He plans a journey towards. And what are we supposed to do while we are waiting? We look after our attitude and use the extra time to praise him. Listen: ‘Though the cherry trees don’t blossom and the strawberries don’t ripen, though the apples are worm eaten…I’m singing joyful praise to God. I’m turning cartwheels of joy to my Saviour Lord.’ (Habakkuk 3:17-18 TM). Begin praising God today for what He’s going to do – because He absolutely will come through for you!

content.title: Prove it – at the altar!
content.introtext:
…WE MUST NOT PURSUE THE KIND OF SEX THAT AVOIDS COMMITMENT AND INTIMACY, LEAVING US MORE LONELY THAN EVER...

1 CORINTHIANS 6:17 TM
There was this famous American newspaper columnist called Ann Landers, she wrote every week for years and years; right up until she died in fact. She wrote about all sorts of things; and was very outspoken on subjects other people would shy away from. She wrote on one occasion for girls whose boyfriends ask them to ‘prove their love’ through sex, check her out: ‘Why not prove your love by sticking your head in the oven and turning on the gas? Or how about playing leap-frog in traffic? It’s about as safe. Clear the cobwebs out of your head. Anybody who asks you to prove your love is trying to take you for the biggest, most gullible fool that ever walked. That ‘proving it’ bit is one of the rottenest lines ever invented. Does he love you? It doesn’t sound like it. Someone who loves you wants whatever’s best for you. Figure it out. He wants you to commit an immoral act, surrender your virtue, compromise your character, throw away your self respect, risk the loss of your reputation and risk getting pregnant, getting diseased or getting into trouble. Wise up! He wants what’s best for him! He wants a thrill he can brag about at your expense. Love? Who’s kidding who? A guy who loves a girl would sooner cut off his right arm than hurt her. The truth is, this self-serving individual has proved that he doesn’t love you at all. That’s when he drops you, picks up his line and goes casting elsewhere for another equally gullible fish. If he loves you, let him prove it – at the altar.’

content.title: Every minute counts
content.introtext:
…JESUS, TIRED AS HE WAS FROM THE JOURNEY, SAT DOWN BY THE WELL...

JOHN 4:6 NIV
Jesus had an amazing way of making every minute of His life count. 2000 years ago they had no cars and they didn’t even have decent shoes; so people walked everywhere. In this story Jesus is halfway through a long, tiring journey. This well He stopped at was a bit like stopping at the motorway services today. But as we read on we see that Jesus wasn’t protective of His ‘downtime’ every minute of His life was available for God to use. The most noticeable thing about Jesus was that He always had time for people. And He wasn’t simply available or approachable. He would kickstart conversations with complete strangers! So who did He meet at this pit-stop? Some famous personality with all the right connections? Somebody with a big cheque book ready to make a donation to His ministry? No, she was a no-name, five times divorced, floozy woman with a bad reputation and a live-in boyfriend. Did that bother JC? No, because even if all the other people tut-tut at your past, Jesus has his eye on your future. Whatever you’ve done, God’s not holding it against you. Jesus didn’t see this woman as bad; He saw her as lost. Big difference! Once she was ‘found’ she was the kind of person who’d be full on for God – gossiping the gospel on every street corner. This woman was destined to shake up her neighbourhood: ‘Many of the Samaritans from that town believed in him because of the woman’s testimony…’ (John 4:39 NIV). So there are two lessons here today: 1) Be ready for God to use you at any minute. 2) Neither you, nor anyone you meet, is beyond the love of God.

content.title: It’s the message, not the messenger!
content.introtext:
…ANYONE WHO WELCOMES MY MESSENGER IS WELCOMING ME...

JOHN 13:20 NLT
Today’s word is dead simple: focus on the message, not the messenger! ‘But shouldn’t leaders set a good example; shouldn’t they be called to a higher standard?’ Yes, those trusted with great responsibility experience greater discipline. But God does that; not you. The Bible gives an extreme example: King Saul repeatedly tried to kill David, yet David realised that God had chosen Saul. Yes, King Saul had blown it, and God’s new plan was in motion, but David didn’t have the right to press fast-forward on that plan! This may come as a shock; God has no perfect messengers (we’re not counting angels here)! He uses ordinary people who have made themselves available to Him. And many of them are still struggling in certain areas. They’re being developed even while they’re delivering the message God wants you to hear. A perfect word from imperfect lips – that’s how God does it. The great prophet Samuel led Israel for 40 years. He even anointed David to be King. Yet Sam’s own sons went astray. David, who God called a man after His own heart, lost the plot for a while and got himself into a shady love triangle that ended up getting a guy killed. Yet the Bible says, he ’…served God’s purpose in his own generation…’ (see Acts 13:36 NIV). And remember, Peter’s dark hour of denial didn’t prevent him from winning thousands to Christ. So, when you see your leader’s imperfections what should you do? a) learn from their mistakes b) pray for them. After all, if you can’t find mercy in the house of God where are you going to find it? c) keep listening to their message. Jesus said, ‘…anyone who welcomes my messenger is welcoming me…’ (John 13:20 NLT).

content.title: U C bones – I C an army
content.introtext:
…AND THE BONES CAME TOGETHER...

EZEKIAL 37:7 NIV
If you think your life is too messed up for God to do anything about? Then visit Ezekiel in The Valley of Dry Bones: ‘He led me around among the old, dry bones that covered the valley floor’ (Ezekiel 37:2 NLT). God gave Ezekiel his Word to speak over them: ‘…I will put breath into you, and you will come to life. Then you will know that I am the Lord’ (Ezekiel 37:6 NIV). Suddenly, ‘…there was a rattling noise. The bones…came together...’ (Ezekiel 37:7 NLT) Next we read that: ‘…[Breath entered them] They all came to life and stood up on their feet - a great army of them’ (Ezekiel 37:10 NLT). Are you trying every way you know to put your life together? Do you long to get back on your feet? Then open the windows of your soul and let the wind of God blow in! And did you notice the role God’s Word played in this miracle? It all started with the Word. Nothing will bring order to your chaotic world like getting the truth of the Scriptures into your life. Now take a closer look: God told Ezekiel, ‘Speak to the winds and say… Come… Breathe into these dead bodies so that they may live…’ (Ezekiel 37:9 NLT). God didn’t tell Ezekiel to speak to the bones; they couldn’t respond. They were too dead and too dry. You don’t organise a group therapy session for skeletons! No, they needed raw power. So God tells Ezekiel, ‘Speak to the wind.’ Cry out for the Spirit of God to come because without Him there’s no hope, no change, no future. Today God says, ‘Come on – cry out to Me and I’ll move on your behalf!’

content.title: A spiritual mindset
content.introtext:
…BE TRANSFORMED BY THE RENEWING OF YOUR MIND...

ROMANS 12:2 NIV
Verses from different parts of the bible often go really well together, like these: First: ‘…Be transformed by the renewing of your mind…’. Second: ‘…Though our bodies are dying, our spirits are being renewed every day’ (2 Corinthians 4:16 NLT). Your mind is a bit like a computer; it responds to what’s programmed into it. Having a spiritual mindset is like having top-notch Anti-Virus software installed. And you need to do the update ‘day by day’. Someone who has an earthly mind is wide open to all sorts of damaging influences. And some people are in between; frustrated because one moment they’re talking out of a spiritual mindset, the next they’re talking out of an earthly one. They haven’t learned to let the Holy Spirit do His work ‘day by day’. It’s important that you understand this because: 1) A spiritual mindset gives you God’s input. What an advantage! God can reveal to you why people act the way they do, He can help you sense trouble coming before it arrives. He can tell you when to speak up and when to chill out, when to get involved and when to walk away. Through His Holy Spirit in your life God will help you in every situation. 2) A spiritual mindset gives you victory where you’ve known only defeat. This is especially important for those who struggle with addictive behaviours and are likely to be ‘easily led’. The earthly mindset has proven it can’t cope with the temptations of the world. Without God’s Spirit we’ll go back to the chaos we came from. That’s why we need to allow Him day by day to flood our lives especially; that big grey lump between our ears!

content.title: Simple faith
content.introtext:
…YOU MUST BE BORN AGAIN.

JOHN 3:7 TLB
When Jesus started talking to Nic, about being ‘born again’, Nic didn’t get it: ‘What do you mean?...How can an old man go back into his mother’s womb…’ (John 3:4 NLT). Sometimes being clever doesn’t help! Jesus told Nicodemus, ‘…you can hear the wind but can’t tell where it comes from or where it is going, so you can’t explain how people are born of the Spirit’ (John 3:8 NLT). In other words, ‘You didn’t have a clue what was going on at your first birth, so why do you expect your second one to be any different?’ Some people have tried to turn Christianity into a pre-packed product. Do this, don’t do this. Believe this, don’t read this, don’t read that. But how did Paul describe it to the churches he planted? Listen, ‘the mystery that has been kept hidden for ages and generations, but is now disclosed to the saints’ (Colossians 1:26 NIV). Who does he mean when he says ‘saints’? Us! You and me – anyone who will simply believe. And what’s this mystery he’s talking about? ‘…God has chosen to make known… the glorious riches of this mystery, which is Christ in you, the hope of glory’ (Colossians 1:27 NIV). You could spend your whole life thinking about that and never get to the bottom of it; it’s just too deep! The things of God cannot be explained, only revealed. Jesus said unless we become as little children, we won’t even be aware of His kingdom. Our biggest struggles come from wanting a reason for everything. All God asks is that we trust Him. When we do, life works the way it’s supposed to.

content.title: Living with loose ends
content.introtext:
TRUST IN THE LORD WITH ALL YOUR HEART; DO NOT DEPEND ON YOUR OWN UNDERSTANDING.

PROVERBS 3:5 NLT
Are you obsessed with trying to figure out things that should be left in God’s hands? When you’ve been working through some questions but have come to the point of deciding that you are going to do, stop fretting and just trust God. And don’t get stressed again a week later because you don’t like the way He’s handling it! Are you expecting God to just wave a magic wand over your life so that everything suddenly becomes all neat and tidy? Maybe as He takes you through the process of sorting out the mess you’ll discover valuable things hidden and forgotten. Paul says, ‘Do not be anxious about anything…’ (Philippians 4:6 NIV). That’s hard to swallow if you’re a bit insecure, or you like to organize things; to find a place to put them so they make sense and feel ‘taken care of’. But how do you file unanswered questions? They annoy you like a crackly earpiece in your headphones or a scratch on your favourite CD! But when you have a crackle or a scratch in your faith, you can’t just go down the shops and get a replacement. Instead you have to talk to God about it and ask Him what He’s gonna do about it. You might find out that the things you think are high priority may not be anywhere near the top of God’s list for your life. So learn to live with loose ends and trust God! If you want growth, you’ve got to be at peace with the messiness and mistakes that accompany it. If you’re one of those people who needs to put everything into a neat little box, this Scripture is especially for you: ‘Trust in the Lord with all your heart; do not depend on your own understanding.’

content.title: Issues with people?
content.introtext:
CONSIDER HIM WHO HAS ENDURED SUCH HOSTILITY...

HEBREWS 12:3 NAS
Today we’re going to think about the best way to handle ‘issues’ with people! Firstly, make sure the issue you’re dealing with is worth your time and energy. Often it isn’t. Ask yourself, ‘Have I got myself worked up by something petty?’ Remember: It’s always easier to be critical than creative, so don’t get involved unless you’re willing to help. Secondly, if you are sure that you do need to get involved in an issue, remember that your aim is to find God‘s perfect way together. Watch out that you don’t destroy the other person’s self-confidence. Stay away from statements like ‘you always’ or ‘you never’. Assure them that you see loads of potential in them and be really practical about how they can do things better next time… that’s what God does with you! Finally deal with people as unique individuals; it’s a bad idea to start down the track of ‘suchabody is really good at this’. Comparisons always cause resentment. Why make the problem bigger? If you do feel like it’s all going Pete Tong and the conversation becomes a confrontation you probably need to call Time-out before you end up in a major no-win situation. Your goal should be to leave them with three things: 1) A clearer understanding of the issue. 2) The complete assurance of your love and support. 3) Encouragement and confidence that with God’s help they can turn things around. Are these three things easy to do? No. But with plenty of faith, grace and Holy Spirit wisdom, you can do it! Living the Jesus life means getting involved in people’s mess so that His amazing transforming power can be displayed again and again. It’s the only kind of life worth living!

content.title: Learning from The Lost Son
content.introtext:
FATHER, I HAVE SINNED...

LUKE 15.18 NLT
The Lost Son didn’t get into trouble until he left home and started to live his life by just doing whatever felt good at the time. There are three really important keys in the story Jesus told about him. Vs 13) ‘…he wasted all his money…’ This story is 2000 years old but it’s so relevant it could’ve been on the news last night. Every weekend young people follow this guy’s example of ‘getting wasted’; and the first place it hits you is in the pocket! Vs14) He ‘…began to starve.’ Something’s gone majorly wrong! The situation changed really quickly, one minute he was loving it, living large, life and soul of the party. But eventually the music stops. The music always stops sooner or later. It’s then that you start to realise the emptiness inside. Are you doing that? David said, ‘The Lord is my shepherd; I have everything I need’ (Psalm 23:1 NCV). Who’s that promise for? For all those who have decided to follow the shepherd and stay as close to him as possible. Vs 17) ‘…he finally came to his senses…’ When his life could go no lower, he had a moment of clarity. God has an amazing way of bringing those moments to us. He is desperate for us to be in relationship with him. He calls out ‘My daughter, My son, I love you, come home!’ The Bible says: ‘…Today, if you hear his voice, do not harden your hearts…’ (Hebrews 3:15 NIV). It wasn’t too late for the guy in the story; and it’s not too late for you. When he came home his father opened his arms, welcomed him home and threw a massive party. And God will do the same for you, if you let him.

content.title: Kodak Christians
content.introtext:
…YOU WILL RECEIVE POWER AND YOU WILL TELL PEOPLE ABOUT ME EVERYWHERE...

ACTS 1:8 NLT
It’s possible to be so concerned with what happened in the past, or so caught up in what’s happening in the present – that we pay no attention to what God has for us next. Look at the early church in the weeks and months after Pentecost: Jerusalem was an exciting place to be: ‘All the believers met together constantly and shared everything with each other, selling their possessions and dividing with those in need. They worshipped together regularly…met in small groups in homes for [Communion], and shared their meals with great joy…The whole city was favourable to them’ (Acts 2:44-47 TLB). Can you see the problem here? It’s too cosy! Who would want to leave Jerusalem to carry the message to the rest of the world? So how did God get them out of their comfort zone to fulfil His purposes? Well in this instance the answer was persecution which basically means severe agro, prejudice and bullying! No wonder it’s an idea we don’t like because we tend to be Kodak Christians. CONFUSED? Well, there was this Kodak Camera advert which had a famous catchphrase: ‘Freeze the moment!’ The problem is – no matter how much we want to be a Kodak Christian and just enjoy one long summer festival buzz all the way to heaven, that’s not the kind of life God promises. But check this out: even through the painful persecution; ‘Those who had been scattered preached the word wherever they went’ (see Acts 8:4 NIV). Here’s a thought: God could be permitting the tough time you’re going through to: a) dig you out of the past or b) make sure you don’t get stuck in a moment you can’t get out of. Bottom line: God’s always on the move – so don’t get left behind.

content.title: Jigsaw pieces
content.introtext:
“IF EACH PART OF THE BODY WERE THE SAME PART, THERE WOULD BE NO BODY…”

I CORINTHIANS 12:18 NCV
Everybody needs to find their part in God’s big story. So here’s three things you need to know: 1) Every Christian has a ministry but less than 10% of Christians have bothered to find out what it is! They go to church ‘for what they can get out of it.’ Giving your time and talents to God isn’t optional. We must all get our boots on and get stuck in; Christianity is not a spectator sport! 2) Every ministry is important. Listen: ‘…God has arranged the parts in the body, every one of them, just as He wanted them to be…The eye cannot say to the hand, “I don’t need you!”’ (1 Corinthians 12:18-21 NIV). 3) We all depend on each other. No single ministry can has everything stitched up. Like a jigsaw, each piece is needed to complete the picture. Or think about it this way: When one part of a car malfunctions, the other parts don’t work as well. It’s the same in our Christian life. The modern lie of individualism must be replaced with the eternal truth that we need each other, that we’ve been called to work together. That doesn’t mean you should try to be like somebody else; be who God made you to be and do what He wants you to do. And one last thing – doing something is better than doing nothing! You might not find a perfect fit for your gifts straight away. You might feel like a square peg in a round hole. If so, just do your best for a season, give it six months then try something else. Let’s face it, if you never try, you’ll never know.

content.title: Bricks in the wall
content.introtext:
“DOOM TO HIM WHO BUILDS PALACES BUT BULLIES PEOPLE…”

JEREMIAH 22:13 TM
When Hurricane Katrina hit the USA almost a year ago it was a catastrophe on a scale we could hardly imagine. What made everything worse was the fact that the city’s flood defences had not been properly invested in. The result? The walls broke and New Orleans went under. In our lives we can build flood defences. We build one brick at a time. Each brick has one word imprinted on it: INTEGRITY; the way we take care of the little things. But a lot of us don’t bother building at all. We think we can do whatever we want when it comes to small things; we believe so long as we don’t have any major lapses we’re doing well. But that’s not the way it works. A little white lie is still a lie. Theft is still theft, whether it’s your sister’s CD or an old lady’s handbag. The truth is, if you can’t be trusted at all points you probably can’t be trusted at any point. Each time you do something shifty or shady you create a crack in the wall of your character. And when times get tough it becomes harder to act with integrity – not easier. When you’re under pressure everything you’ve done in the past, and the things you’ve neglected to do, come to a head. One Christian leader writes, ‘Integrity commits itself to character over personal gain, people over things, service over power, discipline over impulse, commitment over convenience, and the long view over the immediate.’ Which is just a fancy way of saying ‘integrity is the bricks in the wall, not the icing on the cake.’

content.title: Be determined
content.introtext:
…WE MUST BE DETERMINED TO RUN THE RACE THAT IS AHEAD OF US

HEBREWS 12:1 NIV
Moving forward in your Christian life means being sensitive to His voice. God’s voice isn’t like a hammer pounding on your head; it’s more like a little prod in your heart. When you know you’ve heard from God, be determined not to let it go. Things worth having never come easy. If you find your grip on that promise weakening, remind yourself that God has given you the grace to succeed at whatever He’s called you to do! The worst thing you can do is ignore His prods, disobey them, argue with them or even try to put them off until tomorrow. The word ‘determined’ can be a real turn-off for some people. It’s a ‘hard work’ word. It doesn’t sit well alongside ‘comfy’ and ‘easy’. You can’t claim any ownership of the word ‘determined’ if you can’t turn off your television and spend a few minutes with God every day. Starting out by obeying God in little things, not big ones, is the key to developing a determined attitude and lifestyle. For example, when He prods you to shut your mouth but you keep on talking – that’s when you get into trouble, right? Check this out; long long ago God made a promise to Israel: ‘If you listen to these commands of the LORD your God and carefully obey them the LORD will make you the head and not the tail , and you will always have the upper hand’ (Deuteronomy 28:13 NLT). You can claim that promise for yourself today if you will put your faith in Him and be determined about doing what He says.

content.title: Don’t let the mud stick
content.introtext:
NONE OF THIS FAZES US BECAUSE JESUS LOVES US

ROMANS 8:37 TM
Have you heard the story of the grumpy old farmer whose donkey fell into a well? Since there was no way to get him out the farmer decided to bury him there. Poor donkey! When the shovels of dirt began landing on him he started freaking out. Then this thought struck him; ‘Just shake it off and step on it.’ So he did. Hour after hour as the dirt fell on him he kept telling himself, ‘Just shake it off and step on it.’ No matter how much dirt the farmer threw on him, he just kept shaking it off and stepping on it – until finally and triumphantly he stepped out of the well! Life can easily bury you – if you don’t have the right attitude. When they throw mud at you, and they will, just shake it off and step on it. No one can make you feel inferior if you don’t let them. What’s important is not what other people say about you – it’s what you say to yourself after they get through talking! Jesus said, ‘….count yourselves blessed every time people put you down or throw you out or speak lies about you to discredit me. What it means is that the truth is too close for comfort and they are uncomfortable’ (Matthew 5:11 TM). So expect a bit of mudslinging; but don’t let it stick. You’ve decided to move ahead in life and you‘re leaving others behind; some of them aren’t too happy about it. The only way to avoid trouble is to do nothing and stay where you are. And that’s just not acceptable for a child of God – is it?

content.title: The Judges
content.introtext:
…“THE LORD KNOWS THOSE THAT BELONG TO HIM”…

2 TIMOTHY 2:19 NCV
Just as your beliefs can move you forward, ‘The Judges’ in your head can hold you back. ‘The Judges?’ Yeah, you know, like Pop Idol, The Judges are those annoying, criticizing voices in your head telling you you’re not good enough, not talented enough.
