Today God is challenging you to stop performing for these Judges in your imagination. Don’t let them control you or decide your future. Refuse to allow any word to find a home in you if it contradicts what God says about you. You can’t continually speak failure over your future and then expect good things to happen. Paul says, ‘…He chose us before the world was made…’ (Ephesians1 1:4 NCV). If nobody seems to value you or show you love in any way, this verse still explodes any kind of rejection by letting you know that God chose you! You weren’t just some wonky brick in the pile and God said, ‘Oh, alright, let’s go ahead and add it to the building.’ No, you came pre-cut to fit a particular slot that nobody else can fill. Stop trying to be like other people! If you give up being who you are in order to become like them, you’ll end up being somebody God doesn’t need one more of. Listen: ‘…The Lord knows those that belong to him…’ (2 Timothy 2:19 NCV). The prophet Samuel may have wanted to pick one of Jesse’s other sons to be king, but he couldn’t because God had already chosen David. So stop listening to those Judges. Nobody else can be you and nobody can take what God has reserved for you!

content.title: Suddenly
content.introtext:
“…I AM ABOUT TO DO A BRAND-NEW THING…”

ISAIAH 43:19 NLT
God says He wants to ‘…do a brand-new thing…’ That means that the ‘old’ stuff in your life will need to move out of the way for it. If you haven’t noticed it yet, God first works IN US then works THROUGH US. For amazing new things to start happening in our schools and colleges, and towns and cities, new things have to happen deep in our lives. Sometimes these ‘new things’ happen in amazing mountain-top moments. Sometimes they only come as we are brought through the valley. OK – let’s take a really good look at this verse then: ‘…I am about to do a brand-new thing. See, I have already begun! Do you not see it?...’ From your perspective it may feel like you’ve been waiting for ever. That’s because so often don’t see that God has already started something – behind our backs! To make the most of all the awesome things God plans to do in us and through us we’ve got to be sensitive to his voice, alert to his movements and live in expectation. After praying and waiting in their prayer room for ten long days we read, ‘Suddenly, there came a sound from heaven…’ (Acts 2:2), and the Holy Spirit touched the crowd of frightened disciples and gave them power that would change the world. When God miraculously brought Paul and Silas out of prison we read, ‘…suddenly there was a great earthquake…and immediately all the doors were opened…’ (Acts 16:26 KJV). God may be getting ready to open some doors for you – make sure you’re ready; because it could happen suddenly!

content.title: Where’s your satisfaction?
content.introtext:
“HE GIVES POWER TO THOSE WHO ARE TIRED AND WORN OUT…”

ISAIAH 40:29 NLT
We can start to self-destruct if we don’t know how to take care of ourselves spiritually. Samson is a prime example. He was a fighter with amazing strength and courage but his personal life was a mess. His weakness was for women. He couldn’t handle the loneliness that so often follows great victories. In his story we find no evidence of a life of prayer or worship; only the numbness and inner void of a violent man. In contrast King David, who was also a fighter, loved to be in God’s presence. But David also went through a time in his life when he fell out of step with God and let human passions take over. Are you in danger of that happening to you? There’s all sorts of stuff that can divert your attention away from God. A hot girl or guy giving you the eye. A bad habit that’s becoming an addiction. An important project that’s becoming an obsession. Watch out! What delights you tonight might destroy you tomorrow. Get real about your life today. Don’t build your life on sand; build it on rock (see Matthew 7:26). Why would anyone look for satisfaction anywhere else but God anyway? ‘He gives power to those who are tired and worn out; he offers strength to the weak. Even youths will become exhausted, and young men will give up. But those who wait on the LORD will find new strength. They will fly high on wings like eagles. They will run and not grow weary. They will walk and not faint’ (Isaiah 40:29-31 NLT).

content.title: Dealing with our guilt
content.introtext:
“…IT’S TIME TO CHANGE YOUR WAYS! TURN TO FACE GOD SO HE CAN WIPE AWAY YOUR SINS…”

ACTS 3:19 TM
It could be by thought, word or action, but, we all sin more than we care to admit. And there are three ways of dealing with it and only one of them is right! 1) Brush it off. Don’t think about it; don’t ask if there is mopping up to do. Bury yesterday in all sorts of distracting experiences. Just keep on running. Maybe the past won’t have time to catch up with you. 2) Accept the burden and get used to it. This means living with an increasing weight of guilt, recognizing that life will get slower and slower as the burden gets heavier and heavier. That’s a recipe for depression. 3) Deal with it. A lot of us spend our lives feeling bad about our habits and hang-ups; but we never do anything about them! We need to learn about ‘repentance’; deciding to ‘change your ways’. Jesus told a story about a lad who left home with a load of his dad’s money and made a total mess of his life. When he reached his lowest point, he finally admitted that he was lost: ‘How many of my father’s hired men have food to spare, and here I am starving to death! I will…go back to my father and say to him: ‘Father, I have sinned against heaven and against you’ (Luke 15:17-18 NIV). He was scared that his dad wouldn’t accept him back as a son but instead his father opened his heart and his arms and welcomed him back home. And God will do that for you too, if you’ll just be brave enough to repent.

content.title: Shelter
content.introtext:
THOSE WHO LIVE IN THE SHELTER OF THE MOST HIGH WILL FIND REST IN THE SHADOW OF THE ALMIGHTY.

PSALM 91:1 NLT
So there you are, out and about in your coolest T-shirt and suddenly you feel it – splat! – a raindrop dribbles down the back of your neck sending a shiver down your spine. You were having such a great time with your mates but now the rain intends to spoil your fun. Let’s face it, we are complete wussies in this country when it comes to the weather. People in other parts of the world have to deal with monsoons and tornados! Listen: ‘Those who live in the shelter of the Most High will find rest in the shadow of the Almighty. This I declare of the LORD: “He alone is my refuge, my place of safety; He is my God, and I am trusting him.”’ (Psalm 91:1-2 NLT) This Psalm is saying that in the storms of life – not rain and sleet and snow – but storms of family problems, health issues and all that stuff, God wants to offer us shelter. There are two ways to go through a storm: in panic or in peace. When a storm suddenly threatened their boat the disciples screamed, ‘…don’t you care if we drown?’ (Mark 4:38 NIV). And where was Jesus? Chilling out on a cushion in the back of the boat! That’s because He understood: a) to get to where God wants to take you, you have to go through storms b) when you’re on God’s business He will get you through c) when it’s over you come out knowing God better, with a story that will inspire and encourage other people.

content.title: Leader = Listener
content.introtext:
…BE QUICK TO LISTEN, SLOW TO SPEAK.

JAMES 1:19 NIV
Want to become a good leader? Become a good listener! Here are two stories of what happens when leaders don’t take time to listen. The first is from a young woman hurt by a manager who constantly cut her off: ‘I expected he would wait and give me answers to serious questions about my work. Many times he walked off when I was in mid-sentence, having heard nothing.’ The next is from a church youth leader who was fired: ‘After serving God there for two years, I was called into an elders’ meeting. They took out a list of all the things I’d done wrong in the past two years. Most of what they said was true, after all, I was brand new in this work. Then they called for my resignation. But not once did one of them care enough to coach or shepherd me. I’d no idea or warning that I was doing anything wrong. Why is it so hard for leaders to listen? Because leaders love to talk, they have been blessed with vision and wisdom, but as they gain more authority they think they have less reason to listen. Leaders can easily fail to lead by example when they become removed from the frontlines where the action is. To keep their edge they must constantly listen to those who are out there in the real world and rely on that information to make wise decisions. When James advised that we should ‘be quick to listen, slow to speak’ he was speaking to everyone; but it is especially relevant for people who want to become leaders. Two ears, one tongue; it makes sense really doesn’t it!

content.title: Big up your relationships
content.introtext:
“…YOU HAVE A SPECIAL PLACE IN MY HEART…”

PHILIPPIANS 1:7-8 CEV
Think back to your best moments: your highest highs, your greatest achievements, your biggest obstacles overcome. How many happened to you alone? Not many, right? When you understand that being connected to other people is one of life’s greatest pleasures, you realize that life’s best comes when we invest in solid relationships. Of the people you know, who seems to enjoy life more – the negative, suspicious and anti-social? No way! The Scrooges of life don’t enjoy much of anything. Jesus summed life up like this: ‘Love the Lord…with all your heart…Love your neighbour as yourself’ (Matthew 22:37-39 NIV). On the other hand, people who love God and love people, live with a smile on their face. If you love God and people you’ll find friends wherever you go. And you’ll get further in life too! There’s no substitute for a positive friendly attitude when it comes to getting on in life. People who alienate themselves have a hard time. Here’s why: a) if people feel like you’re ignoring them, they’ll ignore you back b) if no relationship exists they’re less likely to help you out c) if they think you’re selfish they’ll hope you don’t succeed. So, if you want to get on in life, start investing in solid relationships. Make it your goal to build friendships like the Apostle Paul did, people about whom he could say ‘…you have a very special place in my heart…I love you…with the tender compassion of Christ Jesus’ (Philippians 1:7-8 NLT).

content.title: Learn to pace yourself!
content.introtext:
“…BE DETERMINED TO RUN THE RACE THAT IS AHEAD…”

HEBREWS 12:1 CEV
No British sports fan will forget the shock story of the 2004 Olympics in Athens – Paula Radcliffe was a dead cert to bring home a medal from the marathon. Suddenly, having reached 23 out of 26 miles her body just seemed to give up on her. You could see the distressed look on her face as she struggled to come to terms with the fact that she couldn’t go on. She wouldn’t even be able to finish the race, never mind winning a medal. The blazing heat and humidity combined with a course that involved several steep hills just got the better of her. The lesson for us all is – it doesn’t matter how spiritually fit or experienced we think we are, the harsh conditions of life can have a deadly effect on us. When the heat is on we can’t crash on as if it’s business as usual. We must learn to pace ourselves so that we reach the finish line and don’t end up left by the roadside. You don’t want to ruin great opportunities, because you underestimated what it would take to get you to your destination. Don’t get so spiritual that you overlook the simple things that God has established for us to live healthy lives – the basics like food, sleep, and exercise. Some of us take better care of our dogs and cats than we do of ourselves. Too often we don’t see the link between sleep and exercise and the quality of our relationship with God. How can you pray when you’re tired? How can you worship when you’re ratty? If you want to reach your destiny, you must pay attention to your running conditions and learn to pace yourself.

content.title: Higher or lower?
content.introtext:
“…FROM THE ONE WHO HAS BEEN ENTRUSTED WITH MUCH, MUCH MORE WILL BE ASKED.”

LUKE 12:48 NIV
Christians can be some of the most annoying people on earth! How often do we show our faith by criticizing the people around us, rather than loving them and looking for a chance to say something encouraging. We can ruin our testimony when we give people the impression that we are happy to talk about Jesus but we don’t seem to act like Jesus. The next step from here is to alienate ourselves as an ‘elite group’ looking down on other people who we see as ‘less than’ us. Not Jesus! He rubbed shoulders with everybody. He was amazing at reaching out to those who religious society looked down upon; the prostitutes, the tax collectors, the lepers. We like to put people into two boxes: the ones we like and the ones we don’t. Jesus said, ‘From the one who has been entrusted with much, much more will be asked.’ Hey, just because you’ve been called to a higher standard it doesn’t mean you are suddenly ‘better’ than everyone else. It means you will be expected to show greater wisdom, humility, and grace in the midst of all sorts of hassles and tension. If your family and friends aren’t part of a Christian community, the only chance they have of seeing the fruit of the Holy Spirit in operation, is in your life. By responding with patience, love and grace you’ll make a lasting impact on them – one that could lift them up into the arms of the Jesus you claim to serve.

content.title: Contamination
content.introtext:
BE PREPARED...

EPHESIANS 6:13 TM
The pollution in our environment is not just to do with acid rain, exhaust fumes and industrial waste. There’s also a kind of pollution which can invade our attitudes, thoughts and behaviour. You can find a list of this bad stuff in Colossians 3:5-9. But God has given us protective clothing so that we won’t get contaminated. Listen: ‘…clothe yourselves with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness and patience. Bear with each other and forgive whatever grievances you may have against oneanother…And over all these virtues put on love…’ (Colossians 3:12-14 NIV). Learn how to get dressed in these holy clothes every day. Maybe you’d like to pray the following prayer to get you started: ‘Father, thank you for all the blessings in my life. As I get ready for today, protect me, strengthen me, use me to bless the people around me. Let me see the world through Your eyes. May Your Word and Your presence overflow from my life, neutralizing all the pollution of pride, insensitivity, anger and failure. My hope is in You, not anything in this world, so I step out in the knowledge that you see all I do, and that my life will make a difference. Amen’ Ships sail on water, but if the water starts getting in, even a battleship will sink. So today, go forward through the murky waters of life without allowing them to get into your hull. God’s destiny for you is that you would go the distance and get safely to your final destination.

content.title: Good communication
content.introtext:
I APPEAL TO YOU…THAT YOU MAY BE PERFECTLY UNITED IN MIND AND THOUGHT.

1 CORINTHIANS 1:10 NIV
A bloke walking down a street one day noticed a woman struggling with a washing machine in the doorway of a house. When he volunteered to help, the struggling woman was overjoyed. After several minutes of struggling but getting nowhere the man said to the woman, ‘We’ll never get this washing machine in there.’ To which the woman replied in amazement, ‘In? I’m trying to get it out!’ Cooperation is impossible without good communication. And that principle holds whether it’s with your family, your friends or your church. Never assume that anybody ‘knows’ anything! The truth is, some people are afraid to admit that they don’t know stuff because they feel embarrassed. Others need more time and personal attention before they ‘get it.’ If you have a reputation for being a fast-mover with a short fuse, people won’t feel comfortable asking for your help. So, if everything’s going Pete Tong the problem could be your inability to communicate clearly, rather than their inability to do listen properly. Without clear communication two things happen: 1) People get discouraged and depressed, like one person who complained, ‘I feel like I’m part of a mushroom farm; left completely in the dark and fed manure from time to time! 2) People make up their own rules, and chaos results. So, if there’s strife and confusion around you, rather than harmony and understanding, go back and read Paul’s thoughts on good communication: ‘I appeal to you…that you may be perfectly united in mind and thought.’

content.title: Ca$h Attitude
content.introtext:
…FOOLS SPEND WHATEVER THEY GET.

PROVERBS 21:20 NLT
The Bible says loads about cash; there are promises of being blessed and warnings about being greedy. It’s clear that God wants us to have the right attitude to money. Listen to this: ‘…Fools spend whatever they get.’ So how does God want us to live? Here’s three Ca$h Attitudes: 1) ‘I’m okay, I’m making ends meet.’ That’s like saying you feel great doing the splits, which for 99.9% of people is extremely painful – if not impossible! God says, ‘Pay all your debts…’ (Romans 13:8 NLT), because when you’re in it up to your neck one little wave can spell disaster 2) ‘I plan to work till I drop.’ What’ll happen if you can’t work? What if you ‘drop’ sooner than you expect? Trusting in your ability to earn a living is just a form of arrogance. Do you think God will be impressed if you start clocking up 60 hours a week at the cost of your relationship with Him? 3) ‘I earned it so I’ll spend it!’ God’s generosity is one of His most amazing qualities. So how can we claim to belong to Him if there is no evidence of generosity in our life? If money is getting a hold of your heart there’s one really easy way to break its grip – give it away! The Bible says: ‘…God loves people who love to give’ (2 Corinthians 9:7 CEV) and ‘Give, and it will be given to you. A good measure, pressed down, shaken together and running over…’ (Luke 6:38 NIV). That’s the kind of Ca$h Attitude to have!

content.title: Stay in touch (2)
content.introtext:
PRAY ALL THE TIME.

1 THESSALONIANS 5:17 TM
OK - so today we’ll cover some practical stuff to help you with your daily rhythm of prayer: 1) Start your day right. When you first wake up and you’re enjoying your duvet more than you’re looking forward to the world outside, pray! ‘God, thanks for a new day, help me make the most of it – let it be a day of destiny!’ Then instead of clicking on the TV or radio, open your Bible, read a Psalm or something from the life of Jesus. Let the words inspire you and challenge you. 2) Tune in to visual clues. Use your daily routine as a trigger for prayer. For example, when you’re showering, pray, ‘Jesus, give me a clean heart and a right attitude’ (Paraphrase, see Psalm 51:10). Whenever you meet somebody, silently ask God to bless them. When your school or college friends are being idiots pray, ‘Lord, give me grace, help me be a light where it’s dark.’ That’s how you ‘pray all the time.’ 3) Invent ways to stay focused. Ever notice how your mind wanders the minute you start praying? Try using a note pad while you pray, just jot down the things that are distracting you under the headline ‘I’ll get to that later’ then talk to God with an uncluttered mind. And remember, God wants to talk to you too, so be alert and listen. What He tells you will be more important than anything else you’ll hear that day. With a bit of rhythm, creativity and determination you can ‘pray all the time.’ But first you have to want to. Do you?

content.title: Stay in touch (1)
content.introtext:
PRAY ALL THE TIME.

1 THESSALONIANS 5:17 TM
Paul says, ‘Pray all the time.’ Why? Because whether you’re exercising, chilling out, shopping, or sitting at an exam desk, God loves to hear from you; He really does. Author Cheri Fuller writes: ‘I used to think if I didn’t pray at a certain time each day, my prayers didn’t count. Then I discovered that Paul’s command to ‘Pray all the time,’ means more than just spending a lot of time on your knees; it means having constant communication with God, and an increasing awareness of His presence. This didn’t really sink in until my son left for college. Busy with his studies, he didn’t call home often. But when he did I’d drop everything just to hear his voice! Now I realize that God feels the same way about me, only 100 times more! I also noticed throughout the Bible God used short prayers to accomplish great things – like raising the dead and parting the Red Sea. Then it dawned on me that thoughts such as, ‘If I can’t pray for an hour, why bother?’ are foolish. It’s wonderful to have longer prayer sessions when I can, but knowing short prayers have a big impact, encourages me to pray throughout the day.’ Everyone has their own rhythm of prayer. Some people pray really well early in the morning. Some find it more exciting late at night. Some pray like Daniel, three times a day. Pay attention to your pattern of prayer today. How is the quality? How is the quantity? Are you really opening up or just going through the motions? God loves to hear your voice, so stay in touch today.

content.title: Visual-eyes
content.introtext:
“…IF YOU OPEN YOUR EYES WIDE IN WONDER AND BELIEF, YOUR BODY FILLS UP WITH LIGHT.”

MATTHEW 6:22 TM
You’re at the cinema watching the latest blockbuster… there’s a moment when everything goes quiet then ‘AAAAAGGHH!’ the bad guy suddenly appears on the screen and you jump right out of your seat! Why? Because your eyes are wired right into the core of your brain and you have built-in reactions which you have very little control over. Jesus said ‘Your eyes are windows into your body. If you open your eyes wide in wonder and belief, your body fills up with light.’ (Matthew 6:22 TM) We live in a hugely visual culture. It seems that everywhere you look these days there is a new advertising display unit or TV screen. You only have to walk into a newsagent and scan the shelves briefly to see that the magazine publishers will do all they can to appeal to the most basic human impulses. You see, pictures work like a springboard to a new level of thought. Do you have a treasured photo album? Why is it so important to you? It's because of the memories and emotions those images trigger. But the even more amazing thing about the brain God’s given us is - we can 'see' even with our eyes closed - our mind can create mental movies! Christian monks do this quite a lot in their prayers, they call it ‘visualisation’. It’s about forming an image that inspires your mind – an ocean of God’s love – His promises as firm as a mountain. The Apostle Paul told his mates, ‘…Think about things that are pure and lovely and admirable. Think about things that are excellent and worthy of praise’ (Philippians 4:8 NLT). What will you visualise today?

content.title: Deal with your fears!
content.introtext:
SAY TO THOSE WHO ARE FEARFUL-HEARTED, “BE STRONG…”

ISAIAH 35:4 NKJV
An old man was asked what had stolen most of his life’s joy. He replied, ‘Things that never happened!’ Sad isn’t it. You see, our fears are the worst liars in the world; we should never make decisions based on them. Instead we should: 1) Tackle them head-on. King David did: ‘When I am afraid, I put my trust in you’ (Psalm 56:3 NLT). Bill Hybels is pastor of one of the world’s biggest churches. As a kid he was very timid, but his dad kept challenging him. Bill says, ‘He’d take me down to our produce company and bark out, “Billy, reverse that lorry!” …I’d drag myself into the cab of that 40-foot artic, shaking with fear. Sometimes it would take me 45 minutes and the lorry would be half jackknifed…but when I crawled out, dad would say, “Good job.” And next time…it would be easier.’ How do you conquer your fear? By confronting it! 2) Hang out with brave people. Solomon said, ‘He who walks with the wise grows wise…’ (Proverbs 13:20 NIV). Success rubs off; so does failure! Don’t hang out with people who habitually cave in or play it safe. Hang out with brave people. If you can’t find any, read up on Bible characters like Daniel, Deborah, Esther and Peter 3) Go for it. Dealing with fear isn’t optional, it’s foundational. You need it to live each day for Jesus, to build better relationships, to reach the lost, and care for the broken. Today God says to those who are fearful: ‘Be strong.’ But you can’t sit back and expect Him to do all the work; you’ve got to deal with your fears!

content.title: Prayer snares
content.introtext:
…GOD WILL HEAR OUR PRAYERS WHEN WE ASK FOR WHAT PLEASES HIM

I JOHN 5.14. CEV
Reality check today: are your prayers ever self-centred? Is there a possibility that your prayer is going off at a tangent from God’s destiny for you? ‘…God will hear our prayers when we ask for what pleases Him.’ God isn’t some kind of genie that comes out of a bottle to grant your every wish. Too many prayers are about our human wishes not God’s holy plans. Three examples: 1) The trivial. We pray for good weather for our day out when maybe it hasn’t rained for ages and the farmer down the road needs water! If you remember when you pray that your life is part of God’s bigger picture, then your prayers will become stepping stones to wisdom and maturity. 2) The selfish. Listen: ‘…your prayers are not answered, because you pray…for selfish reasons’ (James 4:3 CEV). One young woman at a prayer group said, ‘My boyfriend’s army unit just got called to the Middle East. Please pray he won’t have to go.’ It’s easy to understand her worries, but her request is a bit selfish. He’s a soldier who has signed up for a very dangerous job. Our lives often include risk and hardship, so God promises peace and protection, not immunity and comfort. 3) The controlling. Jesus said, ‘Don’t bargain with God. Be direct. Ask for what you need…’ (Luke 11:10 TM). Why ask God to make the people in your life conform to your wishes, when He doesn’t even force them to conform to His? Jesus taught us to pray ‘…your will be done…’ God always answers when we ask ‘for what pleases him’.

content.title: Self inflicted stress.
content.introtext:
…INSTEAD OF WORRYING, PRAY...

PHILIPPIANS 4:6 TM
Striving to do better is a good thing, but perfectionism isn’t. A mother of three children complained to her doctor, ‘I just can’t get the house cleaned the way I like it before everyone leaves in the morning.’ She was so stressed out, he put her on antidepressants. But why? Nobody was holding a gun to her head saying, ‘Every dish must be put away and every towel folded – or else!’ Life had become one big ‘to-do list’ and she could never get to the bottom of it. Yet no one but herself had created the stress she was experiencing – and passing on to her family! Answer these questions: 1) Have my ambitions become so all consuming that I’ve forgotten how to just chill and be happy? 2) Have I made ‘having everything under control’ a condition for my happiness? 3) Do I beat myself (or other people) up when I can’t meet my own stupidly unrealistic expectations? The first step toward recovering your peace is to make sure that none of the stress in your life is self-inflicted. The second is realizing that life will not pay any attention to your fancy plans anyway. So don’t risk losing your friends or making yourself ill. Whether it’s obsessing over your looks, or your performance at school or college, the roots of perfectionism grow in the soil of insecurity. Don’t listen to any voice that whispers, ‘You’ll never measure up!’ That’s a lie; don’t believe it. You are loved, approved and accepted – by God! Your worth comes from Him, and His opinion of you never changes!

content.title: Standing in the gap
content.introtext:
“…I SEARCHED FOR SOMEONE TO STAND IN THE GAP…BUT I FOUND NO ONE.”

EZEKIEL 22:30 NLT
When Chris Milbrath went to work with Co-Mission in the Ukraine, the last thing he envisioned was being hospitalized. He had a constant hardcore stomach-ache. His doctor diagnosed a ruptured appendix and told him that without surgery he’d die. Things didn’t go well and infection set in. Then halfway across the world a lady who was one of Chris’s prayer supporters woke suddenly during the night. She didn’t know why, but she knew she had to pray for him. Within 24 hours a missions group in Moscow heard about the situation. A small jet ‘just happened to be available’ to airlift Chris to Geneva where one of Switzerland’s best surgeons ‘just happened to be available’ to perform additional surgery that saved his life. Later, comparing notes and making adjustments for the different time zones, they discovered that her prayer-burden ‘just happened to coincide’ with the time he was clinging to life. Chris said, ‘I can’t help wondering what would’ve happened to me if that woman had just rolled over and said, “I’ll pray for Chris tomorrow.’’ God says, ‘“I searched for someone to stand in the gap…but I found no one.”’ Prayer can be a lonely business with very anti-social hours! Prayer warriors realize what’s at stake and stay on their knees until they sense they’ve broken through and God’s heard them. James writes, ‘…When a believing person prays, great things happen’ (James 5:16 NCV). So when God prompts you to pray for somebody, don’t wait – do it! Your prayers may be the only thing standing between that person and catastrophe.

content.title: Be an Amy for God
content.introtext:
…A WOMAN WHO FEARS THE LORD IS TO BE PRAISED.

PROVERBS 31:30 NIV
Amy Carmichael was born in Ireland in 1867. She was one of those people who didn’t fit the mould. Her unconventional outlook was a problem for those who were more dedicated to maintaining tradition than to reaching a lost world. During her early years as a missionary, a ‘Get-Amy-out-of-India’ movement was started by people who didn’t understand her unwavering obedience to what she believed to be God’s will for her life. In her book, Roots, she writes: ‘It’s not that we think…ours is the only way of living, but we are sure…it’s the way meant for us.’ Amy served God in Japan, China and Sri Lanka before being called to India where she spent her time working with children, especially young girls forced into temple prostitution. Tenderness marked her life, but not weakness. She had an ‘iron fist in a velvet glove’ approach. Burning with holy anger she’d storm into a mob to rescue a little girl, then weep openly about the child’s situation. When she died in 1951 she was buried under a tamarind tree in a grave marked by the Indian word for mother: Amma. Have you ever noticed how often single women are called to do some of the toughest jobs? Did you know that the majority (though certainly not all) of missionaries are women? The Bible says, ‘Charm is deceptive, and beauty…fleeting; but a woman who fears the Lord is to be praised.’ Today if God’s calling you to be another Amy Carmichael, don’t be scared of saying ‘yes’, because the safest place in the world is right in the centre of His will.

content.title: BAAAA!
content.introtext:
…WE ARE HIS PEOPLE, THE SHEEP HE TENDS.

PSALM 100:3 NCV
Sheep are not the cleverest of animals; so it’s not very flattering when the Bible compares us to them! But there is stuff we can learn. So just for now, get creative and imagine you’re a sheep, living in the middle-eastern landscape of the Bible. Thorns prick. Rocks cut. Mosquitoes bite. So the shepherd regularly inspects his sheep searching for wounds. That’s because he doesn’t want today’s wound to become tomorrow’s infection. King David, who was a teenage shepherd writes: ‘We are his people, the sheep he tends.’ He was referring to God. Right, you can stop being a sheep now, but listen; God does care for you, and actually much more than he cares about sheep! God has a whole load of special soul-remedies that heal and protect. Like a sheep you need to stand still for a minute and let the shepherd do his work. Peter writes, ‘Be humble under God’s powerful hand so He will lift you up when the right time comes’ (1 Peter 5:6 NCV). Are you one of those people who asks lots of questions; you need to work it all out in your head? Great; as long as that doesn’t stop you simply trusting God. God will always give what is right to his people. (See Luke 18:7 NCV). Sheep don’t understand how the smelly ointment repels mosquitoes or heals wounds. All the sheep know is that something happens in the presence of their shepherd, that doesn’t happen anywhere else. And when push comes to shove that’s all we need to know as well.

content.title: Change-makers
content.introtext:
LET’S KEEP FOCUSED ON THAT GOAL, THOSE OF US WHO WANT EVERYTHING GOD HAS FOR US...

PHILIPPIANS 3:15 TM
Following Jesus means getting involved in the business of change; changing lives, changing families, changing communities… but not everyone likes change. In 1829, Martin Van Buren, Governor of New York, wrote to President Andrew Jackson warning him about the future. ‘President Jackson, the canal system of this country is being threatened by the spread of railroads. We must preserve the canals for the following reasons: 1) If canal boats are supplanted by railroads, serious unemployment will result. Captains, cooks, repairmen and lock tenders will be left without jobs, not to mention farmers now employed in growing hay for horses. 2) Boat builders would suffer, whip and harness makers would be left destitute. 3) Canal boats are absolutely essential to the defence of the United States. In the event of the expected trouble with England, the Erie Canal would be the only means by which we could ever move the supplies so vital to waging modern war. As you may well know, Mr. President, railroad carriages are pulled at the enormous speed of 15 mph by engines, which, in addition to endangering life and limb, snort their way through the countryside belching out smoke, setting fire to crops, scaring the livestock and frightening women and children. Surely the Almighty never intended people should travel at such breakneck speed.’ You might think that’s just a funny story from a long time ago but even in these times of rapidly advancing technology people still don’t like change. And sadly, the church has lost its revolutionary edge over the years. It probably needs to embrace change now more than ever. Will you be one of the change-makers?

content.title: Saved from the flames
content.introtext:
“…I HAVE LONGED TO GATHER YOUR CHILDREN TOGETHER, AS A HEN GATHERS HER CHICKS UNDER HER WINGS…”

MATTHEW 23:37 NIV
We hear a lot about God being our Father and Jesus being His Son. Does this mean that women are kind of spiritually sidelined then? Not at all. When we speak of God as Father we don’t actually mean He’s a bloke – it’s not a reference to maleness – in fact it’s nothing to do with gender at all. And Jesus, all though he actually did become a man in every sense of the word, could still see the world in amazingly female ways. Here’s a great example In the event of a fire on the farm a mother hen has an innate response: to gather her chicks tightly under her wings. When the fire has done it's worst all that's left is the blackened embers. Sifting through the smouldering debris afterwards you would find the charred remains of that mother hen. But if you were then to lift what's left of its matted carcass, underneath you'd find, preserved and eagerly chattering, every one of that mother hen’s little brood. In the days before His death, Jesus cried ‘“O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, you who kill the prophets and stone those sent to you, how often I have longed to gather your children together, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, but you were not willing.”’ You see, He saw the danger of the flames of judgement coming, and was yearning for us to enter the protection of His embrace. Like that mother hen He made the ultimate sacrifice so that we could live.

content.title: Loving the unlovable
content.introtext:
“…WHATEVER YOU DID FOR ONE OF THE LEAST OF THESE…YOU DID IT FOR ME.”

MATTHEW 25:40 NIV
Her parents didn’t want her, so at birth they put her in foster care. Shuffled from place to place, she dreamed of the day they’d return. It never happened. So, she lashed out at the world by attempting suicide. Then through a series of events she found her parents again. She lived with them but things were strained. When they told her they wanted to adopt a baby and ‘start over,’ she longed to be included. But when she said, ‘I don’t want to be a burden, so maybe I should go’ her dad helped her pack. Cramming her possessions into a bin bag, he pressed a tenner into her hand and said goodbye. Today she lives on the streets, sleeps in doorways and scrounges just enough food to live on. Sadly, her story’s not unique. It’s been multiplied into infinity. In fact, there’s probably somebody just like her in your town or city; forgotten, unloved and isolated. They’re usually the hardest to reach because they feel unwanted and useless. They wrestle with inferiority, poor self-image and lack of self-respect. What do we do? Instead of loving them we label them. Instead of caring, we criticize. What should we do? Open our hearts. Love is much more than giving a bit of your loose change. It takes time to develop and grow. So start early. Remember, that tough exterior is just a cover up. Every day look for new ways to reach out, encourage, and show hurting people you care. Why? Because Jesus said, ‘“…whatever you did for one of the least of these…you did it for Me.”’ And you won’t get a better reason than that!

content.title: SAY IT LOUD
content.introtext:
“…WHERE ARE THE OTHER NINE?”

LUKE 17:17 NIV
One day ten men with the deadly disease leprosy came to Jesus saying, ‘…have pity on us…!’ It was obvious that they were desperate for whatever charity Jesus might provide. ‘…Go show yourselves to the priests…’ was Jesus’ response. ‘As they went,’ the Bible says, ‘they were cleansed’ (Luke 17:12-14). But the story doesn’t end there. ‘One of them, when he saw he was healed, came back, praising God in a loud voice. He threw himself at Jesus’ feet and thanked him – and he was a Samaritan’ (Luke 17:15-16 NIV). Great isn’t it; but the story doesn’t end there. Jesus asks, ‘…Where are the other nine?’ (Luke 17:17 NIV). Jesus is making a point: saying thank you is important to Him. This story is in our Bibles to point out the importance of getting verbal with our thanks. Just feeling grateful isn’t enough – you have to say it – and this guy said it loud! The words ‘He came back’, are worth underlining. When was the last time you ‘came back’ to say thanks to the One who made it all possible. Thanks isn’t a natural thing for most of us, so we need to practice – lots! ‘Thanks’ shows humility: that I can’t get along by myself. ‘Thanks’ shows reliance: that I need people around me, and that I need God. ‘Thanks’ shows value: that I recognize the cost involved in giving. ‘Thanks’ shows gladness: that my life has been filled with a joy that only comes when I reach out to others with grace.

content.title: The power and reach of memory
content.introtext:
“FORGET THE FORMER THINGS; DO NOT DWELL ON THE PAST. SEE, I AM DOING A NEW THING!”

ISAIAH 43:18-19 NIV
Christian author Gordon Macdonald wrote, ‘When I asked a ninety-three-year-old man if he and his ninety year old wife ever have conflict, he assured me they do. I asked him how they treat each other in such moments, and he told me how important it is that he speaks tenderly to her. When I asked why, he told me that when his wife was a girl her father always spoke to her in a harsh and hurtful tone of voice. “Now whenever she hears any man speak in an angry manner, the feelings of hurt and fear return.”’ I said “are you telling me that she still remembers”’ “More than ever!” he responded. When we are little kids we watch those who are the most significant people in our lives and see how they act, how they express anger, joy, sadness or fear. We react now to what we saw then. So what should you do with those painful memories? The Bible gives us some pretty good suggestions: 1) Practise repentance, in other words admit when you’re wrong and say sorry! We often inherit the behaviour of people who brought us up so if you do stuff wrong say sorry 2) Have grace. Forgive people when they hurt you and forgive yourself! 3) Be thankful, focus on the good stuff rather than the bad. Everyone will make mistakes so let it go and move on 4) Be wise, find a way to turn your tough experiences into pain into learning experiences

content.title: Repairing the past
content.introtext:
“…IF I HAVE CHEATED ANYBODY OUT OF ANYTHING, I WILL PAY BACK FOUR TIMES THE AMOUNT.”

LUKE 19:8 NIV
Zacchaeus discovered that you can’t be right with God until you’re right with those you’ve hurt. Relationships are like a house. If you don’t look after it and fix stuff straight away, you won’t be doing repairs you’ll be rebuilding it! Everything that happens in the past makes us the people we become. The past will influence our relationships, our choices, our view of ourselves and even how we see God. You can’t live a spiritually healthy life if your past isn’t repaired. For a long time Jacob lived that way. He took advantage of his brother Esau, ripping him off with inheritance money that Jacob wasn’t entitled to. After that he did a runner. Eventually (years later) Jacob came home, terrified of what his brother would do. In that case Esau forgave his brother and the relationship was sorted but that’s not always the case. Repairing the past is better done straight away. Fixing up wounded relationships, dealing with regrets, letting go of feelings towards someone who’s betrayed you; these things will stay inside as though we’re asleep. Suddenly they will be triggered by a song on the radio or face in a crowd or a date on the calendar. They won’t go away until we deal with them. How? By forgiving. Forgiveness isn’t for the other person’s benefit – it’s for yours. So is there a relationship you need to repair today? If so, take care of it, God will help you.

content.title: Generous with…what?
content.introtext:
MAY THE LORD MAKE YOUR LOVE INCREASE AND OVERFLOW FOR EACH OTHER...

1 THESSALONIANS 3:12 NIV
So, what does it mean to be generous? And generous with…what? 1) Your time. Listen to what Paul said about his mate Onesiphorus. ‘May the Lord show mercy to …Onesiphorus, because he often refreshed me and was not ashamed of my chains…he searched hard for me until he found me’ (2 Timothy 1:16-17). Doesn’t he sound like a good bloke? He’s the type who will stand by you and go out of his way to be there no matter what 2) Your encouragement. Paul had a mate called Barnabas (which means ‘son of encouragement’). Barny was the one who played a huge role in Paul’s success and when everyone else doubted he was even a Christian, Barnabas welcomed him in. The last mention of Barny is of defending another guy who needed a second chance, John Mark. Are you willing to do that for others? 3) Your cash. Jesus watched loads of people giving money to look good but none of them impressed him at all. The one who caught his eye was a poor widow. Jesus called his disciples over and explained that she had given more than the others. The bit she gave was all she had whereas the others gave their left-overs (see Mark 12:43-44). We may love glamour and power but Jesus looks for true generosity. So you think you’re generous? Generous with…what?

content.title: The last spike
content.introtext:
I PRESS ON TOWARDS THE GOAL TO WIN THE PRIZE...

PHILIPPIANS 3:14 NIV
Here’s a little history from across the pond…right across America lies the Transcontinental Railroad. When the railroad was started some people thought it would be a great idea to hold a ceremony and loads of important people were invited to the place where the first rail was to be laid. One of the West Coast’s biggest backers of the railroad was invited to the ceremony but he refused to go. Instead he said ‘Anybody can drive the first spike, but there are months of labour and unrest between the first and last spike.’ The railroad was finally completed in May 1869 with a golden spike and a telegram informing the President. Starting something new is never difficult; it’s finishing that’s the problem! Imagine how many people have a half written book sat in their bottom drawer or have a half decorated room in their house. How many people have started to learn instruments or a language or bought expensive running shoes determined to get fit? Everyday thousands of us start new things but never even see the end in sight. Paul said ‘I press on toward the goal to win the prize…’ Instead of starting something you have no intention of finishing how about asking God today what He wants you to do, and do it with all your energy and might? With God’s help you may just reach your goal, win the prize and it will be seriously worth all the effort.

content.title: When all around is failing
content.introtext:
…I LIFT UP MY EYES TO YOU, TO YOU WHO’S THRONE IS IN HEAVEN.

PSALM 123:1 NIV
Ever had one of those days when everything seems to be going wrong, life has a distinct feeling of rubbishness about it and God seems to have vanished entirely? Those are the days that generally go one of two ways. Either you wake up the next morning and everything feels ok again or you wake up and everything seems ten times worse! Satan will use these times to bring up your insecurities, tell you lies about your relationships or the way you spend your time or your church. Suddenly everything is about you. Nothing EVER goes right for you, God loves everyone EXCEPT you, everyone else is joyful and happy and you’re left wondering what on earth life is about. The reality is God does love you and He does care. You’re not so special that you’re the only one to get left out! You see it’s these moments in life that challenge, change and grow us. How you react to those days will have a lasting impact on how you live your life. If you believe the lies and spend the day wallowing in self-pity, that will carry on until you lift your head and chose not to believe that stuff. But, to lift your head and say ‘God, I feel rubbish. I don’t understand you but I know you are God, I know you love me and I’m going to worship you anyway’, takes a lot of faith and a new way of thinking. But it’s guaranteed, you won’t feel rubbish for long and you will learn an awful lot about God very very quickly!

content.title: Knowing God intimately!
content.introtext:
THAT I MAY KNOW HIM…

PHILIPPIANS 3:10 KJV
Luke gives us an amazing description of a lady called Anna, who recognised Jesus as being the Son of God: ‘Anna the prophetess was also there…by now a very old woman. She had been married seven years and a widow eighty four. She never left the temple area, worshipping night and day…At the very time Simeon was praying, she showed up, broke into an anthem of praise to God, and talked about the (Christ) child to all’ (Luke 2:36-37 TM). Anna never stopped searching for God! What a challenge to people who get older and never get any further or deeper with God! Sadly as many people ‘grow up’ and get older the fire begins to burn out and they can easily spend the second half of their life never moving forward, never going deeper and never reclaiming their lost passion. This happens for loads of reasons. It may be caused by disappointment – they haven’t seen promises of God happen or feel they’ve been let down by Him some way. It may be that other things, relationships, children, work etc, just take a higher priority! The crazy thing is that it’s obvious if you want to stop a fire going out, you put more fuel on it! Anna never left the temple for 84 years, now that’s stoking the fire! As youngsters you have a choice about the way you live your life. You can put things in place to make sure that fire keeps being stoked. Set aside time to seek God and make sure that’s your no.1 priority, for the rest of your life!

content.title: Developing spiritual discipline
content.introtext:
WATCH YOUR LIFE AND DOCTRINE CLOSELY..

1 TIMOTHY 4:15 NIV
‘Spiritual discipline’ – two words most of us hate. What does it mean? It means making ourselves do stuff that doesn’t come easily in order to know God more. It doesn’t sound like much fun, and often it’s not but it’s absolutely essential if we want to get anywhere with God! It’s important to remember that satan will make you think it’s really hard and not worth it so you don’t even try. In reality though, when you’re closer to God and growing it’s totally worth everything you found hard to get there! Developing spiritual discipline is demanding, mostly done in secret and usually humbling. Demanding? Absolutely. It means being harder on yourself than you want to be. You need to think about your speech, relationships, life choices and if they’re not good enough, change them! Done in secret? Too right. Talk is cheap. Telling everyone everything that’s going on is not wise. How do you know someone’s wise? A good sign of wisdom is someone who thinks carefully before they speak! Humbling? O yes! Realising your weaknesses and all the areas you need to change and grow is never going to make you feel great! Spiritual discipline means that you stick with it while others make excuses and fall away. Listen to Paul: ‘…I’m running hard for the finish line. I’m giving it everything I’ve got. No sloppy living for me! I’m staying alert and in top condition. I’m not going to get caught napping, telling everyone else all about it and then missing out myself’ (1 Corinthians 9:26-27 TM).

content.title: God knows your name
content.introtext:
“…HE CALLS HIS OWN SHEEP BY NAME AND LEADS THEM OUT.

JOHN 10:3 NLT
When we see a flock of sheep, we see exactly that – a flock. All the same. Shepherds disagree; to them every sheep has a story and every face a name. When we see a crowd of people, we can think like we do about that flock of sheep - all the same. Jesus disagrees; to him every person has a story and every face a name. ‘“I have written your name on My hand…”’ (Isaiah 49:16 NLT). How good is that? Your name – on God’s hand where He sees it constantly. You may have seen your name on some impressive things – a trophy or certificate or maybe in your local newspaper but on God’s hands and lips – quite a thought isn’t it! That means what matters to you, matters to God. You probably think that’s true when it comes to big stuff like death, illness, sin or disaster. But what about the little stuff like driving lessons, arguments with your friends or a little cold? Get this: you are God’s child. John writes: ‘…we really are His children…’ (1 John 3:1 NCV). It’s almost like John knew some of us we shake our heads and think ‘Don’t be daft. Maybe Mother Teresa or Billy Graham is, but not me!' If that is what you think then this word really is for you: ‘We really are His children’. That means He’s your parent. As a parent it is important to your kids then it’s important to you. How much more is that true when God is the parent! Try to hold onto that truth today.

content.title: No unity, no blessing
content.introtext:
…FOR THE PEOPLE WORKED WITH ALL THEIR HEART

NEHEMIAH 4:6 NIV
Read Nehemiah chapter three. In this story Nehemiah has been given permission to rebuild the broken walls of Jerusalem, and chapter three shows us how he did it. Team work. Nehemiah brought together every group he could find from priests to perfume-makers and each group rebuilt their own section of the wall. Alone it was impossible but together, they achieved what everyone said they couldn’t. Notice some things about teamwork: 1) The team members must care for one another. In football you have to pass the ball! If a player goes for glory, refusing to pass to an unmarked man in better position, the chances are he will lose the ball. No one is more important than another 2) The team must communicate. In Hurricane Katrina, hundreds died while those who could have been rescued them stood by. Why? Communication broke down 3) ‘Your rights’ must take second place. The success of the team will always be more important than the success of the individual. If you think ‘I’ll do it myself so I know it’s done right you’re robbing others of the chance to take part, learn and grow. If Nehemiah had tried to build the wall himself with his own team, it wouldn’t have happened. It was only through encouraging everyone to play their own unique part that the wall got built. Sure, every section probably looked a bit different but the city was secure again, and that was the goal! The bottom line, God blesses those who work together in unity.

content.title: The need for appreciation
content.introtext:
ENCOURAGE ONE ANOTHER AND BUILD EACH OTHER UP...

1 THESSALONIANS 5:11 NIV
After 30 years of marriage his wife was ready to throw in the towel. ‘I have had it, living with you. You never tell me you love me anymore.’ The husband replied, ‘I told you I loved you when we got married; if I change my mind I’ll let you know.’ Way too many leaders expect their followers to run on autopilot like the guy in the story. They don’t get that people do much better if they think they’re appreciated. Comments like ‘don’t worry, you’ll get your reward in the end’ don’t help! We are all working for a ‘well done’ on that final day but still, God expects us to pat each other on the back along the way. Paul wrote ‘Encourage one another and build one another up...’ It may well look as though some people don’t need encouragement, like they can just keep working away but even the strongest person needs a little something every now and then. Often as you encourage someone they won’t know what to do with it, probably give an uncomfortable smile, a quick ‘thanks’ and change subject. These are the people that don’t believe much good about them selves and need even more love – until it goes in! Go out of your way to encourage your leaders! These people often need it most! No matter who you are, I guarantee a little email of ‘you’re doing a good job’ or pat on the back when you see them could be just the thing they need. Compliments disappear pretty soon after we’ve said them which is why you can never give enough!

content.title: David’s five ‘I wills.’
content.introtext:
I WILL SING OF YOUR LOVE AND JUSTICE...

PSALM 101:1 NLT
Today we’re going to take a look at the five ‘I wills’ of David in Psalm 101: 1) ‘I will sing of your love and justice...’ (v1.) When dealing with others, some of us are all mercy and no justice; others are all justice with no mercy. God needs both. 2) ‘I will be careful to live a blameless life…’ (v2). How you behave will impact someone much more than what you believe. Even if someone doesn’t hold the same beliefs as you and can still be won over by your love and lifestyle. 3) ‘…I will lead a life of integrity in my own home’ (v2). How many of us struggle to live right more at home than anywhere? If your family thinks you’re joyless and judgmental you’ll never see them become Christians. David prayed, ‘…how I need Your help, especially in my own home, where I long to act as I should’ (Psalm 101:2 TLB). 4) ‘I will refuse to look at anything vile or vulgar…’ (v3). Get real. TV is on 7 hours a day in most homes. Look at some of the things you’re watching – violence, sex, abuse, bad language etc. You may say you’ve no time to hang with God and pray but is the truth that you don’t really want to? 5) ‘I will not tolerate people who slander their neighbours…’ (v5). How many times a day do you hear people moaning or badmouthing about someone else? How about just for once you don’t accept it. Even if they have a point, defend the person, correct their comments then walk away. Those are five fantastic ‘I wills’ to live by today!

content.title: Praying, for the right reasons
content.introtext:
TO YOU, O LORD, I LIFT UP MY SOUL.

PSALM 25:1 NIV
Read Psalm 25. It describes a person who’s chosen the right road, yet not found it easy to walk. In the first ten verses we learn five things about the person who prays: 1) (v1) They know where to go for help ‘To You, O LORD, I lift up my soul’ Others can help us and we often go for help everywhere we can think of before God but only He can truly help and sustain us 2) (v2) They know who to trust. ‘In you I trust…do not let me be put to shame, nor let my enemies triumph over me,’ Love your enemies, because God does. Whatever others say or do to you it’s them that will be answerable to God. Pray for them, give them to God, then move on 3) (v4) They know what prayer’s all about. ‘Show me your ways, O Lord, teach me your paths.’ When we pray we change. We get some of Gods heart, we learn His ways, we find out who He is and we realise our weaknesses and need of Him. It’s one of the main tools God uses to transform us. When we pray life, choices and paths become clear. At that point we have a choice whether to go deeper with God or to abandon it and refuse to change 4) (v7) They know why they’re saved. ‘…According to your love remember me…’ We can’t get to God because of what we’ve done, it’s all about His grace and love! 5) (v9) They know prayer works. ‘He guides the humble in what is right…’ When you can’t see the way forward, pray. God will show you one step at a time.

content.title: A father’s legacy
content.introtext:
THE RIGHTEOUS MAN WALKS IN...INTEGRITY; BLESSED ARE HIS CHILDREN AFTER HIM.

PROVERBS 20:7 AMP
Author Max Lucado writes: ‘Today’s my first [Father’s Day] without a father. For 31 years I had one of the best but now he’s...buried under an oak tree in a west Texas cemetery. Strange he isn’t here...because he was always available. His words were nothing novel; his achievements, though admirable, were nothing extraordinary. But his presence was. Because he was there life went smoothly...the future was secure...and my growing up was what God intended. He taught me how to shave and how to pray. Helped me memorize verses for Sunday school, and taught me that wrong should be punished...that rightness has its own reward. He modeled... the elusive balance between ambition and self-acceptance. I knew if I ever needed him he’d be there. Like a warm fireplace. Maybe that’s why this Father’s Day’s a bit chilly. The fire’s gone out. The winds of age swallowed the splendid flame, leaving only golden embers. But there’s a strange thing about those embers, stir them...and the flame will dance...and knock just enough chill out of the air to remind me that he’s still... present.’ Compare that to an interview with actor Gene Hackman who remembered: ‘I was just 13, but that Saturday morning is still vivid. I was playing down the street...when I saw my father drive by and give me a light wave. Somehow I knew that gesture meant he was going away forever. To this day, the memory’s a ghost that never seems to fade.’ Think today about who has taught you the things a father should. Whether it’s your dad or someone else take the time to thank God for that person, and tell them too!

content.title: Overcoming life-limiting thoughts
content.introtext:
“…I WILL STRENGTHEN AND HELP YOU; I WILL UPHOLD YOU WITH MY RIGHTEOUS RIGHT HAND.”

ISAIAH 41:10 NIV
Labels tend to stick. When we’re young our parents tend to say things like ‘oh, she’s just a plain Jane,’ or, ‘He’ll never be as smart as his brother.’ We drag those comments around with us like a ball and chain for the rest of our lives. Fortunately God sees your potential differently. Listen: ‘God can pour on the blessings in astonishing ways so that you’re…more than…ready to do what needs to be done’ (2 Corinthians 9:8 TM). Seventy five years ago Johnnie Weismuller, better known as Tarzan to film-lovers, was called the greatest swimmer in the world. Doctors and coaches said, ‘Nobody will ever break Johnnie’s records.’ He held more than 50 of them. Today 13-year-old girls break them on a regular basis! For decades experts declared nobody would break the 4-minute mile. Roger Bannister refused to believe it and as a result became the first man to run a mile in under 4 minutes. Today hundreds of runners do it every year. The words of others can stop you temporarily, but you are the only one that can do it permanently. If God says you can – you can! And His opinion is the only one that counts. Edgar Guest wrote, ‘There are thousands to tell you it cannot be done, there are thousands to prophesy failure, there are thousands to point out, one by one, that dangers want to assail you. So buckle right in with a bit of a grin, take off your coat and go to it; just start to sing as you tackle the thing that ‘cannot be done’ and you’ll do it.’

content.title: Do you need strength?
content.introtext:
…THOSE WHO WAIT ON THE LORD WILL FIND NEW STRENGTH…

ISAIAH 40:31 NLT
God doesn’t tell us how he’ll answer our prayers or even when. But He does promise one thing to those who wait on Him – strength. The Bible word ‘wait’ comes from a Hebrew word used in the making of rope. Every rope starts as a thread, and every thread added increases it’s strength. You see every time you wait on the Lord it’s like another thread being added to the rope, you get a bit stronger and a little bit more able to cope. So what does it mean to ‘wait on the Lord’? If you’re waiting for a bus you literally just stand, do nothing and wait for the bus to arrive. But what about a waiter? Waiters do a little standing around but their job is to serve, to be on the ball and be available at all times to make sure the customers have everything they need. The job of a waiter is to be active; ready for action at any time. Whether its sitting prayerfully in God’s presence or actively carrying out His will, you have His word that strength will be renewed. Listen to these promises: ‘Wait patiently for the LORD. Be brave and courageous. Yes, wait patiently for the LORD’ (Psalm 27:14 NLT). ‘I wait quietly before God, for my hope is in him.’ (Psalm 62:5 NLT) ‘As the eyes of slaves look to the hand of their master…so our eyes look to the LORD our God…’ (Psalm 123:2 NIV). Need more strength? Wait on God more!

content.title: Hovering
content.introtext:
…AND THE SPIRIT OF GOD WAS HOVERING OVER THE FACE OF THE WATERS.

GENESIS 1:2 NKJ
Before God completed His creation, the Bible says His Spirit ‘hovered’ over it. You get the feeling of anticipation, of something beautiful about to be revealed. The Spirit hovered; watching, protecting, nourishing and preparing for what was to come. We need to do the same in our own lives. If something incredible is going to happen, you can be sure it will take time. The great King David spent many years alone on a hillside watching sheep. No one saw any potential in him, his gifts weren’t being fully expressed. He hadn’t had his shepherd-boy annual appraisal with targets and goals set for the next year! Only God saw the potential in David and as David patiently waited, trained, developed and grew in his relationship with God, all the foundations were set in place. During that hillside time David would have perfected the harp; which was used to calm the King Saul. He would have learned to use a slingshot; the skill used to bring down Goliath. All the time David was being prepared while the Spirit ‘hovered’ and God knew the exact time he would leave that hillside. Don’t get impatient and rush the work God is preparing you for. God will prepare each of us in the right amount of time and if you seem to be taking longer than others, chances are he is preparing you for greater things! So make the most of your hillside time while it’s there, you’re going to need it!

content.title: Don’t just operate – cooperate
content.introtext:
…WE HAVE SHARED TOGETHER THE BLESSINGS OF GOD…

PHILIPPIANS 1:7 TLB
‘You can’t whistle a symphony, it takes an orchestra’. This means that we all need to realise that we can do a much better job with other people than we can by ourselves. Your future is connected to certain people and without them your destiny won’t be complete. If you can actually accept that, your possibilities are unlimited! A key bloke in the Billy Graham association (Billy Graham being the most famous evangelist of the 20th century) was his childhood friend, Grady Wilson. In 1948 Billy asked Grady to come and work with him. At first he said no, but Billy went on: ‘God’s told me you’re to come and work with me. I need an evangelist; somebody who knows me and my ministry, somebody I can trust.’ Speaking later Wilson remembered ‘I didn’t want to come. After all, I already had a successful ministry of my own holding citywide crusades.’ After praying, he made the decision to follow Billy Graham (and God). He set aside his own dreams to be part of another man’s. That decision made a huge difference, not only in his life but also in the lives of the people they reached together until Grady Wilson’s death. Sometimes you have to sacrifice a smaller dream to fulfil a bigger one. You may even be asked to lay down your dreams not knowing what other thing is ahead and it takes a lot of strength and courage to do that. But look at the results. Heaven alone knows the impact that Grady Wilson and Billy Graham had together.

content.title: Compartmentalised
content.introtext:
“LOVE THE LORD YOUR GOD WITH ALL YOUR HEART…”

DEUTERONOMY 6:5 NIV
Is your life like a wardrobe with a separate compartment for each area of your life? One for school or college, one for work, one for home, one for each set of friends, one for church. Each one means that you talk and act a different way and even have a different set of values. You may find that the behaviour or language you use with one set of friends would be shocking to your church friends! Every time you start a new thing with different people you start a new compartment and reinvent yourself. What happens is that rather than having openness and honesty, your life is split into so many different roles that no one quite knows who you really are, including yourself. God doesn’t see you as a collection of compartments or a cast of different characters. He sees you as a whole person, no matter which group you are with, what part of your character you’re putting across today or the person you are when no one’s looking. God wants to bring wholeness and completeness to your life. Don’t live and talk a certain way around Christians and act differently with other mates. You can’t fool God, He sees everything you do and think. Trying to be several different people just doesn’t work’. We were made with one mind, one heart and one spirit. So what’s the answer? ‘Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your strength’ (Deuteronomy 6:5 NIV). Refuse to live ‘compartmentalised’ lives!

content.title: Excuses or results
content.introtext:
I CAN DO EVERYTHING THROUGH HIM WHO GIVES ME STRENGTH

PHILIPPIANS 4:13 NIV
You don’t have to search the internet for very long before coming up with an enormous list of websites dedicated to providing you with excuses for just about everything. These range from the clever ‘Mum ate my homework, she's heavily pregnant and having very odd cravings’ to the naughty ‘I can’t go to church today, I come out in a rash when I hear ‘Shine Jesus Shine’ to the utterly ridiculous ‘I’d love to but the man on TV told me to stay tuned.’ Whether they are true or totally made up, we can come up with an excuse for everything. Very often the problem is not that other people don’t believe our excuses, but the fact we do believe them ourselves. We convince ourselves we can’t do more with our lives because we need to be taller or thinner or smarter or faster or better-looking or funnier. The Bible says that ‘I can do everything through him who gives me strength’. This means we need to do our best and where we’re lacking God will give us the rest. So what’s your excuse? With Gods help you can rise above any circumstances or challenges that seem to guarantee failure. The real problem is not about the way we look or our intelligence, it’s negativity, self-pity and an attitude that ‘I’m not good enough so it’s not even worth trying.’ When God says He will give you strength, take Him at His word! Put aside your doubts and any negative attitudes and then see what you can’t do!

content.title: Care enough to confront (2)
content.introtext:
“IF A FELLOW BELIEVER HURTS YOU, GO AND TELL HIM--WORK IT OUT BETWEEN THE TWO OF YOU…”

MATTHEW 18:15 TM
Working out your differences requires a few ground-rules: 1) Clarify in your own mind exactly what the problem is. Carefully figure out how you see things and ask yourself if you might be missing anything. Is this a mountain or a molehill? Temporary or long-term? Avoidable or unavoidable? 2) Sort your attitude. Jesus asked how you take a speck out of your brother’s eye? The answer was to take the huge great log out of your own so you can see clearly to sort your brother’s eye! Give your attitude to God. When you’re angry it’s easy to wreak havoc and do more harm than good 3) Think about where to meet. Have plenty of time, when you’re not tired, in a fairly private place and try to meet on neutral territory 4) Make sure they know you’re not trying to give them a last chance – it’s not ‘my way or the highway’, you just want to make things better 5) Try to chat. Don’t make strong comments like ‘you always’ or ‘you never’. When you say something important stop and ask if you have your facts straight or if you’re missing something. When they say something, don’t react off the cuff, repeat back what you heard – it might be different from what they thought they said! Let’s face it; sometimes confrontation will end in division. That’s why Paul said, ‘Do your part to live in peace with everyone, as much as possible.’ (Romans 12:18 NLT). Too many of us just give up when things get rocky. Relationships are very valuable; they take years to build. That’s why real love keeps on hanging in there and works through them.

content.title: Care enough to confront (1)
content.introtext:
…SPEAK THE TRUTH…

EPHESIANS 4:25 NRS
The things we say are really important. And the way we say them is really important too. Even when it’s done out of love, telling someone the truth can still create tension. That’s why we’ll do anything to avoid confrontation. Our heads say ‘why rock the boat’ and as a result we let things go that really should be dealt with. The problem with this is that a) the problem always comes back b) untreated, it gets worse c) disappointment can wreck the relationship d) unexpressed anger makes you bitter e) our love goes cold. If we don’t confront people we’re not using the tools that God’s given us. ‘Peace at any price’ is a tactic of satan. If you actually care enough to confront someone he’ll whisper, ‘Why bother? It’ll just make trouble. It’ll sort itself out’. Listening to those lies will kill the relationship for certain! The Bible says, ‘If a fellow believer hurts you…work it out between the two of you…’ (Matthew 18:15 TM). The same goes for confronting a friend who maybe hurting themselves. Phrases like ‘I care too much to stand by and watch you…’ show you’re not saying it for your own benefit. Speaking the truth means taking a risk and will only work if you believe two things: 1) That honesty is more important than avoiding conflict 2) That the other person’s well-being is more important than being comfortable. God says ‘…speak the truth…’ because any other way destroys relationships. So – is there somebody you need to speak to today? If so, pray, then do it!

content.title: Life does have a point
content.introtext:
I PRESS ON TOWARDS THE GOAL TO WIN THE PRIZE FOR WHICH GOD HAS CALLED ME…

PHILIPPIANS 3:14 NIV
Japan has always had a reputation for crazy game shows like ‘Takeshi’s Castle’. The programme begins with 100 bonkers contestants all aiming to get through each crazy round in order to storm the castle at the end. Each round generally involves muddy water and normally sees contestants trying to balance on things, hang from things and jump over things. The result is normally that contestants fail quite spectacularly and obviously do themselves a serious injury. Eventually a few make it through to the final and, on the very rare occasion that they successfully storm the castle, receive absolutely nothing! Many people live their lives as though they are on Takeshi’s castle. They follow the crowd and like the 100 nutty people in the first round run like maniacs to try and be the first to climb a huge slippery wall. No one really knows why they are doing it, but it looks fun so they do it anyway. As life goes on people get more hurt along the way and wonder what the point is. The survivors make it through to the end, battered, bruised, alone and exhausted and win absolutely nothing. The Bible makes it clear that life does have a point, to know Jesus and make Him known. It’s life lived for an eternal goal and for heavenly rewards. If we live the Jesus life, we won’t get to the end and find we have nothing. But if we go along with the crowd just because that’s what they do and it looks fun, we’re in trouble. Chances are you will get seriously hurt along the way too.

content.title: Have you found your calling? (2)
content.introtext:
WE ARE GOD’S WORKMANSHIP, CREATED IN CHRIST JESUS TO DO GOOD WORKS, WHICH GOD PREPARED IN ADVANCE FOR US TO DO.

EPHESIANS 2:10 NIV
‘Calling’ is a funny word that’s used a lot by Christians. But what exactly does that mean? Well if someone calls you to wash the dishes they want you to wash the dishes. It’s the same with God. Your call is simply anything He’s asked you to do. So how do you find your ‘calling’? It normally comes in several ways. 1) You feel ‘moved’. You will see something, often a need that no one seems to be doing anything about and something inside just tells you to go and do something about it 2) It’s confirmed by others. People will see God at work in your life. People who know you well will say stuff like ‘you come alive when you…’ or ‘You’re at your best when you…’ 3) You’ll be good at it. Occasionally someone will start out with no obvious gifts but that’s a bit rare. When God calls you He also gives you all you need to do that job. Sure you’re going to have to take some risks, learn some new skills and have a go at some scary stuff you’ve never done before but if God’s called you, you will get good and quick! When you’re in your calling and going for it you will soar like an eagle no matter what obstacles might be in your way. People will stand back in amazement and you will know God’s pleasure 4) You’ll see results! You’ll change things, touch lives and glorify God. If you’re walking in God’s call the results may not be exactly what you thought or planned, but at the end of the day that’s not your problem!

content.title: Have you found your calling? (1)
content.introtext:
“I HAVE FILLED HIM WITH…SKILL, ABILITY AND KNOWLEDGE IN ALL KINDS OF CRAFTS.”

EXODUS 31:3 NIV
Have you ever thought that may be your ‘call’ does not necessarily mean you are going to be a full-time worship leader or world evangelist? Often we can think that to live for God means doing a full-time job for a church but that’s totally not always the case. Check out Nehemiah – called to build walls, Daniel – called to work for the government, Luke – a first century doctor. Your job could well be part of your calling! Many jobs involve having influence whether you are in teaching, in health care, in social care in media and arts or in the government. When you demonstrate your faith and Christian character and use your income to fulfil God’s purpose, you are as called as any full-time pastor – maybe more! Remember, your past doesn’t disqualify you from fulfilling your God-given destiny. Paul wrote, ‘…I used to scoff at the name of Christ. I hunted down his people, harming them in every way I could…’ (1 Timothy 1:13 NLT). The good news is God doesn’t need to see our CV to give us our future! Also, the chances are God will call you to a job that looks too big for you. Why? That way you’ll never forget where your strength and success comes from. Your call is not a general advert for anyone who fancies it to respond to, it’s specifically for you. If you go off and do your own thing, chances are you’re stealing someone else’s! Everything you achieve yourself will eventually leave you empty. When you do something you are truly called to do you will know and experience the real lasting pleasure of God.

content.title: ‘Older brother’ attitudes!
content.introtext:
“THE OLDER BROTHER BECAME ANGRY AND REFUSED TO GO IN...”

LUKE 15:28 NIV
In this story the younger brother has gone way off track, lost everything and come home again. The older brother stayed at home, was good and faithful yet at the end of the parable it’s him who’s left out in the cold. You see, while the older brother didn’t run around obviously sinning like the younger, his attitude was rubbish. He was jealous and selfish and couldn’t stand the thought of his naughty little brother being welcomed home. When we focus on ourselves, working for number one, we become like the older brother. This ‘older brother’ attitude has three possible results: 1) He was a son but refused to act like a brother. Be careful about your attitude towards other Christians, your brothers and sisters! A wrong relationship with them can cause a real strain on your relationship with your Heavenly Father 2) It’s possible to serve God faithfully but with the wrong motives and attitude. If you’re not serving God out of love, you will never understand why a father would throw a huge party for the return of someone who’s gone miles off track 3) It’s possible to be first in line to receive everything from your father yet have less joy and freedom than someone who will get nothing. Even the hired servants were happier than the older brother. They ate, laughed, partied and celebrated while the older brother stood outside demanding his rights. His attitude robbed him of his relationship with his dad, the love of his brother and the joy of the servants. Don’t let the ‘older brother’ attitude rob you of relationship, love and joy too.

content.title: Experiencing the miraculous
content.introtext:
“DO WHATEVER HE TELLS YOU.”

JOHN 2:5 NIV
Do you need a miracle? Reread the story of Jesus turning water into wine. Look at what Mary tells the attendants at the wedding reception: ‘Do whatever he [Jesus] tells you.’ Do it, even though: 1) You’re not in the right place. When Jesus performed this miracle they were at a wedding, not in a church. If we’re sensitive and obedient to God He will work wherever we are 2) You’ve got a lot of problems. Embarrassingly they had run out of wine at a wedding! When we have problems we often turn anywhere but to God. When something hurts is the first place you go to the Bible or the chemist? Miracles start when we focus on Gods power instead of our own problems 3) You’re not being encouraged. When Mary turned to Jesus for help, He tested her faith saying, ‘Dear woman, why do you involve Me?…My time has not yet come’ (John 2:4 NIV). But she passed the test. Instead of being put off she pressed in, believed God and saw a miracle 4) You’ve not been a Christian very long. The servants who obeyed Jesus had just met Him and His disciples had only just been recruited. But, they were still expected to obey Him. So are you 5) You haven’t seen Him do miracles in your life yet. This was Jesus first miracle. They had to obey Him even without a long track record.
