content.title: He’ll be waiting
content.introtext:
…I’M ON MY WAY TO GET YOUR ROOM READY...

JOHN 14:3 TM
Born during the 1880’s, John Todd was six when his parents died. His wealthy auntie offered him a home, and when her servant Caesar went to get him the conversation went like this: John: ‘Will I like living there?’ Caesar: ‘You’ll be in good hands.’ John: ‘Will she love me?’ Caesar: ‘Yes, she’s got a big heart.’ John: ‘Will I have my own room and a puppy?’ Caesar: ‘Everything’s all set.’ John: ‘Will she go to bed before I arrive?’ Caesar: ‘No, she’ll be waiting for you.’ Sure enough, as they approached he saw a candle in the window and his auntie standing in the doorway. She kissed him and welcomed him. Over the years she became a true mother to him. Todd eventually became a church leader. Years later, when his Auntie’s health was failing she wrote to him about her impending death, wondering what would become of her. Todd wrote back saying, ‘My Dear Aunt: Years ago I left a house of death not knowing where I was going, whether anyone cared, or if that was the end of me. The ride was long but your servant encouraged me. Finally I arrived to your warm embrace and a new home. I was welcomed; I felt safe. You did all this for me, now it’s your turn to go. I’m writing to let you know someone will be waiting up for you. Your room’s ready, the light’s on, the door’s open, and they’re expecting you. I know, because once, long ago, I saw God standing in your doorway.’ Good news: you don’t need to fear death because Jesus went ahead; and He’ll be waiting for you.

content.title: A bizarre history lesson
content.introtext:
…KEEP AWAY FROM ANYTHING THAT MIGHT TAKE GOD’S PLACE...

1 JOHN 5:21 NLT
There are some pretty extreme stories in the Old Testament that leave us scratching our head and thinking, ‘What..?’ Like when the Israelites started dissing the food God miraculously provided. ‘Then the LORD sent venomous snakes among them; they bit the people and many Israelites died.’ (Numbers 21:6 NIV). Heavy scenes! Not surprisingly, the people repented and begged God to remove the snakes. Then something weirder happened - God told Moses to make a bronze snake sculpture, and said whoever looked at it would be healed - and they were. It was a bizarre sequence of events. But there’s more... For centuries the people preserved, protected and polished this bronze snake, dragging it with them everywhere, until they ended up worshipping it. Something that had once been an answer to prayer became an idol. The Bible describes how eventually a King called Hezekiah ‘…broke into pieces the bronze snake Moses had made, for…the Israelites had been burning incense to it…’ (2 Kings 18:4 NIV). Think it can’t happen? John says, ‘…keep away from anything that might take God’s place in your hearts.’ Anything or anybody can become an idol; your football team, your favourite band, your fashionable wardrobe, your fancy new mobile... Don’t get the wrong idea; there’s nothing wrong with enjoying all this stuff. It’s only when wrong stuff begins to take God’s place! Jesus said, ‘Your heart will always be where your treasure is’ (Luke 12:34 CEV). Jesus deserves ‘…first place in everything’ (Colossians 1:18 NAS) – without exception. When He’s truly at the centre of your life everything else is just icing on the cake.

content.title: PLAN A
content.introtext:
…I KNOW THE PLANS I HAVE FOR YOU...

JEREMIAH 29:11 NIV
Nothing shocks God or catches Him off guard. He didn’t panic when Adam messed everything up in the Garden. He didn’t freak out when the ancient world was becoming a 24-7 sin factory; He was ready with a flood to cleanse it and start afresh with Noah. Israel may have tried His patience but they never made Him gasp in surprise. That’s because God has always had a plan. And His plan includes your life too. It’s detailed, like a road map, whatever wrong turns you’ve made in your life, however lost you feel, He can get you back on track. The Bible says He has ‘plans to prosper…and not to harm you…to give you hope and a future.’ But sometimes you feel like you’re travelling through the night, it’s hard to see the signposts, the road gets bumpy... maybe you get sick, fail an important exam, fall out with your best friend...one thing is happened after the other, you’re not sure you’ll survive. When the crisis you’re facing makes you want to throw in the towel, remember this: our problems become God’s opportunities. He loves to transform our stupidest mistakes into priceless gems of wisdom, He turns our cuts and bruises into greater strength, and our deepest fears into unshakeable faith. How? By showing us a bit more of His master plan! When we think the story’s over, He just turns the page. He loves making order out of chaos – and He’s been doing it since Genesis 1 verse 3! So trust Him today; Plan A is still on track - and refuse to give place to discouragement no matter what – okay?

content.title: Parrots and Eagles
content.introtext:
…THE VISION IS …FOR AN APPOINTED TIME…

HABAKKUK 2:3 NKJV
Dreams come in all sorts of shapes and sizes. There are dreams that buzz around in your head like a bee for a few days, then just vanish. Other dreams seem to make a permanent cosy nest in your heart. Then there are dreams that seem to grow daily deep in your spirit until you feel like they’re getting so big you’re gonna explode! Often we don’t pursue our dreams because we’re afraid of failing; it’s safer to pet them in private instead of letting them fly in public. Broadcaster and author Chuck Swindoll says, ‘We’re short of eagles and running over with parrots. Content to sit safely on our evangelical perches and repeat religious words, we’re fast becoming overpopulated with bright-collared birds having soft bellies, big beaks, and little heads. What would help would be more keen-eyed, wide winged creatures willing to soar…exploring the illimitable ranges of the Kingdom.’ Listen: ‘Commit to the Lord whatever you do, and your plans will succeed’ (Proverbs 16:3 NIV). God’s the One who gives us the courage to step out on to the tightrope of life and He’s also the one who promises to ‘…keep you from falling…’ (Jude 1:24 NIV) He strengthens us to do what we’ve never done before. He empowers us to get off square one! Remember, going out on a limb can be scary; but that’s where the best fruit is. So what if your dream is currently more parrot than eagle? You obviously need to pay a visit to the Master of Transformation. The one who turned water into wine, a lunchbox into a banquet, fishermen into world changers! In fact He may be waiting for you to make a move so He can transform you too.

content.title: God is a DJ!
content.introtext:
…I WILL ANSWER YOUR PRAYERS…I HAVE SET A TIME...

ISAIAH 49:8 CEV
On the dance floor it’s quite easy to tell the people who have rhythm from the people who don’t! But you don’t need to worry if it’s not you who’s ripping up the place with your moves; there’s a rhythm that’s a lot more important than Usher… and God determines the beat. God has a ‘set…time.’ It’s not always predictable, sometimes He moves suddenly. But usually He tips you off in advance about changes He has in mind. He gives you the passion to pursue fresh interests, and before long you’re thinking, ‘Hey – the beat changed – when did that happen?’ Well isn’t that how all the best DJs do it!? Then comes the dramatic pause. Why? Because it takes time for change to produce the maximum impact. During that time God: a) helps you forget your past so it can’t pollute your future, and b) prepares your heart for fresh experiences. Why is it that even though God says, ‘…when the time comes, I will…do all this’ (Isaiah 60:22 CEV), we generally don’t appreciate His timing until after the dust has settled? If only we would allow God to work out His plan at His tempo! It makes sense really, doesn’t it? It’s easier to know when to bust a move, if you’re already in step with God and bouncing to the beat. Maybe the Apostle Paul was a bit of a mover on the dance floor? Well after all, he’s the one who first encouraged us to ‘…keep in step with the Spirit’ (Galatians 5:25 NIV)

content.title: IT’S A SET UP!
content.introtext:
…SO THAT THINGS MIGHT GO WELL FOR THEM...

DEUTERONOMY 5:29 NCV
Check this out: ‘I no longer call you servants; because a servant does not know his master’s business. Instead I have called you friends; for everything that I learned from my Father I have made known to you’ (John 15:15 NIV). Jesus describes the difference between being a friend or a servant by talking about sharing inside information. David said, ‘The secret of the Lord is with them that fear him…’ (Psalm 25:14 KJV). God will share things with those who are intimate with Him that He won’t share with others. When you see somebody who’s focused in the confusion and cool when the heat is on, they might know a secret; shared with them by a Friend. Realize that when God tells you to do certain things He’s not trying to make your life hard. No, He’s setting you up for a blessing. Listen: ‘I wish their hearts would always respect me and that they would always obey my commands so that things would go well for them…’ (Deuteronomy 5:29 NCV). On the other end of anything God asks you to do, is the promise ‘so that things would go well for you.’ Don’t be surprised if sometimes God expects things of you that: a) He doesn’t require of others b) He won’t explain and you can’t understand c) when you’ve obeyed, you won’t immediately see the benefits. But if you’re convinced that God has a unique plan for your life and loves you unconditionally, you’ll throw yourself on Him in complete trust, knowing that in the end it will ‘go well’ for you.

content.title: Job’s secret!
content.introtext:
IN ALL OF THIS, JOB DID NOT SIN BY BLAMING GOD.

JOB 1:22 NLT
When God called Job ‘…the greatest…among…the people of the East’ (Job 1:3 NIV), the title was well-deserved. Job was massively respected by everyone who lived around him. The guy had 10 children, loads of property and his own servants! Then, without warning he lost everything including his children and his health. Yet ‘Through all of this Job did not sin nor…blame God.’ Instead he asked, ‘…Shall we accept good from God and not trouble?...’ (Job 2:10 NIV). How could anyone endure this without becoming bitter? What was Job’s secret? Here are 3 ideas: 1) He recognized God’s right to control events in his life. When the dust settled, Job said, ‘…even if he killed me, I’d keep on hoping…’ (Job 13:15 TM). If we take that literally it doesn’t make a lot of sense – but Job is just stressing the point that anything God permits is ultimately for the best, so he said, ‘I know that you can do anything, and no one can stop you’ (Job 42:2 NLT). 2) He looked beyond the immediate tragedy. Listen: ‘My flesh may be destroyed, yet…I will see God…and I long for that moment’ (Job 19:26-27 CEV). Job had nothing to praise God for in the present – so he looked to the future! Job chose to take his eyes off the here and now, he looked through the doorway of death to the other side, and was strengthened to handle whatever life threw at him. 3) He acknowledged his limited understanding. Instead of feeling the need to explain his extreme highs and lows, Job told God, ‘…I have talked about things that are far beyond my understanding…I heard about you from others; now I have seen you with my own eyes’ (Job 42:3-5 CEV). Finding God in it – that was Job’s secret!

content.title: The disease to please
content.introtext:
…I’M NOT TRYING TO BE A PEOPLE PLEASER…I AM TRYING TO PLEASE GOD...

GALATIANS 1:10 NLT
A talented young musician studied under a famous violin teacher. Now it was time for his first public performance. He played amazingly and a huge chorus of ‘Bravos!’ from the audience. Strangely he seemed not to hear them, but kept glancing nervously at the front row. It wasn’t until a white-haired man stood up and nodded graciously, that the young violinist started to smile. His master had praised his work! He’d received the only approval that mattered. Whose approval do you look for? Be honest! It’s important to get real about how much of what you do is just to win the favour of other people. Paul said, ‘…we speak as messengers…approved by God…Our purpose is to please [Him], not people’ (1 Thessalonians 2:4 NLT). He also said, ‘…I’m not trying to be a people pleaser…If I were…I would not be Christ’s servant.’ (Galatians 1:10 NLT). Will Smith has been heard saying ‘Too many people spend money they haven’t earned, to buy things they don’t want, to impress people they don’t like’. The problem is, that’s not his own wisdom – he stole the quote from someone else – he obviously feels like he needs to impress someone! You really need to watch out for this trap. Don’t be like the people in the Bible who ‘…loved human praise more than the praise of God’ (John 12:42-43 NLT). Remember, any time you set new goals, establish new boundaries, or change old patterns, you’re going to get flack from people who are used to you behaving in a certain way. Have the courage of your convictions. Don’t stop doing what you know is right!

content.title: Your ‘EXPLAIN BY’ date
content.introtext:
…I AM THE WAY…THE TRUTH AND THE LIFE...

JOHN 14:6 NIV
Why do we pretend we have all the answers when we don’t? When Paul wrote, ‘…we know in part…’ (1 Corinthians 13:9 NIV) he wasn’t having a crisis of faith, he was just being honest. It’s as if some things in life are labelled by God just like products in a supermarket – with an ‘EXPLAIN BY’ date. Thomas may not have arrived at the truth of the resurrection when the others did; but he got it soon enough! A Christian broadcaster said: ‘I find airtight conclusions mainly in people who have not hurt much. They’re usually people who have become tightly wired, rigid and isolated from the real world. They’re closed…unwilling to be vulnerable. Suddenly a divorce comes. Or someone dies in a tragic set of circumstances or loses his job. Reality hits and a storm blows in that threatens their once tranquil existence. Their emotional explosion results in more questions than answers. They discover things they didn’t really know. They are in the vortex of dilemmas they cannot solve. At that point simplistic solutions are replaced with realistic reflections, and the deep things of God begin to emerge, eclipsing shallow answers’. That explains why Jesus didn’t have a go at Thomas and say, ‘Are you just going to diss me to my face by saying I’m a ghost!’ No, Jesus didn’t push Thomas away because of his doubts, He called him closer, close enough to touch him. Thomas knew stuff in his head, Jesus had said to him earlier, ‘I am the way and the truth and the life’ but it had not entered his heart. However, when Jesus appeared to him, that changed. Jesus knew the EXPLAIN BY date for Thomas and he knows it for you too.

content.title: How big is your God?
content.introtext:
GOD, YOUR GOD, IS AMONG YOU – GOD MAJESTIC, GOD AWESOME

DEUTERONOMY 7:21 TM
In his book, Living the good life, John Ortberg writes: ‘A friend and I were going to spend two weeks preaching in Ethiopia when it was still under Marxist rule. The underground churches there asked if I would bring 50 study Bibles. I had reservations about smuggling Bibles, but we decided to give it a shot. Sure enough, the customs agent opened the suitcases and confiscated the Bibles. A few days later we received a call that the head customs official wanted an interview with the leaders of the churches. We feared the worst – church leaders in Ethiopia spent so much time in prison, they referred to it as ‘The University.’ (This is where God would send his leaders when He really wanted them to grow. Like the biblical Joseph, some of them would actually be put in charge by the guards, when the guards wanted to go on break. They would take the bullets out of their rifles and hand them to the Christian prisoners to stand watch until they got back!) Imagine our surprise when the official said, ‘These Bibles are illegal. You may keep them on one condition – you must tell no one. I want one for myself.’ Ortberg says, ‘That day my God got a little larger!’ Every time you step out in faith, your see that God is bigger than you thought and you realise the truth of Paul’s words, ‘…His power at work in us can do far more than we dare ask or imagine…’ (Ephesians 3:20 CEV).

content.title: Temporary v Permanent
content.introtext:
…WHAT GOOD IS THE BIRTHRIGHT TO ME?

GENESIS 25:32 NIV
The deal Esau made with his younger brother Jacob goes down as one of the worst of all time. After a failed hunting trip, having been without food for three days, Esau finds his brother Jacob cooking a pot of stew. ‘Give me some before I die’ he says. Jacob says, ‘Give me your birthright in exchange’. Esau replies, ‘Look, I’m about to die…what good is the birthright to me?’ The birthright entitled Esau, the firstborn, to the privilege of one day becoming head of the family. It was a position of great honour. Sadly, Esau is remembered as a man who threw it all away in a moment of weakness. He went after the wrong things in life and did stuff for the wrong reasons. His brother Jacob may have been a con man, but Esau was a fool. His appetites devoured his values. In the heat of the moment he exchanged something permanent for something temporary; something which would last for something which would fade. Esau let his God-given destiny slip away. To Esau everything was negotiable. He acted like a gambler who loses his house in a game of cards. He found out too late that some things in life can’t be replaced. There’s a lesson here for you. There will be times in your life when you are offered something temporary at the cost of something permanent. It’s never worth it! Don’t be someone who gambles with God’s good gifts. The word for you today is, ‘…Hang in there, even if your life’s flashing before your eyes, I’ll give you the life crown with your name on it’. (Revelation 2:10 Street)

content.title: Pass it on!
content.introtext:
…THIS IS THE WONDERFUL MESSAGE HE HAS GIVEN US TO TELL OTHERS.

2 CORINTHIANS 5:19 NLT
Why don’t we share our faith with others: a) we’re not sure of it b) we don’t know how c) we fear rejection. But do you really want to be pulling out one of those excuses when you stand before the throne of God?’ Paul writes, ‘…my life is worth nothing unless I use it for doing the work assigned to me by the Lord Jesus – the work of telling others the Good News about God’s wonderful kindness and love’ (Acts 20:24 NLT). You don’t have to use fancy words; you just have to share the story! What story? Listen: ‘The word became flesh and blood, and moved into the neighbourhood. We saw the glory with our own eyes, the one-of-a-kind glory, like father, like son, generous inside and out, true from start to finish’ (John 1.14 TM). It’s amazing – Jesus left heaven and came to earth with all its hurt, sorrow and sin. When you tell your friends about Jesus you can let them know that he understands all their frustration and pain. The charity Christian Aid have a slogan, ‘we believe in life before death’ – and we should too! Heaven is an awesome thing to look forward to but it’s not the ONLY thing we have to look forward to. Take the pressure off yourself! You don’t have to bust a gut to convince or convert anybody; just share with them the answers you’ve found to the questions they’re facing. Bit by bit they’ll come to see that their life really does fit into God’s big story, a story with a fantastic ending!

content.title: Shattering the perfection lie
content.introtext:
…IN CHRIST…WE FIND OUT WHO WE ARE AND WHAT WE ARE LIVING FOR…

EPHESIANS 1:11 TM
Dr. David Burns writes books on relationships. He says, ‘Remember that fear always lurks behind perfectionism. Confronting your fears and allowing yourself the right to be human can, paradoxically, make you a far happier and more productive person.’ The media and the entertainment industry spend millions daily bombarding you with impossible images of airbrushed perfection. They try to make you think you should be thinner, more fashionable; anything other than who God made you to be. Looking around, it’s easy to just see are people who seem happier, cleverer and cooler than you. It’s like they know the secret and you don’t. Do you realize that by constantly putting yourself down, you’re insulting your Maker? God’s Word says you are ‘…made…in an amazing and wonderful way…’ (Psalm 139:14 NCV). In His eyes you’re ‘just right’ because He never makes anything that isn’t. God made you unique and for a special purpose. Paul says it’s in Christ that ‘we find out who we are and what we are living for.’ So if you’re struggling in the endless quest for perfection, make this your prayer: ‘Father, You are my Maker, my Sustainer, my Rewarder. You’re the Lover of my soul. In spite of my weakness and struggles I thank You for the work You’ve done, and continue to do in me. Help me to please You by loving and accepting myself the way You do. In Jesus’ Name, Amen.’

content.title: Just for today!
content.introtext:
THIS IS THE DAY THE LORD HAS MADE; WE WILL REJOICE AND BE GLAD IN IT.

PSALM 118:24 NIV
Take a moment to think about that verse from Psalm 118 and ask yourself, ‘Is this how I live?’ If not, make some changes! Start with today; don’t worry about tomorrow. Say to yourself, ‘Just for today, I’ll enjoy each moment to the full and try not to tackle my whole life’s problems at once. Just for today, I’ll try to improve my mind by learning more than I know; I’ll read my Bible because it’s my source of wisdom and strength. I’ll be open to those Scriptures that require obedience, action, and commitment. Just for today, I’ll be agreeable, wear a smile and make sure my words are ‘seasoned with grace.’ Just for today, I won’t find fault or try to change or improve anyone – except myself. Just for today, I’ll have a plan and a goal which I’ll reach towards and chase after. Just for today I’ll develop my character. I’ll do a random act of kindness and keep it secret; if anyone finds out it won’t count. Just for today, I’ll do something I don’t naturally want to do, which will train my spirit to rule my flesh and my faith to rule my emotions. Just for today, I won’t be afraid to love or to risk; I’ll take steps of faith that stretch me beyond my present comfort zone, I’ll enjoy all God’s blessings, and believe that every seed I sow in His Kingdom will be multiplied back to me many times over. This is how I’ll live – just for today – and when tomorrow comes, I’ll do it again!’

content.title: The last minute
content.introtext:
…THE LORD’S RETURN WILL SURPRISE US...

2 PETER 3:10-11 CEV
You can get T-shirts these days printed with designs that say ‘Jesus is coming – look busy!’ But seriously though, we need to be regularly reminded that Jesus is coming back soon. Critics have always poked fun and cast doubt by saying, ‘…what’s happened to the promise of his Coming?…everything’s going on just like it always has…Nothing’s changed’ (2 Peter 3:4 TM). But the second coming of Jesus is not just some flimsy hope, the New Testament refers to it over 300 times! Peter says, ‘The Lord isn’t slow about keeping his promises…[His] return will surprise us…so…honour God by the way you live…make certain [He] finds you pure, spotless, and living at peace’ (2 Peter 3:9-14 CEV). Paul adds, ‘…the Lord…will come down from heaven…Christians who have died will rise…we who are…alive…will be caught up…to meet the Lord…and remain with him forever’ (1 Thessalonians 4:16-17 NLT). So, are you ‘looking for the blessed hope…the appearing of…Jesus’ (Titus 2:13 NAS)? Are you living like it could be tomorrow; or even today! Are you reaching out to your mates, grabbing every opportunity to sprinkle salt and shed light? (See Matthew 5:13-14). You should be! If the Apostle John could tell people 2000 years ago ‘…this is the last hour…’ (1 John 2:18 NIV) then we must now be in the last minute. Wow! What an awesome time to be alive!

content.title: The life-cycle
content.introtext:
…A GRAIN OF WHEAT…IF IT IS BURIED…SPROUTS AND REPRODUCES…MANY TIMES...

JOHN 12:24 TM
Wheat can’t be planted and harvested in the same season. In order for it to ‘sprout and reproduce’ the seed must be buried deep in the ground where nobody sees it. There it undergoes a complete transformation as the seasons pass by, soaking the soil with rain and sun. In the same way, God’s purposes for your life can’t be rushed. You can only carry them, like seed in your heart, let them grow, then harvest them whenever He says it’s time. Every living thing has a life cycle, a process from infancy to maturity, from frailty to strength. When God plants a dream in your heart He starts preparing you for its fulfilment. He strengthens your character. He deepens your spiritual roots. But because we don’t understand His timing we get frustrated and try to rush things. It may be weeks, months, or even years from when you first sense something stirring within you, until the time you actually start living the reality of it. Do you think you’re growing a seed that can’t be harvested just yet; one that needs to go through more stages of its lifecycle? If so, don’t risk wrecking it by trying to bring it out prematurely. Instead, trust God’s timing. Remember, there’s not one instance in the Bible where He was ever late! In the meantime, just get on with enjoying life. That shouldn’t be too hard to do; if God has planted His seed in your heart, and it’s growing, you’ve obviously got a lot to look forward to in the years ahead.

content.title: Talking about worship
content.introtext:
…GOD IS SPIRIT, SO THOSE WHO WORSHIP HIM MUST WORSHIP IN SPIRIT AND IN TRUTH.

JOHN 4:24 NLT
Here are 3 things about worship for you to chew on today: 1) There is no ‘correct’ style of worship. The worship style you feel comfortable with says far more about your cultural background and personal preferences than it does about your faith. True worship is an expression of both emotion and intellect, heart and mind. Jesus gave only two requirements for true worship ‘in spirit and in truth.’ 2) You don’t need a building to worship God. There’s nothing wrong with buildings, unless you start loving them instead of God. The Bible says ‘“…the Lord of heaven and earth does not live in temples built by hands’ (Acts 17:24 NIV). No building, or the lack of one, should ever be allowed to control, limit or distract you from worshipping God. Jesus said, ‘…where two or three come together in my name, there am I with them’ (Matthew 18:20 NIV). 3) Worship makes a powerful statement. More people are won to Christ by feeling God’s presence, than by all our clever arguments. Not many people are converted to Christ on purely intellectual grounds. No, it’s getting a sense of the reality of God with us that melts hearts; His love breaks through mental barriers. In true worship God’s presence is felt, God’s pardon is offered, God’s purposes are revealed, and God’s power is displayed. When the spiritually hungry are brought into an atmosphere of worship, where people are pouring out their hearts to God, it creates in them a desire to know Him too!

content.title: Trading in your old net!
content.introtext:
“…FROM NOW ON YOU WILL FISH FOR PEOPLE.”

LUKE 5:10 NCV
When you choose to follow Jesus you always get back more than you give. Always! When Jesus asked these fishermen if He could use their boat they were happy to oblige. It had been a pretty boring night out on the lake, they’d caught absolutely zilch. All they had left to do was clean their nets, then head home and catch some zeds. But using their boat as a platform, the life-giving words of Jesus began to carry over the water to the crowd on the shore. The fishermen sat in the back of the boat listening as they rinsed the nets. Then the crowd left and Jesus said, ‘…“Put out into deep water, and let down the nets for a catch.”’ (Luke 5.4 NIV) They were completely unprepared for what came next. Their net was suddenly filled with fish. It was only the help of some friends in nearby boats that saved them from sinking under the weight! By the time the boat reached the shore its net was torn to shreds. Fishing was all they knew; what would they do tomorrow? Then they heard the Master say, ‘Follow me.’ And today He’s saying the same to you. These men laid down the tools of their old life and followed Jesus into a new one. In just a few short years God would use them to change their world. What did they give up in exchange? The tattered remains of an old lifestyle. Whatever’s keeping you from following Jesus, take a long hard look at it today. If you decide to lay it down and follow Him, you’ll never regret it!

content.title: ‘I’m loved by God!’
content.introtext:
…YOU ARE PRECIOUS AND HONORED IN MY SIGHT…BECAUSE I LOVE YOU...’

ISAIAH 43:4 NIV
One of the most awesome promises in the Bible is found in Isaiah Chapter 43 ‘…you are mine. When you pass through the waters, I will be with you; and when you pass through the rivers, they will not sweep over you. When you walk through the fire, you will not be burned…For I am the Lord, your God…you are precious and honoured in my sight, and…I love you…’ (Isaiah 43:1-4 NIV). Why not write down that last phrase on a card and carry it with you: ‘…you are precious and honoured in my sight…I love you…’ Wow! You are loved by God. Who else do you need to impress? What other ladder do you need to climb? What are you going to add to your CV that’ll top that? Make your life a showcase of living in the love of God. Every morning when you wake up let your first words be ‘I’m loved by God.’ And every night when you go to sleep let your last words echo, ‘I’m loved by God.’ As every day goes by you’ll start understanding more and more deeply just how amazing those four little words are. When you’re tempted to jack it all in because you’ve blown it, remember, ‘I’m loved by God’ When you’re overwhelmed by all the stuff you have to do, say it: ‘I’m loved by God’. Say it when you’re tempted to sin, to dishonour God, to lash out in anger and hurt someone, or deceive someone, or use someone. Say it when you’re afraid, when you’re anxious, when you’re alone… remember and feast on the words that give life: ‘I’m loved by God.’

content.title: Keep your head down!
content.introtext:
…IF WE ARE TO SHARE HIS GLORY, WE MUST ALSO SHARE HIS SUFFERING.

ROMANS 8:17 NLT
It’s exciting to talk about the blessings of following Jesus, but Paul writes: ‘If we are to share his glory, we must also share his suffering.’ That changes things, doesn’t it? The only time the crowd cheered Jesus was when they thought He was gonna overthrow the Romans. The only time Jesus was above anybody was when they nailed Him to the cross. He died like a common criminal. Very few believed He’d risen. Now Jesus says to us, ‘…[If you] intend to come with me…Don’t run from suffering; embrace it…’ (Matthew 16:24 TM). Easier said than done right?! Taking flack because you’re a Jesus freak is never easy. You’ll need shed-loads of character, discipline, love and vision. Why vision? Check this out; when He comes back He won’t take the spotlight alone. Oh no. Listen: ‘When Christ, who is your life, appears…you also will appear with him in glory’ (Colossians 3:4 NIV). Did you get that? Until Christ returns, we have a serving role not a starring one! But later, after the final curtain falls, we get to join Jesus for the encore, taking our place in the line-up of the greatest cast in all of history. Jesus told the religious leaders of His day that if you get the applause of men now, enjoy it, coz it’s at the expense of the honour God will give you later. The higher your calling takes you, the more vulnerable you become to pride, so for now, keep your head down. John the Baptist said, ‘He must increase, but I must decrease’ (John 3:30 KJV). And John got it right!

content.title: Even though…
content.introtext:
…GIVE THANKS WHATEVER HAPPENS…

1 THESSALONIANS 5:18 NCV
If you tend to look at what’s negative in life rather than what’s positive, here’s a prayer just for you! ‘Even though I hide under my duvet and growl when the alarm goes off, thank You Lord that I can hear; there are many who are deaf. Even though I close my eyes as long as possible against the morning light, thank You Lord that I can see; there are many who are blind. Even though I put off the effort to get up thank You Lord that I have the strength to get up; there are many who are bedridden. Even though the first hour of my day is hectic when socks are lost, toast is burned and tempers are short, thank You Lord for my family; there are many who are all alone. Even though I never look like the pictures in the magazines thank You Lord for the clothes I have; there are many who have no choice. Even though my school is sometimes boring, thank You for the opportunity to learn; there are many who don’t get the chance. Even though I complain from time to time and wish things were different, thank You for the gift of life; there are people in the graveyard who would gladly change places with me. Even though I make mistakes, stumble and fall, thank You for the grace to get up again; there are many who didn’t make it. Thank You Lord for all these blessings – and 101 others that I’ve taken for granted. Amen.’

content.title: Why pray?
content.introtext:
…WHEN A BELIEVING PERSON PRAYS, GREAT THINGS HAPPEN.

JAMES 5:16 NCV
Why pray? Because nothing lies beyond the reach of prayer. You’ll never know how many people have made it through a tough day because you asked God to encourage them. Or how many are healed because you stood with them in faith. Or how many spiritual runaways have come home because you pleaded with God to get on their case. None of us will ever know the full effect of our prayers this side of heaven, but we know this: God’s kingdom on earth comes through people who pray. Through prayer we’re invited to chat with God; a two way chat that involves both talking and listening. Prayer is ‘talking with God about what we are doing together’ as author Dallas Willard puts it. Have you ever thought that actually, besides all the cool stuff that gets done through prayer, the greatest thing of all is the joining of our heart with God’s heart. Lots of people on their deathbed end up regretting their obsession with work, money, pleasure and power. But have you ever heard of anyone who regretted spending too much time in prayer? An old minister once said, ‘Prayer does not consist of battering the walls of Heaven for personal benefit or the success of our plans. Rather, it’s the committing of ourselves to carrying out God’s purposes. It’s not bending God’s will to ours, but our will to His. In prayer we tap reservoirs of spiritual power whereby God can find fuller entrance into the hearts of men.’ Why pray? Because everybody knows, you start to become like the people you spend most time with.

content.title: A-level love
content.introtext:
…ANYONE WHO SACRIFICES…WILL GET IT ALL BACK A HUNDRED TIMES OVER...

MATTHEW 19:29 TM
A-level’ stands for ‘Advanced level’, it’s beyond the ordinary, a cut above the rest. A-level love is about work, not play; it’s about being a servant, not a hero. Jesus said, ‘…Whoever wants to be great must become a servant…’ (Mark 10:43-45 TM). You can give without loving, but you can’t love without giving. Real fulfilment can’t be found by only looking after numero uno! One Christian leader writes: ‘When I set about the task of loving, I usually end up giving instead of receiving. Love inevitably costs me three commodities that are most precious; my time, energy and money. I don’t part with these easily…because I have them in limited quantities…It’s time to strip away the false glamour, and tell the truth: true love is sacrificial.’ Another Christian leader says, ‘When I get up each morning I remind myself that today I may be called upon to give more love, more care and more patience than I get back. In times of sickness and hardship I’m required to do this for weeks or months on end. But then it’s my turn and God gives it back, either through my family or someone else. Either way it always comes back in an amount equal to my need.’ Peter wondered if it was all worth-while when he asked ‘We have left everything and followed you. What do we get out of it?’ Jesus replied, “…anyone who sacrifices…because of me will get it all back a hundred times over…”’ (Matthew 19:29 TM). A-level love may cost you - in time, energy and moments of heartache - but gives back so much more.

content.title: Forgiveness!
content.introtext:
…I AM THE ONE WHO TAKES CARE OF YOUR SINS - THAT’S WHAT I DO...

ISAIAH 43:25 MSG
In Old Testament days when a man ‘blew it,’ he brought a lamb to the altar as payment for his sins. But notice this: the priest didn’t examine the man, he only examined the lamb. If the lamb met God’s requirements the man was instantly forgiven. That is still how it works! When you fail, you need only approach God and say, ‘Father, I come in the name of Jesus asking for forgiveness.’ In that moment the Father’s focus moves from you to Christ, and you are automatically forgiven. What an arrangement! But you need to forgive yourself too. If you don’t, you’re saying God’s forgiveness isn’t good enough. That’s wrong! If a perfect God says He will forgive you, on what grounds do you, an imperfect person, refuse to forgive yourself – or anybody else? ‘You get nothing for nothing,’ you say. Nothing? Are you serious? God’s forgiveness is the most expensive thing in the world. It may have cost you nothing, but it cost God everything. Its pride that makes us think that somehow we’ve got to pay, at least in part, for what we’ve done. Yes, there are consequences and correction that build your character – but don’t think that’s what deals with your sin! When Jesus cried, ‘It is finished,’ and died, God wrote, ‘paid in full’ across every sin debt you’d ever owe. And you must accept that by faith. Why? Because no more will ever be required, and no less will ever be accepted!

content.title: Give what you’ve got
content.introtext:
DO NOT DESPISE THESE SMALL BEGINNINGS...

ZECHARIAH 4:10 NTL
Everything big starts with something small; all God needs is something to start with! Have you ever noticed what the disciples said to Jesus just before He fed the 5,000? Listen: ‘”Here is a boy with five small barley loaves and two small fish, but how far will they go among so many?” (John 6:9 NIV). Sound familiar? The challenge is too massive and you’re too tiny. Realise this: the miracle of provision only started when they took what they had and put it into the Master’s hands. As long as you try to make it happens and control it, it won’t happen. But the moment you give what you’ve got to God, it will start to grow. Imagine, just a boy’s lunch – all God needs is something to start with. The prophet Zechariah wrote, ‘Do not despise these small beginnings, for the eyes of the LORD rejoices to see the work begin…’ (Zechariah 4:10 TLB). Don’t be afraid to take small steps. Make them steps of faith and God will work with you. Jesus said, ‘…I will build my church…’ (Matthew 16:18 TLB). Build it with what? Twelve flawed people just like you. But when He poured Himself into them it was so powerful, that when two of them got together they could turn any town upside down. ‘But I have so many weaknesses,’ you say. We all come to the Lord damaged and in need of repair. The good news is, you can be strong in certain areas and struggling in others, and God will still use you.

content.title: Your ‘ites’
content.introtext:
…THE KINGDOM OF HEAVEN HAS BEEN FORCEFULLY ADVANCING, AND FORCEFUL MEN LAY HOLD OF IT

MATTHEW 11:12 NIV
Sometimes we think God’s like Santa Claus; if we just sit and wait He will drop His blessings into our lap without any effort on our part. No. The Bible says, ‘forceful men take hold of it.’ Sometimes to get what you want from God you have to get down into trenches, grab hold of His promises and resist the enemy’s attacks in your life. Even when you are in the right place to succeed, unless you become proactive it may never be yours. Before Israel could inhabit the Promised Land they had to fight the Canaanites, the Hittites, and other ‘ites.’ So, basically to get God’s best, sometimes you need to kick some stuff out of your life. Your ‘ites’ could be a bad attitude, too lazy to care, or a low self-esteem that stops you, coz you’re afraid. Don’t let those things rule your life! In fact ‘forcefully’ push them away – God’s called you to a life of purpose and blessing. But you had to fight for it! There were 31 kings and seven nations that had to be conquered before they could move in and possess it. And they had to be dealt with one by one. Are you getting the idea? It’s not enough to be strong in faith, you must be strong in fight! The enemy’s strongholds in your life must be pulled down. Your ‘ites’ must be dealt with! God will give you the strategy and the weapons. He’ll even empower you, but you’ve got to fight for your inheritance! Plus – what you become in the process is often more valuable than what you gain on the other side of it!

content.title: 5 Big Questions
content.introtext:
…NOTHING CAN EVER SEPARATE US FROM HIS LOVE...

ROMANS 8:38 NLT
Paul asks five life-changing questions – take a minute and think them over: 1) ‘…If God is for us, who can ever be against us?’ (Romans 8:31 NLT). That means someone messes with you, they mess with the big G-O-D! 2) ‘Since God did not spare even His own Son but gave Him up for us all, won’t God… also give us everything else?’ (Romans 8:32 NLT). Would God save your souls then leave you to fend for yourself? If you can let God save you, why do you find it so hard to let God look after you? 3) ‘Who dares accuse us… ? Will God? No! He is the one who has given us right standing with himself’ (Romans 8:33 NLT). Every voice that accuses you, including your own, must shut up in the face of God. Through Jesus – no accusation can stand. 4) ‘Who then will condemn us?...the one who died for us…is sitting at the place of highest honour next to God, pleading for us.’ (Romans 8:34 NLT). Let your accusers rise up and speak against you. Jesus, your defender, silences them. Why? Because you’re a child of God and no one messes with God’s kids. 5) ‘Can anything ever separate us from Christ’s love?...’ (Romans 8:35 NLT). Paul answers his own question: ‘Death can’t, and life can’t. The angels can’t, and the demons can’t. Our fears for today, our worries about tomorrow, and even the powers of hell can’t keep God’s love away…nothing in all creation will ever be able to separate us from the love of God that is revealed in Christ Jesus our Lord’ (Romans 8:38-39 NLT).

content.title: How awesome is that?
content.introtext:
…IT IS MARVELLOUS IN OUR EYES

MATTHEW 21:42 NIV
The heroes of the Bible were powerful, but they weren’t perfect. They were disciplined, but never discarded. Does that make you believe that you can be used by God too? Paul was the first to admit that he didn’t always hit the mark, yet the life He led, the challenges He faced and got through still sets our pace two millennia later. God’s perfect word can be communicated through normal people, what a responsibility! It’s through ordinary people He fulfils His plan. How awesome is that?! Listen: ‘…whose weakness was turned to strength…’ (Hebrews 11:34 NIV). God’s heroes were strengthened through struggle. Don’t judge them by one weak moment, judge them by the whole of their lives. The dent in their armour didn’t affect their performance on the battlefield. Why does God use people like that? Because: a) ‘…My [His] strength comes into its own in your weakness’ (2 Corinthians 12:9 TM) b) He’s not limited by our limitations (Ephesians 3:20) c) He uses what’s available (1 Corinthians 1:27). How awesome is that?! Listen: ‘When you mess up it’s not the end of the story. You have a choice to dust yourself off, get up on your feet and try again. If you stop at the first hurdle, it’s like agreeing with all the lies of the devil; he would love you to believe that you’re all alone and once you’ve failed you can’t take the test again. Rubbish! Our Bible heroes made some big mistakes, but as their lives went on they learnt that if you say, “I can’t do this on my own; help me, God”, He steps in and does everything in His power to help – how awesome is that?

content.title: Am I a dreamer?
content.introtext:
…”HERE COMES THAT DREAMER. LET’S KILL HIM...

GENESIS 37:19-20 TM
Joseph was a dreamer; his life teaches us the following lessons: 1) Don’t give up on your dream, even though it might be a rough ride. At 17 Joseph dreamt that one day his family would bow down to him. But he made the huge mistake of telling them about it. It got him into a whole heap of trouble. But it didn’t stop him. Joseph talked, before he understood. Sometimes what we think something means isn’t always the case. If God has spoken to you, give it time to get rooted in your heart, before you strut about it. 2) Don’t give up on your dream, though others don’t always get it. Joseph’s brothers said, ‘Look, this dreamer is coming . . . let us now kill him.’ It is hard to keep your dream alive when some people are trying to kill it. But when your dream comes from God; it holds you, even when you are can’t hold it! 3) Don’t give up on your dream, though your life is full of surprises. A God-dream will invite attack; don’t let that discourage you! Attack means your dream is a threat. Take it as a compliment – the devil is worried. It says five times: ‘The Lord was with Joseph.’ Check this: He’s with you too! 4) Don’t give up on your dream, though it takes time to fulfil. Twenty-three years passed before Joseph’s dream actually came true, but in the end he ruled his family, made friends with his brothers, and saved the nation. Not bad going, eh? Fact: God will work in His time frame. But remember, if it’s a God-dream, He gave it to you in the first place – it’s for a purpose. The important thing to remember is – never give up on your dream!

content.title: The 4 Powers of Praise
content.introtext:
PRAISE…GOD…AND…MAGNIFY HIM WITH THANKSGIVING

PSALM 69:30 NAS
When Dr. Robert Schuller, founder of California’s Crystal Cathedral, was growing up, drought ravaged their family farm. They prayed for rain that never came. His Dad, who normally harvested 100 wagon loads of corn, reaped only half a wagon full. Schuller says, ‘I’ll never forget it. His calloused hands holding ours as he looked up and prayed, “Thank you Lord, I’ve lost nothing. I’ve regained all the seed I planted in spring.” While other farmers were saying, “We lost 90 or 100 loads,” my father told me, “Never count the might-have-beens or you will be defeated. Never look at what you have lost, only look at what you have left”’ Top advice! King David said, ‘Praise . . . God . . . and . . . magnify him with thanksgiving,’ because gratitude has: a) driving power. Paul says, ‘…thanks be to God, who always leads us in victory…’ (2 Corinthians 2:14 NCV). Thanksgiving helps you make the hard decisions. It gives you courage to believe against all odds b) energising power. Listen: ‘…Don’t ever stop thinking about what is…worthy of praise…And God, who gives peace, will be with you’ (Philippians 4:8-9 CEV). Stop and remind yourself of God’s goodness. It gives you perspective and strength c) persevering power. Gratitude gives you the oomph to ‘press on’. Paul could ‘press on’ because his goals included knowing Jesus (see Philippians 3:14 NIV), and seeing a lost world saved (see Romans 10:1). What goals are you striving for? d) arriving power. When you reach your destination you will find you have developed selflessness and humility.

content.title: Life was meant for living
content.introtext:
”YOU KNOW EVERYTING I’M GOING TO SAY BEFORE I START THE FIRST SENTENCE”

PSALM 139:4 MSG
Did you know that no one on earth has the same eye colour? Each eye has a different pattern and blend of colours – no two pairs of eyes are the same. No one else has the same finger print as you – that’s amazing – no one else in all the world. God is the greatest designer, with an artist’s eye for colour and an architect’s intricate attention to detail. When He set about making you, not only did He make you like no other, but He knew what plan He had for your life even before He spoke, ‘Let there be light’, and the sun was born. He knows you, better than your mates or your Mum and Dad, and He knows you better than you know yourself. Check this: ‘You know everything I’m going to say before I start the first sentence’ (Psalm 139:4 MSG). Doesn’t that blow your mind? You might be saying to yourself, Why does He bother with me? Listen: ‘For we are God's masterpiece. He has created us anew in Christ Jesus, so that we can do the good things he planned for us long ago.’ (Ephesians 2:10 NLT). God has unlimited time just for you. He can’t get enough of you. You make Him happy. The whole point of creation was for God be in a relationship with you. Yep – to be your God but also your best friend. Just like an artist loves their work, God is passionate about His prize creation, you are His ‘handiwork’. Know this – you are loved and you have a purpose. Life was meant for living – enjoy!

content.title: Are you meant to fit in?
content.introtext:
…FIX YOUR ATTENTION ON GOD...

ROMANS 12:2 MSG
There is so much going on around you it can be really hard to sift through the noise and find the still small voice of God whispering to you. The media has so much influence on your life, through soaps, reality shows, magazines etc. And everyone seems to have an opinion on something; ‘So and so is too fat or too thin’, or ‘What’s hot and what’s not this season’. The thing is, what one magazine says one day can change the next; a lot of the articles are based on speculation from a bunch of bad photos. What’s true and what is false has become blurred. So in all this noise, how do you know how to tell what God is saying? Well, the Bible gives us loads of tips to help us; here’s a few of them: Tip no.1) ‘Plans go wrong for lack of advice – many counsellors bring success.’ God puts people around you who are wise and trustworthy; take advantage of that. If you need advice, ask. Tip no 2) ‘Trust in the LORD with all your heart…and He will make your paths straight…’ (Proverbs 3:5-6 NIV). Put your trust in him – He is faithful and as you acknowledge Him He promises to make your way straight and clear. Tip no 3) ‘Don’t become so well-adjusted to your culture that you fit into it without even thinking. Instead, fix your attention on God. You’ll be changed from the inside out…’ (Romans 12:2 MSG) God doesn’t want you immune to His voice – He wants you to know it well and follow it. Focus is the key; don’t lose sight of God and ‘You’ll be changed from the inside out!’

content.title: In-between
content.introtext:
…WAIT. IT’S ON ITS WAY. IT WILL COME RIGHT ON TIME

HABAKKUK 2:3 MSG
Waiting isn’t easy, but it’s necessary. God is working on both ends of the line; He’s getting you ready for it (even when you don’t know what it is), and He’s getting it ready for you. Look at Joshua. He’s been to the Promised Land, now he got to go back and live with a bunch of people who have no idea, and in most cases no interest in what he’s talking about. Can you relate? To get from one place to another there is always a journey of some kind. It’s hard to let go of what you know and stand empty handed waiting for God to fill them, especially in the area of: a) The feelings: Face your anger and decide to let it go. You might feel empty for a time, but that’s normal. You’re in-between pain and the peace that comes from forgiveness and acceptance. Don’t panic! It will pass. b) The relationship: When you let go of someone it can be hard, because you’ feel a sense of loss. Don’t rush into another relationship to fill the gap. Talk to God; you need this time to heal and let Him fill any holes in your heart. c) The situation: You have let go of the old but you are not sure if you can handle what’s next, or even when it’s coming. When Jesus said, ‘”…Let us go over to the other side”’ (Mark 4:35 NIV), the lessons His disciples learned in-between changed them forever – and they will change you too!

content.title: Esther
content.introtext:
…IF I PERISH, I PERISH!

ESTHER 4:16 NIV
Esther was born a slave in captivity. Because of her beauty a pagan king made her one of his wives. Talk about feeling out of place! But no place is out of place when you are in God’s place. When Haman plotted to have all the Jews killed, Esther was put in the right place by God to save them. Esther discovered her life’s purpose when her Uncle Mordy said, ‘”…who knows whether you have come to the kingdom for such a time as this?”’ (Esther 4:14 NKJV). And what was her response? Listen: ‘”…I will go to the king, which is against the law; and if I perish, I perish!”’ (Esther 4:16 NKJV). So what do we learn from Esther? 1) Sometimes you won’t understand God’s timing or His plan for your life. But just because you don’t understand God’s plan right now doesn’t mean He doesn’t care, or doesn’t have one. Seek Him. He will show it to you – step by step! 2) When you discover God’s plan for your life you feel empowered. Whether you are a slave or a queen, when you know God’s called you it enables you to deal with each obstacle as it happens. 3) Taking a risk is easier when you know that God’s in control. When Esther said, ‘”…if I perish, I perish!”’ she wasn’t being dramatic; she was simply putting herself in God’s hands, she knew that even death is something that can be faced with confidence when you trust God. You see, not only does God have a place for you here on earth; He also has one waiting for you in Heaven. So you can’t lose, can you?

content.title: Misunderstood
content.introtext:
…PRAY FOR THOSE WHO MISTREAT YOU

LUKE 6:28 NIV
If you feel misunderstood today, Jesus understands. Critics joked about Jesus being born in a stable, questioned that He was God, even accused Him of belonging to satan. They rejected His teachings, were jealous of His success, critical of how He did stuff and wound up by His message. And in the end, they put Him to death. John writes, ‘The Light shines in the darkness, and the darkness did not comprehend it…He came to His own, and those who were His own did not receive Him’ (John 1:5&11 NAS). Whoever thought up the saying, ‘Sticks and stones may break my bones, but names will never hurt me,’ is completely wrong! Nothing is further from the truth. Unfair names and ugly words do harm us, and that harm can last a lifetime. We need to be careful what we say to other people, especially to the people we love. When you’ve been misunderstood, ask: ‘What can I learn from this experience? Could I have responded to the situation in a better way? Have I acknowledged my mistakes?’ Learning from misunderstanding can make you wiser and stop future pain. The bottom line is, the answer to misunderstanding is – forgiveness! Forgiveness doesn’t mean you agree, or that you even want a close relationship with your offender. But it does mean you let it go – FOREVER! That means don’t just forgive it; forget it. Here’s a quote to scribble in big letters in your notebook: ‘To be great, is to forgive the one who misunderstood you.’

content.title: Mafia boss or gossip?
content.introtext:
…I RECOGNISE MY SHAMEFUL DEEDS...

PSALM 51:3 NLT
King David is probably the guy most referred to in churches for having an amazing friendship with God. He had a deep connection with the creator that still challenges so many people today. But David was no super-hero; he made some spectacularly bad choices too. If you read his story, you’ll probably think you’re like a saint in comparison – adultery, murder and destruction – David did it all! So what made Dave so special? Answer: he recognised that what he had done was wrong and did all that he could to make it right with God. You see God hates sin but He promises that if we say sorry and stop doing the bad stuff and truly change our ways, He will forgive us and even turn our bad situations around for our good and His glory. We’re so good at pointing out other peoples’ faults and excusing our own. But we forget that all sin is wrong in God’s eyes. If you’re a Mafia boss dealing drugs and killing people or if you just gossip behind your mate’s back, God sees it all in the same light. What we all need to do is look closely at our own heart and actions and recognise those things that you know God wouldn’t like. Take your faults to God. Don’t be scared coz He loves you and wants to help you deal with that stuff. You’ll be amazed how quick God is to forgive and how much freedom you’ll feel knowing you’re forgiven.

content.title: Check your head
content.introtext:
…TAKE EVERY THOUGHT CAPTIVE AND MAKE IT OBEDIENT TO CHRIST

2CORINTHIANS 10:5 NLT
We all make mistakes – no one is without fault, but what makes us go from having a bad thought to actually doing bad stuff? Well it’s all to do with the way we deal with that thought. Our thoughts are powerful and there is a war going on for your mind, coz the devil knows a bad thought can give birth to bad actions. That’s why Paul says, ‘…take every thought captive and make it obedient to Christ.’ How do we do that? Someone once said, ‘Your mind is like a nest and your thoughts are like birds flying over it. It’s up to you what birds you allow to nest there.’ All through the day, random thoughts fly through our heads, but what we choose to focus on can really influence our actions. For example, if we focus on all the negative thoughts we have about ourselves each day, we can end up believing that they are true and end up with a bad self image. Taking our thoughts captive just means controlling what we think about and dwell on. We sometimes need to make a choice to focus our minds on what God says about us. The more we do that, the more our thought processes and decisions will come from the healthiest source. It’s important to read the Bible because it is full of what God thinks and we need to know His opinion above all others, so that our thoughts stay healthy and influence our actions and choices.

content.title: Keep it ssshhhhhhh!
content.introtext:
WHEN YOU GIVE…DON’T SHOUT ABOUT IT!...

MATTHEW 6:2 NLT
Listen: ‘When you give…don’t shout about it as the hypocrites do…to call attention to their acts of charity! I assure you they have received all the reward, they will ever get.’ (Matthew 6:2 NLT). That means don’t insist on having a plaque with your name on it coz you gave a few quid to a charity… you don’t give to make yourself look good! Jesus shows the perfect way to give, ‘…when you give to someone, don't tell your left hand what your right hand is doing…and your Father, who knows all secrets, will reward you.‘ (Matthew 6:3-4 NLT). Give generously. Give gladly. But keep it ssssshhhhh! Your giving is nobody’s business – it’s just between you and God. If you broadcast your giving you immediately have your reward, 10 seconds of glory. But you give up the chance to receive something even better when you get to Heaven. And you will receive it. Listen: ‘God is not unjust; he will not forget your work and the love which you have shown him as you have helped his people and continue to help them [served others]’ (Hebrews 6:10 NIV). That’s a promise you can trust. Next time you’re sat in church, remember there are loads of faithful people around you who have given, and given again, and told no one. You may be one of them. Every Sunday you’re rubbing shoulders with some of the great givers of our day. And they’ve done it for God by keeping it to themselves. Others may never know, but God will never forget. How good is that?

content.title: No Risk, No Reward
content.introtext:
MAKE A CAREFUL EXPLORATION OF WHO YOU ARE...

GALATIANS 6:4 TM
Take a good look at your life and decide to make it count. Life’s saddest words are found on a tombstone that reads: ‘When it came time to die, I had not lived.’ It’s flippin’ scary to take risks and try new things. We think, ‘What if I fail?’ What if you do? It won’t be your first mistake. And no matter how bad it is it probably won’t be your worst. And unless you fail at something really spectacular like attempting to climb Mount Everest or swim the English Channel and die doing it, it probably won’t be your last mistake. One thing you can count on, whatever happens you’ll grow up; in wisdom, experience and character. Basically, you’ll be wiser for just having a crack at it. Rick Warren who wrote ‘Purpose Driven Life’ remembers: ‘I could have taken a hundred gift and ability tests as a young man and would never have discovered that I was gifted at teaching, because I had never done it! It was only after I began accepting opportunities to speak that I saw the results, received confirmation from others and realised God has gifted me to do this.’ Unless you’re willing to risk getting involved you’re not gonna know what you’re good at. The road to success is never mistake-free. But then, neither is the road to failure. The choice is yours. That’s why Paul writes, ‘Make a careful exploration of who you are and the work you have been given, and then sink yourself into that…’ (Galatians 6:4 TM). No risk, no reward!

content.title: Free 2B yourself!
content.introtext:
…[A MAN MUST BE CONTENT TO RECEIVE THE GIFT WHICH IS GIVEN HIM FROM HEAVEN...

JOHN 3:27 AMP
Has it dawned on you how much ‘they’ control your life? They say what’s cool and we wear it, drive it, quote it or do it! Now that may be okay in some areas, but not when it comes to your life’s direction. Jesus said, ‘…if the Son liberates you [makes you free men], then you are really and unquestionably free’ (John 8:36 AMP). That means you are: a) FREE from the peer pressure b) FREE to be who God called you to be c) FREE to look to Him for your own answers instead of always running to other people. Jesus said, ‘A man must be content to receive the gift which is given him from heaven.’ So many of us struggle with insecurity and fear of what people think. We’re competitive; we compare ourselves with others. We’re jealous of the stuff they have, their abilities and talents. We’re always trying to keep up with certain people or be like them. As a result we are totally frustrated because we are jumping our own fence, getting outside of what God has called us to be. We’re not being ourselves! You can’t run somebody else’s race. You’ll never enjoy God’s blessing to the maximum until you commit yourself to being the person God ordained you to be. No one else on this planet is you… So rise up and announce, ‘I am what I am. I can’t be anything other than what God has called me to be. So I’m gonna concentrate on being the best me I can be, and enjoy it every day!’

content.title: A God-slap
content.introtext:
IT’S THE CHILD HE LOVES THAT HE DISCIPLINES...

HEBREWS 12:6 TM
Do you want to change? To grow up in God? Real change can’t start until you understand first that God loves you as you are; otherwise you will keep trying to change yourself to earn His love and acceptance. This is pointless task ‘cause, you already have it – you just don’t know it! Most of us think that if we accept ourselves as we are, we are excusing what’s wrong in us. Rubbish! You can’t take God’s correction properly until you have a clear understanding of His love for you. Otherwise you’ll see His correction as rejection, His disapproval of your actions as disapproval of you. To grow up in God you need to believe that God is committed to you, and He will tell you when you’re way off target, and will guide you along the best pathway for your life (see Psalm 32:8). During those times you need to know His love for you is not just wishy washy – it can be tough love – now and again you may get a God-slap! The Apostle Paul was 100% convinced that nothing could EVER separate him from God’s love (Romans 8:39). Are you convinced? You need to be! In Revelation 3:19 (NLT), God speaks to each of us and says, ‘I am the one who corrects and disciples everyone I love…’ Evidence of God’s love and approval of you is the fact that He convicts and corrects you! It’s not His correction that should worry you; it’s the absence of it! If you feel like you’re going through this right now, get happy; it means God loves you and has amazing things in store for you!

content.title: Led by God (4)
content.introtext:
FOR IT IS GOD WHO WORKS IN YOU...

PHILIPPIANS 2:13 NIV
You can’t put your life into compartments by saying, ‘In this category I’m gonna do things my way, but in that category I’m gonna be led by God.’ Every step you take must be synchronised with the beat of God’s heart! Nothing is more important than keeping pace with Him. Listen: ‘…God…works in you to will and to act according to his good purpose’ (Philippians 2:13 NIV). God works through us as we engage our minds, open our mouths, move our feet and use our hands to do what He has already put into our hearts. The moment you say ‘yes’ to God He gives what you need to do what He asks. Check this: He doesn’t show His will to you first then call you next. No, He calls you, and as you move out and obey Him He shows it to you step by step, helping you as you go. God is never content with the ‘normal’! Never! Every day in different ways He will develop you into a greater God carrier. You’re not out for a stroll, you’re on a mission. Again and again you will be given challenges and be put into situations that will mature you to the point where you have the same attitude, the same responses and the same desires as Jesus. When you start to understand that, walking with God will take on a whole new meaning. Realise that your walk with Him is the only walk that will ever satisfy you or fulfil your purpose for being on this planet.

content.title: Led by God (3)
content.introtext:
…HE WILL DIRECT YOUR PATHS

PROVERBS 3:6 NLT
Here are some examples of when hearing God about something makes all the difference. 1) Future choices. When trying to decide what’s next, look carefully at your options and ask God to make the right one clear. 2) Before you make a choice based on someone else’s idea. Why? Because peoples’ ideas aren’t God’s commands. Don’t commit yourself to stuff you can’t do and end up trapped by promises you can’t fulfil. Be there for people, but be led only by God’s Spirit. 3) When someone’s being awkward. What people say can totally effect how we think. Don’t make bad decisions because your mate is being moody – that can totally manipulate you from making the right choice. 4) At a tough time. Don’t change your college course just coz it’s a bit tough…take a minute and ask what God wants you to do. If someone asks you to do something, think first…is this something that is gonna be pleasing to God? 5) When you’re tempted. Don’t just cruise along with the crowd. Often saying ‘no’ is the right answer. Think: ‘Is this in tune with God’s heartbeat?’ 5) When you have popularity. A compliment is always nice but don’t let it navigate your decisions. Flattery just inflates the ego and can make it tough to hear God clearly. Some people will be excited by your dreams because they don’t have their own… but are you ready to carry passengers? It’s wise to share your heart with people you know have a good relationship with God.

content.title: Led by God (2)
content.introtext:
I WILL GUIDE YOU ALONG THE BEST PATHWAY FOR YOUR LIFE…

PSALM 32:8 NLT
Solomon says, ‘Many are the plans in a man’s heart, but it is the LORD’S purpose that prevails.’ (Proverbs 19:21 NIV). Even though your plans aren’t perfect, if your heart’s motive is right, God will make things work out for your good and His glory. Are you having difficulty sorting out your ideas from what He is saying? We all struggle with that, especially when the Bible doesn’t give us specifics. For example, when it’s time to go to Uni or marry or get a job, what should you do? Listen: ‘I will guide you along the best pathway for your life.’ You say, ‘That’s nice, but I’d like a little more detail.’ Okay: 1) Ideas go away but God’s direction stays. God moves at His pace and He invented you and time, so He can make it work! There is persistence in His leading, that is why time is on your side. Do not rush ahead of Him. 2) God’s direction is usually impossible to follow without Him. He plans it that way. Jesus said, ‘…without Me you can do nothing’ (John 15:5 NKJV). 3) God’s direction usually begins with discomfort. Listen: ‘like an eagle stirs up its nest…The Lord…led him…’ (Deuteronomy 32:11-12 NIV). Eagles learn to fly when their mum pushes them out of the nest and over the cliff’s edge. Can you imagine their thoughts? ‘Mum what you playing at!’ But it’s only when the eagle is forced out of its comfort zone that it discovers it was born to fly, spreads its wings, releases its power and finds its place in the heavens. Has God been stirring up your nest? Relax! He’s leading you!

content.title: Led by God (1)
content.introtext:
…ALONG UNFAMILIAR PATHS I WILL GUIDE THEM…

ISAIAH 42:16 NIV
Don’t ask God to bless your plans, ask Him to show you His – they are already blessed. When the time is right the plan will be clear, the people in place and the resources available. Peter writes. ‘Everything that goes into a life of pleasing God has been miraculously given to us…’ (2 Peter 1:3 TM). Did you hear that? Everything! God told Abraham when to leave home (see Genesis 12:1), and Jacob when to go back home (see Genesis 31:3). He even told Elijah where to find food in the middle of a famine (see 1 Kings 17:1-5). And His promise to you is ‘…along unfamiliar paths I will guide them...’ The path you are on today may be unfamiliar to you but it’s not to God. He has already gone ahead of you. All you need is the faith to step out and follow Him. God never changes. If He talked to people all through the Bible He’ll talk to you too. Question is, have you learned to recognise His voice yet? Nothing should be more important to you than learning to hear from God for yourself. Other people’s ideas should only confirm or clarify what He’s already shown you. If you have not heard from God you will be tempted to think that human ideas are His commands – and that could hurt you. Listen: God has a personal plan and a specific destination for you. Take the time to ask Him about it. His Word says, ‘He guides the humble in what is right and teaches them his way’ (Psalm 25:9 NIV).

content.title: Keep on keeping on!
content.introtext:
I PRESS ON…

PHILIPPIANS 3:14 NAS
When the bottom falls out what should you do? Blame somebody else? That only makes you bitter. Wallow in self-pity? That only paralyses you and alienates those around you. When David returned from battle and found his home burned to the ground and his family taken prisoner, he cried till he had no tears left to cry. But then we read, ‘…David strengthened himself in the LORD his God’ (1 Samuel 30:6 NAS). That’s it! You have got to learn how to get alone and give yourself a good talking to! You have got to learn how to pray for yourself and speak God’s promises to yourself. Here is one worth quoting: ‘…Weeping may go on all night, but joy comes with the morning’ (Psalm 30:5 NTL). Did you get that? Joy is coming! Help is on the way! You must learn how to rise up and say, ‘What does not destroy me will only make me stronger. No day lasts forever. This too shall pass. In the meantime I will let it drive me closer to God.’ Come on – start talking to yourself! Your weakness can be the discovery point for strengths you never knew you had. It is the biggest battles that produce the biggest victories. When Joseph recalled the worst time of his life he said, ‘…God turned into good what you meant for evil…’ (Genesis 50:20 NLB). Others do not control your destiny, God does, and He’s not like others! You will come out of this a better person. Look beyond the pain and you will find perspective. The word for you today is – Take a deep breath, refocus, and keep pressing on!’

content.title: Make it right!
content.introtext:
…GO…AND MAKE THINGS RIGHT...

MATTHEW 5:24 TM
One of the reasons we love Jesus is because He wasn’t stuck up. He allowed a prostitute named Mary to anoint His feet, while the religious crowd looked on making judgements. He chilled with tax collectors, the most hated, dishonest blokes in town ‘because He knew they needed Him just as much as anybody else. He took risks on people. Listen: ‘…God is not ashamed to be called their God…’ (Hebrews 11:16 NIV). If God was not ashamed of the likes of Zacchaeus and Mary, then He’s not ashamed of you. If God could brag about the faith of a Rahab (another prostitute) beside people like Esther and Moses, who are we to judge anybody? Jesus had a massive impact on the people he met. Like Zacchaeus, the cheating tax collector, who, on meeting Jesus, cried out, ‘”...Lord! Here and now I give half my possessions to the poor, and if I have cheated anybody out of anything, I will pay back four times the amount”’ (Luke 19:8 NIV). Understand this: the root of all inner healing rests on our willingness to forgive, and when possible, to make things right with those we have hurt. There is no statute of limitations in God’s Kingdom when it comes to responsibility. If you owe someone a debt, pay it. If you have hurt them, apologise and try to make it right. Jesus said, ‘…If you…remember a grudge a friend has against you…leave immediately, go…and make things right…’ (Matthew 5:23-24 TM). That leaves room for no excuses, does it?

content.title: Building great relationships
content.introtext:
…DO THE HARD WORK OF GETTING ALONG WITH EACH OTHER...

JAMES 3:18 TM
If you are serious about making good friend, do the following: 1) Put others first. Listen: ‘Serve [others] wholeheartedly, as if you were serving the Lord, not men’ (Ephesians 6:7 NIV). If you serve God by serving others, you can’t go 2) Chuck out any emotional baggage. If someone hurt you and you need to deal with it, do it right away. Ask God to help you forgive them and move on. If it’s not worth bringing up, forget it and move on. 3) Invest in your most valuable relationships. Think about who you hang out with. It says in the Bible that who you relate to moulds your character and ultimately your choices and destiny. 4) Be happy to serve. One airline executive explained how difficult it is to hire and train people for his industry: ‘Service is the only thing we have to sell, but it’s the toughest thing to teach because nobody wants to be thought of as a servant.’ 5) Constantly express your appreciation. Tell the people you care about how much you love them – do it a lot! Too many of us think that the best way to help people is to criticise them or give them ‘our thoughts on the matter’ Wrong! The best way to help others is to see the best in them. Practice the 101 percent principle: look for one thing to admire, then give them 100 percent encouragement for it. That will help you to like them, and them to like you. What could be better for a relationship?

content.title: It’s not ‘Death Row’
content.introtext:
…THAT WE WOULD NOT TRUST IN OURSELVES, BUT IN GOD...

2 CORINTHIANS 1:9 NAS
Paul was in one of those ‘dead-end’ situations when he wrote: ‘We felt like we’d been sent to death row, that it was all over for us…Instead of trusting in our own strength…we were forced to trust God…’ (2 Corinthians 1:9 MSG). ‘Sent to death row.’ That’s pretty dramatic language! Paul felt sentenced! In court, sentencing comes when the evidence has been presented, the judge has ruled and the verdict is final. It looked like there was no way for Paul to survive; he was in a dead-end situation. Is that where you are today? Don’t give up. What looked like the end of the story was really God saying, ‘Right, you can’t get yourself out of this, but I can. Let me help!’ That’s why he went on to say that through it all he learned not to trust in himself, but in God Who ‘raises the dead.’ Think: when your hopes seem buried and you have nowhere to turn, isn’t that when God’s power is working strongest in your life? You have a loving Heavenly Father you can call on. You can trust what He says and know that as you go through life with Him, He will make your paths straight (Proverbs 3). You have a future! So speak to your Heavenly Father today, trust Him. Don’t doubt. Expect Him to work and fight and your behalf and watch as your dead-end situation turns around. Why? Because now you are beginning to trust the One Who can really do something about it!

content.title: Hectic!
content.introtext:
…I SAW THE LORD...

ISAIAH 6:1 NIV
Listen: ‘…I saw the Lord seated on a throne, high and exalted...above him were the seraphs…they were calling to one another: “Holy, holy, holy is the Lord Almighty...” At the sound of their voices the doorposts…shook and the temple was filled with smoke. “Woe to me!” I cried. “I am ruined! For I am a man of unclean lips and live among a people of unclean lips…” Then one of the seraphs flew to me with a live coal in his hand, which he had taken...from the altar. With it he touched my mouth and said, “See, this has touched your lips; your guilt is taken away and your sin atoned for.” Then I heard the voice of the Lord saying, “Whom shall I send? And who will go for us?” And I said, “Here am I. Send me!”’ (Isaiah 6:1-8 NIV). Woah, that must have been totally hectic! Isaiah was only young when he had this mad God experience. Imagine if you were praying and suddenly you found yourself in the throneroom of God!!! Well actually in a very special way you are. God loves to hang out with all His kids and He communicates to us in different ways. You might hear a song and the lyrics might touch your heart. You might read the Bible and hear God speaking to you through what He says. But however God speaks, trust that he’s got something to say to you and wants to be with you. God’s holy and powerful, but he’s also your Father and wants to be your friend!

content.title: Your attitude
content.introtext:
…AS A MAN THINKS IN HIS HEART, SO IS HE…

PROVERBS 23:7 AMP
Here’s why your attitude makes such a difference: 1) Your attitude affects what happens. Successful people know this; whether it’s a doctor going into surgery, a singer performing a song or a business-person launching a new company. Confidence can increase your chance of success in life. When you approach something new, especially something you’re not looking forward to, fix your mind on the facts, not your feelings. That will put your attitude on the right track. 2) If you give someone attitude, you’ll get it back in your face. Smile at people and they’ll probably smile back. Act harsh and you’ll get a hash response. If you wanna get on with people today and the next, treat them well. It’s not rocket science, and it will actually make you feel pretty good too! 3) Your attitude can give you the winning edge. When world heavyweight champion Joe Louis got knocked down by Tony ‘Two Ton’ Galento in Yankee Stadium, he immediately jumped back to his feet and went after his opponent. When his trainer protested saying, ‘Why didn’t you stay down for nine?’ Louis said, ‘What! And give him a chance to rest.’ Louis went out in the fourth round and won the fight. Having a good attitude gives you the winning edge. 4) Your attitude, not your achievements, brings happiness. You could have all the money in the world and still have an attitude that sucks. You could be drowning in ‘bling’ and still resent your family and friends. A good attitude helps you through tough stuff as well as being successful. Ask God today to give you not just a good attitude, but a ‘God attitude’.

content.title: How Far?
