content.introtext:
IF SOMEONE FORCES YOU TO GO ONE MILE, GO WITH HIM TWO...

MATTHEW 5:41 NIV
What is the kingdom of God? It’s when God has number one priority in every area of life. In God’s Kingdom what you get back is always greater then what you give. Listen: ‘Give away your life; you’ll find life given back, but not merely given back – given back with bonus and blessing. Giving, not getting is the way…’ (Luke 6:38 MSG). Notice, Jesus said that God would give back to you. But He didn’t say ‘Only give to those who can give back to you.’ That is self-centredness! John Bunyan, who 400 years ago wrote an awesome book called ‘Pilgrims Progress’ said this: ‘You have not lived today unless you have done something for someone who can never repay you.’ In the Roman Empire a military officer could force any Jewish civilian to carry his heavy backpack for up to one mile. That was the officer’s right, and the person refused at their peril. So to walk the first mile was only to do what was required. Jesus said, ‘I’m telling you to go the second mile.’ Why? Because extra-mile-service gives you an opportunity to make an impact on the lives of others. A person with an extra-mile-attitude is someone who: a) cares more about others than themselves b) risks more than others think is safe c) dreams bigger than others cab believe d) believes for more than others think is possible e) gives more than others think is necessary. And you’ll notice – there is no traffic jam on the extra mile! People aren’t fighting to help others out, but Jesus said it’s the key to a happy life!

content.title: Prayer
content.introtext:
WHEN YOU PRAY, DON’T BE LIKE THE HYPOCRITES...

MATTHEW 6:5 NCV
Jesus said, ‘When you pray, don’t be like the hypocrites. They love to stand in the synagogues and on the street corners and pray so people will see them. I tell you the truth, they already have their full reward.’ (Matthew 6:5 NCV). This was a case of prayer gone wrong because: a) their prayers had become totally shallow, not from their hearts b) their prayers were rituals, rather than genuine expressions of a loving heart c) their prayers were long winded and wordy, designed to impress others d) their prayers were filled with hollow, fancy phrases e) the prayers made them look good but didn’t touch God’s heart. They had forgotten the point of prayer. But Jesus didn’t leave us guessing. No; He talked straight: ‘But when you pray, go into your [most] private room, and, closing the door, pray to your Father, Who is in secret; and your Father, Who sees in secret, will reward you in the open.’ (Matthew 6:6 AMP) If you spoke to your parents how you speak to God, they’d all laugh out loud. ‘O, great, most gracious and loving earthly parent, what is it that thou dost wish me to do?’ No wonder people get turned off! If you want to learn how to pray – read Psalms. A guy called David wrote most of the prayers and songs in it. They are spontaneous. Personal. Honest. No gobble-de-gook. No impressive Christianeze. They just let it all out. Straight talk thrills the heart of God and gets results!

content.title: What time is it?
content.introtext:
MEN OF ISSACHAR, WHO UNDERSTOOD THE TIMES...

1 CHRONICLES 12:32 NIV
Describing life in chilly New England, Chuck Swindoll writes: ‘Newcomers…get the false impression that there will hardly be much of a winter, so they continue…sightseeing and relaxation with little regard for the deep freeze that inevitably arrives. Seasoned souls are not so foolish…they use that brief interlude to prepare for winter’s bitter blast…Early on I learned a valuable lesson…winter can be endured with much greater success if you prepared for its arrival.’ God’s Word says, ‘Get ready; be prepared…’ (Ezekiel 38:7 NIV). You need to suss what’s going on now not later! People respected the men of Issachar because they ‘understood the times.’ Times change: a new college course, something massive like the loss of a loved one, a new friendship or moving to a new place. Before a new ‘time’ arrives you can often feel restless; a feeling you’ve outgrown something that used to excite and challenge you. Different times help you grow in different ways and keep you progressing towards the ultimate fulfilment of God’s plan for your life. Sticking with the familiar can be fatal. It’s dangerous to wait for circumstances to change before making a move that God already has planned. The best way to avoid that is by staying connected to Him, developing your spiritual radar, and moving whenever He says it is ‘time’. So while you’re taking down your decorations and Christmas lights, take down those old attitudes that are stopping you from moving into the next thing God has for you. The art of living means understanding the times, navigating through them, and squeezing the joy out of every minute on the way.

content.title: Your year of Grace and favour
content.introtext:
...THE LORD LONGS TO BE GRACIOUS TO YOU...

ISAIAH 30:18 NIV
On December 31st the clock strikes midnight ushering in a New Year. Three hundred and sixty-five days of potential to fulfil your dreams and ambitions. A new beginning. A gift full of promise. But you must accept it, unwrap it and use it. Not everybody does. Maybe you dread what the New Year holds; exams, your first job, new schools, moving house, life without a loved one. Well, God loves to take fragile people and set them on the road to peace, joy and victory. He is the expert at drying tears, calming fears, giving courage to worried hearts and taking away bad memories. He is '...making all things new...' (Revelation 21:5 NIV). He never leads you back, just forward. Listen: 'The Lord longs to be gracious to you.' So what do you want to see one year from now? Does it include making new friends? Achieving some awards? Leading a cell group? Only you can complete the question, 'What if I could...?' because only you know what makes your heart leap. Famous US author Stephen Covey says, 'Begin...with the image of the end of your life as your frame of reference... Each day will then contribute to the vision you have of your life as a whole.' Go for God in 2006! Set your goals now, write them down. Picture your life in a year, five years and ten years and work towards that vision. '...the Lord longs to be gracious to you...' To be gracious means 'to show favour.' Wow! The desire of God's heart is that you should walk in His grace and favour every day of this year.

content.title: Rest and recreation
content.introtext:
...GOD . . . RESTED FROM ALL HIS WORK.

GENESIS 2:2 NIV
Listen: God...rested from all his work.' It's interesting that God should feel that He needs a day off, after all He IS God! The truth is that God probably didn't need a day off, after all He's been working everyday since. But, God taking a day out to rest sets a good example for us. After all, our bodies were designed to need rest and time out, especially to make sure we spend time with God! In the world in which we live, Sundays are no longer special days. The shops are open, many people now have to work and it's not seen generally regarded as a rest day, in fact it's quite the opposite. After a chokka week Sunday's a great time for a lot of people to get busy on their homework, shopping washing and cleaning done. So what about your life, is there a balance between work time, you time and God time or is life one non-stop rollercoaster that you can't get off? Remember, when you put stuff off until tomorrow, it never comes. Invest in your relationships, serve God as he has asked you to, don't neglect your responsibilities at home and make sure that every day you take time out to be with God. Your time is a balancing act so ask God to help you to use it wisely. Keep what's important in perspective. God knew exactly what He was doing when he gave us 24 hours in a day so if there are not enough, you're not using them right!

content.title: Hold on to your dream
content.introtext:
...IF IT [THE VISION] SEEMS SLOW IN COMING, WAIT. IT'S ON ITS WAY...

HABAKKUK 2:3 TM
Whether you are in a prison cell like Joseph, a boring classroom at school or stuck at home with your brothers and sisters, God has not forgotten you and the dreams he has given you. You may not know how to get from where you are to where your dream will take you, but God knows! Simply ask Him to reveal the next step. The more you see yourself leading the CU, launching your own business, serving a ministry, writing your first book or helping others through your unique gifts, the sooner it will become a reality. Before our vision becomes clear God gives us glimpses of it - like a picture developing in a dark room - it slowly appears before your eyes. Take your God-given vision and run with it. Let it inspire you to put your best into everything you do at the moment, while always praying and speaking with Him who knows and loves you best. Today pray: 'Lord, I thank You for all You've given me - even those things that seem unfair and annoying, even the pain that others have caused by trying to hurt me. Help me to do my best, to stay Christ-like and positive, because I know that where I am right now is not where You're taking me. Give me glimpses of Your vision for my future so that my understanding can grow just at the right times. Give me patience along the way, and faith to trust that You're working for my good every moment of the day. Amen.'

content.title: Don't you dare bury it!
content.introtext:
...HE HID IT...

MATTHEW 25:25
In the 'parable of the talents' Jesus teaches us about using what God has given to us. The 'talent' the story refers to is not a talent like turning your eyelids inside out but a currency of money. In the story a rich man gives three amounts of cash to three servants and goes on holiday. When he returns, two of the servants have invested the talents and made more, but one was so scared of losing what little he had, he just buried it. When the man returns he tells the two servants well done and gives them more. But to the one who wouldn't take a risk he says 'you wicked and lazy servant' and tells him he would have even made interest if he'd put it in the bank. God has given each of us gifts and talents. How we use those gifts is entirely up to us. As you use your talents you get better at them and as you push yourself, which may mean taking risks, you'll be rewarded with greater gifts, talents and responsibility. The lazy servant was so scared of failing that he didn't even try to invest, he just clung tightly to the little he had. Remember, your talents have been given to you for a reason. God has a purpose but it's up to you to stretch yourself and discover that purpose. When all is said and done remember that our most fulfilling reward is not human approval, it's the 'well done, good and faithful servant' at the end of it all.'

content.title: Forgetting and looking forward
content.introtext:
...FORGETTING THE PAST AND LOOKING FORWARD TO WHAT LIES AHEAD.

PHILIPPIANS 3:13 NLT
Every experience you've had from the moment you were born until now, has made you what you are today. The things that happened to you, both good and bad, decide how you will act and react for the rest of your life. Jesus said, '"A good man gives out good from the goodness stored in his heart; and a bad man gives out evil, from his store of evil"' (Matthew 12:35 PHPS). There are things stored up in each of us that must be dealt with before we can move on in life. That's why Paul wrote, '...forgetting the past and looking forward to what lies ahead.' Paul understood that forgetting and looking forward are the keys to developing and growing. One won't work without the other. Forgetting closes the door to your past; looking forward opens the door to your future. What did Paul have to forget? A lot! On his orders, Stephen, the first Christian martyr, was stoned to death while he watched. And there were many more to follow. Could you forget that? If Paul hadn't learned to deal with his past, he would never have written half of the New Testament or helped build a church that would last for two thousand years. Understand this: the only place the past can live is in your memory. The only power it has over you is the power you give it. So the word for you today is - '...forgetting the past and looking forward to what lies ahead.'

content.title: For the One who has everything
content.introtext:
...THEY...PRESENTED HIM WITH...GOLD...INCENSE AND...MYRRH.

MATTHEW 2:11 NIV
It's Christmas. Jesus' Birthday. But what can you possibly give to the One who not only has everything, but created it all? The wise men probably asked the same question. As wise blokes they were clever enough to navigate thousands of miles guided by a star, important enough to get an audience with King Herod and rich enough to go on such a long journey carrying expensive presents. But in addition to 'gold...incense and...myrrh,' they gave Jesus some gifts that are priceless - here's what they gave: 1) Their time. Long before His birth they had invested years researching and preparing for it - not counting the two years it took them to travel to where He was born. Do you know what? You're as close to God today as you want to be, planned to be, and took time to be. Want to get closer? Spend more time with Him. 2) Their worship. Once they found Him, '...they fell down...and worshiped Him...' (Matthew 2:11 NLT). Worship changes us completely because when we stand in God's presence with an open heart and let His Spirit work in us, '...we are being changed to be like Him...' (2 Corinthians 3:18 NCV). 3) Their hope. While those around saw only darkness these men recognised 'The light that shines in the darkness...' (John 1:5 NCV). And that hasn't changed. God's love still shines brightest in the darkness of our broken dreams and messy hearts. So in the middle of your family celebrations, take time out to be with Jesus; after all, it's His birthday.

content.title: When it's hard to believe
content.introtext:
...HOW CAN THIS BE?...

LUKE 1:34 NASB
Have you ever tried to put yourself in the place of Mary? A young girl, enjoying her life, excited about her new fella when suddenly this angel pops up and says that God has chosen her to be the mother of His Son! Given the circumstances, her response was pretty calm: 'How can this be, since I am a virgin?' Imagine what she was thinking! What would people think? How could she care for a baby? What would Joseph say? Would he abandon her? No wonder she '...was greatly troubled...' (Luke 1:29 NIV) most people would be! Maybe you're facing a tough situation and trying to trust God but getting nowhere. Maybe you or someone you know is sick, and although you know that '...by His stripes we are healed...' (Isaiah 53:5 NKJ), you are wondering, 'How can this be when my symptoms are still there?' We all have issues which stretch our faith to its limits. What's even more challenging is that Mary's situation was caused by God. Hang about... he's not supposed to do that is he? He's supposed to bless and rescue us! But God had a plan. Mary was about to be involved in something amazing and never to be repeated. To get her through the faith-test she was given a simple but powerful promise: '...the Lord is with you...' (Luke 1:28-30 NKJ). Once you understand that 'the One who called you is completely dependable. If He said it, He'll do it' (1Thessalonians 5:24 TM), your attitude changes completely. So today if you are wondering about the future, remember what the angel said to Mary, '...nothing is impossible with God' (Luke 1:37 NLT), because He promises the same to you!

content.title: The arrival of peace
content.introtext:
…AND HE WILL BE CALLED...PRINCE OF PEACE

ISAIAH 9:6 NIV
School was finished and ten-year-old Charlie was thrilled to be out of London celebrating Christmas in the country. Driving along the winding roads with his Mum he was captivated by the snowy winter landscape. But suddenly the snow got heavy, the visibility turned bad and the car slid out of control ending up in a ditch. Charlie tried to push while his mum pressed the accelerator, but it was no use. They left the car and walked down the road where they knocked on the door of a little house and asked for help. Flustered, the lady invited them in to use the phone and warm up while she sorted out some tea and biscuits. 'It’s a nice story, but what's so special about that?' you're asking. Well, it was special for the woman who opened the door that day; she has already told the story hundreds of times. And can you blame her? It's not everyday the Queen of England, and Prince Charles, turn up on your doorstep! On a winter's night over 2,000 years ago the Prince of Peace knocked on our door - and it was no accident. Christmas can be a crazy time full of emotion, laughter, sadness, happiness, loudness, quietness, madness and Uncle Arthur's terrible jokes. But remember, however your Christmas is shaping up, make sure that the Prince of Peace reigns in your life and family. Celebrating the birth of Jesus together, let the love and peace he brings be central to all you do. Have a blessed Christmas!

content.title: Set an example
content.introtext:
…SET AN EXAMPLE . . . IN SPEECH, IN LIFE, IN LOVE, IN FAITH AND IN PURITY

1 TIMOTHY 4:12 NIV
It seems young Timothy was easily intimidated by powerful, older people. He was scared to challenge them to live with more faith. And it sounds like he was a bit less disciplined than he should have been. So Paul writes to him, 'Do not let anyone look down on you because you are young, but set an example... in speech, in life, in love, in faith and in purity... devote yourself to the public reading of Scripture . . . Do not neglect your gift… so that everyone may see your progress...' (1 Timothy 4:12-16 NIV). What's Paul's message to us? Look at your life. Put it under a microscope. Make sure that every part is operating according to the highest standards. Set an example. Your age doesn't matter, live in a way that will make people will want to follow you. In what areas? In speech, the things you say and the way you say them; in life, your daily habits will decide your future; in love, the quality of your personal relationships; in faith, the amount that you trust God; in purity, your character and integrity. Live in a way that makes people study your life and see Jesus. French artist Henri Matisse once said, 'Artists should have their tongues cut out.' Why? Because the artist's message comes through paint on canvas, not through the words they use. That’s a bit extreme, but it makes a powerful point! So today will your life be an example for others to follow? Don't tell them what to do, just let them see you.

content.title: Recognise your Tutors!
content.introtext:
”…WHERE YOU GO I WILL GO

RUTH 1:16 NIV
You can spend your life anywhere, with anybody, doing anything, then suddenly get involved with someone and know that your destiny's tied to that person. It's what made Elisha leave his farm and follow Elijah, to wash his clothes and set up his tent. It's what made Timothy hang out with Paul, an old man preparing to be executed. As he passed books and blankets through a prison window Timothy was saying, 'There's something about you that touches me. Without you I will not reach my destiny.' Ruth developed a special bond with her mother-in-law Naomi. Listen: '”…where you go I will go...”' The fact that Naomi was from a different country and was at a different stage of life, didn't matter to Ruth. There must have been times when they didn't relate to each other at all. When God wants to mature and stretch you, He will send somebody into your life with different experiences and insights. Naomi was Ruth's eyes and ears in a world she didn't know; she was her tutor and guide in avoiding the pitfalls of life. Naomi understood where Ruth had been; that's important because we are all products of our past. She also knew where Ruth needed to go; all Ruth needed was the courage and guts to follow. God's constantly raising up people to take on new challenges. If you hope to be something for God, recognise the people He sends into your life to prepare you. Whether they come to comfort, counsel, correct or challenge you, remember the words of Jesus '”…whoever accepts anyone I send accepts me…”' (John 13:20 NIV).

content.title: Finish strong!
content.introtext:
”…I AM EIGHTY-FIVE . . . I AM AS STRONG . . . AS I WAS AT [FORTY]…”

JOSHUA 14:10 TLB
Caleb is the champion of the second half. Listen: '”Give me the hill country. Even though I'm eighty-five, I'm as strong as I was at forty...”' (Paraphrase. See Joshua 14:7-12 TLB). Caleb probably said this in front of a load of young men each trying to get the best deal when it came to moving into the Promised Land. The hill country was full of walled cities and giants. Who wants that? The old guy did. Maybe your life has not been too impressive as yet. You don't think you've done anything important, lost a few mates and are wondering what life has in store. Don't stew on it. If Caleb was still up for new challenges at 85 it’s probably a bit soon for you to think about giving up! E Stanley Jones spent more than 50 years in India. At 83, after a lifetime of constant travel during which he spoke to millions, met with Presidents and Prime Ministers and was the main man in the conversion of masses, he had a stroke. It left him without speech or physical mobility. In the long months before he died, Jones managed to mutter through virtually paralysed lips the manuscript of a remarkable book. In one amazing paragraph he writes: 'There are scars on my faith, but underneath those scars there are no doubts... I'm 83, and I'm more excited today about being a Christian than I was at 18, when I first put my feet upon this way!' With God, running stumble-free doesn't make you a winner, finishing strong does!

content.title: The power of silence
content.introtext:
….IN QUIETNESS AND TRUST IS YOUR STRENGTH

ISAIAH 30:15 NIV
Sometimes talking makes things worse. Listen: 'The tongue is a small thing, but what enormous damage it can do. A tiny spark can set a great forest on fire.' (James 3:5 NLT). Look at how an argument can start with just a small comment and turn into a massive fight. Often people are just waiting for some loud mouthed individual to say what they wish they had the guts to say, and once the door is open they join in. Don't be that person. Learn to stop that spark before a huge fire breaks out. If you want to get on in life and make a difference, learn to tame your tongue. Your mouth can talk you out of more blessings than you can count. In the Bible we see David arriving at the palace to work for Saul. Saul was a bit of a psycho due to his 'evil spirit' but David wasn't stupid, he could see what was going on. David got on with his job and kept his mouth shut, knowing his time would come. Make sure you’re not there when disgruntled, complainers start moaning on. '…pour out [your] complaint before [God]…' (Psalm 142:2 NIV). If something’s bugging you just tell Jesus! Is that hard to do? No! Talk to him then hold of that situation and bring light and life to it. Our conversations need to be full of grace and love. Speak positively. With a few words you can change a whole lot of attitudes.

content.title: Temptation (4)
content.introtext:
”I WILL INVITE EVERYONE WHO IS VICTORIOUS TO SIT WITH ME ON MY THRONE…”

REVELATION 3:21 NLT
As we enter the prime season for temptation to take hold, here’s 12 top truths to keep you on track. 1) Christmas is not an excuse to give in to temptation. 2) Any weakness you constantly give in to, excuse, deny or hide, will control you. 3) You must identify and target your biggest weakness first. 4) Ignoring your weakness guarantees you'll lose 5) Satan will use certain friends to trip you! 6) Your weakness will try to take over your life and ruin God’s plan for you 7) Your weakness will always draw you to the wrong people and make you uncomfortable around the right ones. 8) Your weakness can show itself at any time, and usually at the most unexpected time 9) Your weakness can't be beaten by any logic or will power 10) God will let you be successful in different areas even when you feel like your weakness is winning. Why? Because He is full of grace and mercy 11) People who love you are praying for you to beat your weakness because that glorifies God. 12) Overcoming your weakness brings great rewards. Listen: ‘”Conquerors will sit alongside me at the head table, just as I, having conquered, took the place of honour at the side of my Father. That's my gift to the conquerors!”' (Revelation 3:21 TM). Understand this: God will not only help you to overcome your greatest weakness - but to turn it into your greatest weapon!

content.title: Temptation (3)
content.introtext:
”…SATAN HAS ASKED TO HAVE ALL OF YOU…”

LUKE 22:31 NIV
Are you struggling with temptation? Here's a plan for victory. 1) Decide that you will not give in. Jesus said, '”…I have given you . . . [physical and mental strength] over all the power that the enemy [possesses]…”' (Luke 10:19 AMP). Get rid of your 'I can't' attitude. Start drawing daily on God's strength. 2) If you slip, don't wallow. Becoming mature is a life-long process. It takes place each time you turn to God in your weakness and allow Him to do for you what you can't do for yourself. 3) Confess your sin. Listen: 'The Lord is near to the broken-hearted…' (Psalm 34:18 NAS). God always responds to a sorry heart. He will meet you at your lowest point, walk you through the pain and healing of regret, and bring you out stronger and wiser. 4) Make a 3-column ‘temptation’ list: a) Discoveries. List everything you have learned about yourself, other people, and God's Word b) The New Me. List areas that still need to be changed and dealt with c) Action Plan. Write down things you want to bring into your life like prayer, confession, accountability, Bible reading and new Christian friendships. 5) Use what you've learned. Jesus told Peter, '”…satan has asked to have all of you . . .but I have pleaded in prayer for you…so when you have repented and turned to Me again, strengthen and build up your brothers”.' (Luke 22:31-32 NIV). Let today mark a new beginning by using what you've learned, not only to avoid falling again, but also to help others facing the same temptations.

content.title: Temptation (2)
content.introtext:
RUN FROM ANYTHING THAT STIMULATES YOUTHFUL LUST. FOLLOW ANYTHING THAT MAKES YOU WANT TO DO RIGHT…

2 TIMOTHY 2:22 NLT
In Genesis, when Eve looked at the tree in the middle of the garden, she 'saw . . . its fruit was good [and] . . . she took some' (Genesis 3:6 NCV). Look out! The tempter knows where each of us are weakest. He knew that God had great plans for Eve so he decided to seduce her, and in doing so, dealt a deathblow to her descendants. Understand this: the battle is always over your future. The issue is not just you - it's about those God plans to bless through you! Look at Samson: his character didn't match his strength. He fooled himself into thinking that he could live as he wanted and escape the consequences. His life is a mine of valuable lessons, such as: a) success in one area does not mean you can't fail in others b) temptation always returns to the scene of its previous success c) playing with temptation means you'll always lose d) even though giving in to temptation may not cut you off from God's grace, it can limit your usefulness to Him e) where we think we are strongest is where we're least likely to be prepared for attack. When all else fails there’s one thing you can always do when you are faced with a temptation… RUN! That's what Joseph did. His boss’s wife fancied him, and she was no minger either. Joseph found himself trapped but decided that giving in would be '”…a sin against God”' (Genesis 39:9 NIV), so he legged it! God is not dishonoured when you run - He's dishonoured when you don't!

content.title: Temptation (1)
content.introtext:
TEMPTATION COMES FROM THE LURE OF OUR OWN EVIL DESIRES.

JAMES 1:14 NLT
Before we give in to temptation we go through certain stages: a) ignoring prayer and Bible reading we become cold to God. Forgetting about danger, we get drawn in like a moth to the flame b) we begin to justify ourselves thinking, 'Nobody knows, what harm will it do?' c) we convince ourselves it's OK and can't even remember why it's wrong d) we surround ourselves with mates who do the same, or are willing to look the other way. 'But I would never do that,' you say. Maybe, but what things would you do? This raises another question, 'Have you reached your time of testing yet?' When Jesus told Peter he'd deny his Lord, Peter replied, 'No way!' Yet within hours he'd fallen flat on his face. James says, 'Temptation comes from the lure of our own evil desires.' You have weak areas which if not disciplined by commitment and character, have the ability to destroy you. 'What can I do?' you ask. When Jehoshaphat came up against an enemy too big to handle alone, he prayed, '”…we have no power against this great multitude . . . We do not know what to do, but our eyes are upon You”’ (2 Chronicles 20:12 NKJ). Jehoshaphat understood three things: 1) he knew that in his own strength he was no match for this enemy 2) he was humble enough to admit it and reach for help 3) he knew where to turn - '”…our eyes are upon you.”' What's the secret of victory? Lean on Jesus, not yourself!

content.title: Are you feeling unqualified?
content.introtext:
...GO, AND I . . . WILL TEACH YOU WHAT YOU SHALL SAY.

EXODUS 4:12 AMP
When Moses told God that he was unqualified for the job, in a way, he was right. When God calls you He gives you what you need, but He doesn't necessarily do it immediately. Your learning often takes place in the process of actually having a go. Have you told God, 'I'm terrified of talking in front of people - what do you mean you want me to lead this talk?' Or, 'I can't do it. Why would You want me to do for this job when I don't know what to do?' You can't rely on your own opinion! The only qualification you absolutely must have to do any job God asks of you is a willingness to try. The rest, as they say, is 'on-the-job training.' You simply have to trust God and act when he tells you. That's not to say you'll never be scared. Like Moses, you may feel so inadequate you can't even imagine succeeding. That's when you must have faith to stretch and grow past what you can imagine and just start doing what needs to be done as well as you can. That can be scary. You'll probably find yourself more dependent on God than ever before. You may have to ask the people around you loads of questions, and sometimes more than once. Don't be afraid to ask, to make mistakes, to get help, or to do things differently than people before you. If God has called you - then you are the person for the job! Do not ever lose sight of that!

content.title: Living by the Holy Spirit's power
content.introtext:
...TWO FORCES WITHIN US ARE CONSTANTLY FIGHTING EACH OTHER...

GALATIANS 5:17 TLB
No matter how long we've been a Christian, our body never improves; it never becomes more like God because we get old! That's why we are told to everyday to give ourselves to him and live by Gods power. Listen: 'Obey only the Holy Spirit's instructions . . . then you will not always be doing the wrong things your evil nature wants you to . . . we naturally love to do evil things that are just the opposite from the things that the Holy Spirit tells us to do; and the good things we want to do when the Spirit has His way with us are just the opposite of our natural desires. These two forces within us are constantly fighting each other to win control over us, and our wishes are never free from their pressures . . . But when the Holy Spirit controls our lives He will produce this kind of fruit in us: love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self-control' (Galatians 5:16-17 & 23 TLB). Is living like this really possible? Yes, but you must do four things: 1) understand that you're a target for the enemy and protect yourself with God's Word and prayer 2) get angry with sin - don't put up with it: '...let us throw off everything that hinders and the sin that so easily entangles...' (Hebrews 12:1 NIV) 3) be continually filled with the Holy Spirit. Without it, you lose every time 4) stand in God's strength, not your own. How? By exercising your choice to obey Him rather than going for the easy option.

content.title: The power of God-given ideas (3)
content.introtext:
...ALL . . . NATIONS . . . WILL BE BLESSED THROUGH YOU...

GENESIS 28:14 TLB
If you found out that a Christian invented the typewriter it would beg the question... why? Well, what's the cheesiest reason you can come up with? Yes, believe it or not the typewriter was invented to write sermons. Christopher Sholes was worried about his pastor who'd been busy all week visiting victims of an epidemic, comforting the families and doing funerals. As a result the poor guy had no time to write his Sunday sermons. One day Sholes was talking to a friend about what could be done. He said, 'It seems a pity there ain't some quick method of writing for busy folks like parsons.' His friend replied, 'Why not invent a machine?' Sholes responded, 'I'll try.' That rainy afternoon was the beginning of months of hard work. Finally a group got together one day to see him tap out on paper, in capital letters, C LATHAM SHOLES, SEPTEMBER 1867. Six years later the Remington's recognised the typewriter as something that could revolutionise business. In those days clerks were mostly men, but the Young Women's Christian Association started offering courses in typing for women. To start with it created a scandal, but as the first typists to be trained were women, employers rushed to hire them. So, the typewriter and the YWCA made sure that a woman's place was not only at home, but could also be in the office.' Have you ever wondered what is and isn't ok to ask God for? Well if it's going to help spread the gospel in anyway you can be sure it's fine.

content.title: The power of God-given ideas (2)
content.introtext:
...ALL . . . NATIONS . . . WILL BE BLESSED THROUGH YOU...

GENESIS 28:14 TLB
One God-given idea can change so much. Braille did! In 1824 Louis Braille, a Christian, invented a system of raised dots on paper so that blind people could read. He invented 63 symbols representing every language, so the Bible was placed into the hands of the visually impaired for the first time. Even heard of the Morse Code? In part, you owe your mobile phone and your computer to a Christian named Samuel Morse. The world was a different place before this guy! First class news took two weeks to reach the USA. And reports of a major victory could take six weeks to reach Britain. One day a friend said, 'Morse, when you were experimenting did you ever come to an absolute deadlock, not knowing what to do?' Morse replied, 'More than once.' His friend asked, 'What did you do then?' Morse shared a secret: 'I got down on my knees and prayed for light, and light came, and when my inventions were acknowledged by flattering honours from America and Europe, I said, "Not unto me, O Lord, not unto me, but unto Thy name give the glory."' That's why the first message sent by transatlantic cable read: 'What God has wrought.' Christians are so creative because God is so creative! We've not really got time to mention Louis Pasteur, the French scientist who discovered that infection is the result of germs and viruses. He introduced sterilisation methods that saved the lives of millions. Do you think God will ever run out of creativity? Not a chance! Ask Him for some today!

content.title: The power of God-given ideas (1)
content.introtext:
...ALL . . . NATIONS . . . WILL BE BLESSED THROUGH YOU...

GENESIS 28:14 TLB
Good ideas come from God, so ask Him for one. The world's been blessed by those who did. Think about anaesthetic: how would you like to be operated on without it? That is the way they did it until a Scottish doctor called James Young Simpson introduced something he called 'artificial sleep.' As a student at Edinburgh University he was attracted to surgery because he was troubled by the pain and death rate experienced during operations. After reading Genesis 2:21, 'And the Lord God caused a deep sleep to fall upon Adam...,' Simpson thought a chemical called chloroform might be the answer. He first experimented on himself. Finally, in 1847, the first three operations with chloroform took place. One of the patients, a young soldier, enjoyed it so much that he grabbed the sponge and inhaled again. 'It was just too good to be stopped' he said. At first Simpson found people against him. Some thought it was a sin to interfere with nature. 'Hand me the Bible,' said Dr. Simpson. 'This is how God operated on Adam.' Simpson made speeches, wrote letters and booklets and tried to convince everyone who opposed him that this was the way forward. In a setback, three deaths caused by chloroform were reported from other hospitals, but Simpson was able to show them that they weren't applying the anaesthetic properly. The tide turned when Queen Victoria gave birth to her eighth child under chloroform and said that she was 'greatly pleased with its effect.' Today ask God to give you an idea that blesses others. Then act on it!

content.title: Death - then glory!
content.introtext:
...DO YOU BELIEVE THIS?

JOHN 11:26 TM
When Jesus stood at the graveside of Lazarus He told the grieving family two things we must never forget: a) '"Your brother will rise again"' (John 11:23 NAS) b) '"Everyone who lives believing in me does not ultimately die at all. Do you believe this?"' (John 11:25-26 TM). That's the basic question of life. '"...Do you believe this?"' What's going to take you past death and onto your heavenly home? Jesus and only Jesus! Only he can guarantee you eternal life. He beat death and the grave for you. You may be reading these words, fighting tears of pain and grief. Perhaps you have lost your friend or family member, or maybe you've just seen horrific images of starving children on the news. Christ understands your grief; like no one else He feels your pain. Maybe you're even scared of dying. If you have never before given your life to Jesus you need to get that sorted now. Don't wait for a better time. Give your life over to Him today and you will be saved, which means when you breathe your last breath - tomorrow or in 80 years, you will pass from death to life - heavenly life. If you know Jesus there's no reason to be scared of death or the unknown; He's already got it sorted and He's made a place for you. It's ready! Unexplainable, unending joy will be yours forever because of Jesus. Then like Paul you can say, 'O death, where is your victory? O death, where is your sting?' (1 Corinthians 15:55 AMP). Think: immediately following death - Glory!

content.title: Be prepared!
content.introtext:
ANTS . . . STORE UP THEIR FOOD IN THE SUMMER.

PROVERBS 30:25 NIV
You will never change your life until you change something you do daily. Success does not suddenly happen, neither does failure; both are a process. Every day of your life is just preparation for the next. The question is, what are you preparing for? Are you setting yourself up for success or failure? In the animation film Antz, the ants spend the whole summer working hard and collecting grain for the winter so they won't go hungry. During the summer the grasshoppers pay a visit and tell the ants they intend to take all the food they want. The ants have enough of the annual bullying from the grasshoppers and fight back. Needless to say the ants win the day and put an end to the grasshoppers, bullying and laziness. The result was that the grasshoppers had no food for the winter but the ants had all they needed. The grasshoppers didn't get that the only real preparation for tomorrow is the right use of today. In an exam, have you ever walked confidently into the classroom, knowing you've revised so hard you're gonna 'ace' it? Impossible? Unfortunately, most of us don't lead our own lives - we just accept them. Life is not a dress rehearsal. You do not get a second chance. Walking with God you can have that kind of confidence every day. Benjamin Disraeli, Britain's first Jewish Prime Minister, once said, 'The secret of success in life, is for a man to be ready for his time when it comes.' Answer this question: if God gave you the things you are praying for, could you handle them?

content.title: Glorious living!
content.introtext:
...HE . . . HAD DESIGNS ON US FOR GLORIOUS LIVING...

EPHESIANS 1:11 TM
Most of us spend our lives focusing on what we have... until we realise that we're running out of time, then we begin to focus on what we've done. Understand this: when you leave this world your material possessions will be forgotten. The only thing that will stay - is your life's impact! During your lifetime you will directly or indirectly impact the lives of approximately 10,000 other people. The question is, how will you impact them? Money, or the lack of it, does not necessarily determine your life's impact. People with fat fortunes have lived, died and made little or no difference. Other people, totally skint but full of vision, have done what Jesus said when He prayed 'your will be done, on earth, as it is in Heaven.' At the end of a life well lived the Apostle Paul wrote, '...I have finished my course...' (2 Timothy 4:7 NIV). Having said that he handed the ministry over to Timothy, walked to the executioner's chopping block and was relieved of his duties. Yet his impact is greater now than ever. He writes: '[God]. . . had designs on us for glorious living...' What kind? Living with impact! Not just making a living but making a difference! In the movie Forest Gump, Tom Hanks plays a character with disabilities, both physical and mental. By following wise advice he goes on to achieve some incredible things. You know what? You have within you huge potential for achieving incredible thing. God's given you a gift. Believe it. Discover it. Develop it. Cherish it. Use it. Give it. That's glorious living!

content.title: Been rejected by your family?
content.introtext:
FOR EVEN HIS OWN BROTHERS DID NOT BELIEVE HIM.

JOHN 7:5 NIV
'Jesus' brothers said to him, "you ought to leave here and go to Judea, so that your disciples may see the miracles you do..." for even his own brothers did not believe him' (John 7:3-5 NIV). At first glance Jesus' brothers seem pretty encouraging, until you realise they were being sarcastic. Have you ever experienced the pain of being rejected by your family? If so, you're not on your own. Jesus did too! This little snippet from John's gospel describes how his own brothers completely misjudged Him. Jesus was full of all the wisdom of God so He understood that they just didn't get Him. But because He was also human through and through it still hurt. However the amazing thing about Jesus is that He chose to keep on loving and respecting them anyway. And then, beyond continuing to love His family, He showed an even higher priority, to those who'd come to hear what He had to say. Taking up your cross and following Jesus often involves misunderstanding and rejection by your own friends and family, and not always just by non-Christians! If that's what's going on with you today why not pray this prayer: 'Father, bring me to the place where I can live like Jesus lived, facing head-on those who misunderstand me, hearing their comments and feeling the pain of their words, yet learning to rise above it. Help me to understand, forgive, and love people no matter what. Bring me to the place of peace, so that no matter who doesn't get me, I can go on, like Jesus went on. Amen.'

content.title: The praise of men
content.introtext:
THEY LOVED THE PRAISE OF MEN MORE THAN THE PRAISE OF GOD.

JOHN 12:43 NIV
How sad! Religious leaders were starting to believe in Jesus because His message made sense, yet they wouldn't follow Him. Why? 'They loved the praise of men more than the praise of God.' We all know how sweet the 'praise drug' tastes; and how we feels when it's not there! Like Sally Field at the Academy Awards, we find ourselves wanting to be able to say as she did after winning her second Oscar: 'You like me! You really like me!' The trouble is, it's not someone's approval that makes us feel good, it's our belief that they are right. How we feel about something can all hang on the reaction of others, not on what's right in Gods eyes. Do you know there are loads of stories of missionaries who have died a 'failure', believing that nothing had changed, but upon their death revival broke out because of their work. Whether we are around to see success or not, the approval of God is all that matters. It's nice to be appreciated, but when we're not, our self-worth must be based on two things alone: 1) God's unconditional love and acceptance of us, which was proven once and for all at the cross. 2) The joy of knowing that one day we will hear '"well done good and faithful servant..."' (Matthew 25:21 NIV). Today God is saying to you, 'Don't despise your place, your gifts or your job. You can't have someone else's and it wouldn't fulfil you if you could.'

content.title: Back to your Bethel!
content.introtext:
GOD SAID TO JACOB, "NOW MOVE ON TO BETHEL AND SETTLE THERE. BUILD AN ALTAR THERE TO WORSHIP ME...

GENESIS 35:1 NLT
What do you do when you have lost your way; when you've blown it all and it seems your whole life is screwed up? These questions haunted Jacob while he was hanging out in Shechem. He'd been a con from a young age and played it well. Now the con man was getting old and mending his ways but his sons had learned a lot from their old man; but they were violent too. Thanks to Jacob's sons, Shechem became like a scene from 'War of the Worlds' - Jacob was terrified. It looked like it was payback time - the scary local tribes were looking for revenge. In despair, Jacob turned back to God who whispered, 'Go back to Bethel.' So Jacob turned around and went back to the place where he'd once met God; where he'd received a heavenly vision; where he'd first known the joy and security of living in a loving relationship with God. Jacob returned to Bethel and made an altar there. Have you stumbled and fallen? Have you made a mess of your life? If so, do what Jacob did; go back to where you met God. Get down on your knees and pray! Stop dancing on the edge of disaster, living a secret life that only you and God know about! Go back to your Bethel! God will meet you there. Listen: 'Let the wicked abandon their way of life and the evil way of thinking. Let them come back to God, who is merciful, come back to our God, who is lavish with forgiveness' (Isaiah 55:7 TM). Those words were written for you!

content.title: Two kinds of givers
content.introtext:
...GOD LOVES A CHEERFUL GIVER.

2 CORINTHIANS 9:7 NIV
There are two kinds of givers: those who give what's left over, and those who give off the top. The first group isn't necessarily greedy, they just live a different way. They see themselves as being responsible for meeting their own needs, so whatever's left over goes to God's work. The problem with giving leftovers is that you will never give what you think you can't afford. As soon as you feel a bit skint, you decide not to give. The other problem is that you buy the new Nike trainers which you've convinced yourself you absolutely need and have no money left over anyway! God says he wants you to be a 'cheerful giver'. But if your heart is more desperate for those new shoes, how can you ever be generous the way God wants? On the other hand, those who give 'off the top' understand that God owns and controls all the blessings in their life anyway, so they feel free to give to Him first and themselves second. Leftover givers always struggle in this area. They know all the stuff about God providing but there are clothes to buy, nights out to fund and friends' birthdays coming up, so they hold back, afraid they can't do all this and give to God. Fear has the power to make you act the opposite to what you believe. Basically fear makes you irrational. Doesn't it make more sense to trust God with your money since it's all His anyway?

content.title: Christ's golden rule (3)
content.introtext:
DO FOR OTHERS WHAT YOU WOULD LIKE THEM TO DO FOR YOU...

MATTHEW 7:12 NLT
Take a look at the following statements: a) I am always honest b) I am mostly honest c) I am quite honest d) I am rarely honest e) I am never honest. Which slot are you in? Most of us put ourselves in the second slot because it's the most convenient. Risking confrontation, being disciplined, putting others first and paying the price for success can all be a bit uncomfortable. Most of us think that being mostly honest is fine - unless we are on the other end of someone's being 'mostly honest'. If you are looking for a real standard of decent behaviour to live by, you will find it in the golden rule. Here's why: 1) His golden rule is easy to understand You just put yourself in the place of the other person and think 'how would I like it?' Even a small child can get that! 2) It's a win-win lifestyle. Have you ever met people who believe that in order for them to win, others must lose? Well if you think about it if I treat you as well as I want to be treated, you win. If you treat me the same I win. Where's the loser in that? 3) It produces peace and self-worth. Ultimately, you have to be able to live with yourself! If the only way you can win is by cheating, you lose self-respect, live with the fear of being found out, lose your confidence before God, and all your successes don't count!

content.title: Christ's golden rule (2)
content.introtext:
DO FOR OTHERS WHAT YOU WOULD LIKE THEM TO DO FOR YOU...

MATTHEW 7:12 NLT
All good relationships are based on Christ's golden rule. The bottom line is show people that you value them! It's easy to tell someone how great you think they are but showing it is often a totally different story. There are loads of ways to show someone how much you value them: you can just tell them straight, or give a little gift, a little note, or tell other people and let it feed back. But, the best way is through the most precious gift you have - your time. Poet Robert Brault said 'I value the friend who finds time for me on his calendar, but I cherish the friend who for me does not consult his calendar'. How can you possibly show someone their value if you never actually have time for them? You can only maintain a friendship for so long with 'thinking of you' text messages and emails with the subject line 'sorry it's been so long'. It doesn't matter how much you think you care for someone or love someone, at the end of the day you have to show it through your time. Other people need to be loved and valued the way you want to be loved and valued. Make sure that you treat people with respect at all times. Don't ever try to use, control or manipulate people. Remember, if your friends think you are taking advantage of them even after you have explained yourself or your behaviour, you need to re-think your idea of friendship!

content.title: Christ's golden rule (1)
content.introtext:
DO FOR OTHERS WHAT YOU WOULD LIKE THEM TO DO FOR YOU...

MATTHEW 7:12 NLT
What did Jesus mean when He said, 'Do for others what you would like them to do for you...'? He was saying: 1) Value others. Seventy percent of people who leave their jobs leave because they don't feel valued. That shows just how poorly some people treat their employees. There isn't a person in the world that doesn't want to be appreciated. Don't you? 2) Thank them. American Psychologist Donald Laird said, 'Always help people increase their self-esteem. There's no higher compliment you can pay someone than helping them to be useful.'. How can you do that? By letting people know that you think they have done well and saying it - especially in front of their mates. When was the last time a group of your friends sat around biggin' each other up? Try it, there's no feeling like respect from your mates. 3) Trust them. Without trust there can be no real relationship. Once lost, it's virtually impossible get back. Did you know the best way to make someone trustworthy is to trust them? When you encourage someone in that way, especially someone you don't know well they will always do their best not to let you down. The opposite is also true. By not even giving someone a chance they have no reason to be trustworthy. It's not easy but that is what Jesus does for us. No matter how many times we fail him, we get another shot. And he believes in us each and every time. Don't others deserve the same chance from you?

content.title: Forgiving sets you free
content.introtext:
‘”COME TO TERMS QUICKLY WITH YOUR ENEMY…”’

MATTHEW 5:25 NLT
The power you have over anyone who hurts you – is the power of forgiveness. Forgiving – sets both sides free from the negative connection that exists between you. As long as you don’t forgive someone you’ll drag them with you wherever you go. Jesus said, ‘Come to terms quickly with your enemy’ because the best healing is a quick healing. Bitterness does more damage to the one who carries it, than the one who it’s focused on. Think: have you ever been wronged? Have there been times you haven’t got everything you deserved? Right! We live in an imperfect world, don’t we, and as long as we do we won’t see a time when everything we do is fully rewarded. Even when truth is on your side you may never be able to right all the wrongs. Continually fighting for ‘your rights’ can make you downright miserable. What are you really hoping to gain at the end of the day for using up all that time and energy? And besides, when you’re focusing on ‘your rights’ you’re usually looking backwards, not forwards. You can’t make progress when you’re facing the wrong way. Only when you turn your focus in the right direction and forgive, can you move ahead. That doesn’t mean you don’t recognise the wrongs; it means you choose to forgive and focus on what you can control – your attitude and your responses. Doing that will increase your energy, build your potential and set a great example. It also honours God!

content.title: Deal with your hypocrisy!
content.introtext:
‘…NO MORE PRETENSE…’

EPHESIANS 4:25 TM
Listen: ‘”These people honour Me with their lips, but their hearts are far from Me”’ (Matthew 15:8 NIV). That’s Jesus talking about hypocrisy – saying one thing but doing another. It stinks! Two things: 1) Practicing hypocrisy is natural, resist it! Hypocrisy comes naturally to humans. It happens when we let our flesh rule our spirit. We let ourselves get sucked into saying and doing things to impress people and taste that sweet sugar of pride. 2) Breaking with hypocrisy is painful, stay at it! It’s easier to train a new Christian than re-program an old one steeped in religion. Winning any personal battle starts with admitting the problem. It is then that the Holy Spirit can begin His work and put us on the path to freedom. But be warned, it is a long, tough brutal fight. Paul writes, ‘…I insist – and God backs me up on this – that there be no going along with the crowd, the empty-headed, mindless crowd . . . that’s no life for you. You learned Christ! My assumption is that you have paid careful attention to Him, been well instructed in the truth precisely as we have it in Jesus. Since then, we do not have the excuse of ignorance, everything – and I do mean everything – connected with that old way of life has to go. It’s rotten through and through . . . take on an entirely new way of life – a God-fashioned life, a life renewed from the inside and working itself into your conduct as God accurately reproduces His character in you. What this adds up to . . . no more pretence…’ (Ephesians 4:17-25 TM). Could language be any clearer?!

content.title: In case I ever forget!
content.introtext:
‘GIVE THANKS IN ALL CIRCUMSTANCES...’

1 THESSALONIANS 5:18 NIV
The following story has been reprinted by request; it needs no commentary: ‘They huddled inside the storm door – two children in ragged over-sized coats. ‘Any old papers, lady?’ I was busy. I wanted to say no – until I saw their feet. Little sandals sopped with sleet. ‘Come in and I’ll make you some hot cocoa.’ There was no conversation. Their soggy sandals left marks on the hearthstone. I served them cocoa with toast and jam to fortify them against the chill outside. Then I went back to the kitchen to work on my household budget. The silence in the front room struck through me. I looked in. The little girl held the empty cup in her hands looking at it. The boy asked, ‘Lady, are you rich?’ I looked at my shabby slipcovers. ‘Am I rich? Mercy, no!’ The girl put the cup in its saucer – carefully. ‘Your cups match your saucers.’ Her voice was old, with a hunger not of the stomach. Then they left, holding their bundles of paper against the wind. They had not said thank you. They did not need to – they had done more than that. Much more. Plain blue pottery cups and saucers, but they matched. Potatoes and brown gravy; a roof over our heads; my man with a good steady job – these things matched, too. I moved the chairs back from the fire and tidied the living room. The muddy prints of small sandals were still wet upon my hearth. I let them be. I want them there in case I ever forget how rich I am!’

content.title: Be honest!
content.introtext:
‘…THEY FALL FLAT ON THEIR FACES.’

PROVERBS 4:19 TM
In the early 1960’s Dr. Joseph Fletcher, published a book called Situation Ethics. In it he said that love was the only standard for determining right from wrong. The result was chaos. Now, everybody has their own standards, which change from situation to situation. To make matters worse, because of their natural inclination to be easy on themselves, they judge themselves according to their good intentions – but hold others to a higher standard and judge them by their worst actions. The same person who cheats at sport or steals office supplies from his employer wants a good deal from his vehicle mechanic and honestly from the client he deals with in business. It is easy to be disgusted with people who fail the ethics test; especially when they have wronged us. It is a lot harder to make ethical choices in our own lives. Understand this: when you walk close to the edge of honesty, you’re likely to slip over that edge! It may be possible to fool people for a season, but in the long haul your deeds will catch up with you. In the short-term being honest may look like a bad idea - just as someone can temporarily appear to win by being dishonest. However, you inevitably lose when you live by the double standard. Can you think of one person who lived a life of short cuts and deception who it worked out well for in the end? No. Solomon writes: ‘The road of wrongdoing gets darker and darker – travellers cannot see a thing; they fall flat on their faces’ (Proverbs 4:19 TM).

content.title: Confident about Judgement Day
content.introtext:
‘…WE WILL NOT BE AFRAID ON THE DAY OF JUDGEMENT…’

1 JOHN 4:17 NLT
Today we fast-forward to Judgment Day. It’s a day when earthly wealth will not matter. Physical beauty will not be factored. Fame will be forgotten. You might stand next to Napoleon or Julius Caesar, but all eyes will be on the judge: Jesus (see Acts 10:42 & 2 Timothy 4:1). Those who throughout their lives ignored Him will hear the words ‘”Depart from Me…”’ (Matthew 25:41 NIV). But to those who accepted Him as Lord and Saviour, there need be no fear: ‘…we can face Him with confidence because we are like Christ here in this world’ (1 John 4:17 NLT). Think about that! When Jesus looks at you he’ll see a reflection of himself! Since you are ‘in Christ,’ you can view Judgment Day with confidence. Should you fear judgment? No. ‘In Christ’ your sin is gone! Should you fear death? No. ‘In Christ’ is indestructible life! So should we, who are ‘in Christ,’ fear about the Big Day? Not at all: ‘…our standing in the world is identical with Christ’s’ (1 John 4:17 TM). Will you get into Heaven because you are worthy? No. You will get there because the One you trusted is worthy! Listen: ‘As we live in God, our love grows more perfect. So we will not be afraid on the Day of Judgement, but we can face Him with confidence because we are like Christ here in this world. Such love has no fear because perfect love expels all fear. If we are afraid, it is for fear of judgement, and this shows that His love has not been perfected in us’ (1 John 4:17-18 NLT). Some people need to be very scared of Judgement Day – but not those who love Jesus.

content.title: Stinging relationships!
content.introtext:
‘”…WHEN A BLIND MAN LEADS A BLIND MAN, THEY BOTH END UP IN THE DITCH.”’

MATTHEW 15:14 TM
There’s some important growing and maturing that can only happen when you’re with the right people. Listen: one day a scorpion that asked a frog to carry him across the river because he couldn’t swim. ‘How do I know you won’t sting me?’ the frog asked. ‘If I do, we’ll both drown,’ he replied. So the scorpion hopped on. Half way across the river the scorpion stung him. As they were drowning the frog said, ‘Aaaagh! You promised you wouldn’t. Why did you sting me?’ The scorpion replied, ‘I can’t help it, it’s my nature to sting.’ Learn to recognise stinging relationships and walk away from them before they take you down with them. Like a deadly scorpion sting; if you don’t amputate, the poison will spread. Unless you have the courage to cut off what will not heal, you will end up losing much more. You can’t partner closely with someone who doesn’t share your faith. When you feel passionately and want to express it, it’s like trying to breakdance with a mosher! (or the other way around). You picked the wrong dance partner…it’s gonna get messy! Why get tied up with someone who doesn’t share your God-given purpose? ‘But I’m reaching out to my friends – they need Jesus’. You’re right. But have you read Galatians 6:1 or Jude 1:23? Both verses give a warning to make sure that in your reaching out you don’t go too far and fall yourself. Why not pray today for wisdom to find the right balance?

content.title: Work, work, work! (6)
content.introtext:
‘…GOD . . . PUT HIM IN THE GARDEN . . .TO TEND AND KEEP IT.’

GENESIS 2:15 NKJ
David knew that God had called him before he went to work for King Saul! That’s important! You’ve got to know who you are, apart from what you do; otherwise you’ll end up working harder at being appreciated than you will at your job. That sends the wrong signal to your work-mates and supervisors. It also robs you of the solid foundation of security, peacefulness and joy your job provides. God has called you by name, so don’t let your self-worth swing like a politician’s popularity in an election year, up one day and down the next. You’ll end up riding a roller coaster of moodiness and unexpected disappointments. Occasionally you’ll enjoy moments of praise, but they may or may not be sincere; for once others learn that you thrive on recognition; they hold the key to manipulating you for their own purposes. So trust your calling, not their opinions. Thirsting for recognition gives others power over you. That’s dangerous! It’s hard to hear God’s voice (often directing you against the tide of popular opinion) when you have tuned your ears to respond only to your peer group. Listen: ‘…whatever you do, you must do all for the glory of God’ (1 Corinthians 10:31 NLT). If you’re pushing a brush, do it as unto the Lord! You can experience God’s pleasure in what you are doing, even if it’s not your idea of a good time. Put your heart into your work today, and the hours will fly by!

content.title: Work, work, work! (5)
content.introtext:
‘…GOD . . . PUT HIM IN THE GARDEN . . . TO TEND AND KEEP IT.’

GENESIS 2:15 NKJ
Think your job is tough? David worked for a violent King who was troubled by an evil spirit and who threw javelins at him! David’s job was to bring peace, order and productivity. Notice two important things: 1) David didn’t run away from his problem! If David had run away, he would have run away from his opportunity to serve God in that environment. David knew God was up to something good so he kept his joy, tuned his ear to God and found out what the moment demanded in order for God to show up. God is a trouble-shooter. When He sees trouble He sends in a shooter. God can empower you to be a solution to the problem – whatever the problem is. That’s what God’s big plan is all about – bringing His kingdom order to sin’s chaos. 2) When David was called; he came with gifts. He brought ‘…a young goat and a donkey loaded down with food and wine’ (1 Samuel 16:20 NLT). He also brought his harp-playing skills! David wasn’t asking, ‘What’s in it for me?’ We need to get rid of our ‘gimme spirit’ and replace it with a heart that comes to serve. That involves keeping a right attitude, saying, ‘This may be a hard time, but it’s just a season. So I will check my attitude and be grateful for what I have. I can be trusted with what I‘ve been given. While I’m here I’m going to make God happy He picked me for the job. And I’ll show these people I work with that I’ve got something they need.’

content.title: Work, work, work! (4)
content.introtext:
‘…GOD . . . PUT HIM IN THE GARDEN . . . TO TEND AND KEEP IT.’

GENESIS 2:15 NKJ
While David was out in the pasture tending sheep, all human eyes were on charismatic King Saul. But God’s eyes were on David, watching how he worshipped, how his character was coming along, how he confronted evil. Would he be easily intimidated, or did he have the stuff kings were made of? How would he cope with battle? Would he tremble at the giant, or trust his giant God for a breakthrough? Was he proud and self-sufficient, running ahead of God, or did he rely 100% on God? Would he be fair with people? How would he handle authority? Would he diss the people placed over him? Or would he respect those in authority, regardless of their personal shortcomings? David was not fully aware of what God had planned for him, but he acknowledged God in all his ways. Someone once said, ‘Character is what you are when nobody is watching.’ Well, God is always watching! He was watching David; and He is watching you! Most of us don’t work as though God is watching, or even cares about the quality of our work. We fail to realise that ‘No one on earth – from East or West...can raise another person up. It is God alone who judges; He decides who will rise and who will fall.’ (Psalm 75:6-7 NLT). Do you understand that as difficult as your current situation may be, God has placed you there for a purpose? You’re there so that you can learn how to grow in grace and maturity and be trained for better things. Think about it!

content.title: Work, work, work! (3)
content.introtext:
‘…GOD . . . PUT HIM IN THE GARDEN . . . TO TEND AND KEEP IT.’

GENESIS 2:15 NKJ
God sends His people into the world to be ‘salt’. Cooking salt brings out the best flavours. In first aid, salt cleans and kick-starts the healing. How salty are you? God knows that if we become too comfortable in any situation we will just lounge there, not confronting issues but enjoying a bit of peace. However, being too laid back means missing the blessings that come through focused purpose and active warfare. Yes, warfare! Does the image of a soldier seem a bit hardcore to you? Well check this out: ‘Endure hardship with us like a good soldier of Christ Jesus’ (2 Timothy 2:3 NIV). We have been called to go into hostile situations, take the territory and demonstrate to others what it’s like to live under the lordship of Jesus. Don’t get caught up in mundane things like back chatting, name calling and who’s wearing what! There’s a bigger, God-given reason for being in that class or in that job. Has it occurred to you that you could be the only Christian somebody in your place of work or study actually knows? Or better yet, maybe the first one to make Christ look good and His message attractive? Someone’s eternal destiny could be riding on your testimony. They may not be interested in what you have to say at the moment, but life’s storms of death, divorce, sickness or adversity can change all that in an instant. That’s when the world starts crying out for help because nobody else has the answer. So, ‘…whatever you do, you must do all for the glory of God’ (1 Corinthians 10:31 NLT).

content.title: Work, work, work! (2)
content.introtext:
‘…GOD . . . PUT HIM IN THE GARDEN . . . TO TEND AND KEEP IT.’

GENESIS 2:15 NKJ
Work well done is its own reward. It gives us a sense of value. When we’re not achieving anything we tend to get depressed. Don’t fall for the media hype that says successful people don’t need to work. We were all created to fulfil a purpose regardless of how much money is in our bank account. From the time Adam and Eve were created it’s been clear that God intended us to be like our Creator – productive, fruitful and involved in work that contributes to His master plan. Adam and Eve were given responsibility over the garden of Eden and enjoyed a maximum level of fulfilment in their jobs before their selfish decision to start doing things their own way. Listen: ‘…God took the man and put him in the Garden . . . to tend and keep it . . . Out of the ground the Lord God formed every beast of the field and every bird of the air, and brought them to Adam to see what he would call them. And whatever Adam called each living creature, that was its name’ (Genesis 2:15&19 NKJ). The first job description included naming and overseeing – the ultimate manager’s position! Eve was created to share in these endeavours as Adam’s business partner! A man who is not busy doesn’t need a business partner! So you don’t need to look any further than your Bible to realise that productive work is God’s plan for your life. So what are you waiting for? Put this magazine down and get stuck in today!

content.title: Work, work, work! (1)
content.introtext:
‘…GOD . . . PUT HIM IN THE GARDEN . . . TO TEND AND KEEP IT.’

GENESIS 2:15 AMP
Have you started to develop what they call a ‘Work-Ethic’ yet? Sooner or later your Work-Ethic needs to kick in or you’ll find yourself skint and frustrated. The opportunities you have in front of you are vast compared to your parents’ and grandparents’ generations. So what are you complaining about? As difficult as it may be to accept, you are in your present position for a reason and you are there for a season. Study the course; take the tests, get your results and move on to what God has for you next. There’s something you need to learn and take with you from your present situation into your next one. Like what? Skill building and character building for starters. You’re gonna need those computer skills; and you need to remember to save your work before the PC crashes! You need to learn how to be patient, persistent, and how to manage your moods. For those who love the Lord, no experience is ever wasted. Listen: ‘…all things work together for good to those who love God, to those who are the called according to His purpose’ (Romans 8:28 NKJ). Sometimes it’s difficult to see this in the moment. When Joseph was in the pit and the prison, it was hard to see how this road would lead to the palace, but it did. God has a master plan for your life. Your current situation may well be the ideal preparation for the job God has in mind for you. Look back at the steps that have moved you in your present direction. Then trust that God is using each experience to bring about His desire – and your fulfilment.

content.title: Keepers of the knowledge
content.introtext:
‘…THE KNOWLEDGE OF THE SECRETS OF THE KINGDOM OF GOD HAS BEEN GIVEN TO YOU…’

LUKE 8:10 NIV
There are some people in life who seem to know everything about everything. Or at least that’s how they act. Well check this out: whatever they actually do know…they only got to know by looking, listening and learning from every opportunity! Some people you’ll meet will be like a rubbish dump of useless information, others will be a goldmine of valuable lessons. Make sure you pick the right people: those who ask you hard questions, bring you new perspective and keep you on track. When God sends you these people, there are three principles that will help you keep them. 1) Show appreciation. An ungrateful attitude acts like a chilly draught that will slam closed the doors to your future. Never take others for granted and never forget to say ‘thank you’. 2) Carry your own weight. Do not be a free-loader. Always look for ways to be a blessing to those who are blessing you. 3) Understand the boundaries. Just because somebody is taking time to invest in your future doesn’t mean they want to be your New Best Friend. Do they really want to get texts and emails from you every five minutes! Chill out and show respect. At the same time don’t go to the other extreme and start hero-worshipping either. Observe the boundaries that are naturally in the relationship and you will always have someone in your life who can help get you to where you need to go.

content.title: Get real with Jesus
content.introtext:
‘”…GO NOW AND LEAVE YOUR LIFE OF SIN”’

JOHN 8:11 NIV
Jesus always told it like it is. He would never put a bandage on an infected wound. He always insisted on getting right down to the root cause of a problem. When a woman who’d been caught having sex with a bloke who wasn’t her husband was brought to him he first dealt with her accusers and then told her lovingly but firmly, ‘”…Go now and leave your life of sin.”’ (John 8:11 NIV) We come to the same Jesus with the same burden of guilt and shame that woman felt. Listen: ‘Since he himself has gone through suffering and temptation, he is able to help us when we are being tempted’ (Hebrews 2:18 NLT). Sadly, in our ‘Do it yourself’ culture, we often try to sort our issues out everywhere else before coming to Jesus. Why? Because He’s the only person we can’t fake it to – we have to be 100% real with him and that’s scary! But it’s worth it! Job writes, ‘…prepare your heart and lift up your hands to Him in prayer. Get rid of your sins, and leave all iniquity behind you. Then your face will brighten in innocence. You will be strong and free of fear. You will forget your misery. It will all be gone like water under the bridge . . . you will have courage because you will have hope. You will be protected and will rest in safety. You will lie down unafraid, and many will look to you for help’ (Job 11:13-19 NLT). Jesus invites you to step into the river of God’s mercy today. Let it flow over you setting you free. Whether it’s the guilt of something you have done, or the pain for something that was done to you – get real with Jesus!

content.title: Darkness vs light
content.introtext:
‘…THE GLORY OF THE LORD WILL SHINE OVER YOU’

ISAIAH 60:2 NLT
The most recent school shooting in America left 12 pupils dead and left lots more wounded in hospital. A student, smiling and shouting, gunned down his classmates then turned the gun on himself. ‘Well, America’s full of guns, it would never happen here.’ Oh really…well let’s consider the warning signs: There have been some heartbreaking stories in our own news recently of kids being really cruel to other kids. And whaddaya know – the American school carnage began as a seed planted in the imagination of a boy left alone with video games in which the good guy is actually the bad guy, and winners blow away losers, leaving dismembered bodies in scenes of blood and gore. ‘Whoa…hang about, they’re only games! Maybe! But the shops report that the more violent and bloodthirsty the game, the better it sells. Think about it: if violence has become your generation’s most popular form of entertainment, what does that tell us about the future? What kind of stuff will we be seeing on the six o’clock news in ten years time? The Bible teaches that as a young person you need to develop an inner life with three elements: a) Love – choosing to work on those vital family ties and not looking for it in all the wrong places b) Law – God has given us rules to live by, including the rewards of keeping them and the consequences of breaking them c) Light – spending time in God’s presence – worshipping, praying – do this while you’re young, and the darkness of the world will never overcome your brightness, listen: ‘Darkness as black as night will cover all the nations…but the glory of the Lord will shine over you’ Isaiah 60:2 NLT.

content.title: Making a difference
content.introtext:
‘…SERVE EACH OTHER WITH LOVE.’

GALATIANS 5:13 NCV
Listen: ‘By love serve one another.’ William Booth, founder of The Salvation Army, lived by those words. And check this out - when he was too old and sick to attend their General Conference, he sent a one-word telegram; one word that ignited the auditorium and brought the crowd to their feet – ‘Others!’ William Wilberforce lived by those words too. History records that in one 30-day period in 1814, without the aid of computers or email, his efforts produced 1,500,000 signatures on a petition protesting against slavery, which he then presented to the British Parliament. He was constantly under threat from the slave owners, not to mention shady MPs who owned their own plantations and slaves. His fight lasted for decades. Encouraged by people like John Wesley, Wilberforce stirred the conscience of the whole nation. One of the greatest influences in Wilberforce’s life was his friend John Newton, writer of the song Amazing Grace. John had been a slave trader but gave it up when he had a real encounter with Jesus. On his deathbed in 1833, that Wilberforce received the news that Parliament had finally passed a law to ban slavery forever. Eventually his influence reached America and slavery was abolished there too. Think one person can’t make a difference? Think again! Why don’t you pray: ‘Lord, You have given me unique abilities. Please help me to be me and not pretend to be someone else. Save me from moodiness or jealousy toward others. Help me to discover who You created me to be. Help me to enjoy the things that make me so special. Help me to realise that I was born to make a difference. Help me to give this world something that no one else can.’

content.title: The Judging Panel
content.introtext:
‘…IF I WERE STILL TRYING TO PLEASE PEOPLE, I WOULD NOT BE CHRIST’S SERVANT.’

GALATIANS 1:10 NLT
When Jesus spoke, He was free from the need to create an impression. That means He was free to ‘speak the truth in love’ (see Eph 4:15). Are you? Or is your life a bit like one really long episode of Fame Academy; where everything you say or do is a performance designed to impress ‘The Judges’? Almost certainly our family would be on that judging panel; our mates too. Plus our teachers, youth leaders and maybe even the people at the bus stop in the morning! It gets pretty crowded in that judges, box. Of course, you will never really know for sure what anybody’s actually thinking about you. The drawback of a performance life is that it’s not really a life at all; it’s an act made up of what we think other people are thinking. When we are young we can get into a bad habit of living to please other people. When we are older and wiser we realise that most of the time others weren’t even thinking about us anyway! When our identity gets wrapped up in other people’s opinions, we set ourselves up for approval addiction. Our sense of self worth is always on the line. That’s not how God wants us to live!
