No one’s approval can affect us – unless we choose to let it. The same is true for disapproval! That’s why Paul writes, ‘…I’m not trying to be a people pleaser! If I were still trying to please people, I would not be Christ’s servant’ (Galatians 1:10 NLT).

content.title: Sun Nov 13 The spirit-filled life
content.introtext:
‘…BE FILLED WITH THE SPIRIT.’

EPHESIANS 5:18 NIV
God’s indwelling Spirit does three wonderful things for each of us: 1) He seals us! Listen: ‘…ye were sealed with that Holy Spirit…’ (Ephesians 1:13 KJV). To protect a letter you seal the envelope. To keep air out of the jar you seal its mouth with a rubber-ringed lid. To seal a deal, you sign the contract. A seal declares importance, value and ownership. Are you getting the idea? 2) He protects us! Peter says we are ‘…shielded by God’s power…’ (1 Peter 1:5 NIV). Do you have any idea how many times God has stepped between you and the enemy, protecting you from harm? Deep within each of us God’s Spirit whispers, ‘You are mine, and what I own I protect and care for’ 3) He makes sure our prayers are heard! Listen: ‘The Spirit comes to the aid of our weakness. We do not even know how we ought to pray, but through our inarticulate groans the Spirit Himself is pleading for us, and God who searches our inmost being knows what the Spirit means, because He pleads for God’s own people, in God’s own way’ (Romans 8:26-27 NEB). Notice: ‘the Spirit comes to the aid of our weakness.’ Weak bodies, weak wills, weak faith. How good to know that it’s not up to us. ‘The Spirit Himself is pleading for us.’ None of us pray as much as we should – but we all pray more than we think – because the Holy Spirit turns our very sighs into petitions and makes sure that we get heard. Sealed! Protected! Heard! Spirit-filled living – refuse to settle for less.

content.title: Welcoming the Holy Spirit
content.introtext:
‘FOR YOU WHO WELCOME HIM...’

ROMANS 8:9 TM
Listen: ‘…Those who trust God’s action in them…experience life on God’s terms’ (Romans 8:5,9-10 TM). All believers have God in their heart – but not all believers have given their whole heart to God! The question is not, ‘how can I have more of the Holy Spirit?’ It’s ‘how can the Spirit have more of me?’ Let’s go down the list: a) your tongue. Do you tend to stretch the truth? Do you gossip? b) your language. Is your conversation all effing and blinding and dirty jokes? c) your grudges. Do you hold resentment vowing to get even one day? d) your activity. Do you just kick back because you think the world somehow owes you something? If you find these questions too personal, maybe you can take it up in heaven with the apostle Paul! Listen to his list: ‘Put away all falsehood and tell your neighbour the truth...do not sin by letting anger gain control over you...If you are a thief, stop stealing. Begin using your hands for honest work, and then give generously to others in need. Do not use foul or abusive language. Let everything you say be good and helpful...And do not bring sorrow to God’s Holy Spirit by the way you live...Get rid of all bitterness, rage, anger, harsh words and slander, as well as all types of malicious behaviour’ (Ephesians 4:25-31 NLT). Notice the words ‘do not bring sorrow to God’s Holy Spirit by the way you live.’ This calls for getting up each morning and saying, ‘Good morning Holy Spirit! Guide me today, empower me please and help me to honour You in all that I do.. Amen.’

content.title: The cross in the chaos
content.introtext:
‘”THOUGH THE MOUNTAINS BE SHAKEN . . . MY UNFAILING LOVE FOR YOU WILL NOT…”’

ISAIAH 54:10 NIV
On September 11th, 2001, as volunteer Frank Silecchia sifted through the carnage at the World Trade Centre he found 47 bodies but no survivors. But something did catch his attention – a cross standing upright against the dusty sunrise. The unmistakeable shape was made by steel beams from two different buildings. As they’d crashed into each other, the girders, forged together by the fire, had created a giant cross in the chaos. When death or disease claims a loved one, or financial disaster wipes out our sense of security, we wonder, ‘Where’s God in all of this? Does He care?’ We can handle almost anything as long as we know He’s there. When we’re not sure, the doubt creates fear. When God introduced Himself to Moses through a burning bush He said, ‘”I Am”’ (Exodus 3:14 NAS). That has not changed. He is still the same right here, right now ‘I Am’ God. Jesus said, ‘”…Before Abraham was born, I Am”’ (John 8:58 NIV). That means He doesn’t need a crystal ball to predict the future, or a rear view mirror to see the past. He is ‘the same yesterday, today, and forever’ (Hebrews 13:8 NLT). He still walks into the events of our lives: weddings, funerals, broken homes, hospital rooms, bankrupt businesses and jail cells saying ‘I am – always with you.’ Listen: ‘”Though the mountains be shaken and the hills be removed, yet My unfailing love for you will not...” says the Lord who has compassion on you’ (Isaiah 54:10 NIV). If you look closer you will see He is standing right there with you – and has been all along!

content.title: Seeing others through God’s eyes!
content.introtext:
‘…WHILE WE WERE STILL SINNERS, CHRIST DIED FOR US.’

ROMANS 5:8 NIV
The old Bible sat in the bargain basket amongst hundreds of tattered books. A lot of people had picked it up and thumbed through its faded pages. It wasn’t in very good shape – certainly not worth the £2 on the sticker. So it was thrown aside. But then a man picked it up and gasped in shock. He rushed to the counter and paid the puny amount for the old book. It was an original Gutenberg, 500 years old and one of the first books ever printed! It was worth more than one million pounds! You have to wonder who turned it over to the ‘Last Chance Booksellers.’ The world cast it aside, unaware of its value. And we do the same thing, don’t we? Seeds of greatness often lie buried within unpromising people that amazingly spring to life when they are watered and nurtured. In truth, we were all overlooked until Jesus saw something of value in us. But rather than paying a bargain price He paid the highest price. Listen: ‘…While we were still sinners, Christ died for us’ (Romans 5.8.NIV). A different world would appear before our eyes if we could begin to see every man, woman, boy and girl as a precious treasure that God could not live without, that Christ died to redeem. Look at Matthew: when Jesus found him he was a dodgy tax collector, a wheeler-dealer working for the Romans. But Jesus said, ‘”Follow Me”’ (Matthew 9:9 NIV). Matthew did and never looked back. Aren’t you glad that God found you!

content.title: The way of love.
content.introtext:
‘…[LOVE] NEVER LOOKS BACK, BUT KEEPS GOING TO THE END’

1 CORINTHIANS 13:7 TM
One night in bed a wife says to her husband of 50 years, ‘When we were young you used to hold my hand.’ Slowly, a little irritated, his hand reaches out. ‘And when we were young you used to snuggle up against me.’ A little more slowly his body creaks and turns; nestling against hers. ‘And when we were young you used to nibble on my ear.’ Abruptly the covers are thrown back and he lurches out of bed. ‘Where are you going?’ she asks, a little hurt. ‘To get my teeth,’ he grumbles. When you’re young, free and single it’s hard to imagine all the changes a life-long relationship will bring. For lots of young people finding the perfect partner becomes an endless quest, filled with heartache. Well, here’s a tip, instead of working on finding the perfect someone for you, why not work on becoming the perfect you for someone! All the instructions are in God’s word. Listen to this, it’s not just for weddings, it’s for the whole of your life: ‘Love never gives up. Love cares more for others than for self. Love doesn't want what it doesn't have. Love doesn't strut, it doesn't have a swelled head, doesn't force itself on others, isn't always ‘me first’, doesn't fly off the handle, doesn't keep score of the sins of others, doesn't revel when others grovel, takes pleasure in the flowering of truth, puts up with anything, trusts God always, always looks for the best, never looks back, but keeps going to the end’. (1 Cor.13.4-7 TM)

content.title: True Joy (2)
content.introtext:
‘YOU WILL GO OUT IN JOY…’

ISAIAH 55:12 NIV
Fred and Betty were driving home from church. ‘Fred, did you notice the pastor’s sermon wasn’t up to scratch today?’ Fred replied, ‘No, not really.’ Betty continued, ‘Well, did you notice that the worship was flat?’ He responded, ‘No, I didn’t.’ Undaunted, Betty continued, ‘Well, you must have noticed that young couple and their kids right in front of us, with all the noise and commotion they made, they ruined the whole service!’ ‘Sorry dear, I didn’t notice’. In disgust Betty finally puffs, ‘Honestly, Fred, I don’t know why you even bother going to church!’ Why do some churchgoers think they have a right to act like Simon Cowell? When Paul writes, ‘Come out from them and be separate…’ (2 Corinthians 6:17 NIV), he’s saying our faith should make us different, but not negatively different – positively different! Understand this: unless you commit yourself every single day to walking in the joy of the Lord, you will find negative ways of separating yourself from non-believers. Stop and think who you represent. Jesus is called ‘…the Good Shepherd…’ (John 10:11 NIV). ‘Good’ is such an understatement! His goodness is a powerful attracting force that wins people’s hearts. Does that describe you? It should! Paul writes, ‘Rejoice in the Lord always…’ (Philippians 4:4 NIV). ‘Easy for Paul to say, he doesn’t have my problems.’ Really? When he wrote those words he was in prison with no chance of getting out! Happiness is an emotion, but joy is a fruit of the Spirit (see Galatians 5.22 NIV). Any time, any where, it is available to you. Every morning you can get up and say, ‘Today I will go out with joy, because God’s Word demands it and a hurting world needs it!’

content.title: True Joy (1)
content.introtext:
...THE JOY OF THE LORD IS YOUR STRENGTH.

NEHEMIAH 8:10
True joy only comes to those who have devoted themselves to something bigger than their own happiness and personal interests. Nehemiah told the Israelites, 'Don't feel bad. The joy of the Lord is your strength' (Nehemiah 8:10 TM). True joy always involves three things: 1) a conscious decision to focus every day on God's goodness 2) reaching out to bless other people every chance you get 3) understanding that joy produces strength, which explains why your joy is so high on the devil's hit list. If you lose your joy you lose your strength, and that's no good! American author Dallas Willard writes: 'to cut off the joys and pleasures associated with our bodily lives and social existence as unspiritual, can have the effect of weakening us in our efforts to do right.' There are basically three kinds of people: 1) the joy-guilty: who believe we are not supposed to be happy, and have fun because life is to be handled seriously. These people feel guilty about feeling good 2) the joy-angry: who've been hurt by life and whose anger simmers just beneath the surface. If you let them, they will turn your sunshine to rain because your joy really bothers them 3) the joy-factory: producing joy everywhere they go. When you are around them, they breathe life into you. If you are joy-guilty or joy-angry try spending a little time with a joy factory. Try to find out how they produce so much joy. You'll probably find it's nothing to do with how easy their life has been, or how much money they have in the bank. More likely they have had a revelation about God that you need to get too.

content.title: On guard!
content.introtext:
...HIS PEACE WILL GUARD YOUR HEARTS AND MINDS...

PHILIPPIANS 4:7
Jesus said, '"Can all your worries add a single moment to your life? Of course not"' (Matthew 6:27 NLT). Worry changes nothing. When was the last time you solved a problem by worrying about it? Imagine somebody saying, 'I got behind on my bills so I decided to worry my way out of debt. And you know, it worked! You can't add one day to your life or one bit of life to your day by worrying; all worry will do is bring you wrinkles and grey hairs! Listen to these two Scriptures: 'Those who trust in the Lord are like Mount Zion, which cannot be shaken but endures forever' (Psalm 125:1 NIV); 'You will keep in perfect peace him whose mind is steadfast, because he trusts in You' (Isaiah 26:3 NIV). We don't get up in the morning and decide 'Today I'm going to doubt God' yet when we worry that's what we do. Paul writes, '...His peace will guard your hearts and minds...' Paul uses a military word here - guard. The Philippians lived under Roman occupation and were used to seeing the Centurions guarding their town. What security! Before an enemy could get to them they first had to get past the rock-hard Roman guards. And you know what? God gives you the same guarantee! His peace is not wishy washy - it is solid. Your heart and mind are completely safe if you'll let His peace stand guard. Why don't you ask Him for His peace right now?

content.title: You can start again!
content.introtext:
WITH YOU THERE IS FORGIVENESS...

PSALM 130:4
Some people grow through failure; others never recover from it. They talk about the past all the time because they can't get beyond it. What's the answer? See your mistakes as stepping-stones rather than stumbling blocks! 'How do I do that?' By doing three things. 1) You must push! You've got to push through emotions like Regret: 'If only I hadn't failed.' Frustration: 'I thought my idea was great, why didn't they?' Self-pity: 'They hurt me so I will just sit here and lick my wounds.' Paralysis: 'I will never get beyond this.' When it comes to emotions, the only way out is pushing through! 2) You must bounce! Solomon says, 'Though a righteous man falls seven times, he rises again...' (Proverbs 24:16 NIV). You must be like the lady who said, 'I'm never down, I'm either up or I'm getting up!' So, if you fall, will you bounce back up and try again? 3) You must remember! There's only one way - God's way! Samson blew it by getting too close to the wrong woman (see Judges 16). Jonah blew it by trying to run from God's call (see Jonah 1:3). Peter blew it by denying his Lord (See Matthew 26:74) But God used all of them eventually - when they were willing to do it God's way. So remember, don't blow it by thinking your way is better than God's. The Psalmist writes: 'With You there is forgiveness...' God's forgiveness is received by faith - and it involves forgiving yourself! 'But what about my past?' The moment you accept God's forgiveness you don't have a past, you only have a future. You're free to get on with your life!

content.title: The pruning process!
content.introtext:
...HE PRUNES THE BRANCHES THAT DO BEAR FRUIT SO THEY WILL PRODUCE EVEN MORE

JOHN 15:2
The pruning process! 04 Nov 2005 '...HE PRUNES THE BRANCHES THAT DO BEAR FRUIT SO THEY WILL PRODUCE EVEN MORE' JOHN 15:2 Listen: 'He cuts off every branch that doesn't bear fruit and he prunes the branches that do bear fruit so they will produce even more' (John 15:2NLT). There's a time for planting and a time for pruning. Maybe God is at work in your life today taking away branches that don't belong, and pruning ones that do. What kind of things does God take away? Things that have served their purpose. Things that refuse to change. Things that will give you trouble later on. Things that are standing in the way of greater fruitfulness. Things that are holding you back. Things He has not chosen for you. Have you ever seen a freshly pruned tree? Doesn't look too good, does it? And when God starts to cut back certain things in your life in order to re-direct your energies, you won't look too good either. Sometimes this means: a) having less nice stuff for a while b) letting go of things you depended on, c) being unable to explain to your mates why you are even going through the pruning process. God knows what needs to be cut back in your life; He also knows what needs to be cut off. Trust Him. Even though you can't understand what He's doing, just pray, 'Lord, if I needed it You would let me keep it, so I open my hand to You today. Send whoever You will and take away whoever You will. I'll praise You when they come and I'll praise You when they go, because Your approval is my reward, and Your purpose is my reason to live.'

content.title: Let's get real!
content.introtext:
...WE ARE LIKE CLAY JARS THAT HOLD THE TREASURE...

2 CORINTHIANS 4:7
If all we ever offer people are one-sided testimonies of success without failure, eventually they'll get fed up. They'll think that while they struggle, we have it all together. That's because we exaggerated our stories and failed to tell the whole truth. God help us! Our message is simple: we were saved by grace, we are being saved by grace, and we will be saved by grace. It was after David's shameful sin with Bathsheba that God's mercy touched his life and enabled him to write his greatest Psalms; the ones we all find comfort and healing in. It was after Paul had filled jails and graves with believers that he wrote, 'I owe a great debt...' (Romans 1:14 TLB) and then went on to impact the whole world with the Gospel. Don't quit because someone has discovered you are 'a clay jar'; it's the treasure inside that counts! There will be times in your life when you will need to reach out through your pain... because the message that saves others is the same one that saves us too! Accepting the rejected is not the weakness of the Gospel; it is its strength! There's a world of difference between a proud heart that says 'I've got it all together' and the cry of a troubled heart that says, 'take my broken life.' One glimpse of God's grace brings all of us to our knees, confessing our sins, and becoming determined to live for him with all our heart, soul, mind and strength... (see Luke

content.title: Lads, learn to listen!
content.introtext:
...BE QUICK TO LISTEN, SLOW TO SPEAK...

JAMES 1:19
There's no doubt about it, men and women are very different. Men generally tend to be 'fixers'; fix the PC, fix the leaky tap, etc. So it comes as a shock to most blokes when it seems like their wives or girlfriends would rather talk about a situation than fix it. Indeed, just having her fella sit down and actually listen to how she feels often changes her entire outlook. Isn't that right girls! Has the situation been resolved? Not necessarily. But something important has happened. The guy who used to hang on every word at the start of the relationship has suddenly returned showing that feelings, thoughts and struggles really do matter to him. A fella who learns this sooner rather than later, finds himself with a happy chick! Often our prayers don't seem to change our circumstances, yet we feel much better when we have prayed. Why? Because we have shared it with One Who is able, and cares enough to listen; so we walk away with a changed outlook. Paul writes, 'Husbands, love your wives, as Christ loved the church and gave Himself [His time, His attention, His support, His encouragement, and His life] up for her' (Ephesians 5:25 AMP). Isn't it amazing how many men can soar in their careers, yet be clueless about their relationships! You lads (you're not too young) whether it's your girlfriend, your sister or your mum the same rule applies! But be warned, the first time you attempt this don't be surprised if a female gets suspicious, looks confused or collapses and has to pick herself up off the floor. Her reaction will be in proportion to the length of time you have been emotionally absent!

content.title: Blessed by your enemies
content.introtext:
THE RAVENS BROUGHT HIM BREAD...

1 KINGS 17:6
Don't limit God to only blessing you through people you approve of. That's daft! Nehemiah built the walls of Jerusalem with money provided by a pagan king. God used a raven, a dirty bird, to feed the prophet Elijah. When God moves, people who you would normally shun may become the source of what you need. By avoiding them you could be blocking a blessing God has in mind for you. Your tendency to alienate certain people can cause your life to get stuck like a scratched CD. You can't escape difficult people but with God's help you can be positive in the middle of negativity. David had the ability to work effectively with difficult people. It doesn't get much more challenging than working with someone who has an 'evil spirit' troubling them like King Saul did. At first David enjoyed Saul's favour, but later Saul tried to kill him. Yet David never changed his strategy. He would never diss Saul or his family because for better or worse he respected God's decision to make Saul King. And because of the amazing character and wisdom with which he handled the situation, he ended up becoming the next King! God's principles are timeless and David followed them daily. David didn't limit himself and he definitely didn't limit God. By getting his eyes off people, being neither impressed nor depressed by them, David made sure God always had priority. And many times God used unlikely people to bless David. So, learn to get along with difficult people; your greatest challenge today may be the very person who assists and blesses you tomorrow.

content.title: Got your back?
content.introtext:
A FRIEND LOVES AT ALL TIMES...

PROVERBS 17:17 NIV
If you fall, not everybody will cheer you on when you get back up. In one of Jesus' stories, the older brother wasn't too happy when the Lost Son came back home. And there are still lots of people like that around. Basically there are three kinds of people: 1) the users. These people will suck up to you but only for what they can get from you. When trouble hits your life, you won't see them for dust because they don't want to be linked with your mistakes. Don't be resentful toward them; users aren't bad, they're just insecure and self-serving 2) the cautious. There are loads of these dudes around. When you're in trouble they'll wait to see if you get out of it. And even then they'll keep their options open. Before they decide to accept you they'll first check to see who else does. Paul says, '...appreciate those who work hard among you...' (1Thessalonians 5:12 NCV). When it comes to the cautious, love them but don't build your life on them 3) the devoted. These are the people Solomon talks about in Proverbs 17:17: 'A friend loves you all times, and a brother helps in time of trouble' (NCV). There's an old saying that says, 'In the good times our friends know us, in the bad times we know our friends.' If you have even a handful of devoted friends you are truly blessed, 'coz they'll stand by you at all times. They're not just strong in faith, they're strong in fight. They help in times of trouble.' Look after these friendships, invest in them, 'coz without them you'll struggle to reach your God-given destiny.

content.title: Purity!
content.introtext:
CREATE IN ME A PURE HEART, O GOD...

PSALMS 51:10 NCV
Even though David was a man of courage, strength and creativity, he constantly struggled with a weakness in his life. What was it? He liked the ladies! Not just the single girls...he went after married ones too. God loved David, but He didn't love his sin - not one bit. He saw what David got up to with another man's wife and waited... He even watched as David sent the woman's husband off to the front line of a battle, where he died... and still God waited. 'Why did God wait?' He wanted to give David a chance to confess what he had done wrong and ask God for forgiveness. In the end a prophet bloke called Nathan was sent by God to David to let him know that God had seen it all and wasn't happy! David responded to God, 'Have mercy on me...cleanse me from my sin...create in me a pure heart, O God' (Psalm 52:1-10 NIV). When God sees real repentance, He comes and totally takes our sin and removes it from us...not only that, He chooses to treat us like it never happened. We all have weaknesses we struggle with, but we have something called, 'self-control' which helps us to not do it. If you know you need to get right with God, say now 'God I have sinned against You and hurt myself and our relationship. Please forgive me, and make me clean. Please help me to choose to say, 'no' when I am tempted. Thank you that You love me'.

content.title: Don't quit!
content.introtext:
BLESSED IS THE MAN WHO PERSEVERES [THROUGH] THE TEST [FOR] HE WILL RECEIVE THE CROWN...

JAMES 1:12 NIV
Are you thinking about quitting? Life's full of quitting points! But if you throw in the towel on your studies, your friends, your hopes or your dreams, you might regret it for the rest of your life. Only by staying in the race can God strengthen you and make you a winner. About 100 years ago a Christian preacher and activist called Fred Meyer said, 'You never test the resources of God until you attempt the impossible.' Quitting doesn't build character, endurance does. It develops something in you that nothing else can; that's why God says it is 'blessed.' It sustains courage, gives staying power to discipline and turns dreams into reality. Nobody knew more about endurance than Jesus. He endured all the way to the cross; when they ripped the hair from His face, when the whip tore His flesh, when they nailed Him to a cross, when His friends abandoned Him, when the crowd mocked Him, when God Himself turned His face away, and hell rose up and cried, 'Quit!' But no! Listen, Jesus: '...for the joy that was set before him endured the cross...' (Hebrews 12:2 NIV). Remember, '...God...rewards those who earnestly seek Him' (Hebrews 11:6 NIV). The Bible says you will find Him '...when you seek...with all your heart' (Jeremiah 29:13 NIV). Those promises apply to you! Test them! Tell God, 'I'm gonna keep going and trusting You for the strength to get through.' Chances are when you do you'll see God step in like a coach and say, 'Come on, you can do it; just focus on me and the finish line.'

content.title: Can you see it?
content.introtext:
PEOPLES' THOUGHTS CAN BE LIKE A DEEP WELL, BUT SOMEONE WITH UNDERSTANDING CAN FIND WISDOM THERE.

PROVERBS 20:5 NCV
Being made in God's image gives us amazing potential. But sometimes it takes someone who is clued up to recognise it and 'draw it out.' Too many of us are good at seeing the obvious. We're quick to label people as arrogant, bad-tempered, or weak. But a person with spiritual understanding sees beyond that to the hopes and fears behind their behaviour. The people who knew Simon knew his tendency put his foot in his mouth and be impulsive. But Jesus saw something else. That's why He renamed him Peter, meaning a rock suitable for a foundation. Just imagine the look on the disciples' faces when Jesus said, '...you are Peter...upon this rock I will build my church, and...hell will not conquer it' (Matthew 16:18 NLT). But Peter did become a rock, a respected leader and a founder of the church. And all because of Jesus' ability and willingness to look beyond his character flaws to what was inside. Today we need more people who'll pray for this generation, look beyond their flaws and 'draw out' their qualities. Set yourself a challenge to look for the hidden amazing qualities in your mates, even when they let you down. Next time you're around your family, don't just start teasing, moaning or picking out faults - make a choice to shut up, open your eyes, and look for their great qualities! Remember, God made them too: you diss them; you diss Him. Ask God today for eyes to see what others miss.

content.title: Go home!
content.introtext:
GO HOME...AND TELL THEM HOW MUCH THE LORD HAS DONE FOR YOU...

MARK 5:19 CEV
Have you ever been in a church event that was so great you were gutted when it finished? Or visited a place so beautiful, you just wanted to stay there forever? Now and again, God focuses on strengthening us in our spirits, so we can do the next task and this strength effects our emotions and bodies too. But there comes a time when He says to us what He said to the man with the unclean spirit, 'Go home...and tell them how much the Lord has done for you...' Notice, when Jesus healed this man the Bible says, '...people came out to see what had happened' (v.14 CEV). And when God changes you, your family, your mates and your neighbours are all gonna notice it too. So don't be shy about telling them what God's done for you. Be tactful, but be bold and be happy about it! This tormented man's first response to being set free was to jump into the boat and go with Jesus. But Jesus stopped him. Why? Because his purpose wasn't in the graveyard where Jesus found him, or travelling with the 12 disciples. No, it was to be a 'mad-for-it' evangelist! And when he '...went [home]...and began telling...how much Jesus had done... Everyone who heard...was amazed' (v.20 CEV). God doesn't want you to live cut off from the rest of the world; He wants you to tell those you know and love what He can do in their lives too. So, today if you ask Him where He wants you to go, chances are He'll say, 'Go home.'

content.title: Not an inch!
content.introtext:
LEAVE NO...FOOTHOLD FOR THE DEVIL...

EPHESIANS 4:27 AMP
Ever notice that Jesus didn't waste a load of time talking about what the devil was doing? Instead He dealt with him by quoting God's Word and kicking him out of people's lives. In Mark chapter five, the man living among the tombs was tormented by evil spirits. When Jesus confronted them, the Bible says the evil spirits begged him 'not to send them out of the area' (v.10 NIV). Why? Because they didn't want to quit their position or give up their assigned turf. When they realized that Jesus was determined to get them out of the man, they pleaded with Him to let them at least stay in the same area. When Jesus gave them permission to enter into a herd of pigs that were nearby, the pigs immediately '...rushed...into the lake and were drowned' (Mark 5:13 NIV). There's a lesson here: satan will object to your freedom, but he'll get really, really annoyed about being kicked out of every area of your life. How can you really annoy the devil? Easy, fill your new life with God! Fill yourself to bursting with the Word of God and ask the Holy Spirit to fill you to the max so that you will have the self control to not go back to your old ways and I bet you'll be amazed! Your immediate response to any suggested compromise by the enemy must always be a resounding, 'No! Not an inch!' Then pray, asking God to protect your heart and mind as you have a God-filled day!

content.title: The devil is a liar!
content.introtext:
...THE TRUTH WILL SET YOU FREE.

JOHN 8:32 NLT
A lie is as effective as the truth - if you believe it. And satan is 'the father of lies.' Here are three ways he tries to crush you: 1) feelings. Through lying words he'll convince you that you don't deserve to be forgiven; through lying emotions he'll try to make you feel like you're not forgiven. Here's where victory is decided. Stand your ground. The work is done in you. God's Word says so; now you must begin to say so too. Chose God's word instead of the lie. Satan will remind you of all your past mistakes and failures. By having to deal with them you will experience the same emotions you had when you went through them before. He plans it that way. The idea is to make you feel like nothing has changed - what a liar! 2) shock. Satan doesn't give up without a fight (attack is just proof that you haven't been conquered). If you're not expecting it, you'll think, 'nothing has changed, or why would I still be fighting the same old battles?' 3) doubt. Satan's third strategy is to get you to give up and say, 'What's the use, nothing's changed!' When you speak like that you are signing the delivery note and accepting the package. Don't do it! The Bible says, 'You might get trapped by what you say...' (Proverbs 6:2 NCV). Stop. Think before you speak. Don't agree with the one who only wants bad for you. Agree with the one who knows you better than you know yourself and is totally mad about you!

content.title: Don't worry - worship!
content.introtext:
WHEN HE SAW JESUS...HE...WORSHIPPED HIM.

MARK 5:6 KJV
What is worship? Worship is our response to God's love for us. We can express our worship through songs, music, dancing, even helping people. When you experience God in any way, you get a massive desire to make some sort of expression. You kinda wanna point and say, 'Look everyone, look how much God cares for me!' Paul says, 'At the name of Jesus every knee should bow...in heaven, and...on earth...and... confess that Jesus...is Lord...' (Philippians 2:10-11 NKJ). Worship is powerful. Next time you have a rough day, make the choice to acknowledge God. When you start to thank God in the hard times, it busts up anything the devil was trying to do. The Bible says, '...no weapon used against you will defeat you...these are the good things my servants receive...' (Isaiah 54:17 NCV). That includes anything that would try to destroy you and your family; old hurts, painful memories, addictions, past sins, they must all bow in submission when the Name of Jesus is lifted up in praise. In the New Testament, when the man from the tombs began to worship, the forces of evil cried out, '...what business do we have with each other...Jesus...Son of the Most High God?...' (Mark 5:7 NAS). The truth is satan's cronies have nothing in common with Jesus - no association and no relationship. And the only business He has with them is to get rid of them! David said, '...my head is lifted...above my enemies all around me...I will sing and make melody to the Lord' (Psalm 27:6 NRS). Worship is one of the keys to not getting down about life. So talk to Jesus today, acknowledge that He is King, and watch your worship work!

content.title: Stop it!
content.introtext:
...HE WAS IN THE...TOMBS, CRYING OUT

MARK 5:5 NKJ
Discussing his low self-esteem, cartoon character Charlie Brown says, 'It goes back to when I first set foot on the stage of life. They looked at me and said, "He's just not right for the part!"' You might smile, but when you have spent your whole life putting yourself down you, know exactly what he means. The man in the tombs spent his days, 'crying out' because he thought he was worthless. And many of us have a similar view of ourselves, we think we have no value. Your self-image is second only to your faith in God. It doesn't matter what others think of you, what matters is what you think of yourself; based on what God thinks! Self-esteem has to come from yourself. That's why it's hard to believe the good things people say about you when you can't see them yourself. Plus, how you treat other people flows directly from your pool of personal dignity and self-respect. It's impossible to '...love your neighbour as yourself' (Matthew 19:19 NIV) when you don't even like yourself. But God is in the business of building up His children. He will reveal how valuable you are, not only in big ways, but in the small things too! One of the only times we're ok about bigging ourselves up is on application forms! Stop putting yourself down! God made you the way you are in order to use you the way He planned. Start telling Him what a great job He did. And remember, He loves you unconditionally - and that's the only reason you need for loving yourself!

content.title: Crying on the inside
content.introtext:
...HE WAS IN THE...TOMBS, CRYING OUT

MARK 5:5 NKJ
Jesus didn't cross the Sea of Galilee in a storm just to meet with a disturbed man. There were plenty of those on shore! He did it because, although this man seemed so fierce and tough on the outside, it was from deep inside that 'he was... crying out.' He hated who he'd become and the situation he was in. How about you? Are you crying on the inside because of how your life has turned out? Maybe you intended to be a better friend, a more focused student, an honest worker or a kinder person, but things didn't work out the way you planned and now you are in a mess. Jesus said, 'Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they shall be filled' (Matthew 5:6 NIV). Wanting to change is the first step! Thank God Jesus never said, 'Blessed are those who are good enough already,' or we'd be in big trouble! No, He was talking to those who want to do the right thing; who still believe they can, even if they're not right now; those who want to do better. Remember, it's not what you've done that makes you a candidate for God's forgiveness, it's how you feel about what you've done. God will never have a go at you for asking for His help. In fact, change begins with a desire and a willingness to challenge your problem. So what's in your heart today? What do you want to change about yourself and your life? Get some space. Ask God for help. He'll respond with love and forgiveness. He won't disappoint you!

content.title: The Holy Spirit
content.introtext:
...THE HOLY SPIRIT WHOM MY FATHER WILL SEND...WILL TEACH YOU ALL THINGS...

JOHN 14:26 NIV
You can either live by what your feelings tell you and what your circumstances say, or you can live by what the Spirit of God says. Have you noticed how music can influence your mood? A really mellow track can chill you out, some tunes make you feel happy, others totally depressed. If music can have such a powerful effect on you, just think what other things you listen to can do. If you listen to all those negative opinions about all your worries and fears, your mood, choices and reactions will be influenced by them. But if you listen to what the Spirit of God says about you, He'll not only influence your emotions but give you wisdom to tackle a tough situation. He'll also give you peace that will keep you calm in circumstances that are out of your control! You might be saying to yourself, 'Yeah, that's all good in theory, but I've never even heard of the Holy Spirit'. Listen: '...no one knows the thoughts of God, except the Spirit of God' (1Corinthians 2:11 NIV). If you wanna know what's on God's mind, ask God for this most precious gift to fill your heart today (see Acts 1:4 NIV). Jesus calls the Holy Spirit our 'helper'. Jesus said, '...The Holy Spirit...whom my father will send...will teach you all things...' (John 14:26 NIV). A life that is directed by the Spirit of God, will be a life in line with the will of God. Go on, ask Him and live by the Spirit!

content.title: Real hope
content.introtext:
F WE SAY WE HAVE NO SIN, WE ARE FOOLING OURSELVES...

1 JOHN 1:8 KJV
How many times have you said, 'Nobody understands me', or felt that you are totally misunderstood by those around you? If you look at Jesus and the people he hung out with, they were the ones society had no time for and had given up on. Jesus made time to listen, live and heal the hurting. The devil does the opposite. He'll do whatever it takes to convince you that there is no hope. Without a support system he knows he can get the better of you. He'll try to convince you, 'you're not like those people; you're better.' Or 'your situation's unique because of your background; others can't relate because they've never had it this bad.' The problem with thinking you are different from everybody else is - you start to think that the bad stuff you do is ok! Jesus loved people but He never said that the bad stuff they had done or were doing was ok. The Bible says, 'If we say we have no sin, we are fooling ourselves.' By hardening your attitude and whipping out the old 'yeah but...' card, eventually you become disconnected from the truth. And that's dangerous, especially when you stop listening to those who are willing to speak truth to you and have your best interests at heart. When self pity starts to get the better of you, ask God to help you keep focus. Stay connected no matter what, try to hang out with people who love you but are truthful. These friendships are God's gift to you. Enjoy!

content.title: Be tenacious!
content.introtext:
...I WILL NOT LET YOU GO UNLESS YOU BLESS ME.

GENESIS 32:26 NIV
Jacob's life was a bit like a soap opera. Family bust-ups, lying, cheating, death threats, marrying the wrong sister...the usual soap storyline. Even Jacob's name set him off to a bad start...if you call your son, 'deceiver', what do you expect? But one night Jacob got jumped... the bloke was big and really strong. Jacob fought for his life but this guy wouldn't give up. For hours they wrestled and then it began to dawn on Jacob, 'If this bloke had wanted to, he could have killed me by now...maybe he's not an assassin...hang on, maybe this is a God thing!' All of a sudden, the fight changes. Jacob isn't fighting to get away anymore; he's fighting to get a better grip and hold on. Jacob got tenacious! Tenacious means to cling tightly to something, to not give up, to not let go! Jacob was so tenacious that the guy he was wrestling with that the tables turned and the guy said, 'Let me go'. Jacob realised that this was no ordinary man and said, '...I will not let you go unless you bless me.' (Genesis 32:26 NIV) Because Jacob held onto God, and wouldn't let Him go, (even though it was hard work), God blessed him, and changed his name and future. You might think you're being attacked, but maybe God has grabbed hold of you, 'coz He wants to change your identity...? Don't run; grab on and be tenacious!

content.title: Giving 2)
content.introtext:
YOU WILL BE MADE RICH IN EVERY WAY SO THAT YOU CAN BE GENEROUS ON EVERY OCCASION...

2 CORINTHIANS 9:11 NIV
Here we go with day two on giving: Why is God interested in money - there's nothing he needs to buy? You're not likely to find yourself behind Him in the queue at your local ASDA stocking up on Angel Cake and Holy Water! God cares not for His own needs but for ours, if we'll let Him. But He's very careful that we don't become greedy - in fact greed is mentioned in the Bible as something God can't stand. So as long as you'll devote yourself to God He'll make sure you get everything you need, when you need it. That's His offer. Don't be afraid to give. God isn't a money grabber, out to line his own pockets. When He talks about giving, He asks for our whole lives...bet that tenner feels a lot easier to let go of now? Watch out though that giving money doesn't become an easy option for you though, it's much harder to spend your time personally serving the soup to the homeless on a cold, wet night than just donating a few quid to pay for the soup. Don't give 'coz you feel bad, give because you're inspired to love others, because of the love God shows you every day. Take your Heavenly Father's example - He didn't give Jesus because He was on a guilt trip - He gave Him out of love. Believe me, God doesn't need your guilt or your money... but He will take and use your seed no matter how small. He'll multiply it and produce something that has the ability to touch thousands.

content.title: Giving 1)
content.introtext:
...THE ONE WHO PLANTS GENEROUSLY WILL GET A GENEROUS CROP.

2 CORINTHIANS 9:6 NLT
Listen: 'Now He who supplies seed to the sower...will also supply and increase your store of seed...You will be made rich in every way so that you can be generous on every occasion...' (2 Corinthians 9:10-11 NIV). The Bible often uses the illustration of 'sowing' and 'reaping' to show there's a direct link between giving and receiving. If you give generously, then God will make sure you have more, to give again. This isn't about money, but about a lifestyle of trusting God for everything. Paul isn't talking about people who are trying to get rich; he's simply saying God wants people who are willing to give to others what is valuable to them. He's saying, 'It's not only safe to obey Me, it's safe to trust that I will look after you!' It's true, you can't out-give God. It can be hard to give something away, especially when you don't have much in the first place. Paul explains that giving to God is like giving to someone who takes the gift, makes it better and gives it back. The farmer who sows doesn't lose his seed, he gains a harvest. Can you imagine a farmer praying, 'God, give me a crop? I'm not ready to sow any seed yet, but I'm trusting You to do something: but just in case, I'll keep a tight fist on my seed.' Are you doing that? News flash! When we stop grabbing and start giving, God gets involved and starts doing some multiplying. We add and the God of the universe multiplies! You'll be amazed how God keeps His word. It's God's plan for us to be generous!

content.title: The reason you have been preserved
content.introtext:
I HAVE SEEN GOD FACE TO FACE, AND...MY LIFE WAS SPARED.

GENESIS 32:30 NIV
Do you realize that without God's hand on your life you wouldn't be here today? David said He 'protects us from death...' (Psalm 103:4 CEV). How cool is that? There must be so many accidents, illnesses or dangerous situations we have avoided or escaped because God has got our backs! The truth is, your mates (and some of your enemies) did not think you would make it this far. But God reached down, rescued you and put you in a good place (see Psalm 18:19 NIV). In the Bible, a guy called Jacob wrestles with God; afterwards, Jacob said, '...I have seen God face to face, and...my life is preserved.' And so is yours. Why? Listen: the Bible says, '...God...with a word, makes something out of nothing' (Romans 4:17 TM). God wants to give you things in life, good things that weren't there before. Check this: 'Jacob was left alone...' (Genesis 32:24 KJV). When God deals with you on important issues He does it 1-2-1, not as part of the crowd. In fact being in a crowd can stop you from hearing His voice. Being alone with God can feel threatening because your camouflage and ego are stripped away. Your first reaction may be to stay with the crowd, but you soon discover that they can't do what time alone with God can. God wants to hang out with you! So, like Jacob, don't be afraid to get in God's face for a while. When you do, you'll experience His love, and discover His purpose for your life.

content.title: Hide and Seek
content.introtext:
...GOD CALLED TO ADAM, 'WHY ARE YOU HIDING?

GENESIS 3:9 TLB
When you don't feel good about who you are as a person you will use clothes, food, relationships, money and humour to build a wall to keep people from getting too close. Lasting relationships are only built when you stop hiding and are willing to let people see the real you. Another alternative is to focus on others by asking, 'How come she got that new MP3 player and I didn't?' Or, 'Why did he get the girl and not me?' That kind of thinking just makes you bitter and totally miserable. Being fake with others is bad, but being fake with God is worse. In the Garden of Eden, God asked Adam, 'Why are you hiding?' But He already knew the answer. Nothing and nobody can hide from Him! God wanted Adam to admit where he was and what he'd done. Why? Because until you face the truth about yourself, tell Him and ask for God's forgiveness you will: a) find it hard to talk to God b) feel lonely and rubbish about yourself c) find it hard to be honest with people; afraid they'll see your mistakes. If you're hiding the real you, ask God to give you the guts to show your true self. Start by praying, 'Father, I know You love me. Nothing can change that, and I'm sorry I doubt that You care for me. You loved me before I was born, made me with a good plan in mind, changed me and gave me a special purpose in the world, and You are working day by day to make me even more pleasing to You' (see Philippians 2:13 NIV).

content.title: Lessons from the gate 3)
content.introtext:
...IN THE NAME OF JESUS...RISE UP AND WALK. AND HE TOOK HIM BY THE...HAND, AND LIFTED HIM UP.

ACTS 3:6-7 KJV
Peter spoke to the lame man using a Name that was bigger than his problem, the Name of Jesus. That's because He's the One who has the legal right to heal us in the areas where we hurt most. Peter moved in faith, reached out, took the man's hand and lifted him up. When he did the Bible says, '...[the man's] feet and ankles became strong. He jumped [up]...' (Acts 3:7-8 NIV). He already knew how to walk, he just needed help getting on his feet. Today you are surrounded by people who need help to get back up spiritually, emotionally, physically and financially. So what are you going to do? Your hand reaching out in compassion and faith can lift them. They don't need you to spend the rest of your life supporting them, they just need a hand up - and an introduction to the One Who is able, willing and waiting to meet their need. Paul said, 'At the name of Jesus every knee should bow...every tongue should confess that Jesus...is Lord...' (Philippians 2:10-11 KJV). What's in a name? In this case - everything! At the name of Jesus hell trembles, habits break, sickness retreats and life-long problems are solved. And one more thought: if you're the one needing to be helped to your feet, don't look to the person who's lifting you, look to Jesus! Leave the how, when, and where to Him. Focus on Jesus - He won't let you down.

content.title: Lessons from the gate 2)
content.introtext:
...NOW IS THE...DAY TO BE HELPED.

2 CORINTHIANS 6:2 TM
Same old thing; every day the crippled man '...was set down at the Temple gate...named Beautiful...' (Acts 3:2 TM). When you've got a problem, even if you are in a beautiful environment you can't enjoy it. This man was so close to the answer, but because he couldn't enter the temple, it seemed totally out of his reach. Is that where you're at? You can see the light, but the tunnel is just too long! You feel like you've lost your hope. Sometimes it's like you're an outsider looking in on a party. Everyone knows each other, but you feel like you're invisible! The Bible doesn't tell us how long the lame man had been sitting there, but he'd no reason to think that today would be any different from yesterday. He didn't wake up that morning saying, 'Today two blokes are gonna come along with the power of God to heal me!' But that's what happened. This is your day! God has got a life-changing, soul-cleansing, health-restoring, relationship-renewing experience for you today. God doesn't just fix us. He makes us new. We just have to say, 'God I need you today'. You are not invisible to him. He knows you well, '...You created my inmost being...' (Psalm 139:13 NIV). If He created you, then trust that He can heal you! Today stop for a moment and make a choice to trust. Trust that the tunnel has an end, and that He will take you through it. Trust that if your hope is in God, you'll not be disappointed.

content.title: Lessons from the gate 1)
content.introtext:
...A MAN CRIPPLED FROM BIRTH...WAS SET...AT THE TEMPLE GATE...TO BEG...

ACTS 3:2 TM
You can learn a lot from the crippled man at the temple gate: 1) a weakness in one area can cripple you in others - like a habit you can't break, always checking out the opposite sex, a bad temper or always being down on others. Apart from lacking strength in his ankles this man was normal, but one weakness stopped him from living his life. We all struggle with something. '...the temptations that come into your life are no different from what others experience...' (1 Corinthians 10:13 NLT). That's why James writes, '...pray for each other so God can heal you...' (James 5:16 NCV). So, how are you handling your weakness? Through denial? By feeling sorry for yourself? By ignoring the problem, hoping it will go away? This man was 'at the temple gate to beg' - why are you there? We all know our own faults, but we don't have to be held prisoner by them. Don't settle; choose: 'This may be who I am now, but it's not who I'm going to be!' 2) what are you looking for? A crutch to help you live with your problem? Don't avoid the only person that can make you better! The guy at the gate had got so used to being ignored that he wasn't even expecting a glance, let alone a solution to his problem. God doesn't just see your pain; He offers you a helping hand and more: '...what I have I give you...' (Acts 3:6 NIV). Wow! When your interest in others is limited to what they can do for you, it causes you to miss what God can do for you. This man ended up walking, leaping, and praising God because that day he experienced God's power - you can too!

content.title: What's that smell?
content.introtext:
WE ARE...THE FRAGRANCE OF CHRIST...

2 CORINTHIANS 2:15 NKJ
In ancient times when the Roman army won a great victory, they paraded their defeated enemies through the streets in chains. As part of the celebrations they burned incense on altars throughout the city, filling the air with perfume. That way those who couldn't see the procession knew the army had triumphed because they heard the music and smelled the incense. The scent became symbolic of victory. Are you getting the idea? Paul says, 'Thanks be to God, who always leads us in triumphal procession in Christ and through us spreads everywhere the fragrance of the knowledge of him' (2 Corinthians 2:14 NIV). Forget Ralph Lauren and Chanel No.5! Your life should be so consumed by God's presence that people around you can pick up the scent of it. After all, you are the most convincing evidence there is that Jesus is alive and well! All over this country there are elegant churches and cathedrals with amazing stained-glass windows which often show important events from the life of Jesus. That's cool. But the truth is, God doesn't need church windows to tell His story; He's looking for tuned-in Christians to do that! It's been said that the longer a husband and wife live together the more they start to look, act and talk alike. And it is the same with us. The more time we spend thinking about Jesus, talking to Him, reading His Word and basking in His presence, the more people are going to want to know, 'What's different about you?'

content.title: It's all about me!?!
content.introtext:
...GOD TURNED INTO GOOD WHAT YOU MEANT FOR EVIL...

GENESIS 50:20 NLT
Joseph had to go through the pit and the prison to get to the palace. Let's see what we can learn from him: 1) when it's hard, hold on! When you're misunderstood or having a hard time, complaining doesn't do any good. You're not learning while you're complaining. In every experience there's a lesson. Learn it and grow stronger. When life gives you a slap, know that it will only sting for a moment! 2) Self-Promotion of yourself is never as good as a God-Promotion. Each time Joseph tried to promote himself it worked against him. Joseph learned the hard way that success comes from God and that we must give Him credit for it. Whether you're a star or the poorest of the poor, God deserves your credit 3) when your dream comes true, it may be different than you imagined. As a boy Joseph dreamed only of power for his own gain. But God had something bigger in mind...set apart to save a nation. If your dream is something you thought up, don't expect God to get involved in it. What He has in mind will exceed your expectations, benefit others and promote His kingdom - not yours. Pray this prayer: 'Lord, help me to see these difficulties as stepping stones to maturity and character. Give me the patience to wait until You open the door. True promotion comes from You. Help me to remember that I'm blessed for one reason - to be a blessing to others. Amen.'

content.title: Wounded 2)
content.introtext:
WHEN JESUS...KNEW HOW LONG HE HAD BEEN THERE, HE SAID, 'DO YOU WANT TO GET WELL?

JOHN 5:6 TM
When you've been hurt, you can choose to remain a victim by dwelling on how things should have been, or use the experience to grow wiser. The paralysed man at the pool had been there for 38 years. When Jesus found out how long he'd been there He asked, 'Do you want to get well?' A bit of a harsh question, but Jesus knew that. It was time for him to stop seeing his disability as part of his identity. Because he'd been that way for so long he thought like a victim. Listen: '...I don't have anybody to put me in the pool...' (v.7 TM). Translation? 'Nobody really cares.' When Jesus commanded him to get up, He knew it would take real courage for the man to overcome his feelings of hopelessness and self-pity. But when the man obeyed, he was healed on the spot. God never forces healing on you, even if you are hurting. No, you must want to get well and make a conscious decision to believe you can. Getting hurt is inevitable; living like a victim is a choice. There will always be people who speak without thinking and hurt others. Listen, you don't have to let your bad experiences of others dominate your thoughts and influence your future relationships and life experiences. Understand this: it takes the same energy to choose healing as it does bitterness - but the results are very different! One leaves you paralysed by the past, the other gives you hope for the future. Choose!

content.title: Wounded 1)
content.introtext:
...MY GRACE IS...ALL YOU NEED...

2 CORINTHIANS 12:9 TM
Are you finding it hard to get over the way someone has treated you in the past? Have you been misunderstood, or neglected when you really should have been taken care of and protected? Most people who've been hurt in life could easily convince a jury it should never have happened. And it shouldn't! But it did - reliving it won't change it! Think: if you were in a car crash and taken to hospital you wouldn't spend all your time obsessing about the driver who crashed into you, would you? No, your main concern would be recovering as fast as possible! Isn't it weird that with physical wounds we ask for help straight away, but with emotional ones we tend to focus on the problem instead of the solution, we try to hide the problem and sort it out ourselves. During the American Civil War General Robert E Lee once visited a house in Kentucky where a very bitter woman showed him the remains of a magnificent tree the Union artillery had destroyed. She expected Lee to sympathize with her and condemn the Yankees. But instead he quietly replied, 'Cut it down, dear lady, and forget it.' Her bitterness could not change that tree, but the tree could change her, and not for the better. Paul says he begged God to take away his pain until, 'He told me, "My grace is enough; it's all you need"...Once I heard that...I quit focusing on the handicap...' (2 Corinthians 12:9 TM). How do you stop focusing on your hurt? Tell God about it, let it go and He will deal with it.

content.title: Hooked up!
content.introtext:
...I KNOW THE PLANS I HAVE FOR YOU...

JEREMIAH 29:11 NIV
Sometimes it can feel like everyone around you has a boyfriend or girlfriend, except for you. God does want us to have good friendships, but so often we start to go out with someone for totally the wrong reasons. Often because we're insecure, we look to the wrong people for our security. Sometimes we start going out with someone just because we think we won't be popular if we're single. None of these are good starting points for relationships. God wants us firstly to have our security totally grounded in Him. It's important to know that we are totally accepted and loved by God; actually it's important to not just know it but believe it too! God doesn't love you just because it's His job to. He loves you because He created you. He took time over you - you are not a mistake but you were made with a purpose and have value. God's best for you is not a string of failed relationships. You're not a jacket that is tried on by lots of different people to see if you fit and then sent to a charity shop when the fashion changes. It sucks when people treat each other that way. God is patient with us even when we're having a bad day. He doesn't dump us like someone who can't be bothered anymore. He is the best mate you will ever have. So before you hook up with someone, ask yourself 'Why am I starting this relationship and will it take me down a good road?' If you know it's not gonna have a happy ending, trust that God has the best person for you if you just chill out and wait.

content.title: Paralyzed!
content.introtext:
…KNOW THE TRUTH...

JOHN 8:32 NIV
Whether you believe in God right now or not, you could be facing a tough situation, one you feel is out of your control and has made you afraid and worried. While everybody around you is moving on with life you feel paralysed. You know inside that you have got what it takes to beat this, but you feel like you’re alone. What’s going on? Well, If you’re just getting on with life without chatting to God and getting His opinion on stuff, you’ll hit a brick wall sooner or later. Do you feel bored? Nothing excites you anymore. One day feels like the next until gradually you start believing nothing will ever change. It doesn’t matter whether you live in a shack or a mansion; unless you are free in your spirit it’s like being in prison. Jesus said, '...know the truth and the truth shall set you free' (John 8:32). You need a daily dose of the truth! Truth is not just a concept; it’s a person. ‘I am the way, the truth and the life…’ (John 14:6 NIV). Jesus is the answer to every question, every fear and every worry. And the amazing thing is He wants to chat to you today. All you need to do is ask him to come into your heart and become number one in your life. You’ll be amazed how much your life begins to change from then on! If you feel paralysed today, you will find your answer in Jesus. He gives life buzz, freedom and purpose. So, refuse to live another day in a paralysed, out-of-control, fearful state. Last tip: If you pack your day with truth, there’ll be no more room for lies!

content.title: Let go!
content.introtext:
...STOP ALLOWING YOURSELVES TO BE...UNSETTLED.

JOHN 14:27 AMP
Some kids at summer camp were chatting about creation. One asked, 'If everything has a purpose, how come God made poison ivy?' Another replied, 'Because He knows there are some things we should keep our hands off!' Keeping your hands off certain things isn't easy, especially when you're involved or it's a friend. 'But sometimes my mates do my head in.' Maybe you wind them up too! No friendship is ever perfect! God says, 'Friends love through all kinds of weather, and families stick together in all kinds of trouble' (Proverbs 17:17 TM). You need to be patient with others coz others are patient with you. Jesus said, '...stop allowing yourselves to be…unsettled' (John 14:27 AMP). You're doing it to yourself! Learn to 'let go' and work on developing the fruits of the Spirit (Galatians 5:22-23). That'll keep you busy! Letting go doesn't mean you don't care, it just means allowing others to learn from their mistakes. It means focusing on Jesus instead of obsessing over the other person. The Prophet Isaiah says, 'You will keep in perfect peace all those whose thoughts are fixed on You' (Isaiah 26:3 NLT). Letting go means caring but not obsessing. It means stepping out of the middle and not trying to influence the outcome by judging, whispering, nagging, arguing, criticizing and fixing. It's about facing each day with God's help and living it to the max! Realise the only person you can change for good is you! Fear less and trust more. Accept that '...amid all these things we are more than conquerors…through Him...' (Romans 8:37 AMP).

content.title: Get Accountable!
content.introtext:
AS IRON SHARPENS IRON, SO ONE MAN SHARPENS ANOTHER.

PROVERBS 27:17 NIV
How do you handle correction? By taking offence? By hearing it as rejection? By getting defensive? All of us need people who'll be honest with us because we're easily blinded by our egos. When God sends somebody to correct you it is because He loves you. He only does that to those He values. Listen: 'If you are not disciplined...then you are illegitimate children and not true sons' (Hebrews 12:8 NIV). So, how do you handle correction? By killing the messenger? By making sure he or she never speaks to you again? By keeping score and saying, 'Look what I've accomplished; what have you done?' By giving in to self-pity and saying, 'People don't understand or appreciate me?' God does put people around us who we can trust to be honest with us, even if it's to tell us we’re out of order. Accountable people always exhibit four qualities: 1) vulnerability. They're capable of knowing when they're wrong and admitting it – even before they're confronted 2) teachability. They're willing to hear, quick to learn and always open to advice 3) availability. They're approachable. They don't avoid you 4) honesty. They hate anything fake and are committed to the truth regardless of how much it hurts. 'That's a high standard,' you say. You're right. It's a standard pride can't handle and fragile egos freak out at. There's something in everyone that would rather look good than be good. So when God sends people into your life who love you enough to tell you the truth – go with it!

content.title: When God says no!
content.introtext:
...NO GOOD THING WILL HE WITHHOLD FROM THEM THAT WALK UPRIGHTLY.

PSALM 84:11 KJV
If it was a good thing God would not have said 'no'. Either the timing is wrong or He has something better for you. Gratitude comes when you realize what could've happened didn't happen because God stepped in. We can get so used to fighting that we forget that God has promised to protect us, even from ourselves. David wrote, 'The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want' (Psalm 23:1 NAS). A shepherd leads, feeds and protects. What a picture; God watching over you 24-7! Like a lifeguard at the beach who spots a dangerous situation God will interrupt everyone's fun, risk embarrassing you in front of your friends and maybe even bruise a rib or two. That's because He loves you too much to let you drown in the thing you think is so good for you. Preacherman Billy Graham's wife is called Ruth, she says, 'If God had said yes to all my prayer requests I'd have married the wrong man – several times.' Listen: 'Commit your way to the Lord; trust in him; and he will do this...' (Psalm 37:5 NIV). What you're bitter about today you'll thank your Heavenly Father for tomorrow. The author Mark Twain said that when he was 14 his father was so ignorant he could hardly stand him. But by the time he was 21 he was amazed how much the old man had learned in seven years. Hello! The more mature you become the more you'll begin to see how loving and wise your Heavenly Father is, and the more you’ll trust Him.

content.title: What do u think?
content.introtext:
...IF ANYTHING IS EXCELLENT OR PRAISEWORTHY – THINK ABOUT SUCH THINGS.

PHILIPPIANS 4:8 NIV
You don;t have more problems than other people – you just think about them more often! Stop: go back and reread that sentence. Take a moment and think about what it means. It's what you think about that determines how you feel. If you don't believe that try getting angry without first having angry thoughts, or getting sad without first having sad thoughts. You can't do it, can you? To experience a feeling you must first have the thought that produces it. That's life-changing information; it's knowledge the devil doesn't want you to have. If you change how you think you'll change how you feel! Nothing can hold your negative feelings in place other than your own thinking. The truth is, it's your thinking that's negative, not your life! Once you understand that you can get back on the path to happiness again. Change takes time. You didn't become negative overnight and you won't become positive overnight. But you can start. How? By doing two things: 1) by treating your negative thoughts in the same way you treat flies at a picnic – shoo them away and start to focus your mind on good stuff! You have that choice! 2) by thinking about God's goodness. David did: 'Praise the Lord, O my soul, and forget not all his benefits: Who forgives all your sins; who heals all your diseases; who redeems your life from the pit; and who crowns you with love and compassion' (Psalm 103:2-4 NIV). So, if you're serious about changing your life, start changing how you think!

content.title: Chill out!
content.introtext:
DO NOT WORRY ABOUT ANYTHING...

PHILIPPIANS 4:6 NLT
Apparently... 40% of what we worry about never happens. 30% has already happened. 12% focuses on things we cannot change. 10% on our health, which only makes it worse. Only 8% are real problems we can influence. Think: 92% of our worries are a waste of time! Worry comes from a Greek word meaning, 'to divide the mind'; worry splits us right down the middle. It doesn’t stop tomorrow's trouble, it just makes us unable to focus on today, so we miss out. And who can afford to lose strength? 'But how can I stop worrying?' Paul offers a two-pronged answer: God's part and our part. Our part includes prayer and thankfulness: 'Do not worry about anything; instead, pray about everything. Tell God what you need, and thank him for all he has done' (Philippians 4:6 NLT). Do you want to worry less? Talk to God more. And let Him know you're thankful. Thankfulness is powerful; it releases God's peace. Listen: 'If you do this, you will experience God's peace, which is far more wonderful than the human mind can understand. His peace will guard your hearts and minds as you live in Christ Jesus' (Philippians 4:7 NLT). Faith-filled prayer brings God's peace. Imagine having God's totally chilled state of mind! Do you think He worries, freaks out or is surprised by anything? Your problem is no more challenging to Him than a twig to an elephant. God enjoys perfect peace because He enjoys perfect power – and He offers His peace to you. Just do your part through prayer and thanksgiving and He'll do His!

content.title: How's your love life?
content.introtext:
..LIVE A LIFE OF LOVE, JUST AS CHRIST LOVED US

EPH 5:2 NIV
You only have to spend 2 seconds looking at the cover of the 'gossip magazines' to get the latest info on some celebrities love life 'Are they together? Aren't they? What will so and so think? Was that a friendly hug or something more?'. Open up the teen magazines and it won't be long before you find a questionnaire that will prove 'Once and for all if your relationship is TRUE LOVE.' The bible's focus is more on our lives of love rather than our love lives (although you check Song of Songs for some steamy talk of love). Paul tells the Ephesians to live a life of love just as Christ loved us and gave himself for us. So it's time for a love life check up, how are you doing with loving others as Christ has loved us. Read this and ask God to speak to show you where you are doing well and not so well: 'Love is kind and patient, never jealous, boastful, proud, or rude. Love isn't selfish or quick tempered.It doesn't keep a record of wrongs that others do.Love rejoices in the truth, but not in evil.Love is always supportive, loyal, hopeful, and trusting. Love never fails!' (1 Corinthians 13:4-8 NCV) God is fascinated with our lives of love (even more than we are with celebrity love lives). The more we love the more we become like God. 'God is love. Whoever lives in love lives in God, and God in him.' (1 John 4:16 NIV). Paul says in his letter to the Colossian church, 'put on love' (Col 3:14 NIV), love isn't always something that just springs up from inside us, sometimes we have to decide to love, to bend down pick it up and put it on. Ask God to help you to wear love wherever you go.

content.title: Be still
content.introtext:
BE STILL, AND KNOW THAT I AM GOD.

PSALM 46:10 NIV
Are you feeling stressed out and anxious today. Wondering if everything will get done and sorted? Remember God says: ‘Be still, and know that I am God.’ And there’s a reason He’s saying it. Ever noticed the more busy you get, the more stressed out you are, the more you NEED God, the less time you spend with Him, talking to Him, trusting Him. Half the time we are stressed over stuff that isn’t even what God wants us to be doing. It was something we wanted to do, no wonder we are stressed! Whatever is stressing you out , ask God to reveal to you His will in the matter, what does he want you to do? Then stop, take a deep breathe, chill out and ‘be still’ and acknowledge that He’s God, He’s in charge, He knows what He’s doing! Life is a lot less hassle and a lot less stressful when we learn to trust Him without always demanding to know what He’s going to do, when He’s going to do it, and how He’s going to carry it out. Jesus said, ‘I am the vine, and you are the branches’ (John 15:5). Until you really grab hold of those words you will keep trying to do things that only God can do – solving your own problems and answering your own prayers. Or worse, you will try to cover up for Him because you think He’s not doing it fast enough, or in the way it should be done. Give it up! Try less and trust more! Jesus said, ‘I am the vine, you are the branches.’ All you have to do is stay connected!

content.title: Abide in His love
content.introtext:
MAY YOU EXPERIENCE THE LOVE OF CHRIST.

EPHESIANS 3:19 NLT
Others love you conditionally with strings attached, only if you are cool or good looking, only if you’ll love them back. But not God, He loves you because He decides to. His love is self-generated and spontaneous, His love is priceless and yet he chooses to give it away freely. Check this out: ‘The Lord did not set his affection on you…because you were more numerous than other peoples, for you were the fewest of all peoples. But it was because the Lord loved you’ (Deuteronomy 7:7-8 NIV). You can neither earn nor influence God’s love. Paul writes, ‘God showed his great love for us by sending Christ to die for us while we were still sinners’ (Romans 5:8 NLT). We think we can measure how much God loves us by what is happening in our lives, or how we feel. But forget it. There is nothing you can do (good or bad) to make God love you any more or any less! Jesus said, ‘Abide in My love’ (John 15:9 NAS). To abide in His love is to feel at home in it. Home: the place where you are known, loved, secure, and always welcome. John writes, ‘We take up permanent residence in a life of love’ (1 John 4:17 TM). To abide in His love is to cling to Christ like a branch clings to a vine. Does the branch ever let go of or drop off the vine? Only at the risk of death. Does the branch ever stop drawing life from the vine? No, it receives nutrients 24 hours a day. Listen: ‘As the branch cannot bear fruit of itself unless it abides in the vine, so neither can you unless you abide in Me’ (John 15:4 NAS).

content.title: He’s working on you!
content.introtext:
MY FATHER NEVER STOPS WORKING.

JOHN 5:17 NLT
In the old days Blacksmiths and Silversmiths could take some hot metal and make armour, swords, horse shoes, spoons, knifes, jewellery, all kinds of stuff just by bashing it with a hammer. The word ‘smith’ means to hit or strike. These guys were experts with a hammer and so is God. He knows the weight of the hammer and the force of the blow required to produce in you Christ-like character. No one yanks the hammer out of His hand and says, ‘Go easy on that silver; you have pounded it enough!’ No, He buffets the metal until He’s finished with it. Silversmiths keep polishing until they can see their face in the finished product. When will God stop with you? When He sees His nature and His likeness reflected in you. Jesus said, ‘My father never stops working.’ The pounding you feel doesn’t suggest God’s distance, it proves His nearness. Trust Him. Hasn’t He earned your trust? Has He ever spoken a word that proved to be false? After a lifetime of walking with God, Joshua said, ‘Not one word failed from all the good words God spoke’ (Joshua 21:45 TM). And Paul adds, ‘If we are faithless, he will remain faithful, for he cannot disown himself’ (2 Timothy 2:13 NIV). Try making a list of His mistakes. Now try making a list of yours, and the times He’s forgiven you. Who on earth has a record like that? You can depend on Him. He is ‘The same yesterday and today and forever’ (Hebrews 13:8 NIV). And because He is your Lord, ‘he will be your sure foundation ‘(Isaiah 33:6 NAS). Be happy, God is directing your steps and monitoring every detail of your life!

content.title: The Rebekah principle 2)
content.introtext:
YOU HAVE SHOWN KINDNESS.

GENESIS 24:14 NKJV
Before we leave her, let’s learn three more important lessons from Rebekah: 1) When you give generously, you get back more than you ever thought possible. Jesus said, ‘With the measure you use, it will be measured back to you’ (Matthew 7:2 NIV). We set the standard of what we receive, by what we give. Rebekah gave more than was asked, and received back more than she ever expected to get. She became the great-great great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-grandmother of the Messiah! Give what you can; you will be amazed what God will give you in return 2) When you give generously, your loved ones will be blessed too. When Abraham’s servant revealed who he was, he brought out gold articles and rich garments and gave them to Rebekah. But he also gave precious things to her mother and brother. The rewards of your generosity will always overflow and touch the lives of those closest to you 3) When you give, the impact of your generosity will often outlive you. In the moment of giving you cannot imagine how your actions might impact the lives of others in the future. Imagine what the world would be like if Noah had said, ‘I don’t do boats,’ if David had said, ‘I don’t do Giants’ if Mary had said, ‘I don’t do virgin births’, if Paul had said, ‘I don’t do letters’, and if Jesus had said, ‘I don’t do crosses’. A lifestyle of generous giving will outlive you and bless those who follow you. So what can you do or give that will make a difference to others long after you done it?

content.title: The Rebekah principle 1)
content.introtext:
YOU HAVE SHOWN KINDNESS.

GENESIS 24:14 NKJV
One day as Rebekah was standing by the well, a man approached and asked her for a drink. Without hesitation she said yes. Then she offered to water his camels. That was no small offer. One camel can drink 20 gallons of water. Do the maths: 10 camels at 20 gallons each equals 200 gallons. 200 gallons drawn with a five-gallon jar equals 40 trips to the well. 40 trips at three minutes each equals two hours. What Rebekah did not realise was that her simple act of generosity would change her life forever. Little did she know that her actions were the answer to a servant’s prayer and the plan of a sovereign God. All she did was do what she felt she should, but in so doing she became the bride of Isaac, the inheritor of Abraham’s fortune, and a ancestor of Jesus. Rebekah went the extra mile. Her generosity seems to be seriously different from the attitudes of today. She said, ‘I’ll not just do what you ask me, I’ll do more.’ In contrast many of us say, ‘I’m going to do the least that is expected of me and try and get the most out of it.’ Sadly this attitude has also crept into the lives of even God’s people. Few desire to do more than they must. Everywhere you look you see an attitude of minimum effort for maximum payment. The Rebekah principle teaches us that when you go through life looking for small opportunities to be generous, there can be a big pay back from God!

content.title: Lessons from Noah
content.introtext:
BY FAITH NOAH.

HEBREWS 11:7
You can make a difference in your family! Listen: ‘By faith Noah…built an ark to save his family.’ Noah’s obedience to God did not benefit just him, it also saved his family. Maybe your family are not yet Christians and it feels like you’ve been praying and talking to them forever.
