It took Noah 100 years and a lot of wood… but you don’t have to make trips to B&Q and start building an ark, just keep making those trips to your bedroom (or wherever you pray) and keep asking God to use you and to save your family. Don’t give up! You can make a difference for future generations! When Noah stepped out of the ark God used him to start the world all over again. Wow! Listen: ‘For the eyes of the LORD range throughout the earth to strengthen those whose hearts are fully committed to him.’(2 Chronicles 16:9 TM). God is still looking for people to partner with so that He can fulfil His purposes. But to qualify you must: a) dare to stand out in the crowd. Noah believed in his vision when nobody else did. Difference-makers are different. Do not let that bother you; b) dare to do things for the first time. Do not let the words ‘it is never been done before’ keep you from doing what God asks. Folks said, ‘It is never rained before, who needs a boat?’ But they were wrong and it cost them dearly; c) hold on through the rain to see the rainbow. So take your stand and believe God, for what He’s promised you – He’ll perform!

content.title: Water-walking (3)
content.introtext:
THEN THOSE WHO WERE IN THE BOAT WORSHIPPED HIM.

MATTHEW 14:33 NIV
The story of Peter walking on the water ends with the words: ‘Then those who were in the boat worshiped him’.(Jesus) There’s an important principle here: God shows you how amazing He is. You stop and think about what He’s done and respond in worship. And therefore your love for Him grows. This may happen to you in a dramatic way such as a walk on the water. But usually it happens in ways that are easily missed, such as a still small voice in you that whispers, ‘I never let you down; never walk off and leave you’ (Hebrews 13:5 TM). John Ortberg, who wrote a book about ‘getting out of the boat’ says: ‘You need to worship God not because His ego needs it, but because without worship your experience and enjoyment of Him are not complete. You need to worship, because without worship you can forget you have a big God and end up living in fear. You need to worship, because without it you can forget His calling and begin to live in a spirit of self-preoccupation (me me me attitude). You need to worship, because without it you can lose your sense of wonder and gratitude and plod through life with the blinders on. You need to worship, because your natural tendency is toward self-reliance and stubborn independence (just doing things your way).’ In Mark’s version of the water-walking story he records that the disciples were amazed ‘because their hearts were hardened.’ Each time you pause to remember what God has brought you through, your heart will become tender and your lips declare: ‘I will praise the LORD at all times. I will constantly speak his praises (Psalm 34:1 NLT ).

content.title: Water-walking 2)
content.introtext:
WHEN HE SAW THE WIND, HE WAS AFRAID.

MATTHEW 14:30 NIV
The truth about water-walking is: the fear never goes away! If you want to grow, you must go! Go into something new, something risky. And each time you do you will experience fear. Give up trying to make fear go away! Fear and growth go together; it’s a package deal. The decision to grow means choosing between risk and comfort. Each time you get out of the boat you become a bit more confident about getting out the next time. It’s not that the fear goes away, you just get used to dealing with it. You realise that it doesn’t have the power to destroy you. On the other hand, every time you choose to stay in the boat rather than obey the call of Christ to ‘Come,’ the voice inside you gets a little quieter, till finally you do not hear it at all. Did Peter fail? No. Other than Jesus, he’s the only man who ever walked on water. All of the other disciples would go on to say ‘we saw someone walk on water’ Only Peter could say ‘I walked on water’. Only Peter knew the joy of being empowered by God to do what could not humanly be done. Walking on water changes you forever. And only Peter knew the grace of being lifted by Jesus in a moment of desperate need. He understood in a way the others could not that when you take baby steps of faith, the Lord will never let you drown. He had an experience with Christ the others did not have. So, failure isn’t sinking in the waves, it is never getting out of the boat!

content.title: Water-walking 1)
content.introtext:
PETER…WALKED ON THE WATER.

MATTHEW 14:29 NLT
Here are some things you need to know about water-walking: 1) Everybody has a boat. Your boat is whatever gives you a sense security. It’s what you’re tempted to put your trust in, especially when life gets a bit stormy. Want to know what your boat is? Your fear will tell you. Ask yourself, ‘What is it that I get most scared of leaving behind or doing without if I was to obey God and and step out in faith?’. It might be being popular or having loads of cash or your best mate or anything that you think need and find it hard leave when God asks you to. 2) Keep your eyes on Jesus not the storm. When did Peter sink? When he ‘saw the wind.’ We do this all the time. Maybe you’re trying to do something new, a new course at college, a weekend job, a new friendship, getting involved in a new activity. At the beginning things are great; it’s blue skies; then reality sets in. You get some problems, some difficulties. Life’s full of surprises so we should expect it, but somehow the trouble and problems take over - it’s all we can think about, all we can see. Because the wind some of us never leave the boat. The problems put us off, ‘better to stick with what we are doing now’! But the truth is, there’s no guarantee that life in the boat will be any safer. Everything’s risky! Understand this: if you live in the boat you will eventually die in the boat, and you will end up wondering what your life might have been if only you would been willing to step over the side.

content.title: In the Potter’s hand
content.introtext:
IN THE HAND OF THE POTTER.

JEREMIAH 18:6 NIV
Ever seen anyone make something on a potter’s wheel? They bang their foot on a pedal and the wheel starts spinning. Soon they’ve chucked on a lump of clay and a load of water and got their fingers stuck in. Before your eyes, with the wheel still spinning, they have shaped a pot. ‘So I went to the potter's house, and sure enough, the potter was there, working away at his wheel. Whenever the pot the potter was working on turned out badly, as sometimes happens when you are working with clay, the potter would simply start over and use the same clay to make another pot’ (Jeremiah 18:3-4 TM) If you are asking, ‘Why am I going through all of this?’ the answer is, you are ‘in the hand of the Potter.’ Knowing that helps – especially when you are on the wheel and everything in your life seems to be spinning out of control. It is not. Look under the table and see whose foot is on the wheel. It’s God and He’s in control. He’s not put off by the clay regardless of where He finds it or how messed up it is. He’s committed to working on it until it becomes what He wants. Listen: ‘to those who believed in his name, he gave the right to become children of God’ (John 1:12). He is interested in what you are becoming. Regardless of what you have been up until now. Notice, even though the pot turned out badly sometimes. God never throws us away, nor is His plan for us held back because we have a mistake or struggle in certain areas. Understand this: whether you are being lifted from the mud, turned on the wheel or made over again, at all times you are in His hand. And you always will be!

content.title: Experiencing the miraculous!
content.introtext:
MASTER, WE'VE BEEN FISHING HARD ALL NIGHT AND HAVEN'T CAUGHT EVEN A MINNOW. BUT IF YOU SAY SO, I'LL LET OUT THE NETS.

LUKE 5:5 TM
After fishing all night and catching zilcho, nowt, nothing, the disciples were gutted. Then Jesus said to His disciples, ‘Push out into deep water and let your nets out for a catch.’ (Luke 5:4 TM). Can you imagine their thoughts? The test of our faith comes when: a) nothing you have tried has worked; b) the word God gives you seems to make no sense at all. Notice Peter’s answer: ‘But if you say so, I’ll let out the nets’ (Luke 5:5 TM). He got it right! Doubt your doubts but don’t doubt God. Why? Because He’s not held back by your idea of what’s possible! One word from Him can change everything. Listen to what happened next: ‘this time their nets were so full they began to tear!’ (Luke 5:6 NLT). Here are four important lessons for you today: 1) Sometimes He’ll involve you in one thing to teach you another. Soon Jesus was going to involve them in an even greater miracle – ‘catching people’ and bringing them into His kingdom. 2) He’ll use the ordinary to do the extraordinary. In their normal workplace where nothing special ever happened, Jesus suddenly showed up and changed everything. You can expect Him in your normal, ordinary life. Not just at big events, festivals or church. 3) He’ll move you from the security of the shore to the risks of the deep water. You’ve got to experience the great storms in order to enjoy the great catches. No risk, no reward! 4) When you obey God nets break, needs are met, minds are blown and God is made famous. But remember, you can’t even begin to live miraculously until you can say, ‘Because you said so, I will…’ (Luke 5:5 NIV).

content.title: Great power = Great responsibility
content.introtext:
LOVE YOUR NEIGHBOUR AS YOURSELF

Matt 22:39 NIV
In the film Spiderman, Peter Parker, is told ‘With great power comes great responsibility.’ Peter had just found out that he could walk up walls, beat up the local tough guys and generally start living like a super hero, so these were important words. In many ways these words shape Peter’s life as he tries to work out what it means to be responsible for other people when you’re a friendly web slinging Spiderman! The bible has some important things to say about power and responsibility: ‘For I was hungry and you gave me something to eat, I was thirsty and you gave me something to drink, I was a stranger and you invited me in, I needed clothes and you clothed me, I was sick and you looked after me, I was in prison and you came to visit me’ (Matthew 25:35-36 NIV) Jesus’ message seems clear, if someone is in need and you have the power to do something about it, then your responsibility is to do it! Britain is the fourth richest country in the world which gives us a lot of power to make a lot of difference but also gives us a lot of responsibility. This year many charities are joining forces to campaign to the government to ‘MAKE POVERTY HISTORY’, to increase aid to poor countries, to erase the debt that poor countries owe us and to improve the trade rules so that people get fairly paid. For example, if you buy a designer jacket for £100 the person who made it will have been paid about 50p! As a Christian, as a neighbour, ask yourself how you can love the poor. How can you give more, get more involved? Talk to your youth leader, talk to your friends, Talk to God. Find out what you can do. You might not think you have much, but every pound, every hour, every prayer can make a difference.

content.title: Set an example
content.introtext:
DON'T LET ANYONE LOOK DOWN ON YOU BECAUSE YOU ARE YOUNG

2 Tim 4:12 NIV
Mary, Jesus’ mum was just a teenager when God sent ‘Gabs’ with a message that would change her life. David was the youngest in his family, when an old prophet came to his Dad’s house looking for the next king. Soon the prophet was pouring oil on his head saying that he was God’s man! Paul writes to his friend Tim who is leading one of the first churches and says ‘don’t let people look down on you because you’re young’. God is not held back by your age. He’s not waiting for you to be older and wiser before he starts to use you in his plans. Of course, God will want you to learn from those who are more experienced. Like Mary had her much older relative, Elizabeth. Timothy had Paul. So it’s important you don’t think you’ve got all the answers. Learn from the successes and mistakes of others – you’ll never live long enough to make them all yourself! Paul also tells Timothy to set an example. Wrinkle creams, extreme makeovers, celebrities lying about their age. Have you noticed that everyone is desperate to be young again. Everyone is looking at you and wanting to be like you. But God wants a generation of young people that everyone wants to be like, not because of their smooth skin, fashion, energy or looks but because of their holiness, purity and speech. He wants young people to lead the way in living lives of love, showing kindness and generosity. He wants young people who will take leaps of faith, do what others are too comfortable or scared to do, who take giant risks because they trust in a massive God. Go for it! Set an example!

content.title: Praising even when it hurts
content.introtext:
OFFER TO GOD A SACRIFICE OF PRAISE.

HEBREWS 13:15 NIV
If you feel like your problems have got you trapped in a downer, read this. ‘About midnight Paul and Silas were…singing hymns to God…Suddenly there was such a violent earthquake that the foundations of the prison were shaken. . .all the prison doors flew open, and everybody’s chains came loose’ (Acts 16:25-26 NIV). Praise opens the doors! Praise breaks chains! Any time you are willing to praise God despite your circumstances and the problem in your life, the forces of heaven come to your aid. ‘Oh com’on, I last thing I feel like is praising God’ you say. Then ‘offer to God a sacrifice of praise.’ Even with gritted teeth and tear filled eyes, we can praise God. Anybody can praise God in the good times, but if you praise when you don’t feel like it, when the problems are massive and everyone else thinks your nuts– that’s when it really counts. The battle of Jericho teaches us that sometimes we have to worship God when: a) we’re up against a brick wall; b) we feel like we’re going in circles; c) the enemy seems to stand over us laughing; d) our mind thinks ‘this is no way to fight a war;’ e) it is the last thing on earth we feel like doing. (Check out Joshua 6 to see what happened) Nehemiah writes, ‘Don't be sad! This is a special day for the LORD, and he will make you happy and strong.’ (Nehemiah 8:10 CEV). If you look to natural things for happiness you’ll live on an emotional roller coaster. But if you choose to look at Jesus and His unfailing love for you, you’ll move from weakness to strength every time!

content.title: God’s call
content.introtext:
BEFORE YOU WERE BORN, I SET YOU APART FOR A SPECIAL WORK.

JEREMIAH 1:5 NCV
In the bible there is a pattern of what happens in a life that God wants to use and improve: 1) There’s always a call – not a phonecall but it will ‘ring a bell’ in your heart. God asks normal people to take a risk and do something ‘not normal’- which will need shed loads of trust. Like when Jesus calls Peter to get out of the boat and walk on water. 2) There’s always fear. God has a habit of asking people to do things that scare them: like Moses who told God, ‘I’m not a good enough speaker, use somebody else’ 3) There’s always reassurance. Listen: ‘As I was with Moses, so I will be with you.’ That is what God told Joshua, the new leader who’d just taken over 4) There’s always a decision. Sometimes, like with Gideon, we say yes to God’s call. Sometimes, like the rich young ruler who spoke to Jesus, we say no, but we must always decide. 5) There’s always a changed life. Those who say yes to God’s call aren’t expecting instant perfection, not by a long shot. But because they say yes they learn and grow even from their failures and become part of God’s plan to rescue the world. Those who say no to God are changed too; they become a little harder, a little more resistant to His calling, a little more likely to say no next time. Is God calling you? Maybe it has to do with your future, your relationships, your money, or facing your deepest fear. God’s call will go to the core of who you are and what you do. If you say yes to Him, you will never regret it!

content.title: People pleasing
content.introtext:
NOT JUST WHEN YOU THINK THEY ARE WATCHING.

EPHESIANS 6:6 CEV
It takes courage to be led by God’s Spirit. It’s not easy to break the mould in your family or step outside the boundaries others create for you. Maybe God’s telling you to serve him when everyone expects you to get a ‘proper job’. Maybe you want to go to college but no one in your families ever done that. Whatever it is, you could face criticism. Jesus did. When they said, ‘Isn’t this the carpenter’s son?’ (Matthew 13:55 NIV), they were saying, ‘He should stay in his place.’ They’ll say that about you too. Two kinds of people always fail – those who listen to nobody and those who listen to everybody. Paul writes: ‘Each of us will give an account of himself to God’ (Romans 14:12 NIV). In the end, it’s only what God thinks that counts. Too often our actions are ruled not by a sense of purpose but by a need to please. We care so much about what certain people think, that with every step we look over our shoulder to see whether they are smiling or frowning. God says, ‘You shall have no other gods before me’ (Exodus 20:3 NIV). Now, your first thought might be: ‘But I don’t have any other gods?!’ But you do when you dedicate your life to impressing people rather than obeying God. When you are a child of God your number one responsibility is to please Him. Your second is to live your life to the fullest. Living on purpose, choosing to live God’s way in God’s world, whatever people say is the way to really live; anything else is just existing.

content.title: Are you a perfectionist?
content.introtext:
IT IS FOR YOUR PLEASURE THAT THEY EXIST AND WERE CREATED.

REVELATION 4:11 NLT
The day you were born God smiled. He did not need to create you, He chose to. When you fully grasp that you will never again have the problem of feeling ‘less-than.’ Farai Chideya graduated from Harvard (a top American uni), worked for Newsweek magazine and quickly rose to the top. Yet she spent years living in the private hell of bulimia, trying to become like the glossy images in the make-believe world around her. When she finally broke free from the destructive grip of her eating disorder she wrote, ‘Losing weight did not change my personality and it did not lighten the emotional baggage I carried from my childhood. I thought I wanted to be thin. What I really wanted was to be happy, and neither my looks nor my achievements could do that. Because I could not love or accept myself, the acceptance of others was never enough. When I tried to be perfect I came across as remote and unapproachable, yet the exact opposite was what I wanted.’ Then she shares four life-changing principles: ‘Your obsession to be perfect will: 1) keep you trapped in loneliness, for satisfying relationships can only be built on honesty and total acceptance; 2) force you to see your shortcomings as something to hide instead of opportunities for growth; 3) keep you obsessed with what you are going to be some day, instead of enjoying what you are right now; 4) rob you of the chance to make your life count, for by focusing constantly on yourself you will have nothing left to give to others.’ Think about it!

content.title: Living a transformed life!
content.introtext:
JESUS…WENT THROUGH THE COUNTRY HELPING…EVERYONE WHO WAS BEATEN DOWN BY THE DEVIL.

ACTS 10:38 TM
The Simpson’s, Brat Camp, Super Nanny… your telly seems to be crammed with programmes showing rebellious kids kicking off and desperate parents pulling their hair out wanting to know why their kids do what they do. But it’s nothing new, it all started with the first book, Genesis, telling us about the first fight in the first family between the first two brothers. And we all wrestle with the same issues because we’re all from the same gene pool. In the first dysfunctional family Cain attacked and killed his brother Abel out of anger, jealously and a ‘me first’ attitude. Now be honest, have you ever felt like that? But do we have to live that way? No way! Maybe the last person you want to look like is your mum or dad but like it or not families do have certain characteristics that pass down the generations. But here’s a bonus… it’s part of God’s plan that we start to look like Him, by reflecting His love and goodness. Paul refers to this as ‘a God-fashioned life, a life renewed from the inside and working itself into your conduct as God accurately reproduces his character in you’ (Ephesians 4:22 TM). Notice, you cannot reproduce Christ-like characteristics in your own strength. New Year’s resolutions, willpower and good intentions are not enough. Only God’s Spirit can make the changes necessary in your life. Listen: ‘God is working in you, giving you the desire to obey him and the power to do what pleases him’ (Philippians 2:13 NLT). Good news: God will give you the desire and the power to live a transformed life.

content.title: Throw it away!
content.introtext:
CASTING ALL YOUR CARE UPON HIM.

1 PETER 5:7
When you hear people talk about forgiveness, are you the kind of person who always thinks of the same BIG SIN? That thing you did years before but just can’t believe God has forgiven. So you find yourself asking Him one more time, ‘God please forgive me. I’m so sorry’. If only we could hear God…’What sin?’ He’d say. ‘You know…what I did...all those years ago’ we shoot back. ‘But my child, I forgot all about that when you asked the first time, why are you still holding on to it?’ Maybe someone offended you big time. They’ve said sorry and you’ve sort of forgiven them, but you just can’t forget. Or maybe you prayed to God for something and He said ‘NO’. Do you keep hoping he’ll change His mind, like a the ‘pop idol’ hopeful who goes to every audition in every town every year? Sometimes you have to LET GO! Check this out: ‘Cast all your cares upon Him; for He cares for you.’ ‘Cast’ is a really simple word, it just means, ‘throw it away.’ What are you dragging around? Old pain? Old scars? A dream or a grudge for somebody who’s already moved on? You are sacrificing your future for something that is not worthy of your time and energy. Throw it away! Why would God tell you to do something so radical? Because ‘He cares for you.’ That is right, while you are caring for IT, He’s caring for YOU. It is hard to watch somebody you love twisting in pain because of something they shouldn’t be carrying to begin with. God has no problem making the thing leave you alone; His struggle is getting you to loosen your grip on it. So today He’s speaking to YOU, not what’s bothering you, saying, ‘Throw it away!’

content.title: Are you hungry for God?
content.introtext:
MY HEART HAS HEARD YOU SAY, ‘COME AND TALK WITH ME.’ AND MY HEART RESPONDS, ‘LORD, I AM COMING.

PSALM 27:8 NLT
If you have ever given up chocolate for a detox or been on a diet or are just trying to eat more healthy food you will know what I mean when I say food talks to you. You can be in the middle of doing something, homework, watching telly, sleeping! Then, your whole body seems to hear the chocolate cake sitting in your fridge start to call out ‘come and talk to me, come and see me, come and eat me!’ You try to tell yourself that you are not eating chocolate, but your mouth waters, your lips twitch and your stomach shouts back ‘I’m coming’ Spending time with God is feeding our spirits. Reading the bible and praying is like have a proper meal every day – and we need it, otherwise we become weak and can’t do everything we need to. God knows we need it too, so He loves to feed us with His word. Sometimes like your everyday meals, your times with God are good, they build you up and keep you strong. But sometimes God can call you for something special. He will call out like the chocolate cake. He wants a bit longer than you normally give, he wants you go a bit deeper and those times are amazing. They don’t happen everyday but we need them too, so if you hear God calling make sure you make time for Him. Don’t miss out your steady meals or your special chocolate cake moments. King David wrote, ‘Whom have I in heaven but you? And besides you, I desire nothing on earth. My flesh and my heart may fail. But God is the strength of my heart and my portion forever… (Psalm 73:25-26 NIV) and also ‘My heart has heard you say, ‘Come and talk with me.’ And my heart responds, ‘LORD, I am coming.’ (Ps 27:8 NLT). Are you spiritually hungry? Spend more time with God!

content.title: Protected by angels 2)
content.introtext:
ANGELS…ARE SENT TO HELP THOSE WHO WILL RECEIVE SALVATION.

HEBREWS 1:14 NCV
Here’s a promise you should remember every day. ‘No harm will befall you, no disaster will come near [you]. For he will command his angels…to guard you in all your ways’ (Psalm 91:10-11 NIV). But angels not only serve you, they are stunned by you. Listen: ‘Do you realise how fortunate you are? Angels would have given anything to be in on this’ (1 Peter 1:12 TM). Angels are amazed by the gifts God has given you. Does the Holy Spirit live within angels? No, but He lives in you. Do angels thank God for salvation? No, they’ve never been lost, broken and messed up by sin and then rescued – but you have. Did Christ become an angel? No, but He became a human just like you, and angels stood in awe. Angels attended His birth, witnessed His death and announced His resurrection. They even watch over the work of the church: ‘Through Christians like yourselves gathered in churches, this extraordinary plan of God is…talked about even among the angels’ (Ephesians 3:10 TM) God’s angels are so involved with us that the Bible says, ‘Do not forget to entertain strangers, for by so doing some people have entertained angels without knowing it’ (Hebrews 13:2 NIV). Awesome eh!! God sends His personal bodyguards to protect you. Is this sloppy sentiment from some cheesy American daytime TV show? No, it is solid scriptural reality! If Jesus is Lord of your life, then angels are watching over you!

content.title: Protected by angels 1)
content.introtext:
ANGELS…ARE SENT TO HELP THOSE WHO WILL RECEIVE SALVATION.

HEBREWS 1:14 NCV
If you believe the Bible you have to believe in angels. There are over 300 references to them. How are they described? Tinsel halos and white nighties? No way! Two words describe them: many and mighty. It took only one angel to shut the mouths of the lions for Daniel and bring Peter out of prison on the eve of his execution. And do you remember Elisha’s servant? When an army threatened to take their lives, Elisha asked God to open His servant’s eyes. Check it out: ‘Then Lord opened the servant’s eyes, and he looked and saw the hills full of horses and chariots of fire around Elisha‘ (2 Kings 6:17). If God opened your eyes today what would you see? Angels sitting on your parents car as you drive along? Or guiding you away from a mugger hiding down an alley? Maybe guiding the hand of the surgeon? Or protecting you while you sleep? Billy Graham (a seriously wise preacher guy) says, ‘If you are a believer, expect powerful angels to accompany you in your life’s experience.’ But who is this protection for? ‘Those who will receive salvation.’ Reject Jesus and you reject this awesome offer of protection. Listen: ‘The angel of the Lord encamps around those who fear Him, and he delivers them’ (Psalm 34:7 NIV). Notice: He doesn’t give you a wink and a wave as He flies past; He encamps, He lingers, He takes off his coat and settles in. You can rest secure beneath the shadow of His wings. Think about that and let it lower your stress level. The truth is, some of the wealthiest people on the planet do not have it that good!

content.title: God has a better plan
content.introtext:
WHEN I GO TO SPAIN I HOPE TO VISIT YOU

ROMANS 15:24 NIV
Sometimes we think we have got the direction of our lives sorted. But then bosh! Something happens and our plans go pear shaped. It only later when we look back we can see than what we thought was pear shaped was in fact God shaped! Remember we don’t decide God’s plan for our lives, we discover it. Paul wrote, ‘When I go to Spain I hope to visit you.’ But he never made it. Instead he finished up in one of Europe’s worst prisons, but from there he wrote the Epistles (letters to churches that end up taking up most of the new testament!). God knows what He is doing! One of England’s finest preachers decided that he couldn’t speak at a big conference in America even though he had already bought his ticket, because his wife was so ill and needed him to stay. The ship sailed without him and J. Stuart Holden missed a golden opportunity in the prime of his preaching career. A devoted husband, Holden focused on caring for his wife and tried not to think of what he was missing on the other side of the Atlantic. We’re too easily disappointed when our plans fall through; too easily discouraged when ‘great opportunities’ are missed. And so do we complain far too easily forgetting that God is the one planning our lives? For example, things don’t happen as soon as we’d like but delay is often just the protective hand of a caring heavenly Father. It sure was for Holden. Until the day he died he decided never to question God’s timing again. The unused ticket he held, reserved his passage on a new luxury liner – The H.M.S. Titanic!

content.title: Get back up!
content.introtext:
THEN DAVID GOT UP FROM THE GROUND.

2 SAMUEL 12:20 NIV
Check out and learn from David: standing on his balcony eyeing up another man’s wife. Then follows a night of sin, an unplanned pregnancy, a failed cover up, a shady murder, a public exposure and a dying child. It doesn’t get much worse! Covered in sackcloth and ashes, he lies on the palace floor pleading for the life of the new born love-child. For a whole week he cries, then it’s over... ‘Is the child dead?’ he asks. The answer is, ‘yes’. Then: ‘David got up from the floor, washed his face and combed his hair, put on a fresh change of clothes, then went into the sanctuary and worshiped.’ (2 Sam 12:20 TM) Facing circumstances he could not change, receiving forgiveness he could not earn, learning a lesson he’d never forget, David closed the book and moved on. In Psalm 51 he prays, ‘Hide your face from my sins and blot out all my iniquity. Create in me a pure heart, O God’ (Psalm 51:9-10 NIV). And God answered his prayer. Check this out: ‘I will sing of your strength, in the morning I will sing of your love; for you are my fortress, my refuge in times of trouble’ (Psalm 59:16 NIV). No doubt about it, our sin offends God. But our unwillingness to repent (flip our lives around) and receive His forgiveness offends Him even more! And that is what we do when we remain stuck in our failures. God never intended such a waste of life! The way to honour and big God up after any failure is to get back up, corrected and redirected, and carry the message of His forgiveness to others who’ve failed!

content.title: What Moses overcame 2)
content.introtext:
WHO AM I THAT I SHOULD GO?

EXODUS 3:11 NKJV
Here are three more lessons from the life of Moses: 1) It’s always hard to leave your safe zone. Moses didn’t want to leave the comforts of Pharaoh’s palace, or the security of his new family in Midian. Yet if he didn’t he’d never have fulfilled God’s destiny for his life. Big destinies call for big sacrifices. Just because you do not feel like doing something doesn’t mean you shouldn’t! 2) Real growth begins when you leave your safe zone. For 40 years Moses benefited from everything Egypt had to offer. But only after he left Egypt for the first time did he begin to learn what’s really important: God’s purposes. And it took another 40 years in the desert to discover how God intended to use him. By then he’d been humbled and remade by God. If you want to grow, you have to go! 3) The safe-zone will rob you of your greatest moments and memories. Many people are so afraid of risk that they spend their lives in Egypt, the land of ‘not enough.’ A few are willing to get out of their safe-zone and as a result they enter the desert, the land of ‘just enough.’ But God wants more for you. He wants you to leave the wilderness and enter the Promised Land, the land of ‘more than enough.’ Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed over the risks you did not take, than the ones you did. But you can pre-empt tomorrow’s regret by moving forward today and getting into the ‘faith zone.’

content.title: What Moses overcame 1)
content.introtext:
WHO AM I, THAT I SHOULD GO…?

EXODUS 3:11 NIV
Your life story will be all about risks – the risks you took and the ones you avoided. Look at Moses. Do you think we’d even remember his name today if he hadn’t stepped out of the safe zone? Look what he overcame: 1) Comfort! Comfort can be a greater threat to your progress than hardship. After Moses left Egypt he spent his next 40 years in a place called Midian looking after sheep. He married one of Jethro’s daughters and became head of the family business. Since Jethro had no sons he was going to inherit everything once Jethro died – a cushy little number in those days. Imagine leaving all that to go back and face Pharaoh! Then imagine leading two million complaining people through the wilderness. God’s plan is always rewarding, but don’t think it’ll be easy! 2) Insecurity! When God called Moses he had loads of questions and doubts: ‘Who am I that I should go?’ (Exodus 3:11 NKJV). ‘What shall I say to them?’ (Exodus 3:13 NKJV). ‘Suppose they will not believe me?’ (Exodus 4:1 NKJV). ‘But I am slow of speech’ (Exodus 4:10 NKJV). Finally Moses said, ‘Please send someone else’ (Exodus 4:13 NIV). Fortunately God wouldn’t take no for an answer. So finally Moses did the only thing that helps when we’re uncertain about our future: he obeyed God, the One Who knows our future in every detail. So he agreed to answer God’s call, leave his safe zone and return to Egypt. As a result the children of Israel were delivered out of the hands of Pharaoh, and Moses became famous. What things could YOU do for God and whose lives could be changed if you took that first scary and uncomfortable step out of the safe zone?

content.title: Persecution is coming!
content.introtext:
NO ONE WHO HAS LEFT HOME OR BROTHERS OR SISTERS OR MOTHER OR FATHER OR CHILDREN OR FIELDS FOR ME AND THE GOSPEL WILL FAIL TO RECEIVE A HUNDRED TIMES AS MUCH IN THIS PRESENT AGE…WITH PERSECUTIONS

MARK 10:29-30 NIV
Some Christians will never stop talking about the all the ‘blessings’ God wants to dish out to those ‘who have faith’, others will always bring you back to the hardship, hurt and persecution Christians must face. Jesus said we’re to expect both. Most western Christians (like us) expect the blessings but don’t know much about persecution. Yet in other parts of the world hundreds of thousands of Christians are banged up in prison, tortured and even executed every year because of their faith. If you are only expecting good things to happen to you, ask yourself why? Bad stuff happens to good people. Look at Jesus and he said: ‘When that happens, remember this: Servants don't get better treatment than their masters. If they beat on me, they will certainly beat on you. (John 15:20 TM) When the winds of persecution you face become gale force and your faith gets pushed to its limits, don’t give up or give in. When jokes, hate, even violence are catapulted at you, hit back with love. Trust God to help you to stand firm under attack, He will be judge. Find and underline these two Scriptures: 1) ‘If the world hates you, remember that it hated me first…I have chosen you out of the world, so you do not belong to it. That is why the world hates you’ (John 15:18-19 NCV) 2) ‘Christ suffered for you and gave you an example to follow… People insulted Christ, but he did not insult them in return. Christ suffered, but he did not threaten. He let God, the one who judges rightly, take care of him’ (1 Peter 2:21-23 NCV). Remember, whatever happens, God will take care of you!

content.title: A Christ-like response
content.introtext:
LIVE GENEROUSLY AND GRACIOUSLY TOWARD OTHERS.

MATTHEW 5:48 TM
Here’s how Jesus says we should respond to those who mistreat us: ‘Here’s another old saying that deserves a second look: ‘Eye for eye, tooth for tooth.’ Is that going to get us anywhere? Here’s what I propose: ‘Do not hit back at all.’ If someone strikes you, stand there and take it. If someone drags you into court and sues for the shirt off your back, gift wrap your best coat and make a present of it. And if someone takes unfair advantage of you, use the occasion to practice the servant life. No more tit-for-tat stuff. Live generously. You are familiar with the old written law, ‘Love your friend,’ and its unwritten companion, ‘Hate your enemy.’ I’m challenging that. I’m telling you to love your enemies. Let them bring out the best in you, not the worst. When someone gives you a hard time, respond with the energies of prayer, for then you are working out of your true selves, your God-created selves. This is what God does. He gives his best – the sun to warm and the rain to nourish – to everyone, regardless: the good and bad, the nice and nasty. If all you do is love the loveable, do you expect a bonus? Anybody can do that. If you simply say hello to those who greet you, do you expect a medal? Any run-of-the-mill sinner does that. In a word, what I’m saying is, Grow up. You are kingdom subjects. Now live like it. Live out your God-created identity. Live generously and graciously toward others, the way God lives toward you’ (Matthew 5:38-48 TM). Need I say more? Enough said!

content.title: Excellent Living
content.introtext:
Let the Lord Jesus Christ be as near to you as the clothes you wear. Then you won't try to satisfy your selfish desires

ROMANS 13:14 CEV
Here’s three things that give you victory and the devil a battering: 1) Soaking yourself in the Scriptures. Listen to this: ‘Man does not live by bread alone, but on every word that comes out of the mouth of God’ (Matthew 4:4). Three times satan tried to get Jesus to listen to his lies, but each time Jesus slammed back with ‘It is written’ followed by words of truth from scripture. After the third attempt satan left Him alone because he cannot get his warped way when we know God’s Word and believe it. Have your ‘It is written’ ready. Get to know and learn Word of God before the attack comes 2) Developing the habit of prayer. Prayer puts a shield of divine protection over you. Don’t try to live without it. Check out what Jesus said: ‘Stay alert; be in prayer so you do not wander into temptation’ (Matthew 26:41 TM). Unless we clock on to how easily we get caught up in sin we won’t pray against it and then we’ll always be vulnerable. The most effective weapon the enemy has against you – is you! The bible says your old nature must be crucified daily. The selfish, rude, cruel you needs to be killed off everyday! Prayer is how you do that 3) Clear out what drags you down. A book or magazine, a certain tv show or web site, a place or person. We all have things that get in the way of living God’s way. The new believers in Ephesus brought out all their old books of witchcraft and pornography and burned them in the town square. Sound extreme? Paul says, ‘Make no provision for the flesh.’ Be ruthless with yourself. Satan is like a parasite always trying to grab on to your life. If you give Satan a toe hold he’ll turn it into a strangle hold! What do you need to clear out of your life?

content.title: Deal with your prejudice!
content.introtext:
...I OPPOSED HIM TO HIS FACE, BECAUSE HE WAS CLEARLY IN THE WRONG.

GALATIANS 2:11 NIV
Prejudice means we accept without question the opinions we hear growing up, the drivel churned out by the media, and the viewpoints of narrow-minded people. Growing up is learning to ask 'Is this right?' or more importantly, 'Is it Christ-like?' Prejudice throws people on the junk heap because of their colour, their gender, their bank balance, their post-code, or the beliefs they choose to follow. Often we can be so blind to our prejudices that we'll even crack jokes at other people's expense - and invent horrible names to call them. If you act like that don't expect God to be laughing with you. God stirred up Paul to confront Peter over his racial prejudice. Listen: '...I opposed him to his face, because he was clearly in the wrong' (Galatians 2:11 NIV). Did Paul excuse Peter because he had so many other good qualities? No! Peter's attitude and actions were wounding people and reflecting badly on God, Who '...loved the world so much that he gave his one and only Son, so that whoever believes in him may not be lost, but have eternal life' (John 3:16 NCV). In previous generations wars have gone on and all sorts of pain has been caused - and the bottom line has been prejudice of one kind or another. Before you can deal with the prejudice passed on to your generation you've first got to deal with it in your own life. Are you ready to do that - to genuinely start looking at people through the eyes of Jesus? Start to speak positive things about the people you've dissed in the past - and your heart will soon catch up.

content.title: Fighting temptation
content.introtext:
SO THAT SATAN WILL NOT OUTSMART US...

2 CORINTHIANS 2:11 NLT
Today we'll look at three effective strategies to help you fight temptation - and win: 1) expect it. Temptation begins in your mind. Unless you expect temptation you won't prepare for it. Any defeat you've suffered was first a battle lost in your mind, so as a young person with a big destiny - wise up 'so that satan will not outsmart us...' (2 Corinthians 2:11 NLT) 2) detect it. Ask God to help you detect satan's advances and brace yourself for the impact. An ink-stained wall in Wartburg Castle, Germany, illustrates the point. A radical 16th century Christian, Martin Luther, suddenly detected the enemy's presence when he was praying. The story goes that he picked up an inkpot and hurled it at the devil and it smashed against the wall. Luther sensed satan's sinister advance and responded the best way he knew how. Sound extreme? Maybe, but do you have that kind of spiritual sensitivity? 3) reject it. Don't start playing games with the devil- you'll get hurt. Listen: 'Submit yourselves then to God. Resist the devil, and he will flee from you' (James 4:7 NIV). Satan wants you do the reverse; resist God and submit to him - that's a trap! If you're fighting temptation today listen: '...our high priest [Jesus] is able to understand our weaknesses ...he was tempted in every way that we are, but he did not sin. Let us, then, feel very sure that we can come before God's throne where there is grace. There we can receive mercy and grace to help us when we need it' (Hebrews 4:15-16 NCV).

content.title: You're closer than you think!
content.introtext:
THEY COULD NOT GET TO JESUS THROUGH THE CROWD, SO THEY DUG THROUGH THE CLAY ROOF ABOVE HIS HEAD...

MARK 2:4 NLT
What's stopping you from getting to Jesus today? Guilt over what you have or haven't done? Disappointment in church or Christians? When the four guys carrying their paralysed friend arrived at the house where Jesus was preaching, they couldn't get through the crowd. Nothing about bringing this man to Jesus was easy; they had to make it happen! At that point they'd a choice to make: give up and go home, or try to find a way through. They went for option two and decided to climb up and dig 'through the clay roof above His head'. When they finally broke through and Jesus 'saw their faith, he said..."Son, your sins are forgiven"' (vs. 5 NIV). Whatever 'roof' is separating you and those you love from Jesus, it can be removed! Tear it off! Don't let any obstacle stand in your way. You can have great mates, a fresh start, good results and a healthy life if you are determined to break through to the presence of Jesus. These men were radical in their approach. They didn't just have faith, they had faith in action. They'd come to see Jesus and some dried mud was not about to stop them. As they dug through the roof they knew they were tantalisingly close to the answer and they weren't going to be put off. No matter how hard it seems, keep going! You're closer to a break-through than you realise, so start dig, dig and dig some more. Don't stop until you feel the pleasure of his presence and hear his words of grace to you.

content.title: It'll cost you!
content.introtext:
FOUR MEN ARRIVED CARRYING A PARALYSED MAN ON A MAT

MARK 2:3 NLT
This man on the stretcher was no lightweight; it took four men to carry him! Want to be a soul-winner? A family-uniter? A community-changer? They are some of the greatest things you can do. But be warned, bringing people to Jesus is not always an easy job, it involves: 1) being sensitive to their needs. Chances are someone close to you right now is lying on a 'stretcher' inwardly. Oh, they look like they've got it together, but don't be fooled by their front. They're hurting, and paralyzed - and they know it. Whenever they're alone they're crying out, 'God, unless you help me I'm finished' 2) carrying them all the way. Many Christians want to see people set free, but only if it doesn't involve personal sacrifice. That's not how it works. Deciding to bring somebody to Jesus means bringing them all the way. It means comforting, encouraging and holding them securely until He touches them. 3) leaving the healing to Jesus. David cried, '...lead me to the towering Rock of safety' (Psalm 61:2 NLT). Hurting people know what they need - and so does Jesus. So once you get them to Him, stand back and watch the Master at work. We tend to look for outward signs of change, but Jesus first addressed this paralyzed man's inner condition, where it really counted (v5), before completing the outer work. Don't dismiss God because He works in ways that don't make sense to you. Rest assured, when He starts working on them, He'll '...keep at it and bring it to a flourishing finish...' (Philippians 1:6 TM).

content.title: Better by far
content.introtext:
...THERE WILL BE NO MORE DEATH OR MOURNING...

REVELATION 21:4 NIV
Think about some of the ways we deal with death: 1) through humour. Woody Allen joked, "It's not that I'm afraid to die, I just don't want to be there when it happens." Somehow laughing about it seems to keep death at a safe distance 2) through denial. Just don't talk about death, remove it from all conversation. That's eas Sat Aug 27 Better by far '...THERE WILL BE NO MORE DEATH OR MOURNING...' REVELATION 21:4 NIV Think about some of the ways we deal with death: 1) through humour. Woody Allen joked, "It's not that I'm afraid to die, I just don't want to be there when it happens." Somehow laughing about it seems to keep death at a safe distance 2) through denial. Just don't talk about death, remove it from all conversation. That's easier than re-ordering our lives in the light of it 3) through traditions. Elaborate floral arrangements and graceful hymns dress death in a strange beauty - which helps people avoid its ugliness. But the Bible calls death 'the last enemy...' Sooner or later we're all forced to face death head-on, it's not funny, it's real, it's not beautiful - but thank God it needn't be fearful. Death may be the end of your earthly life, but it won't be the end of you. Paul, who had an amazing vision of heaven, came back and reminded his friends life there is '...better by far' (Philippians 1:23 NIV) because Jesus is there! Remember your most treasured memory, your greatest accomplishment, your most precious relationship, then think '...better by far' Listen to this, from near the very end of the Bible, '...God himself will be with them. He will remove all their sorrows and there will be no more death, or sorrow, or crying or pain. For the old world and its evils are gone forever...' (Revelation 21.3-4 NLT). But remember that the Bible's very clear - you don't get to heaven by chance, you go by choice. You must first accept Jesus as Boss of your life. Elaborate floral arrangements and graceful hymns dress death in a strange beauty - which helps people avoid its ugliness. But the Bible calls death 'the last enemy...' (1 Corinthians 15:26 NIV) 4) through fear. Lots of people are really scared of death - check out the other passengers when air turbulence causes your flight to get a big bumpy! Sooner or later we're all forced to face death head-on, it's not funny, it's real, it's not beautiful - but thank God it needn't be fearful. Death may be the end of your earthly life, but it won't be the end of you. Paul, who had an amazing vision of heaven, came back and reminded his friends life there is '...better by far' (Philippians 1:23 NIV) because Jesus is there! Remember your most treasured memory, your greatest accomplishment, your most precious relationship, then think '...better by far' Listen to this, from near the very end of the Bible, '...God himself will be with them. He will remove all their sorrows and there will be no more death, or sorrow, or crying or pain. For the old world and its evils are gone forever...' (Revelation 21.3-4 NLT). But remember that the Bible's very clear - you don't get to heaven by chance, you go by choice. You must first accept Jesus as Boss of your life. Have you done that yet?

content.title: God-ability 2)
content.introtext:
...THE WEAKER I GET, THE STRONGER I BECOME.

CORINTHIANS 12:10 TM
Paul writes: 'I came to you in weakness - timid and trembling. And my message and my preaching were very plain. I did not use wise and persuasive speeches but the Holy Spirit was powerful among you.' (1 Corinthians 2:3-4 NLT). Writing to the same people a few years later he says, '...we are like clay jars that hold the treasure. This shows that the great power is from God, not from us' (2 Corinthians 4:7 NCV). Paul didn't just acknowledge his limitations, he found them to be God's way of using him even more effectively. Listen: 'After these incredible visions it's easy to get cocky, but to keep my feet on the ground I got this stab wound from satan - the blade's still in there. It's agony; it does my head in. Three times I'm there begging the Boss to pull it out for me, but he says, "All I've given you is plenty to drown out the pain of a tiny flick knife. Anyway, my energy works best when your energy's on zero". So now I love bragging about my lack of energy, my weakness - 'cos then the liberator's power really kicks in...I'm over the moon about all the things that make me weak: the slurs, the hassles, the victimisation, the problems. For when I've no energy of my own, it's bizarre, but that's when I'm at my strongest' (2 Corinthians 12:7-10 Street). Regardless of how long you have walked with the Saviour, every ounce of your ability comes from Him, not you. Let that sink in today, chew it over and never forget it!

content.title: God-ability 1)
content.introtext:
...IT IS GOD WHO MAKES US ABLE TO DO ALL THAT WE DO.

2 CORINTHIANS 3:5 NCV
Let's face it: most of us don't wake up in the morning feeling invincible! No, we're very aware of our limitations when it comes to things like getting along with our family, fulfilling the demands of school, college and work, keeping on going in spite of pain and illness, confronting difficult situations, battling a bad habit, or finding the strength to keep pushing ahead when our dreams have crashed and burned. But we pretend we've got it together. We act like we're capable of handling any situation when we know we're really not. You might be surprised to hear that one guy who constantly struggled to cope was the Apostle Paul. He wrote: '...Who is able to do this work?' (2 Corinthians 2:16 NCV). However - even when he felt swamped Paul enjoyed remarkable success. How? Listen: 'We are not saying that we can do this work ourselves. It is God who makes us able to do all that we do' (2 Corinthians 3:5 NCV). Without God and the power He pours into us we're totally sunk! This is tough for the independent 'stand on my own two feet' generation to swallow. It grates on our egos to think, 'Without God I don't know what the right thing to do is, or how to do it the right way, or where the power to do it will come from. So I must choose to rely on Him at all times.' But once you embrace those words and begin to live by them, you are standing on the threshold of the life you have always wanted.

content.title: Repentance!
content.introtext:
CREATE IN ME A PURE HEART, O GOD...

PSALM 51:10 NIV
Tough-guy Samson went too far. He ended up blinded and ridiculed by his captors in a Philistine dungeon. Why? Because of two unguarded areas: pride and sex. King David also struggled against unrelenting temptation. In a moment of weakness he gave in to lust and paid dearly. But his life took a different route to Samson, because deep down he was 'a man after God's own heart.' What made the difference? Repentance! In brokenness and gutsy honesty David got real with God and found mercy and grace to get back up. Stop and ask yourself, 'Am I living a secret life that only God and I know about? Have I allowed myself to become so addicted to my sin that I fear there's no possibility of turning back?' It's never too late to start doing what's right. You can't sink so deep that Christ is unable to lift you. Repentance is the place to start. Repentance means turning around 180° from your sin, confessing your failure and recognising your inability to change on your own. It means asking for God's strength. Stop making excuses for what you're doing; you're only fooling yourself. You may have kept it a secret so far, but ultimately you'll be found out. Don't go another day without falling on your knees before God and praying, '...cleanse me from my sin... Create in me a pure heart, O God...' (Psalm 51:2&10 NIV). When you've done business with God, reach for people who can strengthen and encourage you. Don't keep pressing on alone, you won't succeed. Get back in the race and run like never before!

content.title: Free from the opinions of people
content.introtext:
IT MATTERS VERY LITTLE TO ME WHAT YOU THINK OF ME...

1 CORINTHIANS 4:3 TM
While we should respect other people's opinions, we should never be ruled by them. If you let it criticism will steal your individuality, rob you of your creativity, and stop you from fulfilling your destiny. That's too much power to give anybody. Insecure people will always criticise you, especially if your choices are more radical than theirs. That's because they're uncomfortable with things that don't fit the limits of their thinking. Secure people can handle being the 'odd one out'. They can allow others the freedom to be different and to make their own choices. That's because they themselves are secure in who God has called them to be. Jesus obviously wasn't too concerned about what others thought of Him. Listen: 'He made himself nothing...' (Philippians 2:7 NLT). He had a goal: to do His Father's will; no more and no less. And He knew that to do it He had to be free from other people's opinions. So do you! The greatest tragedy that could happen to you would be to grow old and realise that somewhere along the way you lost yourself and never succeeded at being the person God called you to be. And that's a distinct possibility if you allow the opinions of other people to rule your life. Paul says, 'It matters very little to me what you think of me, even less where I rank in popular opinion. I don't even rank myself...The Master makes that judgment' (1 Corinthians 4:3-5 TM). Today ask God to set you free from other people's opinions.

content.title: On your own.
content.introtext:
HE WILL GIVE YOU ALL YOU NEED FROM DAY TO DAY IF YOU LIVE FOR HIM...

MATTHEW 6:33 NLT
It's great to have a circle of friends whose company you enjoy. And it's great to find a 'special someone' who you can share your life with. But being around other people isn't the only way to be happy. Get rid of the idea that anybody's company is better than your own. At the end of the day no one but God can fill the spiritual emptiness within us. Think about that for a minute and you'll realise that often the answer to loneliness is not people - it is purpose, it is not an absence of affection but a lack of direction. John had no friends on Patmos; it was a prison island - like Alcatraz! But it was there that God showed him the glories of heaven. As a result, we have the Book of Revelation. Paul was in prison when he wrote most of his greatest stuff. Could you do that? When other people say nice things about you it reflects their opinion of you. In the same way, when you speak well of yourself it reflects your opinion of yourself, and you have to live with you every day - so enjoy your own company! Loneliness is only a halfway house on your journey from companionship to contentment. Contentment is when your options seem to close in the natural realm but doors suddenly swing open in the spiritual realm and you begin to see the possibility of having the kind of relationship with God you never had before.

content.title: Toughen up
content.introtext:
BE ON GUARD. STAND TRUE TO WHAT YOU BELIEVE. BE COURAGEOUS. BE STRONG.

1 CORINTHIANS 16:13 NLT
Where did we get the idea that everybody has to like us? Certainly not from God's Word. Jesus said His blessings are especially for the 'persecuted and insulted' (see Matthew 5:10-11). If you are 'thin-skinned' you will have a tough time facing life's challenges. That's why perseverance counts more than popularity. The Apostle Paul had to put up with being deserted by his friends, getting awkward letters from the Corinthians, being let down by the Galatians, mistreated by the Philippians, mocked by the Athenians, then imprisoned and beheaded by the Romans. So what are you complaining about? Writing to the Corinthians Paul mentions four things you need to pay careful attention to: a) be on guard! The enemy is out to get you. What's he after? The deposit of God that is within you. You're a seed capable of producing a harvest for God in the earth, so protect yourself! b) stand true to what you believe! You can't stand on your present circumstances or the opinions of others because those things constantly change. No, you can only stand on the Word of God. Are you? c) be courageous! Being childish won't cut it when the battle rages. It is time to grow up. Will you still be making the same excuses in ten years time or will you realise today is the day to get involved? d) be strong! Weakness is an invitation to your enemy. It always precedes surrender, and quitting is not an option for you! God told His people that the Promised Land was theirs, but they had to fight for it. And He's saying the same to you today!

content.title: Let people help you.
content.introtext:
...WHOEVER ACCEPTS ANYONE I SEND ACCEPTS ME...

JOHN 13:20 NIV
Too many of us don't reach for help because we have an image to uphold. That's dangerous! To grow we must be open to the Lord, AND to whoever He sends our way. Listen: 'He was in the desert for 40 days and was tempted by satan...and the angels came and took care of him' (Mark 1:13 NCV). Even Jesus needed strength from others. With no food for 40 days He was very hungry and satan tried to take advantage of this weakness: '...change these stones into loaves of bread' (Matthew 4:3 NLT). One of the hardest things to do is say 'no' when you have the chance to fulfil a real need in a wrong way. Even though He created the angels, Jesus let them care for Him. The greater was willing to receive help from the lesser. What a lesson for us. When your pain level gets high enough you would not care who God uses! If you were ill you wouldn't care who the doctor was, would you? Their accent or skin colour would mean nothing because of the urgency of your need. Perhaps you need someone, but you don't trust anyone. Trust God! Who do you think brought you this far? Listen: '"The mountains may disappear, and the hills may come to an end, but my love will never disappear; my promise of peace will not come to an end", says the Lord'. (Isaiah 54:10 NCV). When God extends His love to you, do not be too proud to accept it, whatever form it comes in. When you accept God's helpers, you are accepting Him!

content.title: A word from a Frenchman.
content.introtext:
YOU WILL SEEK ME AND FIND ME WHEN YOU SEEK ME WITH ALL YOU HEART.

JEREMIAH 29:13 NIV
Want to improve your prayer life? Today, we'll take some advice from Francois Fenelon, a 17th century French priest: 'Tell God all that is in your heart, as one unloads one's heart, its pleasures and its pains, to a dear friend. Tell Him your troubles that He may comfort you; tell Him your longings that He may purify them; tell Him your dislikes that He may help you conquer them; talk to Him of your temptations that He may shield you from them; show Him the wounds of your soul that He may heal them; lay bare your indifference to good, your depraved taste for evil, your instability. Tell Him how self-love makes you unjust to others, how vanity tempts you to be insincere, how pride hides you from yourself and from others. If you thus pour out all your weaknesses, needs and troubles, there will be no lack of what to say. You will never exhaust the subject, for it is continually being renewed. 'People who have no secrets from each other never want for subjects of conversation. They do not weigh their words for there is nothing to be held back. Neither do they seek for something to say. They talk out of the abundance of their heart. Without consideration they simply say just what they think. When they ask, they ask in faith, confident that they will be heard. Blessed are those who attain to such familiar, unreserved communication with God'.

content.title: God is calling U 4)
content.introtext:
...GIVE YOURSELVES FULLY TO THE WORK OF THE LORD...

1 CORINTHIANS 15:58 NIV
A career is something you choose; a calling is something you are given. A career is something you do for yourself; a calling is something you do for God. A career might promise status, money or power but a calling generally promises difficulty and suffering - with the opportunity to be used by God. A career may end with retirement and lots of executive toys; a calling isn't over until the day you die. A career can be disrupted by any number of events; but when God calls you He enables you to fulfil your calling even in the most difficult circumstances. For some people in the Bible, the call of God involved living in slavery, going on a long, dangerous journey or being put to death! And not just in Scripture. Charles Colson had one of the most high profile careers in America. He had access to power and influence, but he ended up in prison. He thought his career was over - and in a way he was right. But his calling was just beginning. He was called to reach prisoners just like him. He reflects: 'The real legacy of my life was my biggest failure - that I was an Ex-convict. My great humiliation - being sent to prison - was the beginning of God's greatest use of my life; He chose the one experience in which I could not glory, for His glory.' Sometimes in the plans of God, you have to sacrifice a career to connect with your calling. Think about it!

content.title: God is calling U 3)
content.introtext:
...WHAT WE SUFFER NOW IS NOTHING COMPARED TO THE GLORY HE WILL GIVE US LATER.

ROMANS 8:18 NLT
Receiving God's call is not the same thing as falling into your dream career. When God called Jeremiah to preach to people who wouldn't listen, he cried so much he became known as 'the weeping prophet.' Our first response to a God-sized calling can often be panic or fear. Bible teacher Henry Blackaby writes: 'Some people say "God will never ask me to do something I cannot do." I have come to the place in my life that if the assignment I sense God giving me is something I know I can handle, I know it is probably not from God. The kind of assignments God gives in the Bible are always God-sized. They are always beyond what people can do, because He wants to demonstrate His nature, His strength...and His kindness ...to a watching world.' Saying 'yes' to God's call could mean putting in hours of work and effort when you'd rather not. Maybe it won't involve the kind of recognition you've always hoped for. People may fall out with you and diss what you are trying to do. For sure it'll involve trial and error and some false starts. Can you go with that? Natural talent alone is not enough to take on a calling from God. You will need to pray for strength and creativity beyond what you currently have to do what He asks of you. And it will have to be God and you doing it together. You are not just called to work for God, you are called to work with Him!

content.title: God is calling U 2)
content.introtext:
THERE ARE DIFFERENT WAYS GOD WORKS IN OUR LIVES, BUT IT IS THE SAME GOD...

CORINTHIANS 12:6 NLT
Discovering your calling involves very careful listening. If you're lying on your bed with your headphones on and Green Day blasting in your ears from your MP3 player, you're not likely to hear your mum shouting to tell you that your dinner's ready. In the same way, if you want to hear God calling you to your destiny, you're gonna have to get away from the other noisy things in your life. Stop and think - what in your life is creating excess noise that is making it hard for you to hear God? Getting connected to your calling will affect the way you relate to the world around you. Skilled potters know that as they knead and press clay, it presses back, telling them what it can and can't become. Amateur potters just haven't developed that 'feel'; and their shoddy pots prove it! As the Holy Spirit works in your life, you will also learn how to 'feel' the world around you differently; and respond to what you 'feel' more sensitively. Philosopher Mortimor Adler speaks of those brilliant minds that have been called to sit at the table of what he calls 'the great conversation of the human race.' Well, guess what? Ninety-nine percent of us will never sit at that table! But we can still hear '...Well done, good and faithful servant...' (Matthew 25:23 NIV). That's a promise to all who hear God's call, accept it, and give their lives fully to it.

content.title: God is calling U 1)
content.introtext:
...LORD, IF IT IS YOU, COMMAND ME TO COME TO YOU ON THE WATER.

MATTHEW 14:28 NAS
Correctly hearing God's calling usually involves lots of attempts and failures. You won't just wake up one morning with your calling suddenly clarified and your gifts suddenly developed. Before Peter walked on the water he said, 'Lord, if it is you, command me to come to you on the water.' Jesus said, 'Come.' There's a lesson here for you, and it's wrapped up in that tiny little word 'if'. Before he took his 'leap of faith', Peter wanted to be sure that it was Jesus calling him. And before you get out of whatever your 'boat' is, you'd better be clear that Jesus is the One doing the calling. God's not looking for impulsiveness. Sometimes we make reckless decisions about relationships, money or future plans, then try to justify ourselves with spiritual jargon. Don't do it; the only one who's gonna sink is you! In many books risk-taking is highly praised. But your risk-taking must be in obedience to God. If you have a thrill-seeking personality, you really need to listen here. Boredom can make you vulnerable. It can tempt you to solve your problems by making a rash decision that is not in line with God's will. The line between 'do not be afraid,' and 'do not be stupid' is one that is easily blurred! Knowing when to get out of the boat and take a risk doesn't just call for courage, it calls for wisdom to ask the right questions, listening to recognize the Master's voice, and patience to wait till He says 'Come!'

content.title: The Master Plan 2)
content.introtext:
...EACH ONE OF YOU IS A SEPARATE AND NECESSARY PART

1 CORINTHIANS 12:27 NLT
The disciples came from very different backgrounds: a fisherman; a tax collector; a terrorist. Seem like strange choices? No, the Lord knows all of our strengths and weaknesses. He never makes mistakes because He created the Master Plan; including the part you are supposed to play in it. The great thing is when you know He chose you; you no longer need the approval of other people to feel good about yourself. Whether you're outspoken like Peter or gentle like John, He accepts you and gives you space (and grace) to be who you are. Everybody doesn't have to be like you in order for you to work with them or enjoy hanging out with them. Paul says, 'the body has many parts...[God] has put each...where he wants it...all of you together are one body...each one of you is a separate and necessary part' (1 Corinthians 12:14,18,27 TLB). Did you get that? You have an important part to play, just like all the other people you've met in your life. There are no unnecessary parts! Do not let anybody intimidate you into giving up your individuality. If two of us were identical, one of us would be unnecessary. It is ok to admire somebody else's talent so long as you don't try to be a replica version of them. Learn from everyone; copy no-one. God loves you just the way you are! Listen, '...we have become gifts to God that He delights in...we were chosen from the beginning to be His' (Ephesians 1:11 TLB).

content.title: The Master Plan 1)
content.introtext:
WE WERE CHOSEN FROM THE BEGINNING TO BE HIS...

EPHESIANS 1:11 TLB
Do you realise that before you were born, God's Master Plan for you was in swing? Paul writes, '...all things happen just as he decided long ago' (Ephesians 1:11 TLB). Notice, it says 'all things'. That includes the things you want to run from! When Jonah tried to run from God's will, God's response was clear; 'No way. My Word is already established. If I let you escape, I wouldn't be God. If I have to send tornadoes, rock your boat, shake up your comfort zone or put your entire life on hold, I'll do it in order to accomplish my purpose.' When Jonah could go no lower, he cried out and God saved him; just in time to preach to the lost people of Nineveh. You can do it the easy way or the hard way; who's gonna give in first; you or God! David said, 'Thy way...is in the sanctuary...' (Psalm 77:13 KJV). He also said, 'Thy way is in the sea [storm]...' (Psalm 77:19 KJV). The choice is yours. You've been chosen for a purpose; God has too much invested in you to let you run away when you don't like what's on the road ahead. When He calls you, go for it. If you have to leave behind a relationship, a habit or a lifestyle, go for it. You will know it's God, because you'll be able to leave behind those things that once seemed important for those things that God has revealed are of much greater value. Aren't you glad He chose you?

content.title: Handling confrontation 2)
content.introtext:
...IF YOU ACCEPT CRITICISM, YOU WILL BE HONOURED.

PROVERBS 12:1 NLT
Christ-like confrontation involves risking rejection. It calls for putting the other person's need for character above your own need for comfort. So how can you do that? 1) be sure! Be sure there's a good reason to confront. Confrontation should be a rare event, not an everyday activity, you shouldn't look forward to the experience! If you do, stop and examine your motives. Are you feeling superior? Are you directing your anger over some other issue against this person? Are you lifting yourself up by putting them down? 2) be specific! Being fuzzy and vague leads to confusion, no matter how tactful and gracious your words. Make sure you know the reason for the confrontation, then make that reason clear to the other person 3) be sensitive! Every person is unique. Some proper soul-searching and prayer should come before any face-to-face encounter. Without that you are cruising for a bruising! Pay careful attention to timing because the person you are confronting will be able to sense any uncertainty and uneasiness in your words. Don't run that risk. If you haven't taken the time to pray and seek godly counsel on the matter, stop. Don't push yourself into this on your own! We've all seen that type of Clint Eastwood; "go-ahead-make-my-day" approach. Without fail it leaves a bloody trail of wounded souls. Make sure your choice of words and tone of voice fit the person you are dealing with when your heart is beating fast always keep your own personal agenda in check. None of this is about you! That kind of Christ-like confrontation is the only way forward.

content.title: Handling confrontation 1)
content.introtext:
...IF YOU ACCEPT CRITICISM, YOU WILL BE HONOURED.

PROVERBS 13:18 NLT
Nobody enjoys confrontation, but it's impossible to grow without it. Confrontation is speaking the truth in a personal, face-to-face encounter. God lovingly confronts us in areas where we need to grow, and He expects us to do the same with others. Is it easy? No! Is it stressful? Absolutely! So, here are four guiding principles to help you: 1) don't talk about them, talk to them. Confrontation is useless when it's indirect and can be a nightmare done publicly. Be clear and thoughtful about what you say, find the right setting, then be firm but gracious 2) provide examples - without the added exaggeration, or emotion! Don't beat around the bush or try to hide behind 'I believe the Lord has shown me that you are wrong'. When Nathan confronted King David about his sin with Bathsheba he got straight to the point - and did it very cleverly (see 2 Samuel 12). Be careful to keep your emotions in check. Make some time between the issue and the confrontation so that you can pray about any anger you may feel 3) show them a better way. Don't leave someone to stew without clear direction on how to improve. That's not fair and not constructive. Actually, it can lead to more intense issues and unwanted complications. The best approach is simple. Identify the problem then calmly suggest ways it can be corrected. Your goal should be to help them, not put them on a guilt-trip 4) show compassion and understanding. Don't miss this part! If you do, you'll find yourself accusing rather than confronting. Be honest, hasn't your own journey involved lots of failures? So confront people with love and genuine concern.

content.title: Starting again
content.introtext:
HE HEALS THE BROKEN HEARTED...

PSALM 147:3 NIV
Are you recovering from a broken relationship? If so, don't rush into another one. Take your time. Unhealthy people make unhealthy choices. Some wounds take longer to heal than others, but you can count on this: 'He heals the broken hearted'. All God asks is that you give Him a chance. Begin by taking time to search His Word and find out how He feels about you. His opinion is the only reliable basis upon which to base your self-worth. If a perfect God can love you with full knowledge of your struggles and imperfections, then the message is lighten up on yourself! You can love and be loved again, but first you need to recover your wholeness, the good feeling about yourself inside. Then, you can be sure your choices are good ones, not influenced by unhealthy need or the fear of being alone. And be careful; when you don't value yourself you tend to attract people who do the same, including those who use you and belittle you. You deserve better so hold out for it. Remember, you show others how to treat you by how you treat yourself. As you go through this process some people may walk away. So? Sometimes you have to give up what's less in order to have what's more. God's got wonderful relationships in store for you, but nothing is going to click until your values and your perceptions line up with His. So follow where God's leading you, step-by-step, one day at a time. Let yourself smile again... your best days are ahead!

content.title: His grace shouts louder!
content.introtext:
...GO AND SIN NO MORE.

JOHN 8:11 NLT
Check out this scene from the life of Jesus: 'The Pharisees brought a woman caught in adultery...they said to Him..."in the Law Moses commanded us to stone such women."' What was Jesus' response? Listen: 'He who is without sin among you, let him be the first to throw a stone...When they heard it, they began to go out one by one...Jesus said to her, "Woman, where are they? Did no one condemn you?" She said, "No one, Lord." And Jesus said, "I do not condemn you, either. Go. From now on sin no more"' (John 8:3-11 NAS). Notice two things: 1) those who are the most unqualified to condemn you, will! Stay away from modern day Pharisees who take pleasure in exposing your sin, lifting themselves up by putting you down. Find your friends among those who celebrate God's grace and know how to extend it to others 2) the One most qualified to condemn you, won't! Stay close to Him. By doing that, you gain strength much more quickly. Christ will bring his light to your dark places and heal the wounds of your past because His grace is greater than your shame. Where sin accuses, His grace shouts louder! There's no stubborn stain of shame He can't dissolve because there's no limit to the grace He can supply. If you are reading this, feeling conscious of your shameful past and stubborn sinful ways, come to Jesus. He's ready to forgive you and set you free; He says, 'Go and sin no more'.

content.title: Honest doubts 2)
content.introtext:
THOMAS...WAS NOT WITH THE DISCIPLES WHEN JESUS CAME.

JOHN 20:24 NIV
How do you get through your doubts? Like Thomas - by facing them honestly, then bringing them to Jesus. Too many of us have received the message of Christianity but placed it in a box marked 'Do not ask - do not tell.' Do you feel like you need permission to weep when you lose a loved one? Do you lack the freedom to admit, 'I really don't know for sure?' 'So is it ok to doubt?' Yes, it's ok - in fact sometimes it's necessary to help you grow. It's actually quite dangerous to go round with a head full of someone else's answers, which were never really relevant to your questions...that is, if you are even honest enough to ask questions. Are you? Or has some religious bully pushed you into a corner, telling you that your questions are an offence to Jesus? Listen again to the tender words of the One who knows your doubts and fears better than you do. He says, 'Peace be with you. Look at My nail-torn hands and feet. Look with eyes of faith and believe. You are blessed when you choose to believe in spite of your doubts.' Why not pray today: 'Lord, like Thomas, I still struggle with some doubts. I have not put my life all together yet. Not until I'm with You will that happen. Thank You for accepting me in my struggles and not ignoring my questions. Thomas finally reached the place where he could say, 'My Lord and my God.' Thank You for being patient with me as I try to get to that place too.'

content.title: Honest doubts 1)
content.introtext:
THOMAS...WAS NOT WITH THE DISCIPLES WHEN JESUS CAME.

JOHN 20:24 NIV
It's far too easy to put Thomas down for having doubts, especially when we have so many of our own. Thomas wasn't there when Jesus first appeared to His disciples after the resurrection. The experience of his mates wasn't enough for him; he had to have his own. And he got it! Jesus understands that we will have questions to ask about things we find difficult to understand or believe. Doubts will always pop up in an honest search for truth. Now listen: 'Eight days later the disciples were together again, and this time Thomas was with them. The doors were locked; but suddenly, as before, Jesus was standing among them... He said to Thomas, "Put your finger here and see My hands.
