Put your hand into the wound in My side; don't be faithless any longer. Believe!"' (John 20:26-27 NLT). There are two important lessons here for you: 1) honest doubt can lead to a greater relationship with Jesus. The testimony of other people can only carry you so far; ultimately you have to have your own experience with the Lord. And you can! Thomas started out doubting Jesus, but ended up giving his last breath to make Him known 2) honest doubt can lead to a new level of trust. When the bottom drops out, when the pain seems unbearable, when some shattering event occurs, doubts march in uninvited. When they do there's no point pretending they aren't there. Instead, let those times of doubting drive you to God and His Word for answers. As you do that an amazing new level of trust is reached.

content.title: The healing of memory
content.introtext:
UT ONE THING I DO. FORGETTING...

PHILIPPIANS 3:13 NLT
Are you struggling to forget what was done to you - or by you? Here's some good news. Contained in every promise God makes to you, is the power to fulfil it. In Phillippians 3v13, the great Apostle Paul chose to forget - and you can too! You can start by reading the following promises and personalizing them: '...Do not fear disgrace; you will not be humiliated. You will forget the shame of your youth...' (Isaiah 54:4 NIV). '...Forget what happened before, and do not think about the past. Look at the new thing I am going to do. It is already happening. Don't you see it? I will make a road in the desert and rivers in the dry land' (Isaiah 43:18-19 NCV). 'The former things will not be remembered, nor will they come to mind...be glad and rejoice forever in what I will create' (Isaiah 65:17-18 NIV). Notice the word 'create'. God can create order out of your chaos and beauty out of your ashes. Will the healing of your memories be instant or easy? No. You will do a lot of maturing and a lot of forgiving in the process, but listen: 'Jesus Christ, the Son of God...is the divine Yes - God's affirmation. For all God's promises have been fulfilled in him. That is why we say "Amen"...' (2 Corinthians 1:19-20 NLT). Today God wants to start healing those painful memories. His grace is greater than your past. So, talk to Him!

content.title: Understanding worry
content.introtext:
...DON'T GET WORKED UP ABOUT WHAT MAY OR MAY NOT HAPPEN...

MATTHEW 6:34 TM
What's making you worry? Take a closer look and you will probably find yourself doing the following things: 1) adding unnecessary pressures. You quickly lose your laughter when you think too much about the unnecessary pressure of how you look, or what you have or haven't got. And it will stress you out if you try to fix everybody or live up to their expectations. A Chaplain called Peter Marshall prayed, 'Father, check our impulse to spread ourselves so thin that we're exposed to weariness and impatience that makes our tempers wear thin, robs us of peace of mind, makes skies grey when they should be blue and stifles a song along the corridor of our hearts' 2) leaving God out of the equation. Listen: 'The Lord tells his secrets to those who respect him...' (Psalm 25:14 NCV). Friendship with God is built by sharing all your life experiences with Him: every activity, every conversation, every problem and every thought. When you don't, you end up becoming unaware of His presence, insensitive to His voice, resistant to His correction, and out of sync with His timing. Living your life like that produces only one result - worry! 3) dividing life into the spiritual and unspiritual. You've not forgotten what we read yesterday already have you? All that stuff Jesus was saying is totally relevant to us today. Jesus was saying loud and clear that God is interested in all of your life - not just the 'holy' bits like praying and singing worship songs! Open up fully to God today and leave your worrying behind.

content.title: The Words of Jesus
content.introtext:
…CARELESS IN THE CARE OF GOD…

MATTHEW 6:26 TM
A guy called Eugene Peterson has re-written the whole Bible in up-to-date language; he calls it, 'The Message'. In this bit he takes the words of Jesus: 'If you decide for God…it follows that you do not fuss about what's on the table at mealtimes or whether the clothes in your closet are in fashion. Look at the birds, free and unfettered, not tied down to a job description, careless in the care of God. And you count far more to Him than birds. Has anyone, by fussing in front of the mirror, ever gotten taller by so much as an inch? All this time and money wasted on fashion – do you think it makes that much difference? Instead of looking at the fashions, walk out into the fields and look at the wild flowers…The ten best-dressed men and women in the country look shabby alongside them. If God gives such attention to the appearance of wildflowers…do not you think He will attend to you, take pride in you, do His best for you? What I’m trying to do here is to get you to relax, to not be so preoccupied with getting, so you can respond to God’s giving. People who do not know God…fuss over these things, but you know both God and how He works… Do not worry about missing out. You will find all your everyday human concerns will be met. Give your entire attention to what God is doing right now, and do not get worked up about what may or may not happen tomorrow. God will help you deal with whatever hard things come up when the time comes…' (Matthew 6:26-34 TM). There’s life in the words of Jesus – so read those words again and let them do you good!

content.title: Who’s cash is it?
content.introtext:
…SHE GAVE ALL SHE HAD TO LIVE ON.

MARK 12:44 NCV
There will be times in your life when God will challenge you to give money to a particular cause or person, more than you think you can afford. In that moment faith will leap in your heart and say ‘yes’, or fear will rise like a brick wall saying ‘no’. Your response to God’s challenge is really important because when God talks to you about giving your money as seed, He has a harvest in mind. Some giving levels are effortless, others make us uneasy. Sooner or later you’ll hit that wall called fear. Until you recognize it you will never be able to break through it. As a result you will live on the wrong side of what God wants you to enjoy. So how do you break through? You shatter your idea of ownership! If you believe everything truly belongs to God, what do you have to fear? If God controls the comings and goings of your money, there’s no reason not to give, right? Easier said than done – right? Surrendering control of your money is scary! Jesus’ model for generous giving was a widow who gave her last penny; she had nothing to rely on but God’s promise to meet her needs. Think about it for a minute; what was she really doing when she put in that last penny? God doesn’t want your generosity to be limited by fear. Either you’ll trust Him totally and experience the buzz of being in on His plans, or you’ll trust your piggy bank and try to get by without His help. The danger of holding your cash in tight fists is that you can miss out on something great that God wants to do for you – and through you!

content.title: Centre of attention
content.introtext:
NOW JACOB LOVED JOSEPH MORE THAN ANY OF HIS OTHER CHILDREN …SO ONE DAY HE GAVE JOSEPH A SPECIAL GIFT

GENESIS 37:3 NLT
Joseph’s Dad gave him an amazing new coat. He must’ve been absolutely buzzing about it – it was the flashiest, trendiest jacket for miles around! Joseph’s brothers were well jealous though and started picking on him. Unfortunately Joseph made matters worse by shooting off his mouth and sharing his weird dreams which made him sound like he was on a massive ego trip. As long as Joseph was dazzled by his flashy coat, he couldn’t understand the struggles and frustrations of his brothers who’d worked just as hard, deserved their father’s love just as much, but always seemed to keep coming up short. The flashy coat made Joseph the centre of attention – but he didn’t know how to deal with it, he wasn’t ready for it. Like so many people in the Bible, it would be suffering that brought out the best in Joseph – not success. Joseph’s destiny was to be the centre of attention; one day he would be Prime Minister of Egypt, but first he would spend years as a slave and prisoner. It was in the prison, not the palace, that he would learn his most important lessons. God wanted Joseph to inspire people – not depress them! Before he could lead people, he first had to understand them. To understand them he needed to stop thinking about what was best for him. Maybe you get the impression that one day God will make you the centre of attention – well maybe He will – but you won’t get there by showing off how flash you are.

content.title: Every day
content.introtext:
HAPPY ARE THOSE WHO LISTEN TO ME, WATCHING AT MY DOOR EVERY DAY...

PROVERBS 8:34 NCV
It’s not what we do every now and again that makes the difference in our lives; it’s what we do every day. King David made a massive impact in his generation because he learned this secret. He even wrote it in one of his songs: ‘I will praise you every day…’ (Psalm 145:2 NCV). So, every day, make time to be alone with God. If you have to, wedge your bedroom door closed or go out for a long walk. Like the cheesy advert says: ‘You’re worth it’. And here’s a tip for how to get the most out of your Word 4U 2Day; read it twice. You’ll be amazed at what you get the second time that you didn’t see the first time round. If something jumps off the page and speaks to you personally, underline it; it’s your magazine, you can do what you like with it. Always take a few moments to pray about what you’ve read too. Don’t be ‘religious’, just chat to God like you’d chat to a close friend. And don’t try to resolve all your character issues in one go, or you’ll get overwhelmed and quit. Just deal with one thing at a time as God reveals it to you. If your life is a bit random and unstructured you might need to slow down for a few minutes and try to work out if there are actually any patterns or rhythms involved. For instance you might catch a certain bus at a certain time. Or you might get a natural pause in between doing different things. Maybe you can start making the most of these moments as a way of deliberately increasing the space for God in your life. Then you can squeeze more and more until God is the first and last thing on your mind every day!

content.title: YOUR SPHERE OF INFLUENCE 1)
content.introtext:
...DANIEL SPOKE TO HIM WITH WISDOM AND TACT.

DANIEL 2:14 NIV
A few years ago a James Bond film was released called 'Tomorrow Never Dies'. As usual the swish spy was trying to save the world from a megalomaniac - a powerful media boss whose communications empire stretched around the globe. The baddie brags to Bond about his achievements, 'Soon I'll have reached out to and influenced more people than anybody in the history of this planet, save God himself.' Why do some people work so hard at becoming influential when others seem to be influential without even trying. What about you? How strong is your 'sphere of influence'? In other words; does the way you live your life really affect those around you; and for better or worse? Looking at the life of Daniel we see that he was not only clever in a brainy sort of way; he was relationally intelligent too. And that's what influence is; who you are and what you know affects how other people think and act. In chapter 2 of Daniel, King Nebuchadnezzar was freaked out by a dream. His magicians couldn't help, so he decided to kill them; all the wise men in his kingdom; after all if they can't help what's the point of having them around! Unfortunately Daniel and his mates were included in the death threat. It's then that Daniel shows us a lesson about influence, 'When Arioch, the commander of the king's guard, had gone out to put to death the wise men of Babylon, Daniel spoke to him with wisdom and tact' (Daniel 2:14 NIV). Now insert your name instead of 'Daniel' - that's right, God wants you to be an influencer for Him too.

content.title: SUPER-SIZE YOUR BELIEF
content.introtext:
I KNOW THE PLANS I HAVE FOR YOU...

JEREMIAH 29:11 NIV
Head-faith says, 'I believe!' Heart-faith says, 'I believe it's so for me,' then acts on it. God says, 'I know the plans I have for you...plans to prosper you...to give you hope and a future' (Jeremiah 29:11 NIV). The Lord can take every negative thing that's happened to you and turn it into something positive, if you'll only work with Him and trust Him. He offers you beauty in exchange for ashes (check out Isaiah 61:3). One lady wrote, 'A lot of very painful and abusive things happened to me that soured my attitude toward life. I was trapped in my past and I didn't believe I had a future. But as soon as I believed God's Word, I was released from my pain and began making progress toward the future God always had in mind for me.' When Lazarus died, his sister Martha doubted that Jesus could do anything about it, so Jesus had to have strong words with her, 'Did I not tell you that if you believed, you would see the glory of God?' (John 11:40 NIV). And he says the same thing to you! He's asking you to put your trust in Him and believe that you can do anything He asks you to do. The Bible says, '...let the weak say, I am strong' (Joel 3:10). So change what's coming out of your mouth! When you begin to shout out that you're strong, even though you're feeling weak, the Lord's strength will rise in you. Paul was practicing this super-sizing principle when he wrote, 'I can do everything through him who gives me strength' (Philippians 4:13 NIV). Go ahead and super-size your belief today!

content.title: Born Twice
content.introtext:
...I WILL PUT A NEW WAY OF THINKING INSIDE YOU...

EZEKIEL 36:26 NCV
When Jesus talked about being '...born again...' (John 3:3), Nicodemus couldn't get his head around the idea that spiritual birth and physical birth are completely different. Jesus told Nic that it doesn't matter how religious you are, '...no one can enter the Kingdom...without being born of water and the Spirit' (John 3:5 NLT). Water, as in, 'Aaah - quick - her water's breaking!' refers to your natural birth. 'Spirit,' as in, 'Aha - I've totally got it - I've ignored Him all my life but now I know He's real!' refers to your spiritual birth. But the new birth doesn't merely erase your past and give you a fresh start. God says, 'I will put a new way of thinking inside you...and...give you obedient hearts. I will put my Spirit inside you and help you live by my rules.' God doesn't just tell you what to do, He gives you the power to do it! 'But if that's true why do I keep falling?' Why did you keep falling after your natural birth? Because your muscles weren't strong and the signals from your brain to your legs were haphazard! As a toddler you stumbled more than you walked. When you tripped as a toddler you didn't say, 'Oops, I've fallen again, maybe I was never born in the first place.' Mistakes don't undo your spiritual birth, they're part of growing up. Some of us just grow up faster than others. So be encouraged! '...He who began a good work in you will carry it on to completion...' (Philippians 1:6 NIV).

content.title: Be courageous!
content.introtext:
BE STRONG AND COURAGEOUS...

DEUTERONOMY 31:6 NIV
The times we're most likely to hear about courage nowadays, is when the media reports how somebody was rescued from a burning building or pulled from a frozen lake. But being a Christian takes courage every day! It takes courage to start the journey of faith, admit you're a sinner and commit your life to Christ. It takes even more courage to 'walk the talk' when the going gets tough. There's always temptation to quit that subject you hate, stop talking to your awkward sister, settle for being popular instead of godly, stay home and watch TV instead of going to church, or not bother sharing your faith with your mates. Every day you must choose between doing what's right or what's convenient. Have you noticed convenience never requires courage; only doing what's right will flex your courage. Courage involves not staying in your comfort zone. In other words, you must decide between trusting God (even when you don't understand His ways), or living a life based on your own feelings and other people's opinions. Old faith-guy Abrahams was given one of the most severe tests in the whole Bible. The story is in Genesis 22. God will test you to your limits too! Sometimes you'll need every ounce of courage you've got - and then some! But you can't have a testimony without a test! Just like God told Joshua, 'Be strong and courageous...' He'll give you strength to equal the test. The road may be rough and the enemy casts long shadows, but remember, '...the LORD your God goes with you, he will never leave you...' (Deuteronomy 31:6 NIV).

content.title: Rebuilding your integrity!
content.introtext:
LET ME BE WEIGHED ON HONEST SCALES, THAT GOD MAY KNOW MY INTEGRITY.

JOB 31:6 NKJV
Integrity. It's a word which describes a life being well lived, a trustworthy person who stays cool under pressure. Bill Hybels - a Pastor of a massive church in Chicago - says, 'People who never use the word... look around them at promiscuity... abortion... sexually transmitted diseases, and mourn its passing. They see officials taking bribes, business leaders demanding kickbacks... investors parlaying inside information into untold wealth, and they lament the demise of integrity. They read about battered wives, jobless husbands and abused children, and wonder what happened to caring.' Unlike your reputation which is how others see you, integrity is who you are when they're not looking. Listen: 'The integrity of the upright shall guide them...' (Proverbs 11:3). What does that mean? Rebuilding your integrity means admitting, 'Often my thoughts aren't fit to print,' or, 'I've hurt that person, I need to go back and make things right,' or, 'I've cheated on my taxes and I need to make restitution.' After Zacchaeus met Jesus he said, '...if I have cheated anybody out of anything, I will pay back four times the amount' (Luke 19:8 NIV). Integrity doesn't stop with regret, integrity doesn't seek to minimize painful consequences, and integrity doesn't attempt damage control. Integrity calls for honest repentance, and makes amends whenever possible. Integrity means living in an accountable way, with real honesty. Ancient God-follower Job said, 'Does He not see my ways...If I have walked with falsehood, or my foot has hastened to deceit? Let me be weighed on honest scales, that God may know my integrity?'

content.title: ...a bit more like Jesus.
content.introtext:
..HE HAD COMPASSION ON THEM...

MATTHEW 9:36 NIV
When you see a homeless person asking for money on the street how do you feel? Maybe you feel sorry for them - maybe you want to help. But do you ever secretly feel you're better than them? Come on, be honest! Our society admires beauty, power, money, and idolises people who flaunt God's laws to get it: the glossy magazines and satellite TV channels reduce people to packaging with no consideration whatsoever for the contents inside. Who care's if their life's a mess - look at that ...no wonder people get puffed up with ego. God says, 'Pride lands you flat on your face...' (Proverbs 29:23 TM). Why? Because it blinds you to the truth - then you're likely to trip up. Pride made Adam and Eve wants to play God (Genesis 3:5). Wounded pride caused Joseph's brothers to sell him into slavery (Genesis 37:8). Pride made King Saul so jealous, he wanted to kill David, 'the competition' (1Samuel 18:8). Pride made Hezekiah foolishly reveals his nation's secret wealth to the enemy (Isaiah 39:2). Pride caused the disciples to compete for the top spot in God's Kingdom (Luke 9:46). Don't let pride get you! If anyone ever had a right to be proud and feel better than other people it was Jesus - the Bible describes Him as '...the radiance of God's glory, the exact representation of His being...' (Hebrews 1:3 NIV). Amazingly, the Bible also says, 'When He saw the multitudes, He was moved with compassion...because they fainted...as sheep having no shepherd' (Matthew 9:36). Jesus didn't see people as bad, He saw them as lost! Once you begin to do that, you're becoming a bit more like Jesus.

content.title: BITTER WEEDS
content.introtext:
KEEP A SHARP EYE OUT FOR WEEDS OF BITTER DISCONTENT

.
Letting weeds of bitterness grow in your heart towards another person is one of the worst things for your spiritual life. The heaviest thing you'll ever carry is a grudge. It'll make you sour and miserable to be around. What happens is this: satan enters the picture and convinces you its okay to feel resentment. After all, you're only protecting yourself from getting hurt again, right? So you dig in, justify your position and get comfortable living with the issue. That is - until it starts choking all the good fruit in your life! The reason God says 'keep a sharp eye out,' is because bitterness can spring up from anywhere: like an absent parent we can't forgive; an obsessive relationship we keep reliving; the careless words of a friend who's not even aware of their effect; why let grudges live rent-free in your head and in your heart! What's the solution? Forgive - before the problem becomes totally embedded in your emotions and starts messing with your memories. Replaying old hurts drives them deeper until their roots are really tough to weed out. Paul said, 'Make a clean break...Forgive one another as quickly...as...Christ forgave you' (Ephesians 4:31-32 TM). And the sooner you do it the better! What about today? God's grace is a powerful weed killer - it gets right down to the root of the problem. The question today is - are you ready to let Him?

content.title: Parents - Who'd have em!
content.introtext:
MEMORIZE HIS LAWS...TELL THEM TO YOUR CHILDREN...

DEUTERONOMY 6:6-7 CEV
Robert Orben jokes, 'I take my kids everywhere; but they always find their way back home!' So some parents do have a sense of humour after all! The truth is most parents didn't get the job by first doing a college course and then passing an interview. Your parents learned from theirs and most of what they picked up was probably subconscious. Even model-parents, who seem to have it all together, still fall short. The only One who never fails is our Heavenly Father; He's the ultimate parent. Here are some examples of His parenting style: He's got high expectations, but He's also understanding (Romans 2:4 NCV) He always serves His justice with big dollops of mercy (Isaiah 30:18 CEV) He teaches us through values, and rewards us for results (Galatians 6:7 CEV) He exercises His authority, but He's willing to share His power (Psalm 115:16 NIV) He insists on 'His way,' but also gives us the freedom to fail, recover and do it better next time (Galatians 5:1) He protects us as we go through life, but still teaches us about reality (Matthew 10:16 TM) He knows when to keep His distance and when to come close (1Samuel 12:22) There's no such thing as a perfect parent, just like there's no such thing a perfect kid. Give yours some slack. Just hold your parents with one hand and God with the other, and keep growing!

content.title: Danger: B & B
content.introtext:
...LET EVERTYTHING YOU SAY BE...AN ENCOURAGEMENT...

EPHESIANS 4:29 NLT
Badmouthing & Backstabbing have become features of life in schools, colleges and workplaces. But this kind of destructive gossips a sick form of entertainment - and a major sign of insecurity! Let's be honest, knowledge is power; the reason we gossip is to impress others with what 'we know.' A student who was the subject of vicious rumours writes: 'I remember it like it was yesterday. The queasy stomach, the tears, the hurt. I thought I'd be sick as I sank to my knees on the cold concrete floor...I knew I didn't deserve this. But that didn't make it any easier. I felt like I didn't have a friend in the world. All because of gossip.' God says, 'Evil people relish malicious conversation...' (Proverbs 17:4 TM). Did you get that? Gossip isn't just frivolous, it's downright evil! So, how should you respond to those who whisper in your ear, 'Have you heard about so 'n so' 1) speak up. Listen: 'Fire goes out for lack of fuel, and quarrels disappear when gossip stops' (Proverbs 26:20 NLT). Make it known that you think badmouthing and backstabbing is out of order. And when you hear it, vote with your feet. Walk away! 2) consider the consequences. Wise up! Smart people know if you'll gossip to them, you'll gossip about them! And what's even worse, you're dishonouring God and degrading your testimony! The Bible says, 'Whatever you...say, let it be as a representative of ...Jesus...' (Colossians 3:17 NLT). Remember whom you're representing 3) be an encourager. Paul says, '...Let everything you say be...an encouragement...' (Ephesians 4:29). So whenever you hear somebody being dished turn the conversation around and 'big them up.'

content.title: 3 Prayer snares
content.introtext:
...YOU DO NOT RECEIVE BECAUSE THE REASON YOU ASK IS WRONG...

JAMES 4:3 NCV
Here are some prayers you may want to reconsider: Prayer-blast. Direct your prayers to God, not others! For example, don't turn your cell group prayer time into a venting of your frustrations, or try to bounce your prayer off the ceiling to hit an unsaved mate from across the room! God gets enough bad PR without that kind of thing. Jesus said whenever we pray '...don't turn [it] into a theatrical production..' (Matthew 6:5 TM). Pray snobbery. In one church a childless couple was praying for a baby but some members of the prayer group decided that the husband wasn't godly enough to be a father, so they spent their time asking God to change him. Listen to the way Daniel prayed: '...We do not ask because we deserve help, but because you are so merciful' (Daniel 9:18 NLT). If God only gave children to perfect parents, the human race would be extinct! Prayer-spam. Maybe you think there's a better chance of getting answers to your prayers if you involve a lot of people. So you send out texts and emails to everyone you know and lots you don't! But with God, what matters is the faith with which you pray, not the size of the team. Jesus said, '...if two of you on earth agree about anything you ask for, it will be done for you by my Father in heaven' (Matthew 18:19 NIV). When you face a situation too big to handle alone, get together with someone who really knows God and pray in agreement with them.

content.title: Fault-finders
content.introtext:
BLESS THOSE WHO CURSE YOU, PRAY FOR THOSE WHO MISTREAT YOU.

LUKE 6:28 NASB
If you've ever watched a reality TV programme like Big Brother or Wife Swap, you'll know that certain people build their own sense of identity and worth by pointing out the faults of the people around them. How does God want us to treat the fault-finders in our lives? Here are some pointers to help you: 1) your number 1 weapon is love. All the nit-picking and the mickey-taking fault-finder usually disguises deep insecurity; it lets them shift the focus off their own fears. The Bible says 'perfect love drives out fear.' 2) move towards, not away from. It's natural to ignore or isolate difficult people. Don't! That will just create emotional distance and confirm their belief that you don't care and you won't listen 3) get behind the mask. Show genuine interest in their family, their dreams, their well-being. Fault-finders usually struggle with being read and open. They may not have any genuine friendships and could be hiding their loneliness. So be patient and prepare yourself for the unravelling of a trail of broken and mixed up relationships 4) bless and encourage. Jesus said, 'Bless those who curse you, pray for those who mistreat you' (Like Luke 6:28 NASB). Fault-finders will be totally stunned when you react so differently to them then everybody else does. As novelist Mark Twain said, 'Kindness is a language that the deaf can hear and the blind can see.'

content.title: Keep it simple
content.introtext:
...THEY THINK THEY WILL BE HEARD BECAUSE OF THEIR MANY WORDS.

MATTHEW 6:7 NIV
One Christian author writes: 'The purpose of prayer is to release our faith - not repeat phrases over and over. For example, if I need forgiveness I can pray: 'Lord, I lost my temper and I'm sorry. By faith I receive your forgiveness, Amen.' Or I can pray: 'Lord, I'm so wretched. I can't seem to do anything right. No matter how hard I try I'm always screwing up. I don't know what I'm going to do - I've gotta stop getting mad. Please forgive me. I'll never do it again. I feel so guilty, so bad; I don't see how you can use me. Well Lord I don't feel much better but I'll try to believe I'm forgiven.' You'll agree that the first prayer is much more effective than the second.' Then she continues: 'My problem was I didn't have faith that my prayer would get through if it was simple, short and to the point. I'd fallen into the trap of the-longer-the-better. Most of the time I felt confused and unsure, as though I still hadn't gotten the job done. But not anymore. Now I 'keep it simple' and I experience a much greater release of faith, plus I've confidence that God has heard and will answer.' What are your prayers like? Do you need to make any changes? If you're not praying enough, pray more. If your prayers are too complicated, simplify them. If you need to keep them more of a secret, quit talking about them to everybody you meet. In other words - keep it simple!

content.title: LET IT GO
content.introtext:
FORGIVE...AS QUICKLY AND AS THOROUGHLY AS...CHRIST FORGAVE YOU

EPHESIANS 4:32 TM
There is a famous story about some scientists who set out to capture a rare species of monkey and bring it back alive and unharmed. To do this they devised a trap; a small jar with a narrow neck into which they place a handful of nuts. Smelling the nuts, the monkeys reached in to get them. But when they tried to withdraw their hands, they discovered that they couldn't get their clenched fists back out. They were trapped - unable to escape but unwilling to let go! Sometimes we can be just like those monkeys. Unable to escape our past with its hurts but unwilling to let it go! Has someone mistreated you? Have you ever said to yourself, 'I'll never forget this as long as I live?' Whether you know it not, you aren't holding on to resentment - it's holding on to you. You're trapped. The real victim of resentment and anger is the one who carries it? Are you a carrier? The answer is forgiveness. Jesus said 'Forgive as quickly and as thoroughly as...Christ forgave you' So how did Christ forgive you? a) when you in no way whatsoever deserved it b) with no strings attached c) knowing that you would fail Him again. So forgive and forget. To forgive is to set a prisoner free and discover that the prisoner is you!

content.title: Building great relationships 2)
content.introtext:
...DO THE HARD WORK OF GETTING ALONG WITH EACH OTHER...

JAMES 3:18 TM
We've all seen the fly-on-the-wall documentaries filmed at airports with tourists laying into some poor air hostess. Well, a man arriving at an airport saw a well-dressed businessman yelling at a porter about the way he was handling his luggage. The angrier the businessman became the calmer the porter remained. After the businessman left, the first man complimented the porter on his restraint: 'Oh, it was nothing,' he said. 'You know, that man's going to Miami, but his bags - they're going to Kalamazoo.' When you disrespect others you not only hurt your testimony, you hurt yourself. In God's eyes everyone has value. So giving people respect is one of the most effective ways of reaching them. Now, that doesn't mean you can demand respect in return. No, you must earn it! But if you genuinely respect others and show them God's love, they'll almost always give you back respect. The trouble is, some of us approach our dealings with others as a transaction. We're willing to give, only if we expect to get something back in return. Check your heart motives! Be sure you're not trying to manipulate others for your own gain. Jesus said, '...freely you have received, freely give' (Matthew 10:8 NKJ). Always start a new relationship by asking: am I trying to get something out of being their friend? Will I care for them with strings attached? Am I likely to use them? If your answer to any of these questions is 'Yes,' leave them alone; they're better off without you!

content.title: Building great relationships 1)
content.introtext:
...DO THE HARD WORK OF GETTING ALONG WITH EACH OTHER...

JAMES 3:18 TM
Ever seen someone that just has great relationships. They might not be the most popular person but their mates are really good mates and if they go anywhere they seem to get on with people. Maybe you even seen them influencing and helping others for God. How do they do it? To start with they put a high value on others. Face it: if you're so wrapped in yourself and your problems. you won't make building good relationships a priority. You've got to place a high value on people - because God does! That means expecting the best of them; assuming their motives are good unless they prove otherwise; valuing them by their best moments, not their worst; giving them your friendship with no strings attached, rather than asking for theirs. Also try to understand people, what makes us all tick, Yeah, we are all different but also there is a lot that's the same. Here are some things to remember that are true of most people, do something about these things and you will start to build great relationships: a) people are insecure, so give them confidence b) people want to feel special so 'big them up', tell them how great they are c) people need to be understood, so listen to them d) people are basically self-centered, so think about their needs first e) people get emotionally low, so encourage them, smile, do something kind to make their day f) people want to be associated with success, so help them to win. When you try to understand people and help them to succeed, you lay the groundwork for great relationships - and you influence people for God!

content.title: Make time to dream
content.introtext:
...I WILL GIVE MY SPIRIT TO EVERYONE...YOUR YOUNG MEN WILL SEE VISIONS AND YOUR OLD MEN WILL HAVE DREAMS.

ACTS 2:17 CEV
One day HC Booth was sitting in a rocking chair watching the sunset. Living in the midwest of America he was also watching the dust blow around. As he took in the scene he began to wonder, 'What if we could reverse the wind so that it sucks dust instead of blowing it?' Later that year he invented the vacuum cleaner! God said, 'I will give my spirit to everyone... your young men will see visions and your old men will have dreams.' Did you get that? Regardless of your age, God's spirit can birth in your heart a dream, a vision of 'what can be.' Stop putting yourself down, thinking 'others are better and more qualified than me.' Listen: 'For it is God who works in you to will and to act according to his good purpose' (Philippians 2:13 NIV). You may have faults and limitations, but the God who lives and works in you has got neither! Don't allow fear to make you settle for less than the life God intends you to live. Go ahead, risk, reach, for 'It is God who works in you,' and longs to be glorified through you. Historian Henry J Taylor, reminds us that 'Vision lit every lamp, built every church and business, performed every act of kindness, and created more and better things for more people. It's the priceless ingredient of a better day.' So start dreaming and don't stop!

content.title: That's how much He loves us!
content.introtext:
...HE...MADE HIMSELF NOTHING...

PHILIPPIANS 2:7 NCV
Dr Maxwell Maltz tells a story about a man who was severely burned attempting to rescue his parents from a fire. But he didn't succeed and they died. Depressed and disfigured, he went into seclusion and hiding refusing to let anyone see him - not even his wife. Desperately looking for help she came to Maltz, a top dog plastic surgeon. Even though he told her he could probably restore her husband's face, the man stubbornly refused treatment. So when the woman came back to see Maltz he was surprised. But this time her question blew him away. She asked, 'Can you disfigure my face, so I can be like my husband and share his pain? That way maybe he'll let me back into his life again!' That's how much she loved him! Maltz was so moved, he kept nagging the woman's husband to accept his help and thankfully the story has a happy ending. The Bible says before Jesus left heaven He 'was like God in every thing...But gave up His place...and made himself nothing. He was born to be a man and became like a servant.' Our limited human minds can't begin to take in the world Jesus left. The homes you see on MTV cribs are like run-down shacks by comparison! The Bible says, 'The Word became flesh and lived among us...' (John 1:14 NRSV). Just think: the God of the universe willingly left the splendour of heaven, was born into poverty and died on a cruel cross for dodgy old humanity. Why? Because that's how much He loves us!

content.title: God can turn it around!
content.introtext:
...ACCORDING TO HIS POWER THAT IS AT WORK WITHIN US.

EPHESIANS 3:20 NIV
When a tragic accident left Will Mitchell with disfiguring burns he decided to focus on his possibilities, not his problems. Although he'd lost his fingers he learned to fly an airplane solo. Then one day while flying from Colorado to California, ice caused his plane to crash. Paralysed from the waist down (and you think you've got problems), Mitchell was understandably depressed about being confined to a wheelchair for life. Then a friend gave him the same advice he'd earlier given her: 'It doesn't matter what happens to you. What matters is what you decide to do about it.' So Mitchell adopted what he called the Triple-A Formula. Accept what has happened, otherwise you live in denial, or open yourself to resentment and self-pity. Appreciate what you can learn from it. Built into every painful experience is the potential to be wiser, stronger and more effective for God. Adapt to the new opportunities it presents. It was darkness that drove Edison to keep searching until he discovered a source of light. Since then Will Mitchell has held public office, found love, and given hundreds of talks. He says, 'Before I was paralyzed there were 10,000 things I could do, now there are 9,000. Should I focus on the 1,000 things I can't do? No, I'd rather concentrate on the 9,000 ways in which life is still good.' So, whatever we're facing today, it's not too big for God. It can be turned around through 'His power that is at work within us.'

content.title: Stop your complaining!
content.introtext:
...STAY AWAY FROM COMPLAINING AND ARGUING.

PHILIPPIANS 2:14 TLB
Don't you hate it when other people moan all the time? But you forget that when you're in the middle of some whopper winge of your own. Once you earn a reputation as a complainer, people will avoid you like the plague! The thing is, right attitudes don't just happen, you choose them. Paul says, 'Rejoice in the Lord always...' (Philippians 4:4 NKJ). Joy is a command. It's non-optional and non-negotiable. Only problem is Christians seem to have more of a reputation to being sad and boring rather than buzzing and brimming with joy - how has that happened! The Psalmist writes, 'This is the day the Lord has made; let us rejoice and be glad in it' (Psalm 118:24 NIV). He doesn't say 'yesterday was God's day, how happy I was then,' or 'tomorrow will be God's day, I'll hack it until then.' No, 'This day with its blessings and challenges is a gift from God, so I'm not going to insult Him by complaining.' Complaining is usually self-centered. It focuses on what you don't like. Get over yourself! True joy is a choice; one that comes to those who have devoted themselves to something greater than their own personal happiness. Listen: 'For we have sinned and grown old, and our father is younger than we.' A life of gratitude and service to others will keep you young till you die. But a life of complaining will age you prematurely and possibly hasten your death. So - stop your complaining!

content.title: People-pleasing
content.introtext:
FEAR OF MAN IS A DANGEROUS TRAP...

PROVERBS 29:25 TLB
In school or youth group you've no doubt had talks about peer pressure. The bible calls this the fear of man and says: 'Fear of man is a dangerous trap.' This kind of people pleasing takes two forms: You turn yourself inside out trying to make others happy OR you quietly make all your decisions because you want to fit in or get their approval. Maybe you became a people-pleaser early in life to get the love and attention you craved, or because no one has taught you to trust your own judgment. Either way it always backfires. Not only do others get annoyed with you, you end up disliking yourself when things don't work out. So why do we do it? Because it's always easier to listen to the people we can see, than to the God we can't see. Peter struggled with people pleasing. One night, when a girl asked him if he was a friend of Jesus he replied, 'I don't even know that man!' (Matthew 26:72 CEV). When the prophet Samuel had a go at King Saul for failing to destroy the Amalekites, 'Saul...admitted..."I was afraid of the people and did what they demanded..."' (1Samuel 15:24 NLT). On the other hand, Paul said, 'I am not trying to please people...If I were...I would not be a servant of Christ' (Galatians 1:10 CEV). God doesn't want us to get caught up in people-pleasing. The Bible says He hasn't '...given us a spirit of timidity, but of power...' (2 Timothy 1:7 NASB). When you give in to the fear of others, you allow them - not God - to control you. God doesn't want you to serve others out of fear, but because you love them - and Him!

content.title: The blame game
content.introtext:
THE MAN SAID, "THE WOMAN WHOM YOU GAVE...ME...GAVE ME OF THE TREE, AND I ATE."

GENESIS 3:12 NKJV
The blame-game is just another way of avoiding responsibility for our actions. It started when Adam blamed Eve: '...she gave me of the tree, and I ate.' Next Adam blamed God, 'The woman whom You gave...me.' And Eve? Well, she said, 'The serpent deceived me...' (Genesis 3:13 NKJV). Remember the song that was in the charts a couple of years ago - 'It wasn't ME!'? Here's a common way of avoiding responsibility and dishing out blame: 'It's my genes!' Yeah right! We'll do anything to avoid taking the rap! One blame-gamer, a recovering alcoholic and addict, admitted, 'Each time I was pulled over for drunk driving I'd reason that the police were out to get me because I drove a sports car. Or, if my doctor hadn't prescribed those pain pills I'd never have gotten hooked. Or, if they hadn't served champagne at my brother's wedding I wouldn't have ended up in jail.' Nowhere in the Bible does God let you off you because of somebody else's behaviour. Listen: '...we'll all have to...take what's coming to us as a result of our actions...' (2 Corinthians 5:10 TM). God didn't buy Adam and Eve's excuses, and He won't buy yours either. Others may have contributed to the mess you're in today, but it's your choice to stay there! What do you want - sympathy or solutions? Do you want to justify your past or change your future? Come on, it's time to clean up your act and admit, 'Lord, I'm the problem. Please fix me by showing me what to do to be forgiven, healed and restored.'

content.title: Only one thing!
content.introtext:
...YOU ARE WORRIED...ABOUT MANY THINGS, BUT ONLY ONE THING IS NEEDED...

LUKE 10:41-42 NIV
Sometimes the reason we approach God with a list of requests the length of Mr Tickle's arm, is because we're more interested in His 'presents' than His presence. Truth is, what we consider needs, are often wants. Can you imagine having 'only one thing' on your list; like just wanting to be with Him? David said, 'One thing have I asked of the Lord...that I may dwell...[in his presence] all...my life...' (Psalm 27:4 AMP). Speaking of His presence, Jesus told Martha, 'You are worried... about many things, but only one thing is needed.' (Check out Luke 10.) No doubt, Martha loved Jesus. In fact she couldn't do enough for Him. The problem was, she was so busy serving Him that she didn't know how to relax and just enjoy just being with Him! Sound familiar? If you're not spending time enjoying God's presence, you need to change how you spend your time. Maybe like Martha you think that unless you do the job yourself it won't get done right (and that doesn't include completing the final level of your latest game!). And who knows, you may be right! But remember this: God will never ask you to do anything that gets in the way of your relationship with Him. He wants that to be your top priority! So, if you're so busy that you're not doing the 'one thing' He really wants from you, right now would be a good time to put that right. How about it?

content.title: What would Jesus do?
content.introtext:
...CHRIST...IS YOUR EXAMPLE. FOLLOW IN HIS STEPS.

1 PETER 2:21 NLT
Do you ever catch yourself moaning when your friends let you down? Do you ever think you're a 'better friend' than they are? Is it always you who invites them over? Are you always lending them your games and CDs but they never lend you any? Are there times when you feel that you give more than you get? Jesus experienced all these things - and more! (Well maybe James and John didn't borrow his CDs without asking!) His closest friends let Him down; they were unreliable and immature. They learned slowly, and always the hard way. One even betrayed Him to death - that's heavy. Yet Jesus forgave them and loved them anyway. Listen, '...having loved His own...He loved them unto the end' (John 13:1). Jesus loved His friends, but not because they were worthy of love. His love made them worthy! In 'Knowing God', JI Packer writes, 'There is tremendous relief in knowing myself. There is great cause for humility in the thought that He sees all the twisted things about me that others don't see. Indeed He sees more corruption in me than that which I see in myself. Yet He wants me as His friend, and desires to be my friend, and has given His Son to die for me in order for me to realize this purpose.' So the next time a friend disappoints you, remember God's grace to you - His love that He gives you even when you don't deserve it. Use His Son as your role model and ask yourself, 'What would Jesus do?'

content.title: Two questions
content.introtext:
...MAKE THE MOST OF EVERY OPPORTUNITY.

COLOSSIANS 4:5 NIV
It's hard to get your head round but how you use your time makes a massive difference to the person you become and the way your life will turn out. Here are two questions to ask yourself every day which will get you thinking about how you use your time: 1) what's required of me? You might not realise this but God has given you things that He wants you to do. Follow him with every bit of strength and passion you have, love other people as you love yourself, honour you parents, love the geeks and freaks. It's important to ask yourself regularly - 'Am I doing all I can to become a better son/daughter, a better friend, a better pupil...?' Always ask yourself challenging questions. Give it time to process before moving on to the next 'big thing' 2) what brings me the greatest fulfilment? Some of the things that God requires will give you a greater buzz than others and that's because God has made us that way. But we can't ONLY do the stuff we get a buzz from and love doing. Some of us want to jump to the fulfilment question before we've answered the requirement question. You might love playing in the worship band but God still wants you to be a good son/daughter. You'll never succeed if you don't have the discipline to take care of the first question, before addressing the second. If you bring your priorities into focus by constantly asking these two questions, you've a good chance of fulfilling God's purposes for your life.

content.title: Resting in God
content.introtext:
IF YOU ARE TIRED FROM CARRYING HEAVY BURDENS, COME TO ME AND I WILL GIVE YOU REST.

MATTHEW 11:28 CEV
Have you ever noticed that the more busy you are and the more stressed you get the less time you spend with God? It's a bit bonkers really because those hectic times are exactly when we need God's strength and wisdom more! Check out what Jesus said: 'If you are tired from carrying heavy burdens, come to me and I will give you rest.' Everywhere He went people were hassling Jesus for His time and attention. Nobody was busier than Jesus, yet He was never in a hurry. He had a lot more to do than you, yet He never seemed to do it in a way that severed or cut off the life-giving connection between Him and His Dad. He regularly withdrew from activity to the place of solitude and prayer. And when His disciples returned, flushed with success, their adrenaline pumping from a busy time of ministry, He told them 'Come away...all by yourselves and rest a while' (Mark 6:31 NRSV). Constant hurry is the mark of an un-prioritized life. It's a sign that second and third things have become first things. Getting involved in the Christian lunch club, playing in the band at church, going to the big youth service and youth group are all important but are you getting too busy to chill with Jesus? Following Jesus can't be done at a sprint; you can't go faster than the One who's leading. So, slow down. Don't just work for God - spend time with Him!

content.title: Angels watching over you!
content.introtext:
...HE WILL COMMAND HIS ANGELS CONCERNING YOU TO GUARD YOU IN ALL YOUR WAYS

PSALM 91:11 NIV
Remember that 'close call' you had? Some called it 'a lucky escape'. Maybe God had sent an angel to guard you - the Bible says it's one of their important roles. Chuck Swindoll (a Christian speaker) tells of a Church youth group who got lost on a mountain-climbing expedition. A snowstorm suddenly covered the trail and their leader hadn't a clue where they were or how to get back to camp. The sun was setting. The temperatures were plunging. The danger was real. Trudging through the snow and getting more and more panicky by the moment, they heard someone on the slopes above yell, 'Hey, the trail's up here!' They glanced up, and to their relief saw another climber just above them. Quickly they made their way up to the big boulder where the man had been sitting. But when they arrived they found nobody there, not even a footprint in the snow. When they looked, however, the trail stretched out before them leading safely back to camp. The Bible says, some people have hung out with angels without knowing it (check out Hebrews 13:2). Even children have guardian angels watching over them. Jesus said, 'Watch that you don't treat a single one of these childlike believers arrogantly. You realize, don't you, that their personal angels are constantly in touch with my Father in heaven?' (Matthew 18:10 TM). Paul discovered that when you go through storms God assigns an angel to protect you. Check this, 'There stood by me this night the angel of God...saying fear not...' (Acts 27:23-24 NKJ). Hey relax, God's got you covered!

content.title: Think! 2)
content.introtext:
THE WISDOM OF THE PRUDENT IS TO GIVE THOUGHT TO THEIR WAYS...

PROVERBS 14:8 NIV
In order to become a better thinker, you need to: 1) do what works for you. Immanuel Kant (philosopher and all-round brain box) would stare out of his window at a tower in order to think creatively; when trees grew up threatening to block his view, he chopped them down. Samuel Johnson (the bloke who wrote the English dictionary) said he needed a purring cat, an orange peel and a cup of tea in order to write. Some of us like music, some like to skate, some think better when chatting through ideas with other people. Do whatever works for you (but I bet it won't be sat in front of the TV!) 2) write down your thoughts. If you don't write down your ideas you'll lose them. In 'Bird By Bird', Anne Lamott says, 'I have an index card and pens all over the house - by the bed, in the bathroom, in the kitchen, by the phones...I used to think that if something was important enough I'd remember it...but then I wouldn't...writing down your ideas right away is not cheating. It doesn't say anything about your character.' 3) put your thoughts into action quickly. Dave Goetz, founder of CustomZigns.com says, 'For me, when an idea hits it strikes fire...the more time that passes after the idea strikes, the less heat it gives off. I forget parts of it, it doesn't seem so great. Ideas have a short shelf life.' Author Alfred Montapert says, 'Every time a person puts an idea across, he finds ten people who thought about it before he did - but they only thought about it.' Don't just think creatively, put those God-given ideas into action and make a difference in His world!

content.title: Think! 1)
content.introtext:
THE WISDOM OF THE PRUDENT IS TO GIVE THOUGHT TO THEIR WAYS...

PROVERBS 14:8 NIV
God gave you a brain - use it! That doesn't mean you have get A* in every exam. Football managers, film directors, the foreman on the building site all have to learn to be thinkers! One night at dinner, a friend of John Kilcullen's described something he overheard in a bookstore. A customer asked the clerk, 'Do you have any simple books on Microsoft DOS - something like DOS for dummies?' It was only a passing comment meant as a joke, but it stuck with Kilcullen and he did something with it. He launched the 'Dummies' books - you've probably seen them with their distinctive yellow and black cover designs. Some unknown customer had a good idea and it went nowhere. In fact, they probably didn't even know at the time that it was a good idea. But in the hands of a thinker, that good idea became a great idea. Then it became a bunch of great ideas. There are now 370 'Dummies' books, in 31 languages, with sales of more than 60 million copies (You can even get 'Prayer for Dummies'!). On your way to becoming a great thinker, you'll come up with loads of rubbish and useless ideas... but keep developing your thinking and your ideas will get better. Coming up with the right solution, the winning plan, the new idea, is determined not by just wanting it, but by thinking it through properly. Once the ideas start flowing, they get better. And once they get better, so does your life!

content.title: Romantic rules
content.introtext:
COMMIT EVERYTHING...TO THE LORD...AND HE WILL HELP YOU.

PSALM 37:5 NLT
Girls - you've done all the questionnaires in the magazines to find out if he is MR RIGHT. Lads - you chatted to your mates about her whilst thrashing them on FIFA Pro Soccer and they think she's fit. But here are four more questions you both should consider: 1) is the relationship based on honesty? The Bible speaks about, '...telling each other the truth' (Ephesians 4:25 CEV). Relationships need openness and trust. When dodgy deceit and little lies creep in, it's time to get truthful in a hurry, or call it quits 2) can you be yourself? Paul writes, '...Each of us is an original' (Galatians 5:26 TM), and '...let's...be what we were made to be' (Romans 12:6 TM). If you feel like you constantly need to reinvent yourself or you're just frontin', you're in the wrong relationship. Use your head! If you think they only go for the fake you then they don't KNOW YOU, and how long can that last? 3) is either of you possessive? The Bible says, 'Love is...never jealous...' (1 Corinthians 13:4 CEV). If one of you can't make a move without the other's permission, it's a red flag, back off! 4) have you established physical boundaries? If your relationship finishes and you eventually marry someone else will you regret how far you've been with the person you are with now? You may know that the Bible says, 'Run...from sexual sin...' (1 Corinthians 6:18 NLT), but do you understand why God says He made sex as a commitment only for marriage? If you're not sure why Christians make such a big deal about this, ask a youth leader or someone you trust. Finally: 'Commit everything...to the Lord...He will help you.' Lasting relationships always put God first - always!

content.title: Inner strength!
content.introtext:
...I AM...EQUAL TO ANYTHING THROUGH HIM WHO INFUSES INNER STRENGTH INTO ME...

PHILIPPIANS 4:13 AMP
You know the score; when you wake up each morning, you've got no real idea what will happen to you (other than your mum pecking your head about the fact you got up so late). Sure, we hope for hassle-free days in which all our dreams come true. Yet we know from experience this isn't always how the day turns out. We live in a real world with real problems. Our enemy, the devil, is real and he works in every way possible to batter us and bully us with discouragement, fear and failure. That's why David said, 'If you make the Lord your refuge...no evil will conquer you; no plague will come near your dwelling. For he orders his angels to protect you wherever you go...The Lord says, 'I will rescue those who love Me. I will protect those who trust in My name. When they call on Me, I will answer; I will be with them in trouble. I will rescue them and honour them. I will satisfy them with a long life and give them My salvation' (Psalm 91:9-16 NLT). No matter what comes our way, we should believe that when it arrives we'll be more than able to handle it. That's why Paul (who had a life packed with hassle and hardship) writes, '...I am ready for anything and equal to anything through Him Who infuses inner strength into me...' (Philippians 4:13 AMP). Inner strength is better than outer strength, because if you can stay strong inwardly you can handle anything that comes against you outwardly, and still keep moving forward.

content.title: 3 Asks
content.introtext:
...ASK HIM, AND HE SHALL GLADY TELL YOU...

JAMES 1:5 NTL
Here's 3 things that are worth asking God for regularly: 1) am I real? A little boy in Sunday school knew the sort of answers you're supposed to give. So when the teacher asked, 'What's grey, furry, has a long, bushy tail and stores up nuts?' He muttered, 'I suppose the answer is Jesus, but it really sounds like a squirrel to me.' So often we try to say spiritual sounding things to impress each other, when the world rest of the world hasn't a clue what we're talking about. Be real! 2) am I judgmental? On an episode of The Simpsons, the Flanders family had been away together. When they got back home Homer asked them where they'd been and got this reply: 'We went to a Christian camp; we were learning how to be more judgmental.' Ouch! Is that what people think about Christians? Is that true about you? Does a little voice inside you categorize people: This one's hard work, got 'baggage' - stay away. That one's fit and has cool stuff, get in there - try to connect. Why do we constantly find ourselves scoring people, as if life's some kind of contest? 3) am I approachable? Speaking of the Pharisees Jesus said, 'they love...to have men call them "Rabbi"' (Matthew 23:7 NIV). In Jesus' day, some rabbis had the idea that being Godly required you to distance yourself from people. Jesus tipped that idea right on it's head getting close to the people at the bottom of the stack. Jesus was the most approachable person they'd ever met. How about you?

content.title: Don't be a gong!
content.introtext:
IF I...HAVE NOT LOVE, I AM ONLY A RESOUNDING GONG...

1 COR 13:1 NIV
When it came to making religious racket the Pharisees were experts: long, loud flowing prayers in public; fierce, judgmental criticism about anything and everything. Sound familiar? Dallas Willard writes, 'How many people are radically and permanently repelled by Christians who are unfeeling, stiff, unapproachable, boringly lifeless and dissatisfied? Yet such Christians are everywhere...Spirituality wrongly understood or pursued, is a major source of human misery and rebellion against God.' When our lives are not marked by true happiness that come from devotion to Christ, it's easy to start looking for other ways of justifying ourselves as Christians - and that's how people get 'religious'. But Jesus didn't come across to people as religious at all. When asked to identify what religion was about, He simply replied 'Love God and love people.' A few years later Paul would say in the same spirit, 'If I speak in the tongues of men and of angels, but have not love, I am only a resounding gong or a clanging cymbal' (1 Corinthians 13:1 NIV). It's possible to think you're becoming more spiritual when in fact you're becoming what Paul calls a 'gong'...a great big, hard piece of metal loosely dangling in the air. The only noise it makes is the one its name suggests, 'GONNNNNG!' The strongest advert for Christianity is Christians displaying the love of Jesus. The strongest advert against Christianity is Christians who are smug, judgmental and complacent. So, don't be a gong today!

content.title: Success myths 2)
content.introtext:
...PLEASE, LORD, GIVE US SUCCESS.

PSALM 118:25 NCV
Here are 3 more success myths that trap us: 1) we believe success is the result of opportunity, so make excuses. Many people who try different things but don't seem to get anywhere, believe that the only thing they need is 'a break'. Their motto is, 'if only'. 'If only I had a better teacher for that subject'. 'If only my parents would let me stay out later'. 'If only they would let me sing in the band' Sound familiar? The problem with people who live with that kind of attitude is that when an opportunity does come along they aren't ready to take it 2) we think success comes from having power, so we push for it. This idea is reinforced by the words of people like industrialist Andrew Carnegie: 'Success is the power with which to acquire whatever one demands of life.' So we assume that all successful people have taken advantage of others to get to where they are, and we begin to look for ways to manipulate people. We believe we can force our way to success, but people just end up getting hurt 3) we believe success comes from connections, so we 'press the flesh'. People who believe in connections think they'll 'make it' by getting in with the right people - the Brit pack - the Jet set! But those beliefs are misplaced. Knowing cool people has its rewards. But connections alone won't improve your life if you're off track. For followers of Christ, success comes by chasing after God and His amazing plan for your life!

content.title: Success myths 1)
content.introtext:
...PLEASE, LORD, GIVE US SUCESS.

PSALM 118:25 NCV
Let's look at some common success myths: 1) we believe success is impossible, so we sack it. Because we want to believe that life should be easy, we assume anything that's difficult must be impossible. So when the road to success gets tough we throw in the towel and say, 'Who wants success anyway?' And if success is achieved by anyone we consider less worthy than ourselves, we have a dig at them because we're jealous 2) we believe success is mystical, so we day-dream about it. The problem is, we want the gain without the pain. Businessman Seth Grodin says, 'We need to stop shopping for lightning bolts. You don't win an Olympic medal with a few weeks of intensive training. There's no such thing as an overnight opera sensation...every great thing has been built in exactly the same way: bit by bit, step by step, little by little' 3) we believe success comes by luck, so we wish for it. Why do people say stuff like, 'She just happened to be in the right place at the right time.' Why do so many millions of people spend good money every week playing the Lotto? Because the believe in the cobblers called 'Luck'! Sadly, luck disappoints 999,999 times out of a million. That's why Paul said to the Romans '...we rejoice in the hope of the glory of God... And hope does not disappoint us, because God has poured out his love into our hearts by the Holy Spirit...' (Romans 5:2 & 5 NIV).

content.title: Detox from criticism
content.introtext:
TAKE CONTROL OF WHAT I SAY, O LORD....

PSALM 141:3 NLT
A detox is a special kind of diet when you cut out stuff that's bad for your body. Really it's a modern version of what the Bible calls 'fasting' - except fasting is good for your mind, body and soul! In A Closer Walk Catherine Marshall writes, 'One morning last week God gave me an assignment for one day. I was to go on a 'fast' from criticism. I was not to criticize anybody or anything. 'For the first half of the day I simply felt a void, almost as if I'd been wiped out as a person. This was especially true at lunch. I listened to the others and kept silent. In our talkative family nobody seemed to notice. Bemused, I noted that the Government, the judicial system, and the church could get a long just fine without my personal observations! But still I didn't see what this "fast from criticism" was accomplishing - until mid-afternoon. 'In the afternoon God gave me a new vision for my life. And it had His unmistakable hallmark on it - joy! Ideas began to come to me in a way I hadn't experienced in years. Now it was apparent what the Lord wanted me to see. My critical nature had not solved a single one of the things I had found fault with. What it had done was to stifle my own creativity.' Listen, 'Take control of what I say, O Lord...' (Psalm 141:3 NLT). Negative words create a bad atmosphere in which positive people can't live. So have a detox from criticism today - in fact, why not see if you can keep it up all weekend.

content.title: Open for ideas
content.introtext:
INTELLIGENT PEOPLE ARE ALWAYS OPEN TO NEW IDEAS. IN FACT, THEY LOOK FOR THEM.

PROVERBS 18:15 NLT
One idea can change everything! Bill Gates had an idea, but when he went looking for investors some of his big-money friends called it 'too risky.' Can you imagine how they feel now? Good ideas are great. God ideas are even better! You see, what God inspires, He also invests in. Paul said, 'My God will meet all your needs according to His glorious riches...' (Philippians 4:19 NIV). According to what? The Bank of Heaven! God's problem has never been lack of ideas; it's finding people who'll leave their comfort zone and turn those ideas into action - people like Abraham, who, 'By faith...when called to go...went, even though he did not know where he was going' (Hebrews 11:8 NIV). And what was his reward? '...All the families of the earth will be blessed through you...' (Genesis 28:14 NLT). Usually God gives us His ideas when: a) Ours have failed b) we've laid aside our conditions, and decided to do whatever He says c) we're willing to risk d) we're committed to giving Him all the glory. Think for a moment about all the ideas you've been involved in so far this year. How many are good ideas and how many are God - ideas? Listen, '...What I have said, that I will bring about; what I have planned, that will I do' (Isaiah 46:11 NIV). Ask God to help you to be open to His ideas today.

content.title: Don't look back
content.introtext:
REMEMBER LOT'S WIFE.

LUKE 17:32
When the Sunday school teacher told her class, 'Lot's wife looked back and turned into a pillar of salt,' one child responded, 'That's nothin'! My mum was driving home yesterday, and she looked back and turned into a telephone pole!' Abraham's nephew Lot lived in a well shady city called Sodom. His wife only appears briefly, in one scripture (Gen 19:26) so why did Jesus tell us to remember her? Two reasons: 1) she wouldn't put the past behind her. John writes, 'This world is fading away, along with everything it craves. But if you do the will of God, you will live forever.' (1 John 2:17 NLT). God got Lot's wife out of Sodom, but she couldn't get Sodom out of her. When she thought of what she was leaving, she looked back and was turned into a lifeless monument. When God says it's time to move, don't hang about! Don't become like those who once walked with Him, standing out as shining lights in their communities, but now have turned cold and unresponsive 2) your decisions have consequences. If Lot's wife had kept moving forward she'd have been there to protect her daughters in the future. Instead they led each other astray with some really wacko ideas. Before you lose your mates, poison your family, and tear up your life by refusing to break with your past, 'remember Lot's wife.' She didn't make it to safety, but she did make it into the Bible just long enough to warn us not to look backwards when God's called us forwards.

content.title: Coming and Going
content.introtext:
HE SAID TO THEM, GO INTO ALL THE WORLD...

Mark 16:15 NIV
Jesus made it clear that our job is to 'Go.' But many churches think it's good enough to sit tight and invite people to 'Come'. Michael Frost from Australia explains: '...I was watching my daughter play soccer in a local park. Next to the field was an area where a group of model-car enthusiasts had set up a track and were using remote controls to race their cars against one another's. The constant buzz of the miniature motors caught our attention and we wandered over to see what they were doing. We soon realized that we had encountered a lost suburban tribe. Everyone looked the same. They all wore tight black jeans and chequered flannel shirts. They wore baseball caps with car manufacturers' logos on them. They had parked their cars - virtually all drove pickups - beside the tracks, and their wives or girlfriends sat in one of the truck beds talking and laughing loudly. It was a tribe in every sense of the word - dress code, language, culture and customs... 'If the nearby church decided that this suburban tribe needed to hear about the saving work of Christ, how would they reach them? The church would hold special services for model-car racers. It would design an excellent flyer explaining that Jesus loves model-car enthusiasts, and they would place one under the windshield wipers of each pickup. It would try to find a recently converted model-car enthusiast and have him share his testimony on a Sunday morning. The church would do anything it could to draw the car racing fraternity into its building.' One of the best ever 'Go-errs' was Paul, who said, '...I try to find common ground with everyone so that I might bring them to Christ.' (1 Corinthians 9:22 NLT) Will you go today?

content.title: Pollute or purify!
content.introtext:
A GOOD PERSON WHO GIVES IN TO EVIL IS LIKE A MUDDY SPRING OR DIRTY WELL.

PROVERBS 25:26 NCV
The attitudes of the people we spend time with rub off on us. That's why Paul wrote, '...Your faith will help me, and my faith will help you' (Romans 1:12 NCV). There are two kinds of people in any group: polluters and purifiers. The polluters are like chimneys belching out dirty smoke all the time. They hate clear skies. No matter how good life is they find a way to make it gloomy. When the people around them breathe their toxins they feel sicker and sicker. The purifiers, on the other hand, make everything around them better. It doesn't matter what kind of rotten atmosphere they encounter. They take in the toxic words of polluters, but they filter and neutralise them rather than just wafting them in someone else's direction. What goes in gloomy and negative comes out fresh and clear. So, are you a polluter or a purifier? When you spend time with people do they walk away feeling better or worse? Do you clear the air giving them fresh perspective and encouragement, or do they leave you feeling hopeless about things? Watch how people respond to you and you'll know which group you're in. Bottom line: Polluters usually get what they expect - nothing! But those who choose to stir up their faith and look for God's best in every situation see opportunities that others miss. Purifiers see people clearly through God's eyes. Is that important? Absolutely! Your attitude will reach them long before your message does.

content.title: Grow up 2)
content.introtext:
LET THE WISE LISTEN AND ADD TO THEIR LEARNING...

PROVERBS 1:5 NIV
If you're serious about growth, here are 4 things you can do: 1) make a commitment to change. Many people want things to get better - without having to change anything. To grow, you must commit yourself to not only accepting change - but to making it! Listen: 'Let us...go on to maturity...' (Hebrews 6:1 NIV). 2) focus on your strengths. Business boffin Peter Drucker said, 'The great mystery isn't that people do things badly, but that they occasionally do things well. The only thing that's universal is incompetence. Strength is always specific. Nobody ever commented that the great violinist, Jascha Heifetz, couldn't play a trumpet very well.' If you try to be good at everything, you'll end up good at nothing. God gave you specific gifts. Find them and use them for His glory! 3) put yourself in a growth environment. Certain fish grow according to the size of their environment. Put them in a small aquarium and they remain small. Release them into the ocean and they grow to their intended size. And you are the same! If you spend your time with the wrong crowd in the wrong place doing the wrong things, you'll squash your growth. 4) learn to enjoy the journey. Most Grand Masters of chess learn and relearn their moves over a period of about15 years before winning their first world title. That's almost a fifth of their lives! If you're going to spend that much time doing something, you'd better enjoy it. If the destination appeals to you but you're not finding any fun on the journey, you'd be smart to ask God if you're on the right path.

content.title: Grow up 1)
content.introtext:
LET THE WISE LISTEN AND ADD TO THEIR LEARNING.

PROVERBS 1:5 NIV
All of us want to grow in God. Yet so many of us don't - we get stuck! Why? 1) we think growth is automatic! When we're children we grow naturally. During that time there are adults such as parents and teachers challenging us to grow on a daily basis. So we get used to growing. The problem comes when we become adults and nobody's pushing us to grow or improve anymore. As you make the step to adulthood, take responsibility for your own growth, or it won't happen! 2) we think growth comes from information! The greatest obstacle to growth isn't ignorance - it's the illusion of knowledge! Have you ever met someone who was a total brainbox but couldn't seem to do anything of benefit for God, themselves, or other people? Who wants to be a walking encyclopedia - filled with knowledge which has no value because it's never used? 3) we think growth comes with experience! Believing that growth comes simply from experience is like a soldier shooting bullets all over the place, believing he's improving because he keeps on shooting. No, experience is profitable only if you learn from it and start hitting your target! Prize-winning composer, Gian Carlo Menotti said, 'Hell begins on the day when God grants us a clear vision of all that we might have achieved, of all the gifts we wasted, of all that we might have done that we did not do.' Don't end your life regretting the time and opportunities you wasted. Give time to prayer. Read your Bible. Worship God long and loud. Growth will come as you do.

content.title: Make a start!
content.introtext:
I AM DOING A NEW THING!

Isaiah 43:19
Lots of people have dreams and visions for their lives but very few actually reach them. The reason is often not that these people experienced some major set-back on the way - they never even got started! Do you have a vision or a dream? Well, don't just sit there, do something about it! Because there are so many excuses and reasons not to start, here are some helpful suggestions: a) start with yourself! If you want those around you to give you more respect, give them a different set of attitudes and actions to respond to b) start early! There's an old saying that Noah didn't wait for his ship to come in; he built one! c) start easy! Hard work is just an accumulation of the easy things you didn't do when you should have. The truth is, the work doesn't seem quite so hard when you stop putting it off d) start small! Just take the first step. You can't do step two until you've done step one. Taking the first step gets you moving in the right direction e) start simple! Don't expect to understand everything up front. Listen: 'By faith Abraham...went out, not knowing...' (Hebrews 11:8). You'll know as you go! Just take the first step f) start now! What are you waiting for? Until you finish school? Get married? Have kids? Your kids grow up? You retire? You die? If you wait long enough you'll have only one regret - that you didn't start now.

content.title: Handling temptation
content.introtext:
GOD BLESSES THE PEOPLE WHO PATIENTLY ENDURE TESTING...

JAMES 1:12 NLT
Every time you are tempted and choose to do right instead of wrong, you grow in the character of Christ. And what are His characteristics? Listen: '...love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, and self-control...' (Galatians 5:22-23 NLT). So, will you wake up one day and suddenly have a big fat crop of all this amazing fruit? No, fruit grows steadily throughout the course of a season. Don't get fed up if the season lasts longer than you'd like it to. Rick Warren who writes all the 'Purpose Driven' books says, 'God develops the fruit of the spirit in our lives by allowing us to experience circumstances in which we're tempted to express the exact opposite quality. You can't claim to be good if you've never been tempted to be bad. You can't claim to be faithful if you've never had an opportunity to be unfaithful.' One of the secrets to overcoming temptation is to be prepared before it comes! Even Paul confessed, '...I have the desire to do what is good, but I cannot carry it out' (Romans 7:18 NIV). Certain situations will make you more vulnerable to temptation than others. Find yourself in the wrong place at the wrong time and you may stumble almost immediately, while at other times in other places you're solid as a rock. Satan targets his temptations to our weakest points! So, you need to identify them quickly because satan is a crafty old snake. He knows what trips you up and he's constantly working to get you into those situations. That's why Peter warns, '...Stay alert. The Devil is poised to pounce, and would like nothing better than to catch you napping' (1 Peter 5:8 TM). Make sure you're wide awake today.
